webTitle: Potential for panic inside Blair's bunker

fields.headline: Potential for panic inside Blair's bunker
fields.standfirst:
PM's small band of advisers are easily spooked
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The latest leaked memo, from Labour's pollster Philip Gould yesterday reinforced the impression that Tony Blair runs the country with a tiny band of advisers. And that band can easily be spooked.
fields.body:
The latest leaked memo, from Labour's pollster Philip Gould yesterday reinforced the impression that Tony Blair runs the country with a tiny band of advisers. And that band can easily be spooked.

A few successful campaigns by the Conservative leader, William Hague, have created an unjustified sense of panic in Mr Blair's team.

Mr Gould, in his memo, warned ominously that the Labour "brand"' had been "badly contaminated" and the party faced dramatic losses at the general election.

Collectively, the memos leaked so far - and Downing Street and Labour headquarters at Millbank are braced for more - point to rule by kitchen cabinet. Accelerating the trend of previous prime ministers, Mr Blair has become increasingly presidential, largely ignoring the cabinet, parliament and his own party, both MPs and the grassroots.

The danger in the confined space of a bunker is that when one member takes fright, as Mr Gould has done, the sense of panic spreads quickly to the other members. A sense of proportion can be more easily maintained by the prime minister speaking widely, especially to cabinet colleagues. Tellingly, the chancellor, Gordon Brown, claimed yesterday that even he was not part of the inner circle on Mr Gould's mailing list.

One ex-permanent secretary recently told Peter Hennessy, a constitutional expert: "There used to be something called cabinet government. It was declining when I was there in the 1980s, but now it seems almost to have died."

At the core of Mr Blair's government are: his press secretary, Alastair Campbell, powerful because he sees him almost every day; Mr Brown (even if he is not on Mr Gould's mailing list); and Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary who, along with Mr Brown, will run Labour's election campaign.

In spite of their personal differences, Mr Blair and Mr Brown speak regularly, just as they did when they had offices side by side in opposition. They often dispense with notetakers at their meetings, to the annoyance of their officials.

There is a cluster of others round this inner core, most unknown to the public: Anji Hunter, who has been Mr Blair's personal assistant since his days in opposition; Jonathan Powell, the Downing Street chief of staff; David Miliband, from the Downing Street policy unit; and Sally Morgan, also from the policy unit and main link with the party. Ms Morgan, for instance, will have a huge say in cabinet reshuffles.

After that, it depends on the policy under discussion: the big-hitting ministers, Jack Straw, David Blunkett, John Prescott and Robin Cook, are regular visitors.

Many of the other ministers are largely ignored, as too are backbenchers and the Labour party at large.

Labour headquarters in the run-up to the 1997 general election had been a centre of power but has been neutralised, with Mr Blair unhappy with the performance of the general secretary, Margaret McDonagh, and other staff members.

They have been blamed for various election embarrassments, though most of these can be traced to Mr Blair's centralising tendency, attempting to block Ken Livingstone in London and Rhodri Morgan in Wales.

One minister yesterday expressed sympathy with the prime minister for ignoring the cabinet, saying many had failed to perform. He added that even when a reshuffle comes - Mr Blair has told colleagues he will not reshuffle the cabinet this year - there is not exactly a pool of talent waiting to get in.

Downing Street will not tell reporters or historians how the prime minister spends his day.

But cabinet meetings last usually less than an hour these days - a brief series of reports by senior ministers, an occasional round-the-table discussion on policy (poverty or Kosovo), sometimes on the overall political situation.

But most business is done via cabinet committee or sub-committee, or between a minister and Mr Blair on the prime minister's white sofa just off the cabinet room in No 10.

A Labour insider who has worked in both Downing Street and Millbank yesterday attempted to dispel the idea that Mr Blair had fallen into the trap of listening only to a few trusted people. "The idea that he is stuck in the bunker is untrue," he said. "The modern political leader has to have lots of communications and meetings for them to be effective."

He claimed that Mr Gould's memos should be seen in perspective. His job was to offer advice on political strategy - and to give Mr Blair views that at times might seem bleak - but not on health, education, transport or other policy issues, which were the domain of cabinet ministers.

Mr Gould's memos are a mix of views from focus groups and his own opinions, and those of other members of the inner circle, such as his friend Mr Mandelson.

He quotes in the memo Mr Mandelson saying: "How did we get here? Something has gone seriously wrong. But what is it?"

They should not be spooked so easily. After three years of having most of his speeches almost ignored, William Hague made the front pages this year over crime and, as Mr Gould's memo points out, has again positioned the Conservatives as the patriotic party.

But the economy, the determining factor in most elections, is in relatively good shape, as Mr Brown demonstrated on Wednesday. And Mr Hague, in spite of his successes, remains largely unpopular.

There would be less panic in Downing Street if Mr Blair expanded rather than narrowed those he listens to. But that is unlikely to happen, at least this side of the general election.

fields.headline: Blunkett calls for 'straight talking'
fields.standfirst:
Ministers try to shrug off memo
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown and David Blunkett yesterday battled to keep the chancellor's £43bn spending plans in the forefront of voters' minds and turn attention away from Labour's apparent preoccupation with spin.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown and David Blunkett yesterday battled to keep the chancellor's £43bn spending plans in the forefront of voters' minds and turn attention away from Labour's apparent preoccupation with spin.

The Treasury's three-year spending plans will be the centrepoint of the government's claims to re-election and ministers are determined to show they will improve people's lives through better public services.

Mr Brown shrugged off the leaked Gould memo: "You've got to take a long-term view of these things. We're in a programme to improve our country, we are not going to be diverted by short term leaks of memorandums or anything else."

Though they rallied to Tony Blair's defence as William Hague mocked Mr Gould's anguished memo about Labour "drifting, growing almost monthly weaker", there was widespread anger among MPs that such thoughts had been written down.

The chancellor, who brushed aside questions about the leak when he promoted his spending review on Radio 4's Today, joined the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, and other MPs in nodding vigorously when leftwinger Dennis Skinner complained about the leaked memo at yesterday's weekly meeting of the Parliamentary Labour party.

In his own tour of the TV and radio studios to promote his £10bn education spending plans, Mr Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, also sent a veiled warning to Mr Blair's inner circle.

"I think there is a very clear message: less memos and more straight, personal talking," he said. Though Mr Blunkett explained that Mr Gould's task is to tell Mr Blair the "harshest" facts, he added that "not getting carried away is very important for politicians".

fields.headline: No 10 insider is leak suspect
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour in power
fields.trailText: Special branch officers suspect an "insider" within or close to Downing Street is responsible for the embarrassing series of leaked memos to and from Tony Blair that ministers expect to continue into August.
fields.body:
Special branch officers suspect an "insider" within or close to Downing Street is responsible for the embarrassing series of leaked memos to and from Tony Blair that ministers expect to continue into August.

Detectives assisting the inquiry by Sir Richard Wilson, head of the civil service, are focusing their investigations on staff and advisers in Whitehall who might have had access to the letters.

Downing Street refused to be drawn yesterday on whether the police had been called in, but a Labour party source with knowledge of the inquiry confirmed that officers are involved.

The source said police believed all four documents recently made public - one written by the prime minister and three by the party pollster Philip Gould - had been obtained by the same individual.

Senior ministers with knowledge of the inquiry are describing the documents as "stolen". The theory that a No 10 file was stolen and a go-between used, possibly to sell the memos, has not been ruled out despite denials from the three News International titles that received the documents.

The Labour source said the Tories were not thought to be involved and that blaming the opposition was a smokescreen. Accusations that the leaks were being orchestrated by the Conservatives were strenuously denied by the Tory party chairman, Michael Ancram.

Although some of the notes are known to have existed in computer form, there appears to be a connecting thread in that all four leaks were faxed at some point to or from No 10.

But the Labour party source pointed out that Mr Gould, who has an office in Express Newspapers' central London headquarters, still has the original copies of at least some. It is thought that not all four originated from or were sent to his office.

The disclosure of the four memos, dated between April 29 and June 4, has rocked the government and threatened to overshadow the huge increase in public spending announced yesterday by Gordon Brown.

"We know what's gone and think there is a lot more to come out," said a government member. The prime minister's "touchstone issues" memo leaked over the weekend is understood to have been distributed within Downing Street by email and faxed to Mr Gould at his Express building office.

The hacking of internal files has not been ruled out although the copying or theft of paper versions is considered more likely.

Memos are officially copied and read widely across Whitehall far beyond their official distribution list, making it more difficult to trace any mole. MPs are furious that Mr Gould was so frank on paper.

Godric Smith, civil service deputy to Alastair Campbell, the No 10 official spokesman, said: "There will probably be another one of these along when we get the transport plan and when we get the health plan. There seems to be a pattern. They will probably be timed to distract from the real issues but we will not be distracted."

Senior ministers confirmed Mr Campbell's official line that they would not be deflected from implementing the chancellor's £43bn spending package by the near certainty of more well-timed leaks.

"When it all blows over, you will have a government left standing that is delivering and can show that it is delivering and an opposition that is going to have to answer some pretty tough questions," Mr Campbell told reporters after Mr Blair traded tax-and-spend blows with William Hague, then flew to the G8 economic summit in Japan.

No 10 took the rare step of printing out interviews with a BBC radio Today programme panel to prove that most people are interested in public services, not party tactics.

David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, also sent a veiled warning to Mr Blair's inner circle at No 10 - from which he, like most cabinet members, is excluded.

fields.headline: Seeking enlightenment on a higher plane
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: The moment prime minister's questions finished, Tony Blair was off to the plane for Tokyo and the G8 summit. People who have been through a near-death experience sometimes report that they are in a long dark tunnel, but the end is a brightly lit scene, filled with happy folk.
fields.body:
The moment prime minister's questions finished, Tony Blair was off to the plane for Tokyo and the G8 summit. People who have been through a near-death experience sometimes report that they are in a long dark tunnel, but the end is a brightly lit scene, filled with happy folk.

Some say it looks like a picnic in a summer meadow, and claim to have seen smiling friends beckoning. Not surprisingly, many people who later recover believe they have had a glimpse of the afterlife, though this can be spoiled by the fact that several say they saw people who were still alive. New research suggests the phenomenon may be chemical, possibly associated with oxygen leaving the brain.

Anyhow, that's how Mr Blair must have felt yesterday. He left behind all the woes and tribulations of this vale of tears, climbed into the long thin tube, and in the distance he could see all his friends - Bill Clinton, Gerhard Schröder, whoever is prime minister of Japan this week - all calling to him in soothing voices, saying "welcome, welcome, Tony, have a harp".

To join the choir invisible must be bliss after Mr Blair's multitudinous sufferings this week on earth. Yesterday William Hague attacked him over the various leaked memos. "Even Napoleon didn't commission memos talking about the right place in history," he said sarcastically, as if Napoleon were a man beyond caring what the vulgar herd thought of him.

Then he spoiled the effect. It was, he said "pathetic" that after three years in government the prime minister was going round Whitehall asking for "eye-catching initiatives". Winston Churchill "did not ask for blood, sweat... " but Mr Hague got no further, for the entire Labour side, sensing that for once their leader might just come out on top in these exchanges, erupted in loud fake derision. Was it because evoking Churchill is such a cliche? Or because Mr Hague seemed implicitly to be comparing himself to that other round-faced baldy?

"Or sweat..." he tried again. The barrage of noise grew louder. "He didn't ask for..."

"Order, order, AWDER!" yelled Betty Boothroyd. "Oh yes, oh yes, there's plenty more where that came from," said the Tory leader. "Plenty more," he added against the wall of sound that threatened at times to overwhelm him. "He didn't ask for blood, sweat and... he didn't ask for blood, sweat... and eye-catching initiatives," he finally finished.

As he sank back gratefully into his seat, I reflected that there can have been few politicians in history who could spot an eye-catching initiative faster than Winston Churchill. A hack himself ("hissing spears answered the scratch of my quill pen" he possibly wrote during the Boer war), he turned up in a silly hat at the siege of Sydney Street, posed with tommy guns, sent the troops into the south Wales coalfields ("tough on grime, tough on the causes of grime") and surrounded himself with more props than Paul Daniels - the V-sign, the hat, the siren suit and the cigars. The man was a sultan of spin, a whirling dervish of photo-opportunities. You might as easily hold him up as a model of sobriety.

So Mr Hague and Mr Blair had another foolish spat. Mr Blair intends to say that the Tories will take £24m from every constituency in the land, which is nonsense, and the Tories are going to abuse Alastair Campbell, as if any sane person cared. But even as I write, smiling women in shining raiment are welcoming our prime minister to a better life, to a happy land where our souls are at peace, and no memos are ever leaked. Or the first-class cabin, as we call it.

webTitle: The Real IRA and terrorism on a shoestring

fields.headline: The Real IRA and terrorism on a shoestring
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The so-called Real IRA is pursuing a twin strategy: terrorism on a shoestring in Britain, pitched at causing maximum disruption for minimum outlay, and a more concerted campaign in Northern Ireland. Security forces fear that deaths are increasingly likely.
fields.body:
The so-called Real IRA is pursuing a twin strategy: terrorism on a shoestring in Britain, pitched at causing maximum disruption for minimum outlay, and a more concerted campaign in Northern Ireland. Security forces fear that deaths are increasingly likely.

After last month's propaganda coup with its bomb attack on Hammersmith bridge in west London, the dissident republicans planted a small device on the Belfast-Dublin railway at Newry three weeks ago. It was its sixth attack in Northern Ireland this year, and was followed by a car bomb in Stewartstown, Co Tyrone.

There have been no injuries in any of its operations this year. But the railway bomb was a wake-up call to the security forces.

The small device was designed to entice them to the scene. Waiting for them was a bomb containing 250lb of homemade explosive, the plan being to kill as many RUC and army personnel as possible.

It was a favoured tactic of the Real IRA's former comrades in the Provisional IRA, from whom they split in autumn 1997. The dissidents were opposed to Sinn Fein signing up to the former US senator George Mitchell's principles of peace and democracy, the cornerstones on which the Good Friday agreement was to be built.

The Real IRA's subsequent campaign culminated in the Omagh car bombing of August 1998, the largest single atrocity of the Troubles. Although it is unlikely that the terror group intended murder, so reckless and amateurish was the operation that 29 died.

It called a ceasefire soon afterwards, and laid low. But a year later, the group's leader, a 50-year-old businessman from Dundalk, Co Louth, formerly an IRA quartermaster, restarted operations.

Its plans for a campaign in Britain initially stuttered. Attempts to smuggle homemade explosives and a car bomb from Irish ports in January and April 1998 were foiled as Gardai penetrated the outfit, and an incendiary bomb campaign that summer was also prevented.

But security sources feared in the aftermath of the Hammersmith bridge bombing that an active service unit had been established in England. Yesterday's operation appears to support fears that such a unit could strike again.

The loose alliance of dissident republicans, including Continuity IRA, more a flag of convenience these days for Real IRA activity, is thought to number about 120. As few as 30 are active terrorists.

The IRA's initiative on putting its arms beyond use, its offer to break the decommissioning crisis, boosted Real IRA support, although security forces are unable to quantify it. But a recent recruit was an IRA engineer with particular expertise in manufacturing mortars.

He joins a Dublin-based motorcycle courier who is the Real IRA's chief bomb-maker. He made the timing devices used at Omagh, and forensic scientists detected his hand in the Hammersmith device.

Its recent activities are an attempt to entice IRA members dubious about the decommissioning initiative and the policing bill. It is also raising two fingers at mainstream republicans, selecting Hammersmith bridge, which the IRA twice attacked unsuccessfully, and targets in the south Armagh area.

Yesterday's operation appears to support fears that such a unit could strike again. The loose alliance of dissident republicans, including Continuity IRA, more a flag of convenience these days for Real IRA activity, is thought to number about 120. As few as 30 are active terrorists. The IRA's initiative on putting its arms beyond use, its offer to break the decommissioning crisis, boosted Real IRA support, although security forces are unable to quantify it. But a recent recruit was an IRA engineer with particular expertise in manufacturing mortars. He joins a Dublin-based motorcycle courier who is the Real IRA's chief bomb-maker. He made the timing devices used at Omagh, and forensic scientists detected his hand in the Hammersmith device. Its recent activities are an attempt to entice IRA members dubious about the decommissioning initiative and the policing bill. It is also raising two fingers at mainstream republicans, selecting Hammersmith bridge, which the IRA twice attacked unsuccessfully, and targets in the south Armagh area.

webTitle: How a small device choked London

fields.headline: How a small device choked London
fields.standfirst:
Snowballing effect on rail and road after careful siting of bomb just before the peak travelling period began
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The disruption began modestly enough at 6.30am, when between 10 and 20 homes were evacuated close to the railway line in west London where the bomb had been planted.
fields.body:
The disruption began modestly enough at 6.30am, when between 10 and 20 homes were evacuated close to the railway line in west London where the bomb had been planted.

Within minutes, Ealing Broadway and Acton stations were hurriedly closed, leaving scores of commuters who had hoped to avoid the rush-hour milling around wondering what was going on.

As officers from the anti-terrorist branch and British Transport police began a frantic hunt for the device, the ripples began to be felt inside and outside the capital. And the reason for the precision placement of the bomb became all too obvious: the Twyford Avenue line is a key artery in and out of London.

The dissidents had obviously done their homework because the device could scarcely have been put in a more effective place to cause maximum paralysis.

An emergency call from Railtrack at 6.25am brought Paddington, the gateway to the west of England and Wales and one of the busiest stations in Britain, to a halt. An estimated 70,000 passengers would have commuted into work on either a First Great Western or Thames Train yesterday.

Instead, nearly every service into the station was cancelled. Hundreds of commuters were stranded at Reading and forced to improvise journeys.

Services to Cardiff and Cornwall were also seriously disrupted. The Heathrow Express did not move from the platform all day. Inside London, things were little better.

On London Underground, the District, Central and Piccadilly lines began to seize up.

By the time John Humphrys, presenter of Radio 4's Today programme, was telling listeners about the appalling jams at 8.30am, the warning was far too late.

The paralysis of the road, rail, and underground networks was already spreading from the west to central London.

By lunchtime, Major John Petrie, one of the organisers of last night's gala for the Queen Mother, had convinced himself the terrorists' real target was the royal celebration at Whitehall.

As preparations continued for an event billed as "the biggest birthday party in the world" - 7,000 guests were due to watch marching bands, carnival floats, choirs, race horses, and the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra - Westminster underground station was closed for a security sweep. Victoria station suffered the same fate.

"There's no question that the bomb alerts are intended to disrupt the pageant," said Major Petrie.

At lunchtime, his fears seemed well-founded. A suspect package was found in a horsebox in Horse Guards Road. It was destroyed in a controlled explosion, but experts later said it was not a bomb and was not being linked to the earlier security alerts.

Scotland Yard said it was understandable that officers were a "bit twitchy".

At 2.30pm, Scotland Yard issued said in a statement: "The Victoria mainline and tube stations and Westminter tube station remain closed while searches take place. All Victoria line tube stations between Warren Street and Brixton are currently closed.

"All tube stations on the Jubilee line between Green Park and London Bridge are currently closed.

"All Central line tube stations between Ealing Broadway and North Acton - and District and Circle line stations between south Kensington and Embankment are currently closed _ the closures are naturally causing some difficulties."

Psychologist Mike Yardley said the dissidents' campaign was designed to create "maximum disruption and maximum publicity, without the infliction of any physical casualties".

He said the terrorists were turning "millions of people into psychological casualties".

"Clearly this has caused tremendous disruption," said Supt Tony Thompson, of the British Transport police, and added that he was sorry for the disruption.

"But public safety comes first, second and third. We hope people understand we did it with public safety in mind."

He described the planting of the bomb as "pretty atrocious activity. It's deplorable."

All stations were due to reopen for the rush hour last night though services were expected to be badly affected with trains and crews in the wrong places.

Deputy Assistant Commissioner Alan Fry, head of the anti-terrorist branch who is leading the investigation, asked Londoners to be extra vigilant.

Mr Fry added the police were investigating the possibility that planting of the Ealing bomb was linked to the device attached to a girder of Hammersmith bridge, in west London. The bridge remains closed.

fields.headline: Silicon Valley's dirty war
fields.standfirst:
Oracle chief Larry Ellison has been forced to admit that he hired private detectives to obtain information about his big rival, Microsoft. But are his tactics any dirtier than those of Bill Gates?

Special report: the future of Microsoft
fields.trailText: Oracle chief Larry Ellison has been forced to admit that he hired private detectives to obtain information about his big rival, Microsoft. But are his tactics any dirtier than those of Bill Gates?
fields.body:
You could almost feel the waves of relief surging from the squat sprawl of the Microsoft campus at Redmond, Washington. Good news hasn't been plentiful there in recent months, but one day last month it started arriving in bucketfuls.

Larry Ellison, the charismatic, Armani-clad chief of the software giant Oracle and a bitter foe of Bill Gates, had been forced into a humiliating admission: he had hired private detectives who had been caught sifting through the rubbish of organisations he believed to be linked to Microsoft. (Ellison denies having authorised anyone to break the law).

Ellison claimed to have uncovered a network of "Microsoft front groups" who were misrepresenting themselves as independent pressure groups opposed to the US government's anti-monopoly action against the firm. But all that was easily dismissed as the ramblings of a man who has never made a secret of his envy of Bill Gates. The resignation two weeks ago of Oracle's president, Ray Lane, though officially unconnected, cemented Microsoft's glee. If this grubby episode ever comes to court, it doesn't look like the sort of thing to detain a jury for long.

But then very little is ever as it seems in the spite-fuelled upper echelons of Silicon Valley, and "Larrygate" has proved no exception. Ellison may be renowned as a brash playboy with a taste for ostentatious displays of wealth but it is by no means so certain that he is a delusional conspiracy theorist as well. Look more closely at the pro-Microsoft groups he targeted - and others like them - and things start to get bizarre indeed. Welcome to the strange, disorienting world of Microsoft's public relations campaign, where appearances are frequently deceptive, and where apparent groundswells of public support turn out to have been heavily financed by the company itself.

One point of entry to this hall of mirrors is to be found on Eye Street, in the Foggy Bottom district of central Washington DC. Number 1225 is the home of the Association for Competitive Technology (Act), and it was here, last year, that a woman reportedly working for Investigative Group International, the firm hired by Ellison, tried unsuccessfully to persuade two cleaners to accept $1,200 in exchange for the contents of its wastepaper baskets. Act's president - an ebullient software developer named Jonathan Zuck - was a regular fixture at the Microsoft trial, briefing the media on the lunacy of the government's case. This much is undisputed. After that, things start to get complicated.

Act - which says it represents "mostly small-and mid-sized companies" - lists Microsoft as one of several founder members. It is not so obvious from its literature that Microsoft is also one of its major funders - the major funder by a long chalk, according to US press reports, though Zuck won't reveal the exact figure. Some might say that from the single-mindedness with which it argues Microsoft's case, it looks a lot like it was established at the Redmond giant's behest.

Nevertheless, Microsoft points out, there are other groups that feel the same way - groups such as Americans for Technology Leadership (ATL), which describes itself as "a broad-based coalition of technology professionals, consumers and organisations dedicated to limiting government regulation of technology". Established shortly after the antitrust case began, ATL also turns out to be heavily funded by Microsoft, though again the amount is unknown. Should you wish to track down ATL, you won't have to go far, because its offices are also at 1225 Eye Street: on the very same floor. And if you want to talk to its founder, you won't have to go anywhere at all - because it's Jonathan Zuck.

"They're definitely one of our biggest contributors - we've been open about that from day one [and] it's the wrong issue to be focusing on," says Zuck. He insists that Oracle indulges in many of the very lobbying practices it criticises: "All this horseshit that [Ellison] was spewing . . . bears very little resemblance to his own business practices."

But there are still more mirrors, more wheels within corporate wheels. ATL's current chief executive, Josh Mathis, benefits from Microsoft money in another way. When he isn't leading the anti-monopoly uprising from Eye Street, Mathis is an employee of DCI/New Media, an Arizona-based company that "specialises in using cutting-edge technology to move public opinion" - setting up large-scale phone-bank operations to stoke indignation among voters and persuading them to lobby their elected representatives. Clients include the tobacco lobby, the National Rifle Association - and Microsoft.

They have a word in Washington for the corporate-sponsored outcry, the grassroots movement that isn't: AstroTurf. By far the most comical example of this is to be found at the Freedom to Innovate Network (Fin), a "non-partisan, grassroots network of citizens and businesses who have a stake in the success of Microsoft and the high-tech industry". Fin doesn't try particularly hard to appear independent - its website, after all, is housed on Microsoft's own - but it has as its online centrepiece a lengthy collection of testimonials from activist groups with vaguely alarming names: the Centre for the Moral Defence of Capitalism, Frontiers of Freedom, Defenders of Property Rights. Their comments appear unsolicited and independent: it certainly looks like there is a groundswell of support for the beleaguered computer giant. Though it isn't mentioned on the site, the vast majority get funding from Microsoft, a company source confirms. There are swathes of them - the National Taxpayers Union, Citizens for a Sound Economy, the Small Business Survival Committee, Americans for Tax Reform, and many more.

"Groups like Jonathan Zuck's wouldn't exist if it wasn't for Microsoft," says James Love, director of the Consumer Project on Technology, a Washington DC-based group (funded by private grant-making trusts) that has been one of the company's most vociferous critics. He calls it "scandalous" for Microsoft to act "as if there's some big, respectable opinion that the antitrust laws shouldn't apply to the computer industry. But then it's always better to report a favourable study from an independent group than from one you gave a grant to."

Strange things have been happening at the offices of the Independent Institute, a think-tank based in Oakland, California: people have been calling in, pretending to be people they aren't. "On June 18, a guy showed up here after hours, asking for directions," recalls David Theroux, the founder and president. "The receptionist came to find me, and I gave the guy directions. But then, apparently, he came back into the office, grabbed two laptops and left. We filed a report to the police. They described it as a professional job."

There is no reason to suspect that the theft is connected to the Oracle revelations. But whoever did steal the laptops may well have held a similar view to Ellison of the work of the institute: it was one of the organisa tions he asked Investigative Group International to target. Theroux is furious, condemning Oracle for its "back-alley tactics" and stressing that he has never concealed Microsoft's support for his organisation.

Unfortunately it hasn't always seemed that way. In June last year, full-page advertisements appeared in the New York Times and the Washington Post that seemed to suggest opinion was swinging behind Microsoft. Headlined "An Open Letter to President Clinton from 240 Economists on Antitrust Protectionism", the ads mounted a scathing attack on the Justice Department's case, backed by experts and carrying the Independent Institute's logo.

What didn't emerge, until it was reported by the New York Times four months later, was that their publication had been paid for by Microsoft. (Theroux maintains there was no specific contract with Microsoft to publish the ads, but a Redmond source confirmed the Times's claim.) Nobody told the economists that Microsoft money was backing the ads, and at least one signatory, Professor Simon Hakim of Temple University in Philadelphia, has expressed outrage at this. Others maintain that the fact they didn't know proves their opinions were sincere. Perception, once again, is everything.

"We are very comfortable disclosing whether or not we have a financial relationship with an organisation or an advocacy group," says Microsoft spokesman Vivek Varma. "And if Mr Ellison is going to stand up and make charges about disclosure, it would be fair for him to disclose all of the places that Oracle has investments, including what the levels of those investments are." Nor does it pay to take too paranoid a view of Microsoft's alliances with free-market think-tanks and pressure groups: in the words of John Berthoud, president of the Microsoft-funded National Taxpayers Union, it is "hardly surprising" that organisations favouring limited government should oppose the antitrust ruling.

But even if Ellison's claims are as preposterous as his opponents make out, Microsoft doesn't exactly make it easy to discount them. In April, reports surfaced in the US media of one of the most embarrassing lobbying incidents in recent history: the revelation that Bill Gates had hired the services of Century Strategies to drum up "grassroots" support and encourage voters to telephone presidential hopeful George W Bush, urging him to take Microsoft's side.

For Gates, a billionaire whose charitable foundation takes a strong liberal line, it was an uncomfortable partnering: Century Strategies is owned by Ralph Reed, former firebrand leader of the far-right Christian Coalition. There was another problem: Reed was being paid by Microsoft to lobby Bush - but was a paid adviser to Bush, too. Though Microsoft had hired Century before Reed officially joined the Bush payroll, the incident caused red faces at Redmond, and it was left to Century to pull out of the deal and issue a sheepish apology.

Maybe it's natural arrogance that makes Ellison so sure of his allegations: he has, cockily, offered to send the relevant garbage to Redmond for Gates to sift through personally. Maybe it is paranoia borne of jealousy. On the other hand, Microsoft's elation may be seriously misplaced. The cracks in its finely engineered public opinion campaign seem to be showing. "If you read a newspaper, you might get the impression that there's a whole lot of people who agree with Microsoft," says Love. "But then a whole lot of Microsoft's campaign is based on all sorts of stuff that's made to appear to be something it's not."

webTitle: UN report scorns UK human rights record

fields.headline: UN report scorns UK human rights record
fields.trailText: A devastating United Nations report has condemned the UK's human rights record and called for sweeping reforms to the security services, an end to gagging orders and protection for journalists who expose wrongdoing inside MI5 and MI6.
fields.body:
A devastating United Nations report has condemned the UK's human rights record and called for sweeping reforms to the security services, an end to gagging orders and protection for journalists who expose wrongdoing inside MI5 and MI6.

The report, from a UN special rapporteur, is highly critical of the government's "gagging" of newspapers over the Shayler affair and attempted prosecution of journalist Tony Geraghty for revealing a top secret surveillance system in Northern Ireland. It also condemns attempts to use laws to force journalists in Northern Ireland to hand over their notes or disclose the identity of informants to the police or investigating authorities.

"The special rapporteur considers the use of the Official Secrets Act to prosecute journalists and writers, as well as the existence of the D notice committee [now the defence advisory committee], to be incompatible with media freedom," it says.

The wide-ranging report calls for the repeal of the Prevention of Terrorism Act and sweeping changes to the Official Secrets Act and the freedom of information and regulation of investigatory powers bills going through parliament. It also wants a reform of the defamation and obscenity laws.

The report will be debated at the next meeting of the UN commission on human rights in New York.

The special rapporteur, Abid Hussein, was charged with examining the UK's record on freedom of expression and civil and political rights as part of regular monitoring by the UN commission. He talked to a wide range of organisations, government ministers, academics and civil servants.

The report, while welcoming action taken to end the conflict by Northern Ireland secretaries Mo Mowlam and Peter Mandelson, demands an end to excessive secrecy in the province over the circumstances surrounding the deaths of people killed by the army or police. It criticises the BBC for refusing to broadcast a programme covering the views of terrorist prisoners who had been released under the Good Friday agreement.

The most critical part of the report is on the gagging measures used against the press. "If media organisations are ordered to hand over confiden tial information, serious damage would be done to public interest journalism in the UK.

"As provided by the European convention of human rights, a journalist should not be used as a source for investigating authorities... Undertakings of confidentiality have to be absolute, since otherwise the information would never have reached the public domain."

He goes on to say that the Official Secrets Act "is used to stifle legitimate debate and to penalise writers and journalists who refuse to reveal their sources".

He says that while the government claims that the D notice system is used to promote self-censorship in the media in matters of national security, "at times its objective appears to be to stifle debate about politically sensitive matters rather than protect national security as such". He says that journalists must be allowed to have a "public interest" defence if they are accused of leaking information from the security services.

Mr Hussein calls on the government to change the present "blanket ban" on disclosing security matters in the freedom of information bill. "Security matters are often of the high est public interest," he says. He also calls for much fewer restrictions on the release of information surrounding criminal investigations and for the release of policy background papers. He opposes the plans of the home secretary, Jack Straw, to use a ministerial veto to stop any document being published.

"In order for journalists to be able to carry out their role as "watchdogs" in a democratic society it is indispensable that they have access, granted on an equitable and impartial basis, to information held by public authorities." Mr Hussein calls for a reform of the defamation laws - including the abolition of criminal libel proceedings. He says that journalists should be able to enter a defence when libelling public figures and politicians that they "acted professionally by seeking to verify the accuracy of the material" - even if it turns out to be untrue.

Maurice Frankel, the director of the Campaign for Freedom of Information, said last night: "This report highlights the difference between what the government promised on civil rights and freedom of expression and how poorly they have performed in practice. This is even apparent to the UN."
fields.bodyText: A devastating United Nations report has condemned the UK's human rights record and called for sweeping reforms to the security services, an end to gagging orders and protection for journalists who expose wrongdoing inside MI5 and MI6. The report, from a UN special rapporteur, is highly critical of the government's "gagging" of newspapers over the Shayler affair and attempted prosecution of journalist Tony Geraghty for revealing a top secret surveillance system in Northern Ireland. It also condemns attempts to use laws to force journalists in Northern Ireland to hand over their notes or disclose the identity of informants to the police or investigating authorities. "The special rapporteur considers the use of the Official Secrets Act to prosecute journalists and writers, as well as the existence of the D notice committee [now the defence advisory committee], to be incompatible with media freedom," it says. The wide-ranging report calls for the repeal of the Prevention of Terrorism Act and sweeping changes to the Official Secrets Act and the freedom of information and regulation of investigatory powers bills going through parliament. It also wants a reform of the defamation and obscenity laws. The report will be debated at the next meeting of the UN commission on human rights in New York. The special rapporteur, Abid Hussein, was charged with examining the UK's record on freedom of expression and civil and political rights as part of regular monitoring by the UN commission. He talked to a wide range of organisations, government ministers, academics and civil servants. The report, while welcoming action taken to end the conflict by Northern Ireland secretaries Mo Mowlam and Peter Mandelson, demands an end to excessive secrecy in the province over the circumstances surrounding the deaths of people killed by the army or police. It criticises the BBC for refusing to broadcast a programme covering the views of terrorist prisoners who had been released under the Good Friday agreement. The most critical part of the report is on the gagging measures used against the press. "If media organisations are ordered to hand over confiden tial information, serious damage would be done to public interest journalism in the UK. "As provided by the European convention of human rights, a journalist should not be used as a source for investigating authorities... Undertakings of confidentiality have to be absolute, since otherwise the information would never have reached the public domain." He goes on to say that the Official Secrets Act "is used to stifle legitimate debate and to penalise writers and journalists who refuse to reveal their sources". He says that while the government claims that the D notice system is used to promote self-censorship in the media in matters of national security, "at times its objective appears to be to stifle debate about politically sensitive matters rather than protect national security as such". He says that journalists must be allowed to have a "public interest" defence if they are accused of leaking information from the security services. Mr Hussein calls on the government to change the present "blanket ban" on disclosing security matters in the freedom of information bill. "Security matters are often of the high est public interest," he says. He also calls for much fewer restrictions on the release of information surrounding criminal investigations and for the release of policy background papers. He opposes the plans of the home secretary, Jack Straw, to use a ministerial veto to stop any document being published. "In order for journalists to be able to carry out their role as "watchdogs" in a democratic society it is indispensable that they have access, granted on an equitable and impartial basis, to information held by public authorities." Mr Hussein calls for a reform of the defamation laws - including the abolition of criminal libel proceedings. He says that journalists should be able to enter a defence when libelling public figures and politicians that they "acted professionally by seeking to verify the accuracy of the material" - even if it turns out to be untrue. Maurice Frankel, the director of the Campaign for Freedom of Information, said last night: "This report highlights the difference between what the government promised on civil rights and freedom of expression and how poorly they have performed in practice. This is even apparent to the UN."

webTitle: Comment: Matthew Engel at the Queen Mother's birthday parade

fields.headline: Extraordinary, naff and a little bit magic
fields.standfirst: On a perfect summer's afternoon, Britain's grandest antiquity never wilted as her 100th birthday was celebrated - 16 days early
fields.trailText: With a truly regal disregard for the technicalities of the calendar, the Queen Mother yesterday accepted the homage of an awestruck nation on her 100th birthday, 16 days before it actually happens.
fields.body:
With a truly regal disregard for the technicalities of the calendar, the Queen Mother yesterday accepted the homage of an awestruck nation on her 100th birthday, 16 days before it actually happens.

On a perfect summer's afternoon, Horse Guards was filled for something the tabloids called "the people's tribute" and the BBC (preferring Neighbours) thought was too trivial to televise.

The putative centenarian marked the occasion by doing something most of her audience could probably never recall happening before: she spoke. Having sat for nearly 90 minutes through a ceremony that overran by 20, she stood up and in a firm voice - not unlike her daughter's - gave a model of a brief speech of thanks. It comprised about 70 words including "joy", "heartfelt", "wonderful" and "lovely", concluding: "I hope you all enjoyed it as much as I did. God bless you all and thank you."

It was an extraordinary occasion (on an actuarial basis, literally so) which, in true British fashion, mixed the impressive and the ludicrous about equally. A hundred white doves were released: they wheeled towards Trafalgar Square then, perhaps seeing their common cousins, turned south. A million rose petals were released, rather pointlessly. A huge birthday card and cake were produced. Overall, it did fair justice to the Queen Mother's indomitability, inscrutability and sheer ecleticism.

She arrived, dressed in pink, in an open coach with the Prince of Wales and settled down to watch what began as a bog standard, if scaled-down, military display. Representatives of service units with which she is most closely connected - from the Black Watch to the Witwatersrand Rifles - marched past briskly. The RAF were particularly brisk: they were reduced to four men with one sword and two bayonets between them, suggesting defence cuts Gordon Brown has yet to announce.

Then the mood changed quite dramatically. There was a parade giving a brief but bowdlerised history of the 20th century, an idea that was perhaps considered too naff even for the Dome. You could tell we had reached the war when the air raid siren went.

"The 1950s," declared the announcer. "The first package holiday. The Mouse Trap. The Belisha Beacon." (And the death of my husband, Her Majesty might have thought). Four Beatles lookalikes passed by, then the 1970s: "Decimalisation! Punk! And the Braemar Games!" The 1980s apparently had "emails!, the Wombles! And of course Del Boy and Rodney!" The 1990s had the Channel Tunnel, the Dome and oil prospecting at Windsor Castle. (Diana? Diana Who?)

After Sir Norman Wisdom had gone by on a rickety trailer marked "The British Film Industry", we got the Queen Mother's corgis Rush and Minnie, who looked overweight.

But then came the centrepiece of it all: the 179 organisations of which the Queen Mother is honorary fellow, honorary freeman, honorary member, patron or president entered the arena to join the others. It was like the old line about watching the population of China go by: the line never ended. There was the Mothers' Union and the Girls' Brigade (whose signs when they relaxed said PPY THD Y), the Institute of Leisure and Amenity Management followed by the Bembridge Lifeboat and the Poultry Club of Great Britain.

The Worshipful Company of Grocers came in on camelback and one of the camels, showing an exaggerated sense of deference, dropped to its knees as it passed the dais. There was the Grand Antiquity Society of Glasgow and the Hastings Winkle Club.

And our grandest antiquity never wilted. On and on they came: 50 men dressed as chefs from the Cookery and Food Association and a lone flag bearer from the London Library, the West Ham Central Mission, the Tidy Britain Group, even for obscure reasons a British Gas lorry. One was left amazed not only at her stamina as a 99-year-old watching all this but her stamina of a lifetime. Whether or not she really has much inkling who many of these people are, they believe profoundly that she does and that in itself is a piece of royal magic.

webTitle: The leaks show whose head must roll. That of Gould

fields.headline: The leaks show whose head must roll. That of Gould
fields.standfirst:
The prime minister's focus groupie is causing self-destructive alarm
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The prime minister's focus groupie is causing self-destructive alarm.
fields.body:
In early May, when Philip Gould wrote the latest of his secret memos to be leaked, the Gallup poll gave Labour a lead of 16 points. Translated into seats at a general election, this would indicate a parliamentary majority of 200-plus. That was the dire context into which Mr Gould, Tony Blair's most powerful poll-monger and focus groupie, thrust his opinion that "our current situation is serious", "we have got our political strategy wrong", we are "not in tune with the people", and we could lose the next election.

This month's Gallup poll suggests, at least to himself, that Mr Gould might have been on track. Labour's lead plummeted to 10 points, while the Guardian's ICM pitched it at seven. We should doubtless pay tribute to the seer's judgment. Perhaps his anxieties were spot on. Maybe he was at the edge of the future curve, where all prophets like to be. Certainly, since the lead once stood at 30, there's no denying that a downward momentum has brought the government in sight of earth.

But there's another way of looking at the shift between May and July. Starting in April, this was the period in which the Gould messages bore down on Mr Blair. The two we know about conveyed a sense of total panic. Everything is going wrong, said Gould. "TB is not believed to be real." "TB is out of touch - he does not really care." "We are outflanked on patriotism and crime." On hearing this, TB immediately jumped to it. We see this in his own leaked memo from the same time, itemising worries about crime, patriotism and his personal image. He was desperately seeking initiatives to meet the Gould perceptions.

Mr Gould's first role, therefore, is as an agent of exaggerated terror. The two months that followed his sepulchral commentaries on a 16-point lead have seen the government looking ever more unstable, lurching about in response to what we now know was his advice. It hadn't been exactly calm before. But the leaks show us a collective state of mind we may have been only half aware of. No wonder, with all that stuff pouring into his head, the prime minister got rattled. This was supposed to be his friend, telling him truths that nobody else was wise enough to spot.

Mr Gould, moreover, had little compunction about many people seeing them. That's why he wrote it all down, ready, as it turns out, for theft. He explains this ideology of exposure in his book about the 1997 victory, The Unfinished Revolution. "If a strategy is not in writing, it does not exist," a Clinton adviser had told him. So these springtime memos virtuously offered Blair the "complete understanding of your weaknesses" which Gould thinks leaders should get from people like him. "The odd leak," his book goes on, "is small change compared with that and, in any event, the leaked truth can not only help prod an organisation in the right direction, but also tell the world that it is still listening, it still cares."

To a talent for hysteria, therefore, the Gould approach to politics adds arrogant naivety. He's probably changed his mind about the therapy of leaks. But assertions about what the public really thinks remain the basis of his business. His interpretation of the focus groups he assembles, whose wisdom he passionately believes in, carried huge influence with Mr Blair in 1996-97. This remains so. We approach the heart of the matter. What I get from the latest leak is not the confessional brilliance of Gould's insights but the part these have played in the very problem that's making him and the Labour leadership despair.

He says, on the one hand, that Labour is seen as lacking conviction. The government needs much more clarity: "uncompromising and single-minded positions in all of the policy and issue areas", instead of "a whole raft of often confusing and abstract third way messages". People need to know what New Labour stands for. "We are suffering from disconnection. We have been assailed for spin." Gould is sincere in his desire to change all this. He's a committed, dedicated man. Yet who invented the culture of spin and the virtue of confusion? The balance between opposites is New Labour's holy grail. Gould had a leading role in the search for it. Successful campaigns, he writes, are built "on the synthesis of contrasting ideas and contrasting policies".

Could there be a better recipe for disconnection? As for spin, it's the essence of what this guru of scientific populism brought to the Labour high command. In both his book and his memos, appearance is what dominates. The politics of perception is all. What people think is what matters. It should be your guide, both on what to do and on whether your actions are effective. In Gould's world, perception, far from being at odds with reality, is reality. And that is exactly Labour's problem. Its substance is not apparent. Its manipulation is too obvious. "We are not believed" (quote: P Gould).

This, then, is a chief apostle of what is going wrong. He recommended a draining of much of the conviction which, he now observes, Labour is seen as lacking. He proposes, instead, ever closer listening to the opinions of focus groups, especially in areas where Labour is seen to be insufficiently rightwing: crime, patriotism (whatever that's meant to mean), the family. Though the Daily Mail isn't mentioned in these memos, it is the fountainhead of wisdom Blair must tap into, notwithstanding the fact, which Gould well knows, that only 13% of its readers contributed their vote to the Labour landslide.

His proposed remedies for the disaster he foresees are the epitome of waffle. "From third way to one way. . . cross a threshold of voter trust. . . stability and security in a context of change. . . security and opportunity in a world of change. . . bla bla bla". His is the politics, essentially, of cowardice, offending no one, challenging nobody, voicing not the conviction of a true prophet but the half- perceived prejudices of the masses before whom he stands transfixed.

Besides being unedifying, this is plain wrong. The guru is talking his party into self-destructive alarm. At 10% it stands, a year before an election, where no party has ever stood and lost. If there is a message from the leaks, it is that the time has come for simple speaking, honest truth, and the display of some convictions, including unpopular ones, for their own sake. Even the focus groups seem to be saying that. If TB is seen as "saying things to please people, not because he believes them" (Gould memo no 1), the answer would not seem to be still more sedulous contrivance. Mr Blair does, after all, have beliefs. Somewhere in there is the big picture of where he wants to go. The Tory party has no credibility. Yet here is an adviser, gripped by a false premise, panicking all around him. It's urgent that somebody should leave the entourage, and the name's not Alastair.

webTitle: Dispute over Jerusalem threatens peace talks

fields.headline: Dispute over Jerusalem threatens peace talks
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The global economic summit was put on hold, the US presidential plane stood by and the Middle East held its collective breath last night as 52 years of Israeli-Palestinian conflict boiled down to its spiritual essence - a few acres of sacred stone in Jerusalem.
fields.body:
The global economic summit was put on hold, the US presidential plane stood by and the Middle East held its collective breath last night as 52 years of Israeli-Palestinian conflict boiled down to its spiritual essence - a few acres of sacred stone in Jerusalem.

Sources on both sides of the peace talks at Camp David said that a comprehensive settlement was within reach on every issue but one. By late yesterday evening neither side would surrender claims of sovereignty over the holy sites in Jerusalem's Old City.

Discussion of possible compromises brought threats of a walk-out by the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, and then the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, who sent a formal letter to President Bill Clinton accusing the Palestinians of bad faith, and threatening to pack his bags.

"The Palestinians arrived at Camp David lacking good faith, and are not ready to have a substantive discussion about a lasting peace and to make historic decisions," Mr Barak's letter said, according to Israeli television yesterday. "Unless there are last-minute changes, the Palestinians will have to rue the tragic consequences of a missed opportunity."

PJ Crowley, a spokesman for the president's national security council, confirmed that the White House had received a letter from Mr Barak, but did not provide details. Other US officials played down the threats as the inevitable brinksmanship of the Middle East endgame.

President Clinton was sufficiently confident that an accord could be salvaged to postpone his departure to the G8 economic summit in Okinawa by 18 hours. The US treasury secretary, Larry Summers, was dispatched to stand in for him at a meeting with representatives of developing nations in Tokyo on the eve of the summit.

The White House spokesman, Joe Lockhart, said Mr Clinton "made a judgment that the issues here are important enough and the stakes are high enough" to make it worth spending an extra day at the presidential retreat in Maryland, where the talks entered their ninth day. He insisted, however, that the president would leave "sometime after midnight" (5am BST).

Mr Lockhart described the atmosphere as reaching "fever pitch", but refused to go into details, maintaining the news blackout that has enveloped the talks.

The noises off also headed to a peak, as the disparate forces and factions of the Middle East sensed that a deal might be close. Sheikh Ahmed Yassin, the leader of the radical Islamic group Hamas, urged Mr Arafat to abandon the talks and "join us in the trench of resistance and jihad [holy war]".

Hanan Ashrawi, the Palestinian spokeswoman who returned to the West Bank on Tuesday accusing the Israelis of trying to dictate a peace, warned: "As it stands now the situation would be extremely volatile and of course there would be a resurgence of distrust and of anger, perhaps of hostilities... This is extremely precarious now."

"I hope that no one will be so irresponsible and reckless to start to do something violent and unilateral. It would be a big mistake," Ephraim Sneh, the Israeli defence minister, said. He conceded there was "a glimmer of hope" as long as Mr Barak was still at the talks.

Israeli sources in Jerusalem in touch with Mr Barak's delegation said that compromises discussed included Palestinian territory in Gaza and the West Bank being joined by a 30-mile overpass and 100,000 Palestinian refugees being allowed to return to the homes they fled in the 1948 and 1967 wars. The remaining 3.5m refugees would have no right of return.

webTitle: Former poll rival defends first lady

fields.headline: Former poll rival defends first lady
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Hillary Clinton has received support from an unlikely quarter in her attempt to fight off claims that she used an ethnic insult against a campaign aide 26 years ago.
fields.body:
Hillary Clinton has received support from an unlikely quarter in her attempt to fight off claims that she used an ethnic insult against a campaign aide 26 years ago.

New York's mayor, Rudolph Giuliani, said he did not believe that she had called the aide a "fucking Jew bastard" and, even if she had, the events of 1974 no longer mattered.

But as Mr Giuliani defended Mrs Clinton, further evidence emerged to suggest that the incident - if it happened - was not isolated.

"I'm willing to accept her at her word that she didn't, and basically say it's irrelevant what she said and did 26 years ago," said Mr Giuliani, who was Mrs Clinton's opponent in the race for a New York Senate seat until he withdrew in the spring after health and marital problems.

"It seems to me that she has a long public career since 26 years ago that people can agree on, disagree on. fields.headline: Straw funds 4,000 extra police recruits
fields.standfirst:
New figures show 2,740 fall in officers since last election

Special report: Labour in power

Special report: the comprehensive spending review
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, moved to lance damaging criticism over falling police numbers yesterday by announcing that he is to fund an extra 4,000 recruits to the police service on top of the 5,000 he controversially promised at the Labour party conference last year.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, moved to lance damaging criticism over falling police numbers yesterday by announcing that he is to fund an extra 4,000 recruits to the police service on top of the 5,000 he controversially promised at the Labour party conference last year.

The announcement was made as Home Office figures showed that police numbers in England and Wales had fallen by a further 1,678 in the last year to 124,418 - a total drop of 2,740 since Labour came to power in May 1997.

Police forces, who are losing thousands of experienced officers each year, are facing an uphill struggle to attract recruits and the 7,000 a year training capacity for new officers is already fully stretched to meet Mr Straw's Labour party conference pledge last October.

Nevertheless the Home Office estimates that the extra 9,000 recruits - who are to be taken on at 3,000 a year over the next three years - will boost police numbers to 128,300 by March 2002 - a level last seen in 1993.

Mr Straw said yesterday there would be record number of police officers by March 2003.

At the same time that Mr Straw was promising extra police to answer criticism that Labour was being seen as "soft on crime", the House of Lords staged a revolt on the government's plan to take welfare benefits away from convicted offenders who repeatedly breached their community penalties, such as probation.

Ministers accepted amendments from Lady Kennedy and Lord Windlesham which restored to the courts from the probation service, the right to deny someone welfare benefits. The amendments effectively make the scheme unworkable.

The promise of more police recruits came as Mr Straw detailed to the Commons the impact on the home office of the chancellor's comprehensive spending review. He also revealed that 2,600 more prison spaces - as part of a prison building programme - are to be made available and an extra £500m is to be spent on extra equipment for the police, including a digital radio system, developing the criminal DNA database and boosting the number of scenes of crime officers.

In the wake of the Tony Martin case, which was highlighted by Tony Blair as badly handled by Labour, the Home Office also announced a £600,000 boost for policing in the Fenlands part of East Anglia.

Simon Hughes, for the Liberal Democrats welcomed the extra recruits but said three years of sticking to Tory spending plans had guaranteed that there would be fewer police officers at the next election than there were at the last.

For the Conservatives, Ann Widdecombe claimed that after the rising crime figures published this week the home secretary's announcements "had as much credibility as Billy Bunter's postal orders."

For his part, Mr Straw claimed that police numbers had been falling since the Major government in 1992. Conscious that his previous announcement ran into flak amidst accusations of double counting, Mr Straw told MPs yesterday that the additional funding was "for a further 4,000 recruits over and above those already planned, taking the total to an additional 9,000 recruits by 2003-04.

"Since 1994 the Home Office has had no direct control over officer numbers. So, the predicting of future numbers is very difficult. But this investment provides the funding to enable chief constables to raise officer numbers up to record levels by the end of the settlement period."

The home secretary said the boost for police recruitment would also help the police service meet its targets which have been set for the recruitment and retention of more black and Asian officers.

A new London allowance of £3,329 for those who joined after 1994 has also been announced to try to meet the particular difficulties of recruiting in the high house price areas of greater London.

fields.headline: MPs urge end to NHS 'cronyism'
fields.trailText: A Labour-dominated committee of MPs yesterday told the government to prevent suspicions of political cronyism in the NHS by setting up an independent commission to fill thousands of jobs on the boards of trusts and health authorities.
fields.body:
A Labour-dominated committee of MPs yesterday told the government to prevent suspicions of political cronyism in the NHS by setting up an independent commission to fill thousands of jobs on the boards of trusts and health authorities.

The Commons select committee on public administration said it was time to remove ministers' power of patronage over local NHS boards, after Rennie Fritchie, the commissioner for public appointments, concluded in March that the NHS had been politicised by a flood of Labour supporters to top positions since 1997.

Between May 1997 and November 1999, 284 Labour councillors were appointed to health authorities and trusts in the Northern, Yorkshire and North-West NHS regions, but only 23 Conservatives and 36 Liberal Democrats.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, offered to divest himself of power to fill nearly 2,000 non-executive jobs on NHS trusts. But, he said, appointments to the authorities themselves should remain under ministerial control.

fields.headline: Drought broken - now it's all about pipelines
fields.standfirst: Special report: the comprehensive spending review
fields.trailText: The 1990s may have been a good decade for the economy, but they were terrible for public spending.
fields.body:
The 1990s may have been a good decade for the economy, but they were terrible for public spending. When Gordon Brown said yesterday that he had to take difficult decisions on public spending when he arrived at the Treasury in May 1997, he did not spell out that equally difficult decisions had been taken by his Conservative predecessors.

According to the Treasury's own figures, public spending was lower in real terms in the 1999-2000 financial year than in the mid-1990s and barely higher than in 1992-93, when Britain began to emerge from the ERM-induced recession.

After the five-year drought the rainy season has arrived. In fact, this year sees a monsoon of money hitting the public sector, with real spending up by almost 7%. Over the next three years, Mr Brown has pencilled in further real rises averaging 3.2% a year, the Institute for Fiscal Studies said yesterday.

In real terms, spending by Whitehall departments will rise by 5.3% on average over the next three years. But not all Mr Brown's cabinet colleagues shared equally in the bounty.

The biggest winner was John Prescott at the department of environment, transport and the regions, with a 15.6% increase. Transport is top of the list because Mr Brown has skewed spending towards infrastructure projects, where investment will rise by 35% a year - and transport is the one department where more than half the budget is capital.

David Blunkett at education and employment is the next biggest beneficiary, with an 8% settlement, followed by Alan Milburn at health (6.6%), Jack Straw at the Home Office (6.4%), Nick Brown at agriculture (6.4%), and Clare Short at international development (6.2%).

The losers - with annual increases below the average of 5.3% - are Chris Smith at culture, media and sport (4.1%), local government (3.2%), Robin Cook at the Foreign Office (2.7%), Stephen Byers at trade and industry (1.8%) and Geoff Hoon at defence (0.3%).

As far as education is concerned the scale of the increases marks a break with the past. The IFS said that spending under the Conservatives had risen by 1.5% a year in real terms, while in Labour's first two years it increased by 0.2%. In the five years from 1999 to 2004, education spending will rise 5.9% a year.

Labour's record on health, despite the spending freeze, was better. Over the duration of the present parliament money was pumped in at the rate of 4.7% a year, compared to 3.1% during the Conservative years and 3.4% since Nye Bevan became the first health secretary in 1948. The 6.2% a year real increase from 1999 to 2004 has been surpassed in only one previous five-year period, from 1971 to 1976.

The IFS shares Mr Brown's confidence that the increases can be afforded. Even at the end of the period covered by the plans, spending will still be lower as a proportion of output than it was in the early 1990s. Higher allocations for Whitehall departments have already been paid for through the higher taxes imposed since 1997.

But affordability is not everything. One of the motivations for three-year spending periods is to allow departments to plan over longer periods - but this is not happening. The IFS said yesterday that only 0.8% of departmental expenditure limits would be unchanged in the third year of the first spending plan, and in almost every case the limit had been raised rather than lowered.

Two other questions remain: has Mr Brown left it all too late and is it possible to manage the public sector through a form of central planning?

There is some evidence that even in areas where Mr Brown has already made more money available - capital spending, for example - departments have forgotten how to spend, or lack the expertise to turn ideas into reality. In some areas, as the IMF pointed out yesterday, even the whopping increases on offer will not make up for the deep cuts seen over the past 10 years. DETR spending will still only account for around 1.5% of GDP after the investment on public transport, compared to 2% in the early 1990s. This is the last chance for the government to get it right. If the public sees no improvement after these increases, Labour will have run out of excuses.

Mr Brown's goal of improving public services by tying Whitehall departments to performance targets is laudable, but the IFS cast doubt on its practicality. The Treasury sets goals which can be quantified; but they are not necessarily the goals that matter.

fields.headline: 5.2m tax files disappear
fields.trailText: Almost 20% of the nation's workforce could be sent incorrect tax bills after the inland revenue admitted yesterday it could not find the records of more than 5m taxpayers.
fields.body:
Almost 20% of the nation's workforce could be sent incorrect tax bills after the inland revenue admitted yesterday it could not find the records of more than 5m taxpayers.

Independent tax planners described the embarrassment as "a nightmare" and predicted that if the files were not located inland revenue would find it almost impossible to assess correctly future tax payments.

If it is unable to locate the files before October, it will be forced to seek ministerial approval to calculate workers' tax bills with incomplete information.

Government officials last night confirmed the contents of a leaked internal memo, seen by the Guardian, highlighting the problem. But they insisted the vital data - apparently lost in the computer system - would be found.

The inland revenue internal memo dated June 16 under the title "missing 1998/99 pay and tax details" states: "There remain some 5.2m taxpayer records for which no 1998/99 pay and tax details are held on COP (computerised operation of the pay as you earn)."

It also admits that some of the data is being entered wrongly.

"It is apparent that there are a significant number of cases where incorrect 98/99 pay and tax details have been posted to COP records resulting in cases failing the tax table test and being left open with potentially serious consequences for incorrectly repaying or coding out overpayments or underpayments," says the memo.

Richard Shooter, a partner of the accounting firm Henstock Shooter, said he was not surprised at the latest disaster because there had been continual stories about computer failures at inland revenue.

"It sounds like a nightmare. If things go missing like this it makes it very difficult to follow up inquiries and could cause problems assessing future tax levels," he explained.

Industry magazine Computer Weekly, which was originally sent the leaked memo, said some taxpayer records go missing each year and full explanations are pro vided later. However the magazine says that in May, 8.04m "open cases" were under investigation compared to 2.5m cases in May 1998.

An inland revenue spokes-man last night insisted there was no long term problem. "These files have not disappeared forever into cyberspace," he said. "The figure was 5.2m in June but we have been working on this and just have to return all of them to the COP system. All major IT initiatives have some kind of teething problems and that is all this is."

A formal statement from the government tax department added: "The IR has well established arrangements to deal with these situations and ensure that the correct information is obtained and the right amount of tax is paid.

At the centre of the crisis are two computer systems which have been handed over to different firms from the private sector. Files appear to have gone missing somewhere between the two.

This interface, called COP/CORR, is meant to link the National Insurance Recording System (Nirs2) to COP.

Nirs2 is run by Andersen Consulting under a seven-year outsourcing agreement while the COP system is in the hands of information technology giant EDS.

fields.headline: Republican bomb paralyses London
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The campaign tactics of dissident Irish republicans opposed to the Good Friday agreement became clear yesterday when parts of London were paralysed by a bomb hidden in a pile of rubbish close to one of the busiest railway lines in the country.
fields.body:
The campaign tactics of dissident Irish republicans opposed to the Good Friday agreement became clear yesterday when parts of London were paralysed by a bomb hidden in a pile of rubbish close to one of the busiest railway lines in the country.

Even though the device did not explode, the closure of tube and mainline stations caused misery for hundreds of thousands of commuters, roads were gridlocked, and the build-up to the Queen Mother's centenary pageant in Whitehall was disrupted.

After the bomb had been destroyed by Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist branch, Victoria and Westminster stations were evacuated for security sweeps.

Seven weeks ago dissident republicans, almost certainly the Real IRA, launched their first successful attack in England by planting a small Semtex bomb under Hammersmith bridge in west London. Nobody was injured but the explosion caused rush-hour chaos and the bridge is still undergoing repairs.

Security sources said yesterday that the dissidents had "learned the lesson of Omagh" - a reference to the Real IRA bomb in Co Tyrone that killed 29 people in August 1998. The goal, sources said, was "to cause maximum disruption without killing civilians".

Yesterday's alert began at 6.15am when various organisations in Dublin were warned that a bomb would go off at 8am in west London. The callers pinpointed Twyford Avenue in Ealing and mentioned possible devices at Victoria and Westminster.

Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, said the bombers' codeword had also been used to warn of a recent attack on a railway line at Newry in Northern Ireland.

Officers from the anti-terrorist branch and British Transport police found a bag hidden in some rubbish on the embankment near the track, which is one of the key rail lines from London to Wales and the west country.

Scotland Yard sources said the device was live. "This was a viable bomb. It was primed to explode," they said. It contained half a kilo of high explosive, probably Semtex.

Paddington station, one of the busiest in Britain, was closed for the rest of the day. Underground stations in west London were also affected.

The closure of Victoria mainline and underground station at 11.20am caused further chaos in central London.
