The goal, sources said, was "to cause maximum disruption without killing civilians". Yesterday's alert began at 6.15am when various organisations in Dublin were warned that a bomb would go off at 8am in west London. The callers pinpointed Twyford Avenue in Ealing and mentioned possible devices at Victoria and Westminster. Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, said the bombers' codeword had also been used to warn of a recent attack on a railway line at Newry in Northern Ireland. Officers from the anti-terrorist branch and British Transport police found a bag hidden in some rubbish on the embankment near the track, which is one of the key rail lines from London to Wales and the west country. Scotland Yard sources said the device was live. "This was a viable bomb. It was primed to explode," they said. It contained half a kilo of high explosive, probably Semtex. Paddington station, one of the busiest in Britain, was closed for the rest of the day. Underground stations in west London were also affected. The closure of Victoria mainline and underground station at 11.20am caused further chaos in central London.

webTitle: Cash pledge to improve BBC output

fields.headline: Cash pledge to improve BBC output
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the BBC
fields.trailText: The BBC yesterday underlined its commitment to plough extra cash into programme making after admitting last month that quality was falling below standards.
fields.body:
The BBC yesterday underlined its commitment to plough extra cash into programme making after admitting last month that quality was falling below standards.

Sir Christopher Bland, the BBC's chairman, emphasised the need to provide a better mix of programmes, expand the online service, and increase accountability. He re-stated the aim of increasing the percentage of the licence fee spent on programming from 76% to 85% by 2006.

The pledges reiterated plans to increase diversity in programming, to experiment with drama and entertainment, to screen more shows made in Scotland, Northern Ireland and Wales to the rest of the network, and better reflect Britain's cultural mix.

The BBC's campaign to foster new talent has attracted 5,200 sitcom scripts, 16,000 people hoping to work on Radio 1 and 1,300 musical compositions to Radio 3.

 Hit BBC programmes such as EastEnders and Changing Rooms will soon reach more than 30m American homes after the corporation signed digital distribution deal with Time Warner for their US channel, BBC America. The service will be carried by the three main US cable operators, and satellite systems.

fields.headline: Judge backs Punch
fields.trailText: A High Court judge yesterday upheld the law that says reporters can refuse to disclose their sources in many circumstances.
fields.body:
A High Court judge yesterday upheld the law that says reporters can refuse to disclose their sources in many circumstances.

The Mirror newspaper had taken Punch magazine to court in a row over leaked internal emails touching on attitudes towards women in journalism, provision for Mirror staff at Royal Ascot, and the newspaper's financial performance. The emails were printed out and faxed. Five of them are reproduced in the current edition of Punch.

The Mirror applied for an order requiring Punch to hand over documents, but Mr Justice Jacobs upheld the magazine's refusal and awarded Punch £9,000 costs. He said Punch was justified in objecting that fingerprints might be a clue to the mole's identity.

The Mirror was given leave to appeal.

fields.headline: Veritas doubts cost 2,000 jobs
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: The government is coming under increasing pressure to give more help to hi-tech industries in Britain after the loss of a £250m investment project that would have created 2,000 jobs.
fields.body:
The government is coming under increasing pressure to give more help to hi-tech industries in Britain after the loss of a £250m investment project that would have created 2,000 jobs.

Veritas, the world's fourth largest software company, said yesterday that it had halved its plan to invest £500m in Britain.

Its decision comes days after Nokia, Yahoo! and Sun Microsystems warned that hi-tech companies would leave Britain unless the government took a more positive attitude towards the sector. The industry believes that the government's actions are at odds with the prime minister's goal of making Britain the best country for e-commerce.

Despite its reservations, Veritas will still be creating 2,000 jobs with a £250m project to build a new European headquarters at Reading and a research facility at Watford.

Philip Bousfield, its vice-president for worldwide operations, said the group would have doubled its investment had it been more confident of the government's policy on hi-tech industries.

Veritas's confidence in the government had been undermined by last year's Budget decision to introduce national insurance contributions on stock option gains.

"At a stroke, this has left hi- tech companies open to uncapped liabilities," he said. Veritas' liabilities in Britain had risen from £300,000 to £8m. "Luckily we are a big company, but for a small hi-tech company this would have been disastrous."

He said the government was stifling the potential of the country's hi-tech sector by implementing "inappropriate US-style measures" on issues such as business taxation.

He argued that copying the US would not work in Britain because the country lacked "an established and booming hi-tech economy, greater venture capital funding and a business culture which is happier to take risks".

Mr Bousfield, who has already raised the issue with Treasury ministers, said Veritas was committed to investing a further £250m in Europe and that a decision would be made in about a year's time.

But the further investment would only be made in Britain if there were signs that the government was providing more support for the technology sector.

He said the government, while offering much-needed support for small hi-tech firms, failed to understand what was needed to create big companies in the sector.

"I am English and would like to see the way to build a company the size of Veritas in the UK," he said, "Veritas is worth $40bn at the moment."

He called on the government to set up a high-powered independent committee to identify what action needed to be taken to accelerate the growth of the technology sector in Britain.

The Treasury said in response to Mr Bousfield that the country had a very good record in attracting inward investment. The government was already taking action to remove the kinds of weaknesses suggested by him.

This included cuts in capital gains tax to encourage entrepreneurs, reward risk-taking and promote wider share ownership among employees.

The government had also made an extra £100m available to stimulate the early venture capital market, and had commissioned an outside investigation into institutional investors' reluctance to invest in venture capital.

Veritas, which is based in Mountain View in California's Silicon Valley, is a market leader in "crash-proof" data storage software.

fields.headline: Catholic leader appointed paedophile priest
fields.trailText: The leader of Catholics in England and Wales yesterday refused to resign after revelations that he allowed a high risk paedophile to carry on as a priest despite warnings that he would reoffend.
fields.body:
The leader of Catholics in England and Wales yesterday refused to resign after revelations that he allowed a high risk paedophile to carry on as a priest despite warnings that he would reoffend.

Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, who became Archbishop of Westminster four months ago, did not call in the police after allegations that Michael Hill had sexually abused children. Hill attacked one child while he read stories about Jesus to him.

The priest allegedly even believed the children enjoyed his abuse of them.

In 1997 Hill was jailed for five years for indecent assault on children and gross indecency over a 19-year period.

While he was bishop of Arundel and Brighton, the Rt Rev Murphy-O'Connor appointed Hill to a ministry after being warned he was a paedophile. The diocese, where Hill reoffended, paid compensation after two brothers, abused by Hill when they were nine and 10, sued the church.

Yesterday's revelations are the latest sex abuse scandal to hit the Catholic church in the UK, amid allegations that senior clergy protected abusers fearing the damage that disclosure would do, rather than doing all in their power to bring the offenders to justice.

In 1983, allegations of Hill's paedophilia led to his removal from his parish in Heathfield, Sussex. Hill then checked into a therapy centre for priests, Our Lady of Victory, but left after three months.

Doctors who treated Hill wrote to the bishop warning that the priest was still a big danger to children: "There is still a risk that Father Hill will act out again... especially when he is reported to have said that he believes the chil dren enjoyed their experience with him." The letter later says "a high risk still pertains in this case".

John Murphy, a programme director at the centre while Hill was there, refused to discuss the case, but said: "Even if there's the slightest risk, someone should not be put in a ministry where there's a risk of meeting children."

But in 1985 the Rt Rev Murphy-O'Connor appointed Hill to the post of chaplain at Gatwick airport. There he met a child with learning disabilities whom he abused over two years.

The mother of one of the abused boys complained to the bishop. She said: "I went to see the bishop personally and told him what was going on. He said he would deal with it. But little did I know he would take Father Hill from this parish and put him in another parish."

Hill's victims were as young as nine. One said of his ordeal: "He used to kneel down next to my bed and start reading stories about Jesus.

"He used to put his hand under the covers and down my pyjamas."

Five years ago some of Hill's victims turned to Margaret Kennedy, of Christian Survivors of Sexual Abuse, for help and advice. Last night she demanded that the archbishop resign: "I don't think he can stay in his position. I don't see how he can gain the trust of the Catholic community having done this. I do not have confidence in [him] now, knowing that he protected and did not do the right thing with a paedophile priest."

Michelle Elliott, of Kidscape, a charity which aims to prevent harm to, or abuse of, children, also demanded the archbishop stand down: "If he resigned he would give a clear message that what happened was wrong. Trying to justify it makes things worse."

Although the archbishop has denied acting irresponsibly, he has admitted making mistakes. He insisted he acted in accordance with advice he received: "One of the recommendations was that he could have a limited ministry, and I believed at that time that the work of an industrial chaplain at Gatwick was such a ministry.

"The understanding of paedophilia that was common 20 years ago is very very different to what it is now. If a similar situation were to arise today, I would act differently."

In a chronology drawn up in 1995 by some of Hill's victims, they wrote: "No attempt was made to counsel the victims or investigate whether other people were assaulted. When families complained, the bishop [Murphy-O'Connor] mediated with the parents. The purpose of this mediation was to reconcile the betrayal of trust with a spiritual adherence to Catholicism. In other words it was hushed up - the parents were dissuaded by the clergy from going to the police."

webTitle: Union head accuses rival over fraud claim

fields.headline: Union head accuses rival over fraud claim
fields.trailText: The trade union leader Roger Lyons has accused the general secretary of a rival union of backing "unsubstantiated allegations" that he was personally involved in a £130,000 fraud and fiddling expenses, and accused the Guardian of fabricating a story that he charged a 25p bun to expenses.
fields.body:
The trade union leader Roger Lyons has accused the general secretary of a rival union of backing "unsubstantiated allegations" that he was personally involved in a £130,000 fraud and fiddling expenses, and accused the Guardian of fabricating a story that he charged a 25p bun to expenses.

A letter from Mr Lyons, general secretary of the Manufacturing, Science and Finance union, to John Edmonds, general secretary of the GMB general union, demanded that Mr Edmonds should give assurances that he did not believe the allegations to be true.

Today 134 MSF members - in a letter to the Guardian - call for an independent inquiry into the union's finances in the light of disclosures that came after the whistleblower Marcia Solomon won a case for unfair dismissal against the union.

In a further letter in the Guardian today, Mr Lyons attacks the paper for "fabricating" stories about his expenses. He says the receipt on his union credit card for the 25p bun followed original expenses of £12.75 when he was recruiting people to the union.

Mr Lyons's letter to Mr Edmonds - leaked to the Guardian after he had posted it to the GMB and the TUC - revealed that John Monks, the TUC general secretary, has been trying to prevent the row from spilling over into an inter-union dispute.

Ms Solomon was a GMB shop steward at the MSF union, and her case was taken up by the GMB. The case, which cost the MSF £140,000, revealed shortcomings in the union's accounts and called into question whether its accountants, HW Fisher, had properly investigated the alleged fraud and expenses of the general secretary and Nelson Mendes, head of finance.

Altogether, the MSF has spent £750,000 paying off three former officers involved in the allegations.

Mr Lyons said in the letter to Mr Edmonds: "When we met informally at the TUC on 19th May I indicated the concerns felt by MSF and its NEC at the unsubstantiated allegations of fraud and theft being supported by the GMB."

He listed why he believed he was cleared - even though Ms Solomon won her case - concluding: "I would therefore ask you and your union to stop supporting completely unsubstantiated allegations of fraud and theft and to confirm this to me and John Monks.

"The TUC general secretary did ask us to avoid airing any industrial relations problems between us in the media, and I thought we both agreed to this, in the interests of our members and the wider movement."

Last night both the TUC and the GMB seemed mystified by the Mr Lyons's outburst. A GMB spokesman said: "We took up the case of Marcia Solomon because it involved wrongful dismissal... The result of the case is public knowledge."

The TUC confirmed that Mr Monks had brought both general secretaries together before the case to "facilitate discussions about personnel". Under TUC rules Mr Monks can not intervene in the affairs of either union.

A spokesman for Mr Lyons said he was "seeking clarification" of the GMB's position after the case had finished.

webTitle: Letters: Confusion reigns with regard the MSF

fields.headline: Lyons on that 25p bun
fields.trailText: David Hencke continues to write articles damaging to MSF and myself (May 23 to July 18). The MSF president explained (Letters, May 25) that the allegations referred to were made in February 1999 and the MSF national executive immediately arranged for an independent investigation by forensic accountants HW Fisher into all the allegations, including my expenses.
fields.body:
David Hencke continues to write articles damaging to MSF and myself (May 23 to July 18). The MSF president explained (Letters, May 25) that the allegations referred to were made in February 1999 and the MSF national executive immediately arranged for an independent investigation by forensic accountants HW Fisher into all the allegations, including my expenses.

The verdict that the allegations "were untrue and without foundation" was confirmed by the government's independent Certification Officer in his report of July 21, 1999. No evidence whatsoever was found to support your "£130,000 fraud" headline (July 4). The former MSF assistant general secretary, John Chowcat, admitted on March 24, 1999 that "the fraud allegation lacks effective supporting evidence and I therefore unreservedly withdraw this allegation and duly apologise to you for any inconvenience caused".

Hencke also misrepresents the facts on my expenses. He states I made unjustified "sustenance" claims for £371 for 43 meetings between January 5, 1997 and September 19, 1998. Of these "normal" meetings, 18 were on Sundays, nine on Saturdays and three on Bank Holidays. Of the rest, five were early morning engagements before 8am, whilst eight were late-night commitments after 9pm. Hardly "normal".

And many have asked me where it is possible to buy a "25p bun" (May 23). Were his story true, the answer would be the café at the Royal Institute of British Architects, where I had addressed our members seeking recognition at an outdoor pre-work rally. After the rally, we met six of the union activists for breakfast, which cost a total of £13. (The cashier put through two credit card slips for £12.75 and 25p).

But we did win our campaign for recognition. Why won't you report our members' progress on employment rights, rather than fabricated stories about "25p buns"?
Roger Lyons
General secretary, MSF

 We have followed your articles on our union with horror and regret.

It now appears that the original investigations into the allegations against Mr Lyons were flawed and cannot be relied on to establish his guilt or innocence. It also appears that large sections of the leadership of MSF have been more concerned to cover up the allegations than to get to the bottom of them. This has so far cost the union at least£700, 000.

There is only one course of action which can restore the union's good name. That is to conduct a new investigation by people with no previous connection with MSF. We call on the MSF executive to arrange for such an investigation to be carried out without delay and to publish the findings in full to MSF members and to the general public. And if it is discovered that wrongdoing has taken place, to ensure the perpetrators are removed from their posts.
Dave Nellist, Hugh MacGrillen
and 132 other MSF members

webTitle: This spree is likely to be hangover-free

fields.headline: This spree is likely to be hangover-free
fields.standfirst: Economy can take extra heat
fields.trailText: Kenneth Clarke used to say that those Budgets which were praised to the skies on the night tended to be the ones that unravelled the quickest. So the hangover-detectors were out yesterday after Tuesday's comprehensive spending review from Gordon Brown.
fields.body:
Kenneth Clarke used to say that those Budgets which were praised to the skies on the night tended to be the ones that unravelled the quickest. So the hangover-detectors were out yesterday after Tuesday's comprehensive spending review from Gordon Brown.

Michael Portillo and Matthew Taylor, the treasury spokesman for the Liberal Democrats, did their best to make something out of two lines in the minutes of the July meeting of the monetary policy committee, when Threadneedle Street's finest had the benefit of a briefing of what would be in the CSR from Gus O'Donnell. But in fact, the MPC's observation that private spending would have to slow to make room for the boost to demand from the public sector simply restates what they have been expecting to happen anyway.

Rather more alarming for the City yesterday were some chunky figures for high street spending, suggesting that Britain's consumers are not yet in the mood to tighten their belts. This was enough to send short-sterling sliding, a clear indication that the money markets think interest rates may have to rise after their five-month pause at 6%.

But, as has been the case for many months - if not years - yesterday's data showed that consumers are only attracted into the shops when they see bargains on offer. Lower prices lead to higher volumes, but the higher volumes do not lead on subsequently to higher prices. It could be, of course, that the steady fall in unemployment will eventually break this pattern. But average earnings growth has slowed sharply this year and that trend has been combined with a rise in inflation prompted by higher mortgage payments and by the pain inflicted on motorists. As a result, real earnings growth has also slowed sharply.

In the short term this is not especially good news for the government. After all, ministers like to see real disposable incomes racing up in the months leading up to an election. But, in the medium term, it is excellent news for Gordon Brown for two reasons. First, it means that the hefty increases in public spending (with the heftiest increases of all coming in the current financial year) will not blow the economy off course. Second, it means that there is genuine scope to run the economy at higher levels of demand without leading to a pick-up in inflation, something every chancellor since the early 1960s has been seeking to achieve.

Fair share
Luring employees with potentially lucrative share options has become a new economy must, especially when the start-up doing the hiring lacks that old fashioned thing called cash. Yet, for years now, analysts have debated the real cost of this form of pay on regular shareholders without reaching a consensus.

So step forward Sir David Tweedie, chairman of our Accounting Standards Board. The body might sound arcane, but Sir David certainly is not, and proposals issued yesterday cut straight to the heart of the matter: the value of employee share options should be dragged straight through a company's profit and loss account, the ASB says.

According to Sir David's number crunching, Microsoft for example would see last year's profits of $7.8bn (£4.8bn) shrink by at least $1bn if the paper handed out to employees was clearly accounted for. What is more, the proposals have been agreed by the self-appointed G4+1 group of global accounting standard setters, which takes in Australia, Canada, New Zealand and the US, as well as Britain. This is a welcome move towards greater transparency. But stand by for a hell of a row over how companies are valued from here on out.

Pulp diction
Some 50% of the product is TCF (totally chlorine free) wood pulps sourced from plantation forests, generally using forest thinnings, offcuts and surplus timber. None of the pulp used in production is sourced from tropical rainforests. What is more, the other half is recycled fibre and "pre- and post-consumer waste", which is de-inked using chlorine-free processes.

So what is the product? The 1999 environmental report from Blue Circle Industries, of course - the company that digs up various parts of the world and turns the result into cement.

The report, published yesterday, guides us through the company's two-year stakeholder consultation process, pours out environmental performance indicator data and then presents the reader with a special verification certificate from a firm called Lloyd's Register Quality Assurance, who have been working to the requirements of ISO 14001, 14010 and 14011.

Bemused? Cynical? Well, Blue Circle has just come through a battle for its independence, staging a stunning escape from an all-cash bid from France's Lafarge. And the textbooks say corporate takeover activity rarely creates value.

webTitle: Analysis: But does the Blair government have more holes than its predecessors?

fields.headline: Pssst... I've got something to tell you
fields.standfirst:
Briefing, said Jim Callaghan, is what I do; what you do is leaking. But does the Blair government have more holes than its predecessors?

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The leak of Tony Blair's memo showed "malevolence at the heart of government", according to Alun Michael. There is indeed something demoniacal about the leak phenomenon: it's that nobody ever gets caught.
fields.body:
The leak of Tony Blair's memo showed "malevolence at the heart of government", according to Alun Michael. There is indeed something demoniacal about the leak phenomenon: it's that nobody ever gets caught.

Here, leading the latest inquiry, you have Whitehall's head prefect, Sir Richard Wilson. GCHQ is his to command; he used to be permanent secretary at the Home Office and so knows the Security Service inside out. Yet the odds are that the cabinet secretary will uncover no mole. Or Macavity the mystery cat. Sir Richard, like his predecessor Robin Butler, is programmed to fail - in the same way as Sir David Omand at the Home Office conspicuously failed to identify the leaker of the Macpherson committee report on the Stephen Lawrence case. In every case instanced in the accompanying list (far from exhaustive) no culprits were found.

But that is because most leaks are not disclosures by those contractually bound to maintain confidences, especially civil servants and officials. As for ministers, only some of them swear the privy councillor's oath enjoining silence and it never did have much moral weight. Leaking, said former Labour prime minister Jim Callaghan in one of politics' greatest aphorisms, is what you do; briefing is what I do.

A precise listing of what we the press call "leaks" would range from deliberate passage of information by a political actor to accidental loss and outright theft. Journalists, the usual recipients of leaks, know perfectly well who the guilty parties are. While they would be sacked for revealing confidential material belonging to their employer, the shoe is on another foot where information to do with the state is concerned. Ultimately leaks are just a decadent form of political communication.

Because they are so heterogeneous it is hard to put numbers on them. Our list includes the leak of draft reports of Commons' committees, but this is simply an instance of MPs' putting party fellowship above parliamentary solidarity, nothing new about that. It cannot be right to call the fingering of Peter Mandelson as a privileged mortgagor a leak: it was an act of internecine political warfare.

Some leaks provoke "official inquiries" but they, too, are movable feasts. No man ual exists to tell permanent secretaries what to do. Even in Sir Richard Wilson's inquiry into the Blair memo leak, it will be the Special Branch who will do the investigating, but only once "suspicion" is established.

Civil servants are being asked to examine the behaviour of politicians or advisers, consultants and the like. There are two problems with this. Civil servants spend their careers deferring to their political masters. As Sir Robin Butler showed in his mild and gentlemanly requests for enlightenment to Jonathan Aitken, they do not amount to the third degree.

The other problem is more profound. The civil service itself is supremely flexible in judging what constitutes authorisation to disclose. The classic case was when Colette Bowe, head of information at the Department of Trade and Industry during the Westland affair in 1986 said Downing Street (ie Bernard Ingham) had given her "cover" to issue politically sensitive information. An "ideal type" of leak, against which to compare the variety of ways in which information is passed, might be when Sarah Tisdall copied FO documents and passed them on; she paid a high price for following her conscience.

Formal leak inquiries averaged about 20 a year in the early 80s but shot up to more than 35 in the year of Thatcherite triumphalism, 1988. John Major enjoyed a honeymoon couple of years after he took over as leaks fell into the teens but from 1992, his average was up to nearly 30 a year. My colleague David Hencke secured figures from May 1997 to the end of last year, which suggested Labour's yearly figure is about 25. But these figures for Labour put paid to the ar gument developed by Tory Euro MP and think-tanker Graham Mather who said more leaks meant the civil service was biased against the Tories.

Departments most heavily leaked against (or which themselves do the leaking) are the Home Office, followed by health, Northern Ireland and social security, defence and the Cabinet Office. The Foreign Office, education and Scotland are virtually leak free. These figures may simply reflect policy salience, perhaps also the degree to which some departments (notably the Home Office) have to engage with permeable external bodies, such as the prison and immigration services.

At some level, as Labour MP Diane Abbott said the other day, leaks correlate with deficiencies in trust. Lack of collegiality, especially over Europe, certainly go someway to explaining Major's difficulties. Labour pre sents a more difficult case. Professor Peter Hennessy, of Queen Mary Westfield College, argues that cabinet government has declined under Tony Blair. Yet the volume of leaks attributable to rivalry is slight, excepting Numbers 10 and 11, and there is a good deal less of that since Charlie Whelan left the chancellor's employ 18 months ago.

When he retired Sir Robin (now Lord) Butler complained that leaks - and fear of leaks - was damaging government. It led ministers to rush out documents that deserved fuller consideration; it inhibited "adult conversation" in Whitehall. Whether 25 or so leaks a year constitutes a threshold of anarchy is debatable. But if leaking is harmful, a government tough on crime has one excellent remedy, which lies squarely in Tony Blair and Sir Richard Wilson's hands - catch the perpetrators.

Major leaks since 1997

 July/Oct 97 Northern Ireland Office pro-Unionist leaks
 Dec 97 David Blunkett letter opposing disability cuts
 July 98 Strategic Defence Review leaked
 Dec 98-Jan 99 Peter Mandelson's mortgage details
 Spring 99 various Commons' committee reports to Robin Cook, Lord Donoughue and other ministers
 March 99 Macpherson report on Stephen Lawrence
 Feb 00 export aid; Pinochet medical report
 May 00 Mandelson's relations with Brian Cowen
 June 00 Philip Gould and Alastair Campbell memos
 June 00 NICE report on beta interferon
 July 00 "Pro-euro" leaks from UK ambassador in Japan and head of Invest in Britain
 July 00 Blair and Gould memos

webTitle: Jobs packs Mac power into 8in cube

fields.headline: Jobs packs Mac power into 8in cube
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Apple computers
fields.trailText: Apple Computer unveiled its first new product line for nine months yesterday, including a cube-shaped power computer and an updated iMac range for the consumer market.
fields.body:
Apple Computer unveiled its first new product line for nine months yesterday, including a cube-shaped power computer and an updated iMac range for the consumer market.

Steve Jobs, wearing his trademark baggy jeans and black polo neck jumper, said the Power Mac G4 Cube combined the power of the group's business-focused desktop with the "iMac magic" of sleek design.

He won an appreciative gasp from an audience of thousands of Mac devotees at the annual MacWorld event in New York when he demonstrated the ease of removing the inside of the eight-inch cube-shaped computer.

Wall Street analysts hope the updated iMac range will help improve sales of the colourful computers.

Although about 3.7m iMacs have been sold since they were introduced two years ago, making them among the most popular desktops, sales slowed in the quarter to the end of June.

Apple hopes that the latest range, which boasts five new colours as well as an optical mouse and keyboard, will reinvigorate demand in the run-up to the all-important Christmas selling season.

Wall Street's immediate reaction was negative. Shares in Apple were down more than $3 to $53.625 an hour after the new range had been announced as traders reacted to the slightly weaker sales released the night before.

Apple took the wraps off four new models of the iMac yesterday. The basic model in a new indigo colour scheme will be priced at $799 in the US and aimed at first-time users.

The entry-level machine is important for the group because internal analysis suggests that 30% of all iMac buyers were first-time users of the group's products.

The more expensive models boast digital video and a palette of colours to extend the "fruit sorbet" range.

Other new developments revealed with some gusto by Mr Jobs include computers with dual processors and a demonstration of a new interface for the version of Mac OS to be released next year.

A senior manager at Microsoft received the least enthusiastic welcome from an audience which included some enthusiasts wearing Monopoly-board images of the company.

However, the company displayed a new software suite designed for Macs, prompting Mr Jobs to exclaim: "The best version of Office is that used on the Mac - who would have thunk [sic] it a few years ago."

Average unit prices have been affected by a bigger than expected shift to lower-priced iMacs and iBooks in the education sector. The company has made generous allowances, too, for the discounting it sees as necessary to clear old stock before the new range arrives in the shops.

fields.headline: What Sarah meant to us
fields.trailText: Sarah Payne's death is an unmitigated tragedy. So too are the deaths of Kieran (8), Jade (7) and their mother Claire.
fields.body:
Sarah Payne's death is an unmitigated tragedy. So too are the deaths of Kieran (8), Jade (7) and their mother Claire.

(Hunt for husband after family killed, July 19). From your report, it seems it could be that this will become another domestic violence statistic. Police officers in specialist "hate crime" units throughout the country will be aware that domestic violence represents, overall, approximately 25% of violent crime toward the person and yet this pernicious crime merits scant, and rarely front page, media attention.

"Stranger danger" is clearly a horrific reality, this most recent example eliciting mass sympathy for the victim and revulsion for the perpetrator. The horrors of domestic violence is that it is perpetrated by those in intimate relationships with their victims. Why does this continue to be a more acceptable crime?

The government intends to target key offences in its crime reduction strategy. Let's hope that a good proportion of Gordon Brown's public spending package will find its way to the doorsteps of the many underfunded and under-resourced domestic violence projects currently struggling to survive.
Pattie Friend
Brentford, Middx

 Sean Stone's dilemma (Truth hurts, G2, July 19) is a familiar one but I have a cautionary tale about trying to shield your children from the news. My son was five years old at the time of the Dunblane massacre. Nearly two years later I discovered he knew all about it, with the exception of the one vital fact that Thomas Hamilton was dead. For all that time he had secretly nursed the fear that Hamilton would one day visit his own primary school, because I had turned off the television news to "protect" him.
Jane Duke
York

fields.headline: Imperial memories
fields.trailText: It is a pity British people are not encouraged to use metric units with patriotic pride (Tesco puts old measures back on its shelves, July 18): in the metric system, more units are named in honour of British scientists than those from anywhere else - Joule, Watt, Newton, Kelvin and Faraday (2 units).
fields.body:
It is a pity British people are not encouraged to use metric units with patriotic pride (Tesco puts old measures back on its shelves, July 18): in the metric system, more units are named in honour of British scientists than those from anywhere else - Joule, Watt, Newton, Kelvin and Faraday (2 units).

How about permitting a price for imperial units only if quoted in old money: £7.33 per kg = 4/2d per oz.
John Turner
Wymondham, Norfolk

 Living many furlongs from the market I signed up with Tesco online. I now await the clip clop of hooves as the wagon bringing my groceries trundles down the lane.
William Wood
Etchingham, E Sussex

 There is one vital element missing from your suggestions for Labour's second-term manifesto (July 17): providing the funds to allow councillors to become full-time, paid representatives of their communities. Without this, the devolution of powers from central government alongside single-member wards means conscientious councillors will become even more overworked and under-resourced than they are today.
Adam Lent
Edgware, Middx

 Re: Jesus and the Garvaghy Road (Letters, July 15 and 18): you might also ask, would Jesus seek to prevent others walking there, with the threat of violence?
Peter Day
Chandlers Ford, Hants

 John O'Farrell (Comment, July 19) has joined Simon Hoggart in using Millwall as shorthand for soccer hooligan. Could you explain last week's excellent article on the Millwall academy to them?
John McCulloch
London

 It was Great Britain's Davis Cup team who lost to Ecuador not England's.
Ken Macdonald
 Sheffield

fields.headline: Sun sets on boulevard cruisers
fields.trailText: It is one of the world's most famous stretches of road, the "boulevard of dreams" immortalised by a television series and home to speakeasies and comedy clubs.
fields.body:
It is one of the world's most famous stretches of road, the "boulevard of dreams" immortalised by a television series and home to speakeasies and comedy clubs.

And it is one of the most famous of American youths' pastimes, immortalised in film and accepted by social anthropologists as one of the rites of passage to adulthood. But now Sunset Strip and cruising have collided and the law has stepped in.

This week for the first time in its long and spectacular history, Sunset Strip has become a No Cruising Zone. The signs have gone up warning motorists that if they are seen in the same famous stretch more than once in a four-hour period over weekends, they will be fined $100 (£67).

The move has been made by the West Hollywood city council and is being backed up by the sheriff's department to try to deal with all the young men and women who stream in from the rather more staid areas of Los Angeles at weekends to cruise up and down, gawking and whistling.

Already the number of those pulled in by the sheriff's men and women is into double figures and next weekend the police will be out again in force. A second offence sees the fine double and a third will mean $500 to pay.

Bad luck if you miss your turning and have to retrace your steps.

Sunset Strip is the 1.7-mile stretch of Sunset Boulevard that runs between Hollywood and Beverly Hills. It first came to fame in the 1920s because it was a home for bootlegging and speakeasies and a favourite haunt for the emerging stars of the film business.

Celebrities were later at tracted by nearby hotels like the Garden of Allah and the Chateau Marmont, and the clubs that flourished there. In the 1960s it became famous for the television series 77 Sunset Strip, and then turned into Los Angeles's hippie area.

Since then it has become somewhat seedy but still houses some of the funkiest music venues, comedy stores and Japanese and Mexican restaurants.

Yesterday, it was sunning itself and trying to adjust to its new, no-nonsense status as a No Cruising Zone.

Cruising has been a popular American pastime since cars and small towns were invented but became particularly fashionable after American Graffiti, the George Lucas film starring Richard Dreyfuss, came out in 1973. Much of the film centred on the cruising activities of the main participants.

Since then cruising has also had a sexual connotation but this was not what has been concerning city officials in West Hollywood.

fields.bodyText: It is one of the world's most famous stretches of road, the "boulevard of dreams" immortalised by a television series and home to speakeasies and comedy clubs. And it is one of the most famous of American youths' pastimes, immortalised in film and accepted by social anthropologists as one of the rites of passage to adulthood. But now Sunset Strip and cruising have collided and the law has stepped in. This week for the first time in its long and spectacular history, Sunset Strip has become a No Cruising Zone. The signs have gone up warning motorists that if they are seen in the same famous stretch more than once in a four-hour period over weekends, they will be fined $100 (£67). The move has been made by the West Hollywood city council and is being backed up by the sheriff's department to try to deal with all the young men and women who stream in from the rather more staid areas of Los Angeles at weekends to cruise up and down, gawking and whistling. Already the number of those pulled in by the sheriff's men and women is into double figures and next weekend the police will be out again in force. A second offence sees the fine double and a third will mean $500 to pay. Bad luck if you miss your turning and have to retrace your steps. Sunset Strip is the 1.7-mile stretch of Sunset Boulevard that runs between Hollywood and Beverly Hills. It first came to fame in the 1920s because it was a home for bootlegging and speakeasies and a favourite haunt for the emerging stars of the film business. Celebrities were later at tracted by nearby hotels like the Garden of Allah and the Chateau Marmont, and the clubs that flourished there. In the 1960s it became famous for the television series 77 Sunset Strip, and then turned into Los Angeles's hippie area. Since then it has become somewhat seedy but still houses some of the funkiest music venues, comedy stores and Japanese and Mexican restaurants. webTitle: US custody battle apes Elian fiasco

fields.headline: US custody battle apes Elian fiasco
fields.trailText: The struggle for Cookie has many of the elements of the Elian Gonzalez saga: Like Elian, the six-year-old Cuban boy finally sent home from the US after seven months of bureaucratic and political wrangling, Cookie's loving, adoptive family want to hang on to "their baby".
fields.body:
The struggle for Cookie has many of the elements of the Elian Gonzalez saga: Like Elian, the six-year-old Cuban boy finally sent home from the US after seven months of bureaucratic and political wrangling, Cookie's loving, adoptive family want to hang on to "their baby".

Like Elian, Cookie, also six, eats ice cream, watches television and is the centre of attention whenever the family leaves home. And, in common with Elian, the authorities say that her protectors must allow Cookie to leave for a more appropriate home. But there is a crucial difference between Cookie and Elian: She is a Cercopithecus diana, or rare diana monkey.

"So what if Cookie is a monkey," said Inna Flikshtein, of Manhattan Beach, New York. "She is part of this family. They want to take the baby from the mother. But she will die without us and we will die if we give her up."

The state's department of environmental conservation says that Cookie is a member of an endangered species and must go to the Detroit zoo. The family's appeal against a court ruling to that effect failed and Cookie could be removed at any time, even though the Flikshteins threaten to barricade their home against a raid.

"It reminds me of Russia when Stalin was killing innocent people," said Michael Yumansky, a business partner of Ms Flikshtein's husband, Roman. "We came to America to live a better life and raise our families as we wanted. I hope we were not wrong."

The couple bought the monkey from a pet shop for $4,500 (£3,000) - neither they nor the dealer was apparently aware of Cookie's rarity.

Dr Shirley McGreal, chairwoman of the International Primate Protection League, said: "This couple may think they love the animal, but they're misguided. If I were that monkey, I'd want to join the other monkeys in Detroit."

webTitle: Pentagon is accused of cover-up in gay murder at army base

fields.headline: Pentagon is accused of cover-up in gay murder at army base
fields.trailText: Relatives and supporters of a gay soldier who was murdered at a Kentucky army base are accusing US military chiefs of a cover-up after an official investigation exonerated local officers of blame and concluded that no climate of homophobia existed at the base.
fields.body:
Relatives and supporters of a gay soldier who was murdered at a Kentucky army base are accusing US military chiefs of a cover-up after an official investigation exonerated local officers of blame and concluded that no climate of homophobia existed at the base.

Private Barry Winchell was clubbed to death with a baseball bat in July 1999 by another soldier, Private Calvin Glover, at the Fort Campbell base of the US army's elite 101st Airborne Division. Glover was convicted of murder by a military court in December and was sentenced to life in prison. A third soldier was also jailed for obstructing the investigation into Winchell's death.

The murder trial was told that Winchell had been repeatedly harassed for many months with name-calling and allegations about his sexuality, which had been the talk of the barracks. As Glover was bludgeoning his victim to death he kept up a torrent of anti-gay invective and obscenities.

The trial, which came just a month after the conviction of two Wyoming men for the murder of a gay student, Matthew Shepard, received nationwide publicity and led the army to commission its inspector-general, General Michael Ackerman, to carry out a detailed investigation into the military's treatment of gay service personnel.

His report, based on hundreds of interviews, concludes that some members of Glover's unit held anti-gay attitudes. The company's senior sergeant, who was aware of incidents of anti-gay behaviour, is criticised because he failed to intervene. Nevertheless, the report concludes that officers did not permit a climate in which anti-gay harassment was tolerated, and says that the 101st Airborne - which has played a key combat role in conflicts from D-Day to the Gulf war - harbours no unusual degree of hatred towards homosexuals.

"There were a lot of times when the problem never surfaced up the chain of command," a Pentagon official told US newspapers this week. "But when the leadership discovered the problem, action was taken."

The report's conclusions are not due to be officially unveiled until tomorrow, but key details were leaked on CBS television news on Tuesday night and confirmed in unattributable briefings to US news organisations.

"I'm not saying no harassment occurred," an official told reporters, "but it is an exaggeration to think that every gay on the base is being harassed."

Relatives and supporters reacted angrily to the news. "We're appalled at what we're hearing. We're very disappointed," said Winchell's mother, Patricia Kutteles.

"To me it seems as if the Pentagon brass and the Fort Campbell command are more concerned about protecting themselves than the safety of our soldiers," she added.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText:
Thailand hit by forest fire smog
Forest fires raging on the Indonesian island of Sumatra have spread a blanket of smog as far north as Thailand. The fires have been blamed on plantation firms that use illegal slash-and-burn techniques to clear land. More than 5m hectares were destroyed by similar fires in 1997. Reuters, Jakarta

Property seized from tycoon
Russian investigators have seized a house and some land from media magnate Vladimir Gusinsky, his company's lawyer has revealed.

Mr Gusinsky, who was briefly detained last month, claims the inquiries are part of a Kremlin campaign to silence his newspapers and radio and television stations. Reuters, Moscow

Eta blamed for Spanish attacks
A bomb explosion rocked the Basque regional capital Vitoria and a bomb was found on a politician's car in southern Spain yesterday, in escalating violence blamed on the Basque separatist group ETA.

The blast tore through the roof of a shopping centre. No one was hurt. Hours later, a bomb was found on a car in Malaga, where a local ruling-party politician was shot dead on Saturday. Reuters, Madrid

400 sentenced to die in Rwanda
Courts in Rwanda have sentenced some 400 people to death since genocide trials began four years ago, according to human rights sources. Twenty-two people have been executed.

Around 800,000 ethnic Tutsis and moderate Hutus were slaughtered by Hutu extremists in Rwanda during the country's 1994 genocide. Reuters, Kigali

webTitle: Showtime returns to the arena of death

fields.headline: Showtime returns to the arena of death
fields.standfirst: Colosseum stages first major event since AD523
fields.trailText: The Colosseum - one of the world's most famous landmarks - entered a new era last night by staging its first major spectacle in 1,500 years.
fields.body:
The Colosseum - one of the world's most famous landmarks - entered a new era last night by staging its first major spectacle in 1,500 years.

Around 700 spectators watched a Greek tragedy at sunset, performed on a new stage built over the labyrinth where gladiators and wild animals were once caged.

Shows will be held over the summer to celebrate an eight-year restoration scheme that has led to the opening of the Colosseum's arena, making it the jewel of Rome's archaeological renaissance.

The stage makes it possible for the first time in centuries to stand where gladiators stood, gazing up at the towering tiers of the ancient amphitheater.

Governments have long dreamed of staging performances at the monument, which was completed under Emperor Titus in AD 80. Last night, the Greek National Theatre performed Sophocles's Oedipus Rex before euphoric dignitaries. "This is an historical event for this monument," Giovanna Melandri, Italy's culture minister, said.

Planks of laminated wood, dusted with sand, were laid over part of the floorless arena, which medieval Romans used as a rubbish tip. Delicate cleaning removed grime from stone walls and seats which last held spectators in 523.

Last night's audience had seats and standing room at the eastern end, near the podium where emperors would give the thumbs-up or down to decide the fate of gladiators. Some spectators sat where archers once stood ready to shoot animals that tried to run off the stage. But most of the upper tiers of seating remain in ruins.

Archaeologists will monitor the impact of the changes on the ampitheatre's walls.

It is hoped that visitors will soon be able to explore the labyrinth where lions, crocodiles, bears, elephants and hippopotamuses were hoisted to the surface. The passages were clogged with centuries of earth and junk until Napoleon ordered their excavation.

The festival will include eight performances of three Greek tragedies. Ms Melandri said that future shows would be vetted to ensure they were suitable. "We are not going back to its gruesome and tragic origins, but will instead give space to art and culture."

The restoration follows a spate of initiatives that have broken the lethargy about archaeology in Rome. Five years ago, bureaucracy and shortages of funds had brought digging to a virtual standstill, but an alliance be tween the mayor, Francesco Rutelli, andthe government released funds in time for this year's Vatican jubilee.

Official figures show that tourists - and even Romans - are increasingly rediscovering archaeological sites and museums, lured by a new policy that allows visitors in while the archaeologists work.

The Colosseum remains the focal point. Begun by Emperor Vespasian in 72AD, it was the largest construction in Rome and seated more than 50,000. Though venerated by the Vatican as the site of early Christian martyrdoms, research suggests that the killings actually took place in the circus.

Ridley Scott's blockbuster film, Gladiator, has used special effects to recreate its scale for cinema audiences. But the conveyer-belt of sadism in which animals, condemned criminals and gladiators were slaughtered was sanitised in the film, said Michael Whitby, professor of ancient history at the University of Warwick.

"There were casts of thousands, with casualties in thousands. It is difficult for us to get a handle on the level of killing. It was remorseless."

Emperor Augustus recorded one set of games involving 10,000 gladiators. Lunchtime executions were carried out in which condemned prisoners were dressed as mythological characters and used as bait for wild animals.

Since December the Colosseum has become a beacon for opponents of the death penalty. The arena is bathed in golden light every time a death sentence is commuted anywhere in the world, or whenever a country abandons capital punishment.

Its restoration has encouraged commentators to revive a dusty quotation from Bede: "While the Colosseum stands, Rome shall stand, but when the Colosseum falls, Rome shall fall."

fields.headline: Woodwards 'fell out with US lawyer'
fields.trailText: A member of Louise Woodward's US defence team yesterday denied that her relationship with the family foundered because they would not allow her to write a book on the case.
fields.body:
A member of Louise Woodward's US defence team yesterday denied that her relationship with the family foundered because they would not allow her to write a book on the case.

Elaine Whitfield Sharp said she was told that the former au pair intended to write a book herself, for which she would receive an advance of £500,000 "and she would never have to work again".

The Boston based lawyer was giving evidence for the third day at Chester crown court, where Gary and Sue Woodward are accused of swindling their daughter's appeal fund.

The estranged couple, both 44, are jointly charged with using a bogus invoice to defraud £9,113 from the Louise Woodward and Family Trust and of furnishing false information that they had been charged rent at the home of Mrs Whitfield Sharp and paid the bill from Gary Woodward's account.

Woodward, a joiner, of Ellesmere Port, and his wife, a clerical worker, of Elton, in Cheshire, deny the charges.

The defence claims the invoice was prepared by Mrs Whitfield Sharp or her secretarial staff.

Donal McGuire, representing Susan Woodward, asked Mrs Whitfield Sharp whether she had talked to Mrs Woodward when she returned to Britain prior to her daughter's appeal. She told the court: "I might have called her once or twice. We had some problems with Louise and I had a discussion with her on the phone about that."

Louise Woodward was convicted of the second degree murder of Mathew Eappen, the eight-month-old baby in her care. The trial continues.

fields.headline: City trader claims sex bias
fields.trailText: A female City trader was told by one of her Japanese bosses to wear "short tight skirts in the office", while a British colleague asked her to "strip down and give a massage", during a high-powered business meeting, an employment tribunal was told.
fields.body:
A female City trader was told by one of her Japanese bosses to wear "short tight skirts in the office", while a British colleague asked her to "strip down and give a massage", during a high-powered business meeting, an employment tribunal was told.

Isabelle Terrillon, 35, of Fulham, west London, is claiming Japanese finance firm Nomura International, based in the City of London, forced her to endure a "male-dominated" atmosphere. She claims her colleagues kept pornography on the trading tables.

Ms Terrillon, who was on £45,000 a year, told Stratford employment tribunal in east London that she was subjected to a range of sexist treatment by the nearly all male eastern European emerging markets desk.

Giving evidence, Ms Terrillon described how in 1993, she was part of a successful financial launch and attended a cocktail party. "Mr Tsutsui, the president of Nomura in London, came to congratulate the team and shake their hands. When it came to my turn, as the only female professional on the desk, Mr Tsutsui simply nodded and walked away and would not shake my hand."

After Ms Terrillon told a senior colleague she was pregnant in June 1998, she was marginalised, the hearing was told.

She is claiming sexual discrimination and unfair dismissal.

The hearing continues.

webTitle: Child, 3, left locked up for 10 hours

fields.headline: Child, 3, left locked up for 10 hours
fields.trailText: A woman left a three-year-old girl in a locked garage with no water for more than 10 hours, a court heard yesterday. The child was discovered strapped in a buggy in the garage only after a passerby heard her screaming.
fields.body:
A woman left a three-year-old girl in a locked garage with no water for more than 10 hours, a court heard yesterday. The child was discovered strapped in a buggy in the garage only after a passerby heard her screaming.

Angela Frankham, 24, said she could not find anyone to look after the child while she went to work. She admitted at Sittingbourne magistrates an act of cruelty. Matthew Quantrill, prosecuting, said Frankham, who worked as a carer and was homeless, left the child with only bananas to eat while she was shut up.

He said: "At 4.15 pm on July 1 a man living nearby heard screaming from the garage." The man managed to open the garage. "The child in the buggy was screaming and her clothing was saturated with urine. The man took the child to his neighbour, who changed her clothes."

Frankham, who had slept overnight in the garage, had tried, unsuccessfully, to contact her grandmother and a friend before work. She left the toddler at 6am, went to work, and after finishing at 1pm went to her mother's flat, staying there until 7.30pm, with the child still locked in the garage.

James Burnham, defending, said Frankham worked that day to get the money for a flat. "She knows full well she made completely the wrong decision. She is extremely sorry."

The case was adjourned until August 9 for reports.

fields.headline: Heaven can wait
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV:  Rupert Smith
fields.trailText: Celebrity Rehab/Little Angels/ The Lipstick Years
fields.body:
Alcoholism and drug addiction are terrible things, but they don't half make for some great stories. Clarissa Dickson Wright recalled in Celebrity Rehab (Channel 4) how she came home one day after drinking her usual two bottles of gin, found her boyfriend in bed with a rent boy, picked the trick up and threw him straight through the window. Marc Almond admitted to being so worried about nuclear war that he started hoarding sleeping pills in carrier bags all around his home - so he'd be able to have a quiet night after they dropped the Big One, you understand.

Celebrity Rehab attempted to trace links between the type of people who become famous and the type who become addicts, without much success. Is the appetite for fame and the appetite for drink and drugs the same thing? Obviously not, although there are plenty of people littering the bars of the West End who think they're pretty bloody special once they've got a couple of bevvies inside them. What came across loud and clear is that fame gives you the opportunity to indulge - money to burn, dealers on 24-hour call, and dozens of hangers-on to put up with each new tantrum.

A handful of pundits tried to put the blame on our celebrity-obsessed culture, or to claim that stars are so damaged by mass adoration that they simply have to get leathered in order to survive from gig to gig. Then they wheeled on Ms Dickson Wright, who was an alcoholic long before she became famous, and therefore didn't have that excuse. Ah, but you see she's the famous type.

The show was much more fun, and really more honest, when it allowed the stars to speak for themselves. Jim Davidson was disarmingly frank about his booze hell, and confessed that he'd made his first New Faces appearance off his head on amphetamines. John Reid, Elton John's erstwhile manager, recalled his first encounter with cocaine with all the misty-eyed nostalgia of an old lover. At its best it got very Valley Of The Dolls, and Davidson's unorthodox recipe for tequila sunrise (vodka and orange plus a heavy nosebleed) will be hard to forget.

Even more atrocious was the behaviour of three demonic children in Little Angels (BBC1), a chilling insight into the hell of parenthood. Beautiful blonde Jade (three) had tantrums in the supermarket, attacked her mother and, when she'd been particularly rotten, gave a truly evil smile. Ellie, also three, was the bad seed in a family of five; her twin sister was as good as gold, while Ellie flung her toast on the floor. Nick (four) was hyperactive, zoomed around the house like a dynamo and flicked Vs at the cameras. Child behaviour specialists descended on the three families and tried to calm things down, with a certain amount of success, but one longed for the simpler remedies of Struwwelpeter, which should furnish these children's bedtime reading.

Concealed cameras provided documentary evidence of the miscreants at their worst, but the parents' faces said it all. Drawn and haggard, they watched their little charges with barely contained despair, wondering what they'd done wrong. One could only begin to guess at their misery, although after 50 minutes spent listening to screaming infants it wasn't so very hard to imagine.

The Lipstick Years (BBC2) was an inconsequential trot through the history of the air hostess, presented by Lowri Turner. Feminist trailblazer or flying mattress? The answers were not here, but there were some entertaining reminiscences from former airline employees about life in the aisles. Hostesses from the 40s and 50s had a better class of passenger, including Marlene Dietrich ("a boring lot") and Cary Grant, who helped dry the dishes. Girls in the 60s got mile-high marriage offers and wore paper dresses, which seemed to bring out the arsonist in most men. In the 80s, with cheap air travel, it all became rather grim and sordid, as they dealt with "lager louts" and "air rage" while still being expected to fit into a size 12 uniform.

Just occasionally, one of the interviewees hinted that life in the sky wasn't all that pleasant, or that they actually might have taken advantage of their gentlemen passengers, but for the most they presented a united front of niceness. Michelle Bertinato, once a stewardess, now a pole dancer, said there wasn't much difference between the two jobs. She must have worked first class.

webTitle: Gollies land hospital in race row

fields.headline: Gollies land hospital in race row
fields.trailText: Golliwog dolls have been withdrawn from sale at Bedford hospital following complaints from the local racial equality council.
fields.body:
Golliwog dolls have been withdrawn from sale at Bedford hospital following complaints from the local racial equality council.

The community health council and Bedford Race Equality Council said they were appalled that the dolls were being sold in a shop in the maternity unit run by the Women's Royal Voluntary Service, and had asked that they be withdrawn.

A Unison official, Willy White, also criticised the hospital. He said: "Given the views from ethnic minority communities, we agree it is inappropriate for these items to be on sale."

A hospital spokesman said: "The trust is not involved in decisions on which items to stock. The trust accepts these items can cause offence and sincerely apologises for any distress that this may have caused."

The WRVS refused to comment.

webTitle: The politics junkie with a deep sense of injustice

fields.headline: The politics junkie with a deep sense of injustice
fields.standfirst:
'Destabilising' visionary's private passion boredom threshold

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: For a man whose name keeps popping up in newspapers, Labour's private pollster, Philip Gould, is a surprisingly private person. As readers of his memo writing style now know, for a number cruncher he is also highly emotional.
fields.body:
For a man whose name keeps popping up in newspapers, Labour's private pollster, Philip Gould, is a surprisingly private person. As readers of his memo writing style now know, for a number cruncher he is also highly emotional.

His abiding passion in life has been the election and success of a Labour government which will deliver what he calls "the new progressive politics" of the 21st century - a winning coalition of "aspirational working class and increasingly insecure white collar workers with middle to low-level incomes".

They are the people he grew up among in the south London suburbs of the 1950s and further out in Woking, Surrey, who live "lives of struggle and hard work" - and have not been given the life chances or the public services they deserved in postwar Britain.

That is Gould's vision, set out in his much-praised, much-criticised book The Unfinished Revolution, published as a defence of the modernisers - led by Tony Blair, Gordon Brown, Peter Mandelson, Alastair Campbell (and Gould) - a year after that intoxicating night when they won a 179-seat landslide in 1997.

In the same raw language he deployed in his latest over-candid and leaked memo to Blair's inner circle, Gould's book also reveals his personal credo, what makes him the driven, shambolic talent which friends and foes both recognise.

Teachers nowadays ( but not in the 50s) would recognise in Philip Gould a classic high-achieving dyslexic, the child of teachers, his mother of Dutch origin ("not an English pragmatist, but a continental idealist") who died slowly of a degenerative illness.

As with many Labour politicians and activists, childhood injustice burned deep. In his book Gould quotes his mother's dying words: "Look after your father."

As a successful pollster, married to Gail Rebuck, UK chief of the Random House publishing group (they have two daughters), Gould was able to fulfil his pledge before his father died during the 1992 campaign.

But it was not easy. Born in 1950, he failed the 11-plus, and passed only one O-level (GCSE). After working in a building society he studied again and went to Sussex University, where he met his future wife.

They married in 1985. About this time the young advertising executive met Peter Mandelson and persuaded him to let this politics junkie and Labour supporter galvanise the talents of his own industry to help Neil Kinnock's plans to revive his battered party.

The rest is history, red roses, the Shadow Communications Agency of volunteer Gould allies, the focus groups, and a growing concentration on the middle class and middle ground where elections are won.

Gould shared the blame for the 1992 defeat (he also advised the Sandinistas in Nicaragua's crucial 1990 election: they lost too). He will be blamed this week for being too gabby in print.

John Smith marginalised him and Campbell and Mandelson, but when Tony Blair took over in 1994 they were back - with a vengeance. Gould had taken himself to Arkansas to help and to learn from the Clintonians, who were grateful for his warnings against George Bush Snr's borrowing of the Tory "tax whammy" tactic.

As Labour's manoeuvres on tax and spending have shown since 1994 - culminating in Gordon Brown's £43bn spending review this week - the Blairites do not intend to be caught on tax again. In the present hubbub over leaks it is still William Hague who is on the back foot over the £24m "spending cuts guarantee" Labour says he will have to make in every constituency.

Yet Labour is still vulnerable to the feeling that a government which started out with such promise is now what the latest Gould memo calls "drifting, growing almost monthly weaker and more diffuse".

Nowadays Gould runs a polling firm with Stan Greenberg, Clinton's old pollster. He has influence at the Daily Express, now pro-Labour, where his mate, Lord Hollick, is in charge. "Philip could have devoted his energies to money or sex or cocaine. Instead he chose the Labour party," an admirer once quipped.

As Gould's enemies in Labour's ranks were quick to spot, great chunks of the memo make perfect material for a Private Eye parody. Yet critics on left and right acknowledge shafts of wisdom buried in such language.

But Gould's mood swings and his boredom threshold is low. "Philip should only be let loose on extremely robust politicians, he could be a very destabilising force," a Millbank official once admitted.

fields.headline: The price is right
fields.standfirst: Who will replace David Duchovny in The X-Files?
fields.trailText: Who will replace David Duchovny in The X-Files?
fields.body:
Robert Patrick ..............4-9

Bruce Campbell ............2-1

Hart Bochner ................9-2

Lou Diamond Phillips ....8-1

"Scully and Mulder are the best double act since Morecombe and Wise", says Ed Nicholson, entertainment odds compiler at Ladbrokes. But with Duchovny committed to just 11 more episodes, producers are interviewing for the next Mulder on the upcoming eighth season of The X-Files.

Hart, Robert, Bruce and Lou are all in the running, according to the Hollywood Reporter. Hart Bochner, son of veteran actor Lloyd Bochner, made his TV debut in a Kool-Aid commercial, and has continued in this vein with bit parts in big exposure movies. "Hart Bochner has the looks, but is he believable?" asks Ed. "The thing about Duchovny is you believed he could be doing the job. Bochner has no real identity, having played a plethora of different characters."

Favourite has got to be Robert Patrick (pictured). He reached critical mass in Die Hard 2 and played the liquid metal T-1000 in Terminator 2. He's only really played cameo roles since, but his profile - both acting and facial - is ideal for this role. "He's good looking," says Ed, "but has one of those faces that makes you ask 'Where have I seen him before?' - and that must appeal to the producers as they need to find an actor who is known, but not famous."

Bruce Campbell recently been in the King of Thieves character, Autolycus, in Hercules: The Legendary Journeys and Xena: Warrior Princess. "They say it's not what you know, it's who you know. Bruce Campbell counts influential director Sam Raimi as a friend. He appeared as the bookstore manager in Ellen, and the absolute cruncher is that he's appeared in an episode of The X-Files. He has the contacts."

Big outsider must be Lou Diamond Philips. "Some critics have questioned his basic acting skills, but he's apparently in the running. His most recent film, Supernova, got a slating, but he would certainly become a shooting star if he were to become Mulder."

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Truman Show/The Bad And The Beautiful/Muriel's Wedding/I Know What You Did Last Summer
fields.body:
The Truman Show (pictured)

(Peter Weir, 1998)

12.40pm, 8pm, Sky Premier

For those who find Jim Carrey a little hard to take, this is an eye-opener. His Truman Burbank is played worryingly straight, but is maybe all the better for it. Truman lives in Seahaven, not knowing he's the subject of a round-the-clock TV show, and his friends and family mere actors. But doubts start to form, and he has to fight for his freedom. An inspired idea, and Weir plays it out superbly - a sharp, emotionally stirring satire on the media-mad 90s.

The Bad And The Beautiful

(Vincente Minnelli, 1952)

3pm, TCM

Kirk Douglas plays a charming producer who's forcing his way to the top of trashy Tinseltown. Lana Turner's starlet, Barry Sullivan's director and writer Dick Powell recount in flashback what a dirty rotten scoundrel he is (perfectly equipped for Hollywood, in fact). Packed with movieland references, and with Gloria Grahame in the wings, it's a grand, over-the-top drama.

Muriel's Wedding

(PJ Hogan, 1994)

8pm, FilmFour

Grooving along to Abba songs and sporting a wicked sense of humour, this comes on like another Aussie feelgood comedy, but the laughs are bitter. Muriel (Toni Collette) is fat and spotty and snubbed by her awful mates, until gritty new chum Rachel Griffiths shows her how to hit back. Underneath the laughter, and despite the forced jolly ending, Muriel's deadbeat family and their suburban semi-existence remain irredeemably awful; it's as bleak as Ken Loach.

I Know What You Did Last Summer

(Jim Gillespie, 1997)

12midnight, Sky MovieMax

Cleverly self-referential chiller scripted by Scream veteran Kevin Williamson. A bogeyman is killing off a group of kids, one by one, but in this case they're culpable - in a hit and run, they finished off the badly injured victim who, it seems, has returned to punish them. Jennifer Love Hewitt and Anne Heche are fun.

fields.headline: Scientists challenge Einstein's relativity
fields.trailText: American physicists claim today they "clocked" light travelling at 300 times the speed of light. This is so fast, according to a report published today in science magazine Nature, that a pulse of light appeared to come out of the experiment before it went in.
fields.body:
American physicists claim today they "clocked" light travelling at 300 times the speed of light. This is so fast, according to a report published today in science magazine Nature, that a pulse of light appeared to come out of the experiment before it went in.

This experiment, which appears to challenge the thinking of the last 100 years, makes nonsense of Einstein's principle of relativity and raises the spectre of time travel. It may, however, be an illusion. The physicists claim it does not violate the old rule that cause comes before effect.

The speed of light in a vacuum is about 300 million metres a second. Modern physics is based on the proposition that whether you are rushing away from light, or rushing towards it, that speed will always be the same. No atom could ever actually travel as fast as light. But as matter got near the speed of light, strange things would happen. Time would, for the speeding object, seem to slow down. In theory, at light speed time would stop, and at superluminal speed it would go backwards.

But a team at the NEC research institute at Princeton, led by Lijun Wang, pumped light through a chamber of caesium gas and recorded a case of faster-than-light light. This has been seen before, although not so closely.

Astronomers have measured jets of light around black holes moving faster than light, and decided they were seeing an illusion. Scientists measuring lightning strikes have reported mysterious rings of light that appear to spread faster than the speed of light.

The Princeton physicists measured light waves leaving their cell of gas 62 billionths of a second before they arrived - "in other words, travelling 20 metres away from the cell before the incoming pulse enters it", says Jon Marangos of Imperial College, London. But, he adds, it could still be a trick of the light. "Although amazing, this does not violate the principle of causality."

And the theoretical physicist Paul Davies, writing in the Guardian, warns: "It's too soon to consign the textbooks to the dustbin. As always, the devil is in the detail."

 G3 Science, Light goes backwards in time

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
While the spotlight lingers on one of Robert Maxwell's favourites (the long-term political strategist Alastair Campbell), it is good to see another doing well also. Onetime Maxwell henchwoman Helen Liddell excels as energy minister, apparently recycling one top civil servant already. The early retirement at 56 of Godfrey Bevan, head of renewable energy at the DTI, sparks rumours that he clashed with Helen after she shifted policy away from the commitment to wind farms in favour of fossil fuels. Helen, a great fan of the "market-based approach" says she is not ready to see "consumers pay through the nose" to advance green energy. (Fossil fuel is on fire at the moment: one of the items excised from the doctored transcript of a Clare Bomber Short interview was her championing of its use by developing countries). Mr Bevan, a loyal and popular chap, insists he left because he was offered good terms. It is baffling, however, why the DTI would want to pay heavily to get rid of a popular and successful person... a rather Maxwellian employment tactic for Her Majesty's civil service.

A letter from Joe Haines has appeared in the Times, in which the former Wilson press secretary attacks our beloved Mo Mowlam for suggesting that Labour take back Ken Livingstone. "If her inclusivity leads to Livingstone being welcomed back," writes Joe, "she can include me out." Well, there's a man who knows how to make a threat. I don't suppose getting Joe to resign from the party would be worth more than a few thousand votes at the general election, but if he could be persuaded to take his colleague from the Wilson kitchen cabinet Gerald Kaufman with him, that might swing a number of key marginals.

Today's extract from Book of the Month, Under No Illusion by Paul Daniels (Blake Publishing £16.99), finds the conjuror losing his virginity in Hong Kong where he is doing National Service in 1957. "Lying motionless on the blanket, the naked streetwalker awaited my attentions," he writes. "I... managed to make contact with what felt like a roll of sandpaper. I can distinctly remember thinking that this was not as good as card tricks!" Indeed not.
