webTitle: Britons escape death in Indian air crash

fields.headline: Britons escape death in Indian air crash
fields.standfirst: Glasgow doctor, daughter and son survive with injuries as mother dies
fields.trailText: Relatives in India told yesterday how a British doctor and his two children had a miraculous escape in Monday's airliner crash in Patna.
fields.byline: Luke Harding  in New Delhi  and  Gerard Seenan
fields.body:
Relatives in India told yesterday how a British doctor and his two children had a miraculous escape in Monday's airliner crash in Patna.

Pramod Rajgarhia, 45, an orthopedic surgeon at Glasgow Victoria infirmary, his daughter Prachi, 19, and son Ketan, 13, were thrown clear when their Boeing 737 hit a housing estate a mile away from Patna airport in the northern state of Bihar. The three were last night seriously ill in a Delhi hospital, but expected to recover.

Dr Rajgarhia's wife, Kirin, 44, was not injured in the crash but died apparently of a heart attack. She was among 44 of the 51 passengers and crew on board who died, along with five people on the ground who died when the plane hit a housing estate.

The three surviving members of the family were airlifted to hospital in Delhi, where the daughter, a medical student at Edinburgh University, was yesterday recovering but unaware that her mother was dead.

"She keeps on saying 'I don't know why my mum's not here'," her aunt, Pooja Gupta said.

Surgeons at the Delhi hospital operated on her father yesterday, and were due to operate on the son today.

Dr Rajgarhia was initially conscious after the crash, and he was able to phone relatives from hospital in Patna. "He was telling the doctors what to do with him, because he is an orthopedic surgeon himself," Mrs Gupta said.

Dr Rajgarhia moved to Newton Mearns in Glasgow from India eight years ago, and has been a senior house officer in the orthopedic department at Victoria infirmary since 1994, where he is known as Dr Kumar.

The family had been on the final leg of a month's holiday in India. They only survived because they were sitting at the back of the Alliance Air aircraft that was en route from Calcutta to Delhi, via Patna and Lucknow. A mass of smouldering, twisted metal was all that remained of the jet yesterday.

Telling her relatives of the final moments before the crash, Ms Rajgarhia said she had started praying when she realised something had gone wrong.

"She was saying her gods," Mrs Gupta said. "She said that the flight nosedived and started rattling, and after that she lost consciousness. She got thrown out of the plane with her seat intact.

"A local resident helped her survive. Because she is very fair he thought she was a foreigner. There was an aircrew member burning in the wreckage next to her. He didn't have time to get them both out. He chose Prachi - she was in a better state, she was young, and it was easier for him to carry her."

Mrs Gupta said that it had been destiny that the three survived: "There were also air hostesses at the back of the plane, but they were not saved."

Mrs Rajgarhia had not been injured but died nevertheless, said her nephew, Vrithesh Agarwal: "The most amazing thing is she suffered no external injuries, no burns, no scars. There was not a scratch on her."

Mrs Gupta added: "My sister was very chirpy, very enthusiastic about life. My father is shattered."

Mrs Rajgarhia was cremated at a family ceremony in Patna on Tuesday, before the surviving members of the family were transferred to Delhi by air ambulance. All three were last night in a stable condition in intensive care. Dr Rajgarhia was being treated for spinal injuries and fractures to his ribs after collapsing yesterday.

His daughter also has spinal injuries and may have surgery today. The son, the most seriously injured of the three, is suffering from head injuries, but is expected to recover, doctors said. The family was likely to remain in hospital for several weeks.

Staff at Parkhouse Manor nursing home in Barrhead, Renfrewshire, where Mrs Rajgarhia worked part time as a secretary, yesterday said they were devastated by her death. One, Sharda Poddar, said: "I have lost my best friend, but I am praying that her family will survive."

A neighbour in Glasgow said the community was shocked by what had happened. "It is amazing that the three of them made it out alive. Kirin was a very energetic, very pleasant and well organised woman," said Carol Meldrum, who had been looking after the family's home while they were away in India.

Ketan was just about to enter his third year at Eastwood high school on the outskirts of Glasgow, where his sister had also been a pupil. "Both are very bright, and popular with staff and pupils," said the headteacher, Bob Gibson. "We will offer all the support the school can at this difficult time."

A spokesman for Edinburgh University, where Prachi has finished her first year as a medical student, said the university was relieved she had survived but expressed condolences for her mother's loss.

The Rajgarhias only boarded the 6.50am flight CD-7412 after deciding to cut short their stay in Calcutta, where Mrs Rajgarhia's parents live.

They had planned to spend a couple of days in Patna, visiting Dr Rajgarhia's father and mother, before returning to Delhi for a family reunion. They had been due to fly back to the UK on July 30. "They tried to come to India once a year. They were last here in December," Mrs Gupta said.

Investigators were yesterday beginning an official inquiry into why the 20-year-old Boeing 737 had crashed - it was reported to have spent the three days before the doomed flight grounded because of technical problems. As the first step in a possible criminal case, the two pilots who died in the crash were charged with violating criminal and aviation law, although a trial against the dead is unlikely.

A fortnight ago, British diplomats were told by the Foreign Office not to use Alliance Air, a subsidiary of Indian Airlines, after Rolls Royce withdrew a service contract for its engines on safety grounds.

webTitle: DNA hampers effort to clear Hanratty

fields.headline: DNA hampers effort to clear Hanratty
fields.trailText: Campaigners working to exonerate James Hanratty, one of the last men in Britain to hang, for the so-called A6 murder 38 years ago, were stung yesterday by fresh DNA tests which appeared to show he was at the scene of the crime after all.
fields.body:
Campaigners working to exonerate James Hanratty, one of the last men in Britain to hang, for the so-called A6 murder 38 years ago, were stung yesterday by fresh DNA tests which appeared to show he was at the scene of the crime after all.

With an appeal against his conviction due to be heard in December, the crown prosecution service asked specialists at the Metropolitan police to examine fluid samples in a handkerchief thought to have been used by the killer.

Previous DNA tests had been inconclusive, but scientists have now reported a strong match between DNA found in the material and a sample provided by Hanratty's brother, Michael. The findings were sent to Mr Hanratty's lawyer, Geoffrey Bindman, this week.

Tamsin Allen, another lawyer for the family, dismissed the results. "This is a very, very complex area and it would be a gross exaggeration to say these tests have proved anything conclusively. A match was found on previous tests, so that is not new. This is a re-run of an old test which has come up with the same result but with a different probability."

The reliability of DNA testing in the Hanratty case has long been an issue because of claims that the handkerchief was "contaminated" through poor storage and careless use.

Hanratty was hanged after a gunman ambushed a couple in their Morris Minor in Buckinghamshire and forced them at gunpoint to drive up the A6 to a Bedfordshire lay-by. He killed Michael Gregsten and raped Gregsten's companion, Valerie Storie, leaving her for dead. She gave crucial evidence against him at the trial.

Hanratty was convicted at Bedford assizes on February 17, 1962. Despite a petition signed by 28,000, he was hanged at Bedford prison, aged 26. A campaign to clear his name has continued ever since.

Last year, the criminal cases review commission announced it was referring the case to the court of appeal because of the suppression of information by the police, a lack of disclosure of information to the defence, and flawed identification.

Hanratty's brother, Michael, said yesterday: "We have such strong evidence to clear my brother's name, and I believe these tests are flawed."

webTitle: Liver cells grown from bone marrow signal end of need for transplants

fields.headline: Liver cells grown from bone marrow signal end of need for transplants
fields.trailText: British scientists today announced they had grown liver cells from blood, following research which could offer hope to those waiting for liver transplants and open the door to gene-based treatment.
fields.body:
British scientists today announced they had grown liver cells from blood, following research which could offer hope to those waiting for liver transplants and open the door to gene-based treatment.

"We may be able to stimulate liver regeneration using cells from the patient's own bone marrow," said Nick Wright of the Imperial Cancer Research Fund's histopathology unit at Hammersmith. "This would be particularly useful for patients whose livers have been damaged due to drug side effects, or through surgery to remove cancers that have spread to the liver, and where there is insufficient functioning liver remaining."

Humans start as one fertilised cell, and end up as 100 million million cells. As skin, blood and bone cells die they are replaced, in a process dependent upon the stem cells.

Until recently, researchers believed this was a one way process; a skin stem cell could only make skin, and the stem cells found in bone marrow could only make blood cells. But Dolly the cloned sheep, a lamb grown in 1997 from a mammary cell saved from a dead sheep, changed scientific thinking - it seemed to suggest the clock of life could be turned back after all.

Two years ago, scientists in the US developed human embryo stem cells which they thought could be used to make almost any part of a human body. But the use of embryos is strictly controlled and the UK government has yet to give a go-ahead for such research.

A team from Hammersmith hospital, the Royal Free hospital, and Imperial College's school of medicine, reports in the journal Nature today that bone marrow stem cells are capable of turning into liver cells and repopulating a damaged organ.

Richard Poulson, one of the researchers, analysed liver cells from women patients who had received a bone marrow transplant from a male donor, and then looked at liver cells from males who had had livers from female donors. He found male liver cells in the livers of female patients, and this could only have come about from the male to female bone marrow transplant.

Researchers had seen such things happen in laboratory dishes. This, however, was the first time it had been spotted in living humans.

The discovery opens the way to a new kind of alchemy. Instead of a philosopher's stone that turns base metal into gold, there might be techniques that could reliably turn one kind of tissue into another. Most organ transplants rely on a donor's death, and there are too many patients and too few donors. The Hammersmith research suggests that faulty livers might one day be repaired with bone marrow stem cells.

"Ultimately it may be possible to regenerate a new liver using the patient's own stem cells. We would avoid the problems with liver transplants where the body rejects the foreign organ," said Prof Wright.

There are about 5,000 people in the UK awaiting organ transplants.

fields.headline: No: 1681
fields.standfirst: Thunderbirds
fields.trailText: Thunderbirds
fields.body:
Help! Help! I'm the victim of a nefarious scheme orchestrated by that megalomaniac arch-fiend The Hood! Sounds like you need the help of a top-secret International Rescue team, ready to strike from behind the facade of a luxurious life on a remote Pacific island.

How can they help? Whenever there's a crisis, anywhere in the world, they unleash their fancy rockets.

It's Tony Blair! No. It's that 60s sci-fi show, remember? Tracy Island? FAB? Puppets?

They were puppets? They looked so real. That'll be Supermarionation.

Isn't that a song in Mary Poppins? No, it's the technique Thunderbirds creator Gerry Anderson pioneered to synchronise dialogue with the movement of his marionettes.

How's it work? It involves the use of special metal control strings in combination with an electrically activated solenoid which moves the lips.

Has anyone told Alastair Campbell? How dare you. International Rescue operates according to the loftiest principles of freedom and justice.

Sounds very American. Crack rescuers Scott, John, Virgil, Gordon and Alan Tracy are named after five pioneering US astronauts.

Were they all called Tracy too? D'oh!

Isn't it old hat? Never. The series has been digitally remastered and returns to British screens this autumn.

And the movie? A film is said to be in development, with Kristin Scott-Thomas as the bit of posh-turned-secret agent, Lady Penelope.

There must be money in it. According to a Christie's toy specialist, "The rarest Thunderbirds set 'mint and boxed, with fluorescent pink Rover' may go for £450."

How much will you give me for a Joe 90 lollipop? Is it mint?

No, it's strawberry! Boom, boom.

Most likely to say: "Thunderbirds are go!"

Least likely to sing: "I've got no strings to hold me down/To make me fret, or make me frown."

Not to be confused with: Thunderball, the Liver Birds, the Parliamentary Labour party.

webTitle: Letters: Readers not happy with yesterday's front page

fields.headline: Comprehensive spending reviewed
fields.trailText: Your front-page headline calls Gordon Brown's spending review plans a "spree" (Brown's £43bn spree, July 19). My dictionary defines spree as: "A session of considerable over-indulgence, esp in drinking, squandering money, etc." Your leader announces, on the same day, that: "This package is necessary and affordable."
fields.body:
Your front-page headline calls Gordon Brown's spending review plans a "spree" (Brown's £43bn spree, July 19). My dictionary defines spree as: "A session of considerable over-indulgence, esp in drinking, squandering money, etc." Your leader announces, on the same day, that: "This package is necessary and affordable."

Not a spree then.
John Butt
Exeter, Devon
Johngbutt@btinternet.com

 The extra money promised by the chancellor for science and universities for the period 2002 to 2005 is welcome. Older, well established members of the scientific community as well as PhD students, whose stipends will rise, will be grateful. But there is nothing in the spending plans (which do almost nothing for the immediate problems) to encourage first-class teachers and researchers who are just beginning their academic careers, after probably six years of financial struggle, to stay in the UK. Why should they when they can work in the US for twice the salary, and where the research infrastructure is already developed to a level the Treasury aspire to after 10 years?

Without extra money to pay university teachers and researchers at the levels recommended by the independent Bett report, which echoed the earlier official Dearing report, the new money will not be used in the most effective way because the best people will be gone.
Prof Michael Rennie
University of Dundee m.j.rennie@dundee.ac.uk

 The decision by David Blunkett to award extra money to schools which have done well in assessment procedures and to deny such extra resources to failing schools is clear proof of how far New Labour has moved from its old Labour origins. Success in education is largely down to resources: good teachers, parental support, adequate books, computer facilities and modern premises. By and large these occur where incomes are above the national average. To those that have shall be given and those that don't have will have to make do. Is this the best New Labour can offer failing schools?
John Turley
Wrexham

My dictionary defines spree as: "A session of considerable over-indulgence, esp in drinking, squandering money, etc." Your leader announces, on the same day, that: "This package is necessary and affordable." Not a spree then. John Butt Exeter, Devon Johngbutt@btinternet.com  The extra money promised by the chancellor for science and universities for the period 2002 to 2005 is welcome. Older, well established members of the scientific community as well as PhD students, whose stipends will rise, will be grateful. fields.headline: Spitting out McDonald's
fields.trailText: Gary Younge's article on the service McDonald's renders to the availability of cheap food to poor people raised some issues that deserve to be aired (Comment, July 17).
fields.body:
Gary Younge's article on the service McDonald's renders to the availability of cheap food to poor people raised some issues that deserve to be aired (Comment, July 17).

Having just spent five years in India, I was struck by the incongruity of a queue of young bejeaned Indians waiting for a McMeal the price of which was 10 times more expensive than the "snakes" (snacks) available on every street.

The status acquired by the diners at McDonalds was palpable. I fear it will spread and absorb the cheaper option.
Paul Carling Oban, Argyll

 Gary Younge never once mentions what is central to the whole enterprise: meat. His attempt to be radical and egalitarian - McDonald's sells cheap meals to the poor - is rather undercut by what he ignores, namely that it is a lynchpin in a system which subsidises those meals at the cost of the still more helpless, namely fellow (non-human) animals. So much for anti-elitism.
Dr Patrick Curry
London pmcurry@gn.apc.org

 So McDonald's employs more people than the steel industry? Then again Big Mac employees aren't paid as much as steelworkers. McDonald's may have redundant steelworkers on its payroll. Apparently they come quite cheap these days.
D Swingewood
London
delwynswingewood.mediaphile@btinternet.com

webTitle: Opera House head leaves sooner than expected

fields.headline: Opera House head leaves sooner than expected
fields.trailText: The Royal Opera House was dealt another blow last night when Michael Kaiser, the American drafted in save to it less than two years ago, revealed that he will be leaving in five months' time, much sooner than expected.
fields.body:
The Royal Opera House was dealt another blow last night when Michael Kaiser, the American drafted in save to it less than two years ago, revealed that he will be leaving in five months' time, much sooner than expected.

With the ROH itself acknowledging that it may not be able to find a replacement in time, the prospect of a destabilising interregnum, and a stop-gap appointment with many of the rebuilt technical "teething problems" still unresolved, is now looming.

The news comes as the house parted company with its marketing guru, Richard Shaw, who was brought in by Kaiser to shake-up its notoriously rickety operation.

The double blow was seen last night by it critics as a sign the "bad old ways" were returning and that the Opera House's "old guard" were again winning.

Kaiser indicated last month that he would leave to return to America, but he said he would not be going until at least the spring of 2001. Last night, however, he confirmed that he was leaving in January to run the Kennedy Center for Performing Arts in Washington. Kaiser is now seen as the natural successor to the legendary Joe Volpe at the New York Met - the biggest job in world opera. The move to Washington puts him in pole position.

The quiet-spoken American denied that he was being forced out. 'There has been no fight, no rift," he said. But there have been persistent rumours of clashes with his ebullient chairman, Sir Colin Southgate, who once said he did not want to let in people in "smelly trainers".

Raymond Gubbay, the classical music impresario and a critic of the Covent Garden regime, said morale at the house was low and the situation was "getting messier by the day". He added: "Having less than six months to find a replacement of the calibre of Michael Kaiser is not a happy situation. It is far from ideal, and there has to be doubts about whether they will find anyone in that time.

"Whatever he says, Kaiser can not have been happy to have gone so soon. Old habits die hard and a lot of the highfalutin board I'm afraid leave their brains at the stage door when they go to board meetings. He should have been given a proper chance to do the job instead of being undermined."

Sir Colin, however, was keen to play up Kaiser's achievements in clearing Covent Garden's debts and steering the opera and ballet companies through two of the most difficult years in their history.

He said a sub-committee of the board, including the philantropist Vivien Duffield, had been set up find his successor. "We obviously hope to make an appointment prior to Michael's departure, however, if it becomes necessary to appoint an interim manager while our favoured candidate becomes available the board will review this option during the autumn.

"Contrary to speculation in the press I have no ambitions to become the executive director of the Royal Opera House."

A number of possible candidates for the job have already made it known they might be interested. Chief among them is Sarah Billinghurst, the artistic manager at the New York Met.

One obvious contender, John Tusa, the former BBC World Service chief now running the Barbican, is thought to be reluctant to take the mantle.

fields.headline: Belgrano relatives lose court claim
fields.trailText: Relatives of Argentine sailors who were killed when the battleship General Belgrano was sunk by a British submarine during the Falklands war had their hopes of winning compensation from Britain dashed yesterday.
fields.body:
Relatives of Argentine sailors who were killed when the battleship General Belgrano was sunk by a British submarine during the Falklands war had their hopes of winning compensation from Britain dashed yesterday.

The European court of human rights in Strasbourg rejected their claims as inadmissible because they were filed long past the legal time limit.

Luisa Diamantina Romero de Ibanez, the mother of one conscript who lost his life, and Roberto Guillermo Rojas, the father of another, accused the British government of violating their sons' right to life, guaranteed by the European convention on human rights.

The convention states that applications must be made to Strasbourg within six months after any remedies available in the domestic courts have been exhausted. Since there were no proceedings in the British courts, the six months ran from the date of the incident, 2 May 1982, when the Belgrano was torpedoed by the British nuclear submarine Conqueror and 323 of the 1093 crew killed.

A committee of three judges dismissed the argument by the families' lawyers that the six months should run from March 2000, when proceedings in the Argentine courts to have the former prime minister Margaret Thatcher extradited for war crimes ended unsuccessfully. The judges held that the domestic courts in this case were the courts of Britain.

The Belgrano was sunk when it was outside the 200-mile total exclusion zone that Britain had declared around the Falkland Islands after an Argentine force seized the colony.

Lady Thatcher has always defended the action, rejecting claims that the Belgrano was heading away from the exclusion zone.

The families maintain that the Argentine cruiser was on course for the Isla de los Estados, never entered the exclusion zone and was not operating in the war "theatre".

Yesterday's ruling will not affect the claim pending at the Strasbourg court against Britain and other Nato countries over the Nato bombing of the Radio Television of Serbia building in October 1999 because that claim was filed last April, within six months of the incident.

webTitle: Killer must not strike again, say Paynes as they mourn Sarah

fields.headline: Killer must not strike again, say Paynes as they mourn Sarah
fields.standfirst:
Parents appeal for witnesses and express anguish over not saying goodbye to their murdered daughter
More about the Sarah Payne case
fields.trailText: The parents of Sarah Payne yesterday described their anguish at being denied the chance to say goodbye to their beloved daughter. Sara and Michael Payne said they had decided not to see the body of the murdered eight-year-old because it was "too hard" and because "it's not Sarah".
fields.body:
The parents of Sarah Payne yesterday described their anguish at being denied the chance to say goodbye to their beloved daughter. Sara and Michael Payne said they had decided not to see the body of the murdered eight-year-old because it was "too hard" and because "it's not Sarah".

Speaking in public for the first time since the girl's body was discovered on Monday, the parents added their voices to the police appeal for more information concerning Sarah's disappearance, saying that the killer should not be allowed to strike again.

They also made a second visit to the spot where Sarah was found, near the A29 between Pulborough and Billingshurst, in West Sussex, this time taking their other three children with them.

At the start of an emotional press conference at Littlehampton police station, where during the search for Sarah the family had appealed for help, Mrs Payne clutched the hand of her father-in-law, Terry, for comfort. Later she held the hand of her husband, too. All three were close to tears.

Mrs Payne began by thanking well-wishers for their support then said: "Thank God we've found her."

Sarah went missing from a country lane near her grandparents' home in Kingston Gorse, West Sussex, on the evening of July 1. Her body was discovered, after a nationwide search, hidden in a field 12 miles from where she was last seen alive.

At first during yesterday's press conference the couple finished off each other's sentences. Mrs Payne started off: "The family is..." and her husband continued "...devastated - we can't believe it".

Mrs Payne said that the news had still not sunk in, a theme picked up by Mr Payne later when he said: "We're still waiting for the police to come and say they've found her even though she's been found dead."

Police officers have been impressed throughout by the couple's determination to do all they can to help the investigation. Mrs Payne said: "We've got a job to do. There's still a need for information."

She focused attention on a white Transit-type van spotted by one of Sarah's brothers on the day their sister was abducted. Police are still keen to hear of sightings of the van in the area where Sarah vanished and where she was found.

Mrs Payne said: "On Saturday night and Sunday morning if you saw something - a car, a van, whatever made you suspicious, made you look twice, then think about it and ring us up."

The family also spoke of their feelings towards the killer. Mrs Payne said: "They must never ever be allowed to put another family through this. They've watched us for the last two weeks. It has torn our children apart. They could have done something about it by picking up the phone.

"We don't believe that anyone should be allowed to do that to anyone. We believe in justice and death is too good for this person. Help us find him, her, them, whoever."

Addressing the killer directly, she continued: "To watch us go through this, I feel no pity for you at all."

Her husband added: "They have watched us suffer. They have watched our family go through something [we] should not go through. The whole thing is just senseless. To take a little girl like that, for what reason would you do this to someone? Whoever it is has got to be caught."

Speaking of the decision not to see Sarah's body, Mrs Payne said: "We can't even see our daughter because it's too hard. It's not Sarah. We haven't been able to say goodbye - it's so unfair."

The family has been staying away from their home and are still torn about returning. Mrs Payne said: "We will be going home, so will Sarah."

The family made another appeal for further witnesses to contact the police. "If you haven't come forward yet please come forward. We have all been in this together right from the start," said Mrs Payne. Her husband added: "It's not over until the man or the persons are in court."

Detective Superintendent Alan Ladley, who has been leading the inquiry, said the response to the appeals for help so far had been "tremendous". There have been more than 28,000 calls since the beginning of the inquiry. About 80 officers are now on the inquiry team with the same number continuing to search for clues and look for the clothing Sarah was wearing when she disappeared.

Det Sup Ladley revealed that the postmortem had not uncovered any violent external injuries. It was possible she had been strangled or suffocated by other means. The police have said they cannot be certain the dead child, who was discovered naked, had not been first sexually assaulted. He said: "Why else would a little girl be taken? That has to be a possibility."

Mr Ladley also referred to an incident on Tuesday night when 20 or 30 youths gathered outside a house in Crawley which they thought held a man who had been questioned then released by police earlier in the inquiry. The youths hurled abuse and threw stones at the building.

Mr Ladley insisted that "vigilante attacks" would not be tolerated by the police.

fields.headline: UK news in brief
fields.trailText: Fuel switch for police fleet
fields.body:
Fuel switch for police fleet

Gloucestershire police force is hoping to replace nearly one-third of its 320-car fleet with vehicles powered by liquid petroleum gas, which can save up to 53% on fuel costs and cut toxic carbon monoxide emissions by up to 70%.

Father held over girl's death

Police were yesterday questioning a man about the death of his 12-year-old daughter. Phillip Andrew Hall was arrested after Emma Hall died from a single stab wound to her chest at their home in Whitelye, near Tintern, Monmouthshire. Police said Emma's mother, brother and grandparents were in the house when police were alerted late on Tuesday night.

'Audition' rapist gets nine years

A bogus film producer who called out "scene one, scene two" as he repeatedly raped a 22-year-old ballerina on his casting couch, was branded "manipulative, predatory and deceitful" as he was jailed for nine years at Snaresbrook crown court in east London yesterday. Mabrouk Melliti, 36, of Piccadilly, London, had staged fake auditions in hired offices.

Hygiene fears for food outlets

Almost half of all food outlets inspected in Britain last year failed to meet hygiene standards, it was revealed yesterday. The food standards agency said most breaches detected were relatively minor, but the number of infringements was not acceptable.

Book returned 30 years late

A battered copy of A Manual of Graphology has been returned to Chelmsford library in Essex from France 30 years after it was borrowed, together with a written note of apology from a French woman who stayed in the town in 1970.

£463,000 for Moore prints

More than 550 rare prints by Henry Moore - well over two-thirds of the total number produced by one of the 20th century's most powerful and original sculptors - were sold for £463,000 at Christie's in London yesterday.

Frozen burgers 'short on meat'

Most frozen burgers are fatty, over-salted products, pumped up with non-meat fillers, water and flavour-boosting ingredients, the food commission said yesterday. The survey of 40 popular beefburgers and grillsteaks found two-thirds contained less than 90% pure meat, and some as little as 60% meat.

Editor named

Mark Douglas Home, 48, Scottish editor of the Sunday Times, is to be the new editor of the Glasgow-based Herald.

fields.headline: Mobile radiation warnings on way
fields.trailText: Mobile phone manufacturers have responded to a public safety inquiry by announcing they are to issue advice regarding the radiation levels consumers can expect to absorb from their handsets.
fields.body:
Mobile phone manufacturers have responded to a public safety inquiry by announcing they are to issue advice regarding the radiation levels consumers can expect to absorb from their handsets.

The Stewart inquiry in the UK published the findings of its year-long investigation in May, concluding there was no evidence of danger from mobile phone radiation but that a "precautionary approach" was recommended.

Nokia, Ericsson and Motorola yesterday confirmed they are working together on warnings to be printed on packaging, about the radiation levels mobile telephones emit.

It is considered to be a move which may protect manufacturers from future litigation, even though there is no link yet proved between mobile phone usage and cancer or other risks to human health.

David Stoneham, Nokia UK's senior communications manager, said he expected labels detailing the specific absorption rate (SAR), a measure of radiation from mobile phone usage, would appear by the end of the year.

He said a final wording had been delayed following disagreements between the phone manufacturers, operators and governments on a standard measure of SAR.

The next hurdle was consensus on how SAR could be explained simply to consumers. "There has been dialogue since May on that," Mr Stoneham said.

"We don't see why information on SAR values couldn't be given to consumers this year."

Phone radiation levels are at present disclosed to various bodies including the US federal communications commission in order to comply with national safety requirements.

In the US, the American trade body, the Cellular Telecommunications Industry Association, has recommended that all mobile phone manufacturers should disclose their radiation levels by August 1.

Jan Ahrenbring, vice-president of marketing and communication at Ericsson Mobile, said from that date it would provide information on its handset in the US, and globally "shortly afterwards". While the Stewart report concluded there was no scientific evidence suggesting that mobile handsets or base stations gave out harmful levels of radiation, it still recommended introducing tough controls.

CTIA president Tom Wheeler said: "After a substantial amount of research, scientists and governments around the world continue to reaffirm that there is no public health threat from the use of wireless phones." Motorola was unavailable for comment.

While the Stewart report concluded there was no scientific evidence suggesting that mobile handsets or base stations gave out harmful levels of radiation, it still recommended introducing tough controls. CTIA president Tom Wheeler said: "After a substantial amount of research, scientists and governments around the world continue to reaffirm that there is no public health threat from the use of wireless phones." Motorola was unavailable for comment.

webTitle: Didata prepares to join the top 100

fields.headline: Didata prepares to join the top 100
fields.trailText: South African IT services company Dimension Data moved a significant step closer to claiming a place in the FTSE 100 yesterday when its shares enjoyed a solid first day's trading in London.
fields.body:
South African IT services company Dimension Data moved a significant step closer to claiming a place in the FTSE 100 yesterday when its shares enjoyed a solid first day's trading in London.

Didata, as the Johannesburg-listed and based firm is known, priced its global offer at 520p a share. The stock climbed immediately, touching a peak of 565p during the day before closing at 563p.

At that price, Didata is valued at £6.4bn and is a leading candidate to make the FTSE 100 at the next quarterly review in September.

Malcolm Rutherford, the firm's finance director, said he was delighted by the response to the offering.

"We have raised £800m, as we said we would, were four times subscribed and have attracted a very pleasing spread of blue-chip institutions in London and the United States," he said.

The company intends to complete the process of buying in the remaining equity in a network integration firm, Chernikeeff Networks, based at Sunbury-on-Thames, and GK Communications of Warrington.

It will also take full control of Comtech in Australia as part of a $500m (£335m) investment plan.

The remaining funds are likely to finance the acquisition of e-commerce businesses in the US, Spain, Italy and Scandinavia, and to support organic growth.

fields.headline: US rival eyes Oxford Molecular
fields.trailText: Oxford Molecular, the struggling supplier of software to the drugs industry, looks set to be snapped up by an American rival, Pharmacopeia.
fields.body:
Oxford Molecular, the struggling supplier of software to the drugs industry, looks set to be snapped up by an American rival, Pharmacopeia.

Industry sources say the two companies are in talks, with a deal possible within weeks.

A takeover would put an end to a troubled time on the stock market for Oxford Molecular, which has seen its shares collapse by 90% over the past four years. The group is valued at £26m.

Oxford Molecular has struggled because the take-up of advanced software to screen chemical compounds has been slower than expected in the drugs industry.

Analysts say the group is likely to be a big loser in the imminent merger between Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham because Glaxo is a big client but its software systems look set to be engulfed by SmithKline's.

Pharmacopeia, which is based in New Jersey, specialises in simulation software for drugs companies testing new drugs.

A Pharmacopeia spokeswoman declined to say whether the company was in discussions with Oxford Molecular. However, she said: "We know Oxford Molecular very well and we know that they are looking to sell themselves. We have spoken to them in the past."

Earlier this month, Oxford Molecular sold its Cambridge Discovery Chemistry subsidiary to a US firm, Millennium Pharmaceuticals, for £35m. In another upheaval for the group, Oxford Molecular's chief executive, Tony Marchington, has given two years' notice of his intention to resign.

 Oxford Asymmetry, which provides contract research to the drugs industry, yesterday said it was in bid talks. Its shares leapt 55.5p to 587.5p, valuing the business at £242m.

Analysts named the drugs groups Quintiles and Elan as possible bidders, as well as the US chemicals firm Eastman.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
EU queries bids for MoD ferries
The European Commission is querying whether bidding for six roll-on-roll-off ferries by Britain's Ministry of Defence is in line with EU public procurement directives, a commission source said.
fields.body:
EU queries bids for MoD ferries
The European Commission is querying whether bidding for six roll-on-roll-off ferries by Britain's Ministry of Defence is in line with EU public procurement directives, a commission source said.

Industry sources said there are four bidders - AP Moeller's British unit Maersk Co; the BAe Systems-led Sealion consortium; a consortium including Britain's Andrew Weir Shipping; and Belgium's Cobelfret.

The commission source said it is looking at an MoD request for the four to make restructured bids and wants to make sure this change is to ensure value for money and not to support a British shipyard.

Yorkshire plan doused by EA

The Environment Agency yesterday doused plans by Kelda to turn Yorkshire Water into a mutual. The EA said Kelda's proposals to demerge Yorkshire Water's assets were primarily concerned with creating shareholder value. "There is less emphasis on the interests of customers and nothing in the proposals on environmental issues." Its chairman, Sir John Harman, said: "The public needs to be confident that if Kelda - and potentially other water companies - go down the mutualisation route, this will not lead to any deterioration in environmental standards."

Share option rules to change
Accounting rules over share option schemes are to be tightened up under new proposals by the Accounting Standards Board that would force companies to put a value on the share options they issue to hire employees.

The proposed move, which is likely to put the accounting board at loggerheads with start-up internet companies and other entrepreneurial business, would mean that options issued by a company would have to be recognised on its profit and loss account. Under present rules no such requirement is necessary, which means that the cost of hiring employees is not made clear.

Investment banker leaves
Jim Boshart, one of the City's best known investment bankers, is to leave the newly created Schroder Salomon Smith Barney. In a memo to staff, also signed by co-chief executive Will Samuel, he told employees that the second half would be tougher than the first when mergers and acquisitions business boomed.

Under management changes yesterday, the bank, which is part of Citigroup of US, also gave greater emphasis to London by naming London-based Michael Klein as co-head of global investment banking.

Ford posts $577m loss
Ford, the world's second largest car maker, yesterday reported a second-quarter net loss of $577m (£356m) after $3.3bn of one-off charges related to restructuring of its European operations and the demerger of its Visteon components business.

It was the first time Ford has dipped into the red since 1992. At the operating level, profits for the quarter rose 10% to a record $2.7bn, with worldwide vehicle sales rising to a record 1,928,000 units.

webTitle: One-way bet IG Group rises 17% on debut

fields.headline: One-way bet IG Group rises 17% on debut
fields.trailText: Punters who had a flutter on spread-betting specialist IG Index were counting their first day winnings yesterday when the stock surged to a 17% premium.
fields.body:
Punters who had a flutter on spread-betting specialist IG Index were counting their first day winnings yesterday when the stock surged to a 17% premium.

Shares in IG Group climbed from their placement price of 240p to close at 280p, valuing the company at almost £145m. The float has raised around £1.15m to fund future growth.

IG Index, set up in 1974, has been at the forefront of the spread-betting revolution which has enabled gamblers to make bets of greater risk and potential reward than traditional fixed-odds betting.

It is particularly popular with City dealers looking to test their skill of reading markets by placing bets on things like possible share price and interest rate movements, as well as top sports events. A growth in betting volume helped IG's pre-tax profits in the year to May 31 climb almost three times to £10m.

Several other firms including City Index and Financial Spreads have been set up to meet the growing demand for spread-bets.

IG's 65-year-old founder and chairman, Stuart Wheeler, has made around £5m from the float but has committed not to sell any shares for three years.

During the coming years Mr Wheeler hopes to leverage IG's growing popularity on the web into new areas like interactive television. Analysts say the ability to place real-time spread bets on sports events from the comfort of your living room is hugely attractive to gamblers with large disposable incomes.

webTitle: Open up or we sue, rivals tell BT

fields.headline: Open up or we sue, rivals tell BT
fields.trailText: BT yesterday faced the prospect of a court battle with rivals frustrated at the failure of the company to allow them access to its local network.
fields.body:
BT yesterday faced the prospect of a court battle with rivals frustrated at the failure of the company to allow them access to its local network.

Colt, Energis and Easynet yesterday said they would consider taking legal action against BT if it failed to agree with a European commission ruling that it unbundle the local loop by the end of the year.

The EC said last week it was not impossible for BT to meet the deadline.

The regulator has issued a binding agreement on all EU member states to meet the ruling by the end of 2000.

However, the UK telecommunications watchdog Oftel set the deadline for the unbundling of BT lines by July 2001.

BT's rivals said they would prefer a group industry action against BT.

Mike Grabiner, chief executive of Energis, said: "I would look seriously at joining such an action. More significant than the timescale is that BT has a significant advantage because it is able to offer DSL [digital subscriber line] services while it is not obliged to provide any wholesale interconnect."

John Docherty, director at Colt Telecommunications, said his company would be able to offer DSL services in the Netherlands and Germany by December. He could not "understand what was taking the UK so long".

"Our interpretation of what the EU has said is that unbundled [access] should be available at the end of this year. Clearly, it [legal action] is an option we would consider," said Mr Docherty.

James Tyler, a spokesman for Level 3, which has an internet protocol network across the US, Asia and Europe, asked about possible legal action against BT, said: "We would welcome anything that increased competition."

Easynet managing director David Rowe said the EU directive had given his company legal grounds to pursue BT if it was obstructing the unbundling of the local loop.

Unbundling would allow other telecom companies to install their own equipment, in or near BT's exchanges, to provide DSL that would deliver such services as fast internet access.

Analysts said the delay to unbundling had given BT a first mover advantage.

However, Oftel has maintained that the UK is "well on schedule" to meet the December 2000 deadline, even if unbundled services would not be widely available. BT is already conducting trials of its DSL services with some other operators.

Sir Iain Vallance, chairman of BT, has maintained that "July 2001 is the earliest feasible target date for opening up BT's local loops for the use of other service providers".

He has pointed out that a single unbundled local loop does not exist in France, Spain and Italy.

If BT sticks to its timetable of July 2000 it may be open to legal action from the European Commission itself.

The European Competitive Telecommunications Association has called for monitoring systems to be put in place to ensure EU member states reach the deadline of unbundling local loop networks before the end opf the year.

"In the next few months we would like to see governments divulge their plans for unbundling as well as the progress made so far," said Phil Evans, managing director of ECTA.

fields.headline: Paddington rail bid 'too low'
fields.standfirst:
Directors spurn £42m French offer for stakes in disaster train operator

Special report: Paddington train crash
fields.trailText: Two directors of a train company at the centre of the Paddington rail disaster who were offered £42m to sell their stakes as part of a takeover bid say it is not enough money.
fields.body:
Two directors of a train company at the centre of the Paddington rail disaster who were offered £42m to sell their stakes as part of a takeover bid say it is not enough money.

Martin Ballinger, the managing director, and Chris Moyes, the commercial director, rejected a £327m French approach for their Go-Ahead group, the operator of Thames Trains which provides key London commuter services.

But shares in the company jumped 20% and ended the day up 110p at 660p as the market anticipated that a higher cash offer would be forthcoming from Caisse des Depots-Developpement (C3D) and Rhone Capital or a rival bidder.

It is the latest upheaval in a volatile transport sector. The French offer came a day after another train operator, Prism Rail, was bought by National Express in an agreed £166m takeover.

C3D controls Transdev, which operates buses and light railways in France and Britain, while Rhone is a venture capital group with offices in Paris and New York.

Mr Ballinger said last night that the approach had been turned away because it was "unwelcome and wholly inadequate". A range of interesting opportunities "in particular in rail and airport services" led to the rejection after consultation with Go-Ahead's financial advisers, Close Brothers and Dresdner Kleinwort Benson.

But Go-Ahead has been through tough times. Its value has halved on the stock market since last October when the 8.05am Thames service from Paddington to Bedwyn, Wiltshire, went through a red light near Ladbroke Grove and collided with a Great Western locomotive with the loss of 31 lives.

Thames Trains was criticised for not making any public statement after the crash. The company has been pushing ahead with attempts to win further franchises, including those now operated by Chiltern Trains and Connex South Central.

Mr Ballinger recently renegotiated contracts to operate buses in London on less favourable terms.

Mr Ballinger, 56, was involved in a management buyout of Go-Ahead, then purely a bus company, in 1987. It took over Thames Trains and Thameslink rail services on privatisation.

Mr Ballinger holds a 7.3% stake in Go-Ahead which would be worth £23.4m at the 650p price put forward in exploratory talks by the French finance groups.

Mr Moyes has a 5.76% holding worth £18.6m. He joined Go-Ahead in 1987 from National Bus Company where Mr Ballinger had cut his teeth.

If a deal was hatched there could be further payments as the executives have two-year contracts and annual salaries of £175,000 and £164,000 respectively.

As well as its rail and bus interests, Go-Ahead last year bought an airport ground handling operation.

Yesterday the French said they were considering their options after the negative response from Go-Ahead. In a formal statement they said: "There can be no guarantee that an offer will be made."

C3D already holds 300,000 Go-Ahead ordinary shares representing 0.6% of the issued capital. It is a subsidiary of Caisse des Depots et Consignations - a French savings trust.

webTitle: Advertisers call ITV bosses to order

fields.headline: Advertisers call ITV bosses to order
fields.standfirst: Network faces criticism over ratings and autumn schedule
fields.trailText: An organisation representing Britain's biggest advertisers is heading for a showdown with ITV over a range of issues from falling ratings to the network's inability to hire a new chief executive.
fields.body:
An organisation representing Britain's biggest advertisers is heading for a showdown with ITV over a range of issues from falling ratings to the network's inability to hire a new chief executive.

The Incorporated Society of British Advertisers has called for an urgent meeting, claiming that confidence in the network has been severely damaged. The society carries significant weight, with its members accounting for two-thirds of all advertising ex penditure on ITV. Bob Wootton, ISBA's director of media and advertising affairs, said: "A number of things are not moving in the right direction that need to be tackled. Now that it seems more certain we will be moving forward with two ITV companies they should begin turning their attention back toward issues that concern us."

Mr Wootton said advertisers' main gripe was ITV's failure to meet its target of 38.5% peak-time share. In the first half of the year ITV managed an average share of only 37.2%. "We are not armchair schedulers but we do reserve the right to be critical if the performance is not everything we would hope for," he said. The autumn schedule he added was "safe rather than spectacular".

An ITV spokeswoman said: "We're surprised to receive this letter. All the points raised by ISBA were dealt with in a meeting at our instigation with senior ITV executives three weeks ago."

Other issues on the ISBA's agenda include ITV's absence on the SkyDigital platform, an alleged "failure" to focus on off-peak programming and inflation in the rates charged for air-time. The ITV Network has had no chief executive since Richard Eyre decamped to media group Pearson at the start of the year.

ITV's peak share has fallen by 1.3% since 1998 but the network has performed better in the face of growing competition than BBC1, which has lost 3.5% of audience share in the same period.

ITV's autumn line-up includes Ross Kemp as a police detective in Without Motive, the first Lily Savage series on the network and the 40th anniversary of Coronation Street with special episodes.

fields.headline: Facing the realities of the Spanish civil war
fields.trailText: Keith Flett writes: Courageous as Bill Alexander was as the last commander of the British battalion in the International Brigades that fought for the republican government against General Franco's fascists in the Spanish civil war, Richard Baxell's remark in his obituary (July 14) of Alexander that he was right to criticise Ken Loach's 1995 feature film about the civil war, Land And Freedom, is unfortunate
fields.body:
Keith Flett writes: Courageous as Bill Alexander was as the last commander of the British battalion in the International Brigades that fought for the republican government against General Franco's fascists in the Spanish civil war, Richard Baxell's remark in his obituary (July 14) of Alexander that he was right to criticise Ken Loach's 1995 feature film about the civil war, Land And Freedom, is unfortunate.

Of course the British followers of the Workers' Party of Marxist Unification (POUM) were a minority in Spain, but they did include George Orwell, who wrote the marvellous book, Homage To Catalonia, about his experiences during the civil war. That book underlined very clearly that while the Communists in Spain were anti-fascist, they also followed the position of the Stalinist Soviet Union in frustrating attempts to turn the civil war into a socialist revolution. That meant, ultimately, the imprisonment and death of socialists who opposed Stalinism. Orwell himself was lucky to escape this fate.

These may be unpalatable realities for those who have continued to support a Stalinist view of the Spanish civil war. They certainly take nothing away from the heroism of Bill Alexander or the work he did over many years to make sure that the deeds of the International Brigaders were not forgotten. However, they cannot be dismissed, as Baxell tries to do.
fields.bodyText: Keith Flett writes: Courageous as Bill Alexander was as the last commander of the British battalion in the International Brigades that fought for the republican government against General Franco's fascists in the Spanish civil war, Richard Baxell's remark in his obituary (July 14) of Alexander that he was right to criticise Ken Loach's 1995 feature film about the civil war, Land And Freedom, is unfortunate. Of course the British followers of the Workers' Party of Marxist Unification (POUM) were a minority in Spain, but they did include George Orwell, who wrote the marvellous book, Homage To Catalonia, about his experiences during the civil war. That meant, ultimately, the imprisonment and death of socialists who opposed Stalinism. Orwell himself was lucky to escape this fate. These may be unpalatable realities for those who have continued to support a Stalinist view of the Spanish civil war. They certainly take nothing away from the heroism of Bill Alexander or the work he did over many years to make sure that the deeds of the International Brigaders were not forgotten. However, they cannot be dismissed, as Baxell tries to do.

webTitle: Market forces: Dealers know when it is summer in the City because things simply do not add up

fields.headline: A touch of the sun
fields.trailText: Dealers know when it is summer in the City because things simply do not add up. Take yesterday. The FTSE 100 ended higher even though the Dow was lower and there were more fallers than risers.
fields.body:
Dealers know when it is summer in the City because things simply do not add up. Take yesterday. The FTSE 100 ended higher even though the Dow was lower and there were more fallers than risers.

Then there was Freeserve, which declined 27.5p to 336.5p after its own broker (CSFB) said the internet service provider is heading for sharply increased losses this year, and the mysterious rise of Hays by 8p to 347p and Ocean Group, 43p better at £11.00.

The day's economic data also puzzled investors, with the minutes of the monetary policy committee meeting conflicting with stronger than expected retail sales data.

In the end investors moved to the sidelines to wait for guidance from today's testimony by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan.

At the close the FTSE 100 was 14.9 points higher at 6,465.4 as market turnover approached 1.2bn, swollen by heavy trading in Vodafone AirTouch, up 8p to 312p, and newcomer Dimension Data, up 43p from its placing price of 520p.

Other market debutantes moved higher. iSOFT closed at 152p compared to an issue price of 110p while IG Group at 280p was up 40p from its issue price.

Some things made sense. Shares in Kingfisher tumbled 30.5p to 576p after Schroder Salomon Smith Barney hit the retailer with a trio of downgrades. To set the ball rolling the broker cut its rating on the stock to "neutral" from "outperform", then lowered its price target to 600p from 650p and cut its profit forecast for the current financial year by £25m.

It seems that problems at Kingfisher's German electrical operation, Wegert, plus rising interest charges and the costs associated with the roll-out of its general merchandise format are to blame. According to traders, SSSB was telling clients that the slippage in estimates - a main theme of last year - is likely to knock confidence in the stock.

Oil stocks were back in favour on hopes that Opec will not after all lift production at the end of the month. BP Amoco finished 16.5p up at 599p, Shell rose 1p to 540p.

Back on the downside, Alliance & Leicester slid 16.5p to 491p as its restructuring plan failed to impress. Analysts at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson said the plan does not address problems the group has with its core mortgage and savings business. Both are said to have stagnated in the first of half of this year

Marks & Spencer, down 1.25p at 234.5p, closed off its low as a trading update drew a mixed response. While there was some disappointment that general merchandise sales were down, there was encouraging news from its store refurbishment programme.

Nycomed Amersham lost 24p to 633p after reports suggested the rumoured flotation of Pharmacia Biotech, in which it has a 55% stake, might not be as lucrative as first thought.

ICI dropped 8p to 500p, after UBS Warburg trimmed its rating to "buy" from "strong buy", and British Telecom slid 13p to 917p as Deutsche Bank removed the stock from its influential "focus list".

Among second-tier stocks, bid speculation continued to swirl around b2b software group Infobank, up 20p to 900p. Yesterday's tales centred on a bid from Oracle or SAP. The more sceptical pointed out the rise was probably to do with the fact that Prudential once again holds more than 11% of the stock. It recently reduced its holding to around 6%.

Takeover favourite Arriva jumped 12p to 212p after Go-Ahead Group , up 110p to 660p, rejected a 650p per share takeover approach.

On AIM, shares in New Capital Invest were suspended at 70p after it announced a reverse takeover of the privately owned telemetrics specialist Eagle Eye Tracking Systems, valued at around £15m. NCI listed in February at 25p per share.

fields.headline: Ferdy Woodward
fields.standfirst: Codebreaker, academic - and Royal Navy rarity
fields.trailText: Professor LJ "Ferdy" Woodward, who has died aged 83, was - in reverse order - a much-loved pillar of St Andrews University, a wartime codebreaker at Bletchley Park and one of the select band of Royal Navy ordinary seamen to be awarded Prize Money.
fields.body:
Professor LJ "Ferdy" Woodward, who has died aged 83, was - in reverse order - a much-loved pillar of St Andrews University, a wartime codebreaker at Bletchley Park and one of the select band of Royal Navy ordinary seamen to be awarded Prize Money.

He had a lonely and unhappy childhood, divided between Liverpool and the Isle of Man. His father left his mother when young Leslie - a name he never used - was seven, and she was too busy running her three shops to be able to give him much time.

Luckily, he won a scholarship to Oulton, a local day school unusual for its time in being co-educational, where an understanding teacher restored his confidence in himself. He took a first in modern languages, in his case Spanish, from Downing College, Cambridge, and fell for a woman student, Elizabeth Bradshaw, whom he saw sweeping into the university library "as if to the sound of trumpets".

Convinced by his own schooldays of the importance of teachers, he did a B Ed and landed a job at Eton, to replace a master called up for military service - the second world war had lately broken out. But the beak failed his medical, so Woodward only taught in those hallowed classrooms for two days. He had himself registered as a conscientious objector.

He was teaching at Merchant Taylors' School in Crosby, near Liverpool, when it occurred to him that much of the food he ate had to be shipped in by sailors at risk from the U-boats. He decided that a conscience was a luxury and enlisted in the navy as an ordinary seaman. He was soon on Atlantic convoy-escort duties, known to his ship-mates either as "the professor" or "bonehead".

It was after their ship had put into Cape Town for repairs that he was singled out for his tiny part in history. As they put to sea again they were ordered to intercept a Vichy-French merchantman. Assembling a boarding-party, the master-at-arms said, "Woodward, you're an educated kind of f----r. You can come along as interpreter." The cargo, destined for the enemy, turned out to be wolfram, a vital ore in the manufacture of armour-piercing shells. It was confiscated, and after the war, in line with ancient naval custom and a rigid apportionment table, Woodward was sent one share of the Prize Money, tax-free. Had he been an admiral it would have been 10 shares. Soon afterwards he was injured in a shipboard accident and transferred to a hospital ship returning to Britain.

There he was selected for officer training and seized the opportunity to marry his Cambridge girlfriend, who after a spell in the Foreign Office was now working at Bletchley. She happened to see one day a list of officers being considered to head the naval watch, which dealt with all intercepted signals relating to the sea war. She surreptitiously added her husband's name and in due course he was summoned for an interview. As he was by then in a boring shore job in Plymouth, he had no regrets when a letter arrived telling him he had been appointed. A single first-class ticket to Bletchley was enclosed.

The couple took a cottage in the area and the first of their four daughters was born. On demobilisation as a lieutenant-commander, Woodward returned to school-teaching until, in 1947, he was offered a Spanish government grant to pursue further studies in Madrid. While they were there they heard that St Andrews was looking for someone to start up a Spanish department. Again Woodward was chosen and took up the post in 1948, arriving on a motorcycle sidecar outfit with a dog as passenger. The rest of the family followed by train. They began to make friends in all faculties.

Students away from home for the first time found Mrs Woodward, mysteriously nicknamed "the Buffer," a warm and wise mother-substitute. The new department expanded, acquiring a particular reputation for its Latin-American studies. Ferdy became its joint professor, along with a colleague who was also a non-stipendary priest in the Episcopalian church and commanding officer of the university officer training corps, and could thus be addressed as Lieut-Col the Rev Professor.

On retirement in the 1980s, Woodward became a visiting professor in the United States for a few terms, but St Andrews, or rather the outlying hamlet of Denhead, remained their home. Students calling on them now were often the children of their earlier students, and one of their own daughters, Miranda, had settled in the town with her husband and family. His wife and partner in the many friendships they made over the years had died 14 months ago after dancing through the night at a Highland wedding. After her death, Ferdy moved into a small house nearby, and was beginning to enjoy town life again when he fell ill.

He is survived by Susanna, Elizabeth, Miranda and Jenny.

 Leslie James Woodward, scholar and teacher, born July 9 1916; died July 7 2000.

fields.headline: High hopes for Alterian
fields.trailText: Trading in database specialist Alterian begins today and talk has it that this new issue will prove to be extremely popular with institutions. Spread betting firm Cantor Index has been quoting a grey market price of 262p-268p for the company which boasts Trinity Mirror, National Power and Britannic Assurance among its client base.
fields.body:
Trading in database specialist Alterian begins today and talk has it that this new issue will prove to be extremely popular with institutions. Spread betting firm Cantor Index has been quoting a grey market price of 262p-268p for the company which boasts Trinity Mirror, National Power and Britannic Assurance among its client base.

Alterian, which has raised around £37.5m via the placement of shares at 200p, has developed a database platform and software tools that help companies analyse customer information.

Alterian claims the speed and volume capabilities of its technology means it can be used in a wide variety of fields - from healthcare to financial markets.

And for once it does not appear to be all hype. Alterian's products have won recognition from Microsoft and it made a gross profit of £749,000 on sales £1m in the last financial year. Since then revenue growth is said to have been exceptional.

fields.headline: At this price?  CGNU
fields.trailText: CGNU, Britain's largest insurer, yesterday demonstrated why investors have been right to admire this newly merged group.
fields.body:
CGNU, Britain's largest insurer, yesterday demonstrated why investors have been right to admire this newly merged group.

The shares have outperformed the market by more than 20% this year on hopes that CGU and Norwich Union can work more effectively together in a rapidly consolidating sector.

The stock was down last night 29p at£10.89 but that was due to profit-taking. CGNU delivered a sparkling set of interim results and gave reason to feel the pace of growth will be maintained.

It reported a 24% increase in new UK business, worth £3.7bn, at a time when the pension and endowment selling scandals continue to scar the industry's reputation.

Total worldwide sales were up 18%, with strong performances in France and Poland. New single premiums, often lump sum personal pension payments which dominate the market, increased by just under 50% in France.

CGNU entered the Polish market early and privatisation of the pensions business has led to windfalls for CGNU: £2m of sales in the first half of 1999 grew to £109m so far this year.

Ireland is also proving a land of opportunity with the help of Hibernian which has just been bought. New single premium sales were up 74% over the first half of 1999 and regular premium business rose 170%.

The only European country to disappoint was the Netherlands where individual life sales were sluggish ahead of planned tax changes.

CGNU chief executive Bob Scott said the results proved the merger had not been a distraction from growing its business.

Charles Landa, insurance sector analyst at SG Securities, was particularly impressed by the 28% increase in British business gained through Independent Financial Advisers, the most profitable distribution channel.

However, combining CGU and Norwich Union's British marketing operations in October could prove a hiccup. Higher interest rates and a cooling house market might also slow British growth.

But this is a good defensive sector of the stock market at a time when the economy is coming off the boil. New initiatives such as the bancassurance tie-up with Royal Bank of Scotland should drive growth.

The shares remain well priced but any dips could be seen as buying opportunities.

fields.headline: Constance Howard
fields.standfirst: As artist and teacher, she transformed the status of embroidery and textile design
fields.trailText: Constance Howard, who has died aged 89, was a remarkable artist, an inspiring teacher and an extraordinary character - and arguably the most influential British pioneer in textile design of her generation.
fields.body:
Constance Howard, who has died aged 89, was a remarkable artist, an inspiring teacher and an extraordinary character - and arguably the most influential British pioneer in textile design of her generation.

She had a colossal impact on contemporary embroidery and in establishing the confidence of textile work in the second half of the last century. When Constance began, embroidery and textile design were seen by many people as comparatively minor crafts. That they have since become important artistic genres owes a great deal to her work and example.

Born in Northampton, the daughter of an impecunious schoolmaster, from the age of 10 she studied art at evening class. After leaving school at 14, she was denied a grant to the Royal College of Art - on the grounds that the money would be wasted because she would end up getting married. The authorities were half right: in 1945 she married the sculptor Harold Wilson Parker.

In 1947, she became a part-time tutor at Goldsmiths College in south-east London, at a time when it was struggling to find its feet again after the dislocations of the second world war. She went on to establish an embroidery department in the arts school, and to become principal lecturer in charge of textiles and fashion. Textiles at Goldsmiths came to influence the field everywhere - partly because of Constance's energetic proselytising and example, which nurtured the idea of embroidery as an art form and vehicle for artistic self-expression.

Her most celebrated commissions in this period included The Country Wife, a large hanging for the country pavilion of the Festival of Britain in 1951. There were also two hangings for the Northampton Museum and Art Gallery, and embroideries for Lincoln Cathedral, Eton College and Makerere University, Kampala.

As well as working in textiles, she did much to build the tradition at Goldsmiths that gave the college its leading role in art and design. Following her retirement in 1975, she was awarded the MBE for services to embroidery. Her standing continued to grow, partly on the basis of visiting lectures in Europe and the US, and her authorship of a number of key texts. At Goldsmiths the Constance Howard Textiles Study Collection was established, which now contains more than 2,000 textile pieces and related items, many of major historical importance.

A prolific writer, her books included Design For Embroidery From Traditional English Sources (1956), Inspiration For Embroidery (1966) and Embroidery And Colour (1976). A year later she published Textile Crafts, in 1979 came The Constance Howard Book of Stitches, and during the next few years she researched and wrote a classic four-volume study, Twentieth Century Embroidery In Great Britain (1981-86).

A small, slight figure, Con stance Howard remained a powerfully individualistic personality to the end of her life. Her enthusiasm for textiles communicated itself to everyone who knew her, while her kind and patient approach to teaching endeared her to generations of students.

She was no shrinking violet. Long before the arrival of punks, she wore bright green hair. In the 1930s, she allegedly used lithographers' ink as dye. Later, she switched to fluorescence: at a recent Goldsmiths lecture held in her honour, the head of the indomitable nonagenarian flashed like a traffic light, unmistakably, from the middle of the audience.

She leaves a daughter, Charlotte.

webTitle: Comment, George Monbiot: The banking systems of the first world create monstrous injustice

fields.headline: They don't owe us, we owe them
fields.standfirst:
The banking systems of the first world create monstrous injustice

Special report: debt relief
Jubilee 2000
fields.trailText: The banking systems of the first world create monstrous injustice.
fields.body:
Between 1503 and 1660, 185,000 kilos of gold and 16m kilos of silver were shipped from Latin America to Europe. The native American leader Guaicaipuro Cuautemoc argues that his people should see this transfer not as a war crime, but as "the first of several friendly loans, granted by America for Europe's development". Were they to charge compound interest on this loan, levied at the modest rate of 10%, Europe would owe the indigenous people of Latin America a stack of gold and silver which exceeded the weight of the planet.

Curiously, this deficit is not scheduled for discussion at the G8 summit in Japan tomorrow. The debts whose forgiveness world leaders have been urged to consider are those which the impoverished nations of the south are deemed to owe the north. The seizures of land, labour, minerals and timber by colonists and corporations is a debt written off before it has even been accounted. The massive "climate change debt" the rich owe to the poor remains, officially, invisible.

These injustices are well documented. But there is another aspect of the debt crisis which has scarcely been considered. Third world debt is a fraud. It is not a debt at all, but the artefact of a deformed accounting system.

In his startling new book Goodbye America!, the economist Michael Rowbotham shows that the debt is the inevitable outcome of the 1944 Bretton Woods conference. John Maynard Keynes, who led the British delegation, foresaw that unless international trade was radically overhauled, debt would become self-perpetuating. He proposed an "International Clearing Union" and a new currency, the bancor, in which international transactions would be conducted. Nations would be charged by the union for both overdrawn and surplus bancor accounts, encouraging creditors to spend their excess bancors in debtor countries, thus swiftly wiping out their deficit.

The United States, by contrast, was the world's major creditor and wanted to keep it that way. Its delegation proposed that nations could borrow from an international bank which would penalise debtors, but not creditors. It insisted that gold, valued in dollars, be used to set exchange rates, ensuring that the dollar became the international banking standard. Having threatened to withhold its forthcoming war loan to Britain, the US won. It established, through the World Bank and the IMF, a global trading system which secured both a lasting US economic hegemony and the irredeemable indebtedness of poorer nations.

The problem has been compounded by the growth in "fractional reserve banking": the process by which banks create money out of nothing by lending far more than they possess. As governments have all but ceased to issue real notes and coins, this magic money now accounts for some 95% of total money supply in most developed nations. Indebtedness, in other words, has become the necessary concomitant of money creation. This means that the total debt the people of a nation owe can never be repaid. This is why, despite Gordon Brown's brave efforts on Tuesday, our massive national debt repayments will only dent the cumulative total. This is why our great "property-owning democracy" has become mortgaged to the hilt.

It also explains why Third world debt has become unpayable. Forced to take loans from commercial banks, the debtor nations create the money which enables first world countries to sell them their surplus goods and services. The debt, Rowbotham argues, is the result not of corruption, incompetence or economic failure on the part of developing nations. It is the inexorable and intentional product of a debt-based financial system. The "debt" is no more than a measurement of the banking system's magical generation of money.

Interestingly, this could mean that the "debt crisis" is much easier to solve than world leaders imagine. As nearly all money arises from the issue of debt, then debt redemption is largely a matter of accountancy. Were banks allowed to cancel the debt bonds they hold, yet keep them on their books, they could balance their accounts without suffering any losses from their reserves. It is a fiddle, of course, but a fiddle of the kind which already keeps international banking afloat, as unrepayable debts are reported at their full theoretical value. And were the IMF and the World Bank to be replaced by a system of the kind Keynes proposed, the mistakes of the past 50 years could not be repeated.

One outstanding task would remain: forgiveness. That we should presume to "forgive" the third world's debts is laughable. Rather, the G8 leaders must beg the forgiveness of the third world for the dreadful and deliberate mess they have made of the global economy.

fields.headline: Work in progress
fields.standfirst: Peter Benchley, author
fields.trailText: Peter Benchley, author
fields.body:
Jaws, the movie, is now celebrating its 25th anniversary, but for me the story goes back a little further. I got the idea for the book during the mid-to-late 60s but wasn't compelled to write it until the early 70s. By "wasn't compelled", I mean nobody offered me any money. After the fact, I learned the movie had a troubled shoot, but I witnessed no problems during the four weeks I was on set. I guess they kept me shielded from any unpleasantness. Now I have no interest in Hollywood, though my time there was quite enjoyable.

I don't think my book has anything to do with sharks' bad reputation: they've had bad press since presses were invented. Sharks are no longer the villain of the sea - that "honour" falls to man. Due to the demand for shark's fin soup some species have declined by as much as 80 per cent. The method by which fins are obtained is barbaric to the extreme: the sharks are pulled up on deck and the fins cut off. The poor creature is then dumped back into the sea, very often still alive. They can take at least a day to die in this condition. This method is as pointless as it is grotesque, since the fin has no actual taste and is just used to provide a gelatinous mass to the soup. I'm currently touring the world to draw attention to this. After I leave Britain I'm heading for Australia and then to Japan, the main culprit in this situation.

Encouragingly, the young seem very concerned about this.

We're still learning plenty about sharks - for instance, that fatalities attributed to them are very few. When a shark bites on something it makes a split-second calorific judgement on its food value. We're not worth the effort to eat. To them we don't taste too good.

Interview by Phelim O'Neill

Jaws: 25th Anniversary Edition is available on DVD from July 24 through Columbia Tristar at £19.99. For more information on Shark preservation contact www.wildaid.org
