fields.headline: Live and dangerous
fields.standfirst: The average British television viewer spends nearly 10 minutes a week watching Richard Whiteley. And if you think that's scary, you've got a shock coming.  Charlie Brooker  on the problem with Britain's TV 'personalities'
fields.trailText: The average British television viewer spends nearly 10 minutes a week watching Richard Whiteley. And if you think that's scary, you've got a shock coming. Charlie Brooker on the problem with Britain's TV 'personalities'.
fields.body:
Heard of screen-burn? It used to affect computer monitors. If you used a particular program a lot, some of its prevailing visual features - the menu bar, for instance - would, over time, become permanently etched onto the screen, remaining faintly visible for evermore. Screensavers were invented to prevent this kind of damage, hence their name.

Fascinating stuff. The point is this: if a similar phenomenon afflicted regular TV screens, you could be forgiven for expecting to find your set indelibly stained with Carol Vorderman. Not that you'd notice the change: it feels like she's permanently onscreen anyway.

But she isn't the worst offender. In fact, in a list of the most-seen presenters on television in the latest edition of industry magazine Broadcast, Vorderman finishes fourth. You're far more likely to wind up with Richard Madeley's face burnt across your Trinitron, like some nightmarish 21st-century Turin Shroud: he and wife Judy Finnegan squat proudly at the top of the league. The charts were calculated according to "exposure factor"; the time in minutes they are seen by an "average" viewer in one week. Richard and Judy win with 14.06 minutes for This Morning.

The rest of the list contains several surprises, such as the news that The Antiques Roadshow's Hugh Scully (number 19 on the overall list) enjoys more exposure than Johnny Vaughan and Lisa Tarbuck (languishing at number 24, thanks largely to the state of The Big Breakfast's ratings, currently at art-house cinema levels). There's also the non-appearance of Jamie Theakston or Dale Winton in the top 25, and the shocking revelation that Gloria Hunniford is still working - although only on Channel 5, which means she might as well be reading Ladybird books to a bunch of worms in a skip. Oh, and one truly terrifying fact: the average viewer watches Jim Davidson for a full 6.49 minutes every week. Coincidentally, this is also the precise amount of time it takes to grind your own teeth to powder in an impotent rage.

But the list also shatters several key TV presentation myths - such as the assumption that to enjoy success you have to be young and attractive. This simply isn't true.

Take the "attractive" bit. Consider Michael Parkinson (number 25), a man with a face like a corpse's shoe - or the downright Tolkeinesque Alan Titchmarsh, who could wander through a forest scaring knotholes from the trees simply by smiling at them. Think: did you really splash out on that top-of-the-range brushed aluminium Panasonic set just so you could experience Titchmarsh's inadvertent gurning in digital widescreen? So you could hear your kids screaming about the scary man with his face pressed against the glass? Well? Maybe it's just me, but whenever Titchmarsh turns to camera I always imagine he's about to lean out of the screen and try to lick my neck. It's frightening. But there he is regardless, sitting unpretty at number nine. Then there's Davidson, Whiteley, Scully... all of them about as easy on the eye as a handful of shattered monkey-nut husks unexpectedly flung in your face by a passing drunk.

Still, it's unfair to judge people on appearance. There's age to consider as well. And the nation's top telly faces are old, man. The average age of the top five BBC1 presenters is 47.8, while their ITV equivalents are even older, at an average of 50.8 years of age. Even the painfully hip Channel 4, which arrives at work riding a pavement scooter and clutching a punnet of takeaway sushi, can only manage 45.6. The unseen, ghostlike Channel 5 has by far the perkiest presenters - their top five come in at around 38.3 years old, despite the handicap of a 60-year-old Hunniford dragging their average age coffinward.

So if duff looks and senility aren't handicaps, what will hold you back? The answer, it would appear, is a personality, since the majority of names on the list are about as inspiring as a scratch on a Formica desktop. Lineker (2), Lynam (3), Aspel (20), Kilroy (23)... they may be professional, but they sure as heck ain't interesting. Perhaps the blandest of the lot is Steve Rider, described as "TV's Mister Charisma" for the first and only time in his life in this very sentence, straight in at number 14 thanks to his Grandstand appearances (doing a regular sports gig is a good way of gatecrashing the list, which explains the appearance of David Vine, six places ahead of Carol Smillie at number 10).

There are bright spots. Ant and Dec (6) are chirpy and likeable, and even if you can't bear Cilla (7), Barrymore (18), or Tarrant (5), they're at least vaguely anarchic in spirit. Otherwise, it seems we like our TV presenters to encompass everything we wouldn't look for in a potential sexual partner: aged, ugly, and utterly personality-free. And considering the amount of time we're going to end up spending with them, that's downright sick.

fields.headline: Ganju Lama VC
fields.standfirst: Two medals for bravery in the space of a month
fields.trailText: On May 17, 1944, Ganju Lama, who has died in Sikkim aged 77, was a young rifleman serving in Burma with B Company 1st Battalion 7th Gurkha Rifles, part of the 48th Indian Brigade, 17th Indian Division, in the advance to recapture Imphal.
fields.body:
On May 17, 1944, Ganju Lama, who has died in Sikkim aged 77, was a young rifleman serving in Burma with B Company 1st Battalion 7th Gurkha Rifles, part of the 48th Indian Brigade, 17th Indian Division, in the advance to recapture Imphal.

The battalion's task was to clear a complex of bunkers and road blocks, defended by components of the Japanese 15th Army. The 17th Indian Division's progress had faltered on the Tiddim Road, north-east of Imphal, and it was here that, unexpectedly, B Company found itself under intense fire from 37mm guns mounted on Japanese light tanks.

Armed with a Piat (projector infantry anti-tank) Ganju Lama fired at a range of some 60 yards, his second shot penetrating the side armour of the leading enemy tank and setting it on fire. Although his platoon was ordered back, Ganju Lama remained in position to cover his comrades' withdrawal. For his courage and resourcefulness he was later awarded the Military Medal.

So tenacious were the Japanese counter-attacks against the 17th Indian Division's thrust towards Imphal that, three weeks later, 48th Brigade had only managed to reach Ningthookong, an advance of barely 12 miles. On the morning of June 12, the brigade positions just north of the village came under a ferocious artillery barrage, and as it lifted, enemy infantry and tanks broke through the brigade's outer perimeter, from where the tanks seemed likely to overrun the British positions.

B and D Companies, 1st/7th Gurkha Rifles, were ordered to counter-attack. At first progress was good, but, faced with fire from the tanks' main armament, the attack faltered. Ganju Lama, again armed with his Piat, crawled forward and engaged the Japanese armour from the flank. By now seriously wounded in his left wrist, right hand and a leg, Ganju Lama held his fire until he was 30 yards from the leading tank. With his first shot he destroyed that tank, taking the next one out with his second shot. The third was destroyed by supporting anti-tank gun fire.

As the surviving crews exited from the burning tanks, Ganju Lama, with one hand useless, launched a grenade attack, pulling the pins out with his teeth. It was only when he had killed or wounded the last of the tank crews that he allowed himself to be evacuated. He spent 22 months in hospital, and was in a wheelchair when he received his Victoria Cross and Military Medal, from the Viceroy, Field Marshal Lord Wavell, at an investiture held that autumn at the Red Fort in Delhi.

The citation for his VC, published on September 7, records that "throughout this action, Rifleman Ganju Lama, although seriously wounded, showed a complete disregard for his personal safety, outstanding devotion to duty and a determination to destroy the enemy that was an example and an inspiration to all ranks. It was solely due to his prompt action and brave conduct that a most critical situation was averted, all positions regained and heavy casualties inflicted on the enemy."

Born in India, in the village of Sangmo in southern Sikkim, of a Tibetan father and Nepalese mother, Ganju Lama, who enlisted in 1943, was only allowed into the Gurkhas because, in wartime, the regiment's usually strict rules on the ethnic origins of recruits were occasionally relaxed.

After India's independence in 1947, Ganju Lama joined the 11th Gorkha Rifles, a regiment comprising men of the 7th and 10th Gurkha Rifles who had elected to continue their service with the Indian army rather than the British army. Later promoted subedar major (senior Indian officer), he became ADC to India's president in 1965. Ganju Lama was made an honorary captain in 1968, while still serving, and on his retirement, in 1972, was appointed ADC to the Indian president for life. In his later years, he was a successful farmer.

A distinguished-looking, highly intelligent and very caring man, Captain Ganju Lama was a regular visitor to Britain. For the last nine years he was vice-chairman (Overseas) of the Victoria Cross and George Cross Association. With his death, only 25 living holders of the VC remain.

Ganju Lama married twice and is survived by his second wife, three children from his first marriage and three from his second.

 Ganju Lama, soldier, born July 22, 1922: died June 30, 2000

fields.headline: Johnny Duncan
fields.standfirst: Tennessee hillbilly singer who helped pave the way for Britain's rock revolution
fields.trailText: In the summer of 1957, the Tennessee singer Johnny Duncan, who has died of cancer in Australia aged 67, achieved a one-off hit, Last Train To San Fernando.
fields.body:
In the summer of 1957, the Tennessee singer Johnny Duncan, who has died of cancer in Australia aged 67, achieved a one-off hit, Last Train To San Fernando.

It epitomised the spirit of the British skiffle boom, remained in the top 20 for weeks and featured an irritating, compulsive catchline that reverberated down the rest of the century.

Duncan had not wanted to record the song - he was a hillbilly country singer with one eye on rock 'n' roll - and he was to pay a price for his association with skiffle. But he had a good voice, a talent for the guitar and mandolin, and, in an era when inept imitation of transatlantic rock 'n' roll plagued British pop, he was, at least, a real American.

It was a time when Musicians Union restrictions limiting the entry of American stars increased the exoticism of those few transatlantic imports. And Duncan was the first in a line of US pop singers - Geno Washington, the Walker Brothers, PJ Proby et al - whose careers blossomed in Britain.

Duncan was a miner's son, born in Oliver Springs, Tennessee. He sang with his local church choir and later with a gospel quartet before heading for Texas in his mid-teens. There he learned guitar and performed with a hillbilly trio. Then came the draft. He arrived as a serviceman in England in 1952. A year later he married a Cambridgeshire girl, Betty. After a brief return to the US, her illness and homesickness brought them back, and he briefly worked on her father's market clothes stall.

It was while performing at the American Club in Bushey Park that Duncan attracted the attention of Dickie Bishop, banjoist with the then hugely successful Chris Barber jazz band. The band had been the launchpad for the "king of skiffle", Lonnie Donegan, who had quit Barber following the phenomenal success of Rock Island Line. Bishop recalls inviting Duncan to the White Hart in Southall to meet Barber - and he was taken on for £10 a week. The American stayed with the band - or with the Chris Barber Skiffle Group, within it - for a year, performing live, recording and broadcasting.

By early 1957, alongside the impact of American rock 'n' roll, skiffle, that "peculiar mixture of country, gospel, folk and blues" as Duncan's sometime recording manager Keith Glass labelled it, had emerged as a British phenomenon, and indeed the seedbed of domestic rock 'n' roll, with Donegan and others enjoying a string of hits.

Thus did Duncan leave Barber and, guided by producer Dennis Preston, recruited the Blue Grass Boys, Lennie Hastings, Denny Wright, Jack Fallon and Danny Levan. Their first single, Hank Williams's Kaw Liga in April 1957, flopped. Then, two months later, came Last Train To San Fernando. fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Crossing Continents/First Ladies
fields.body:
In Crossing Continents (11.0am, Radio 4) Olenka Frenkiel visits Odessa, where favoured Soviet workers once repaired for a reviving breath of Black Sea ozone. The city is considerably less appealing now, housing an estimated 300,000 people infected with HIV and a vast number of heroin addicts. The disastrous state of the local economy means that addicts who can't pay for heroin make their own from local poppies. They then cut it with paint stripper and other agents, often infected with tuberculosis.

Anthony Howard's survey of America's First Ladies (8.0pm, Radio 4) comes bang up-to-date with a portrait of the presidential wife seeking her own political career. The hurdle Hillary Clinton (pictured) faces in this year's run for the senate is only partly political. She was born in Illinois and lived most of her adult life in Arkansas, neither of them wonderful recommendations for a notoriously prickly New York electorate. Even the withdrawal of her main opponent doesn't seem to have helped.

fields.headline: Written in the stars
fields.standfirst: A photograph of the star birth regions at the heart of the galaxy is one of the most flamboyantly beautiful artworks of our time. Continuing his search for beauty Jonathon Jones peers through the Hubble telescope.
fields.trailText: Looking into the satellite photographs of the smoky, glowing gas clouds of the "starburst" galaxy NGC253, a galaxy so far away that its light takes 8m years to reach us, we are savouring a beauty that is the accidental product of events that happened in a distant time and part of the universe.
fields.body:
Looking into the satellite photographs of the smoky, glowing gas clouds of the "starburst" galaxy NGC253, a galaxy so far away that its light takes 8m years to reach us, we are savouring a beauty that is the accidental product of events that happened in a distant time and part of the universe.

The result looks like a great painting. To be precise, it looks like Turner. At the heart of NGC253, a ball of yellow fire reddens the clouds like a Turner sun. Colossal wisps of gas part to reveal the blue light of newly born stars. The entire structure arcs and wheels with a vast, turbulent grandeur.

When John Ruskin, the champion of Turner, started to go mad he saw a new kind of cloud, "the storm cloud of the 19th century", in the sky above his home in the Lake District. For Ruskin, the object of art was to reveal the divine hand in nature. That was what he meant by beauty. What would he have said now, looking at the pictures taken by Hubble?

Hubble was put into orbit by Nasa's Discovery space shuttle in 1990. This unmanned, ground-controlled telescope orbiting outside Earth's atmosphere is like an eye with a cataract removed: it sees into deep space with a hard, bright precision that is almost uncomfortable. These pictures have totally transformed public perceptions of astronomy (and have done wonders for Nasa's image). Since the telescope - which had been sent into space with an inaccurately ground lens - was repaired by shuttle astronauts in 1993 it has relayed astonishing pictures to us.

There has never been a more gratuitous addition to our store of beauty. Ultimately, when we call a work of art beautiful we are comparing it to nature. The underlying structures of nature were imitated by artists from ancient Greece until the middle of the 20th century because nature was perceived as beautiful. If we don't talk much about "beauty" in contemporary art, that is because art is no longer concerned with the representation of nature.

The photographs taken by the Hubble space telescope are the most flamboyantly beautiful artworks of our time. They are aesthetically devastating, and that visual power comes from the revelation of natural phenomena we have never seen before.

"On the one hand there is this emotional response," says Mario Livio, head of science at the Space Telescope Science Institute in Baltimore, which runs the Hubble research programme for Nasa. "You look at those images and they are astoundingly beautiful. But then there is this hidden beauty in the physics, namely that underneath all this richness and complexity there is a relatively simple truth which allows these phenomena to occur."

The things Livio has seen. He was there, for example, when scientists at the institute got their first glimpse of the Hubble Deep Field. In 1995 the institute decided to train the telescope for several days on a single patch of blank black sky, selected for its apparent emptiness. What this meant was that there were no foreground objects - no near stars - to get in the way of the phenomena that this long, hard look revealed. You can see the Hubble Deep Field in colour photographs. It is studded with glowing objects, some of which you might mistake for stars but which are all galaxies - so far away that we are seeing them millions, even billions, of years ago. The light from the most distant galaxy photographed in the Hubble Deep Field took 13bn years to reach us. It is a red, blurry glimpse of a galaxy in the process of formation, in the early years of the universe.

You can see how looking at this stuff regularly might get the most hard-headed scientist thinking about beauty. And that is what Livio has done in his new book The Accelerated Universe, an accessible account of the latest discoveries in cosmology (the study of the structure of the universe) that is also a plea for scientists to admit what they are really engaged in: the pursuit of the beautiful. Physicists, argues Livio, are not cold, objective calculators. They are aesthetes, trying to see behind the apparent chaos of nature a beautiful underlying order.

"I call this a cosmological aesthetic principle," explains Livio. "In physics, things that are difficult to prove we tend to call principles. I can't say why it is that a theory of the universe should be beautiful. All I can say is that history has taught us they are."

This is surprising because beauty is a shunned word in current thinking about art. It's back there in history with Greek temples and Ruskin. Livio, a self-confessed "art fanatic", who compares looking at distant stars to contemplating his "all-time favourite painting", Vermeer's Girl with a Pearl Earring, is happy not just to discuss beauty but to define it.

He argues that what makes a description of the universe succeed or fail - what scientists are looking for - is beauty. Beauty in a theory of physics consists of reducing the apparent complexity and chaos of the universe to a simple set of propositions. If the theory is correct, this beautiful order is a property of the universe itself; we exist because of beauty. The object of physics is therefore to prove that the universe is beautiful. He quotes his fellow cosmologist Steve Weinberg: "We believe that, if we ask why the world is and then ask why that answer is the way it is, at the end of this chain of explanations we shall find a few simple principles of compelling beauty."

Livio's three criteria for beauty in a theory of the universe are "symmetry, simplicity and Copernican humility". By "Copernican humility" he means sticking to the tradition of Copernicus, who pointed out that the earth revolves around the sun; we are not the centre of the universe. This is a polemical point by Livio. Among the brain-warping ideas of contemporary physics is the "anthropic principle", that because there are multiple universes and our universe may be the only one that can support life, it effectively exists solely for us; we are at the centre of our universe after all, even if it is only one of an infinite number of universes.

Livio rejects this idea as "ugly" because, he says, it abandons the search for a beautiful explanation for everything and instead says things are the way they are because we need them to be that way.

Yet his book is actually about a crisis of beauty. The new information from deep space collected by Hubble - the same telescope that generates those gorgeous images - defies any simple ("beautiful") explanation. By observing to new degrees of accuracy the velocity at which supernovae (exploding stars which release tremendous bursts of energy) are receding from us, Hubble has apparently confirmed what had been tentatively suggested from telescopes on earth: that the universe is expanding much faster than anyone imagined, and without end. It is getting faster and faster. There is no explanation for this that is "beautiful".

Livio thinks this current ugliness of the universe is an aberration. It is because we don't understand enough. He finds the alternative (the "anthropic" reasoning that says the weirdness of our universe is as it is because that is what human life requires) lacking in humility. "Maybe this simply represents a misunderstanding on our part of what is truly fundamental. History of science has shown that whenever something ugly appeared, this represented a misunderstanding of the entire picture. I think most physicists would agree that when all is said and done, the emerging picture was a beautiful one."

Livio is very careful about not applying his cosmological aesthetic principle to art. But what if we did? Richard Bright, who runs the Interalia Centre in Bristol, an organisation that tries to foster links between artists and scientists, thinks scientists have a lot to learn from art as well as the other way round. He is working with cosmologist John Barrow and art historian Martin Kemp to find ways to represent the multi-dimensional spaces hypothesised by contemporary physics - but he agrees that most efforts by artists to engage with the new physics are poor. There is a lot of art that explicitly talks about things like quantum theory but doesn't seem to go beyond a rhetorical use of it. The worst example of this is Antony Gormley's sculpture Quantum Cloud, which is outside the Millennium Dome - a colossal figure of a man glimpsed through a matrix of metal tubes. "It's got nothing to do with quantum physics," says Bright.

This is a hideously ugly work of art, like the worst efforts of the second-rate Cubists who tried to combine Picasso's discoveries with a more traditional art. A truly quantum view of things would not resolve itself into a traditional human figure. Indeed, the ugliness of this piece could be seen as confirmation of what Livio says about the anthropic principle - that a human-centred universe is an ugly, messy, arrogant idea.

The emerging picture from Hubble - which has only a few more years to observe far-flung realms of space and time before being replaced by the even more powerful Next Generation Space Telescope - may not be beautiful in the underlying, orderly sense demanded by Livio, but it certainly beats most contemporary art. Meanwhile we are all in the gutter while Hubble is looking at the stars.

Next week: Jonathan Jones examines beauty and horror in contemporary art.

fields.headline: Easy does it
fields.standfirst: Brevity and simplicity dominated the Cheltenham Festival. By  Stephen Johnson
fields.trailText: Brevity and simplicity dominated the Cheltenham Festival.
fields.body:
New British music featured in all the main orchestral concerts at Cheltenham this year. I don't know whether festival director Michael Berkeley told his chosen composers to keep it short and sweet, but that's more or less what we got. There was nothing hard-edged and difficult - nothing anywhere near as challenging as the Saariaho and Stockhausen pieces featured by the London Sinfonietta in its late-evening concert at the town hall on July 4. But on Tuesday 11, violinist Rebecca Hirsch and the BBC National Orchestra of Wales introduced something that would certainly stand repetition: Ian Wilson's compact, one-movement Violin Concerto, An Angel Serves a Small Breakfast. The title comes from a painting by Paul Klee.

Perhaps comparison with Klee's whimsical imagery might add new dimensions of meaning; perhaps not. But this exquisitely lyrical and remarkably single-minded piece came over well enough on its own terms. Troubled, yet at the same time beguiling, Wilson's concerto occasionally echoed the long-breathed, sweet-and-sour melodic writing of Berg, and perhaps Szymanowski, but it never sounded derivative or unsure of itself.

Wilson's concerto compared favourably with Joseph Phibbs's Dreams of a Summer Night, sandwiched between popular fail-safes by Mozart and Tchaikovsky in the BBC Symphony Orchestra concert on Saturday July 8. At about half the length of the Wilson, Phibbs's piece felt a good deal longer. It started well: a dreamy, exotically coloured modern impressionism, which could have continued very nicely. But the faster, more turbulent music that followed it lacked conviction and focus. Was that entirely Phibbs's fault? Conductor Gianandrea Noseda seemed to have difficulty keeping even Tchaikovsky's well-known Francesca da Rimini on the straight and narrow. The opening downward run for cellos, basses and bassoons was messy, and there were other unsteady moments. A conductor with a firmer, tauter beat might have made more sense of Phibbs's denser, more active textures.

Wolfgang Rihm's failure to complete his promised new work for the Takacs Quartet (July 15) was a big disappointment, though that superb ensemble's polished but grippingly intense reading of Janacek's First Quartet was more than compensation - extraordinary how challenging and contemporary Janacek can sound three-quarters of a century after his death. But a concert earlier that day by members of the National Youth Orchestra of Great Britain included thought-provoking works by two of this country's most individual modern composers: Diana Burrell and Judith Weir.

One of the most refreshing things about Burrell is her lack of inhibition. Unlike many younger British composers, she doesn't write as though she had an elderly, over-fastidious, donnish critic peering over her shoulder. There were good things in Black, Starlight, Bright, Cinnamon, Earth - especially its weird, lamenting end. But in its earlier stages a lot of it sounded fatally opaque.

Perhaps the problem lay in the line-up: a chamber group including a bass tuba. The tuba is a glorious, misunderstood instrument, but in a small ensemble it tends to stand out like a Beryl Cook bottom in a supermodel parade. There were no such problems in Weir's Piano Concerto (for piano and nine strings) - not a premiere but a well-deserved repeat performance. Weir can be charming and witty, but the way her music moves and thinks is utterly original - delightful and unsettling at the same time. Weir was this year's festival composer-in-residence. Cheltenham could hardly have made a better choice.

Bob Flynn talks to Woody Harrelson about his latest project, Grass
fields.trailText: 'Nobody's ever died from smoking marijuana. Some nights I've tried and you can't do it.' Bob Flynn talks to Woody Harrelson about his latest project, Grass.
fields.body:
A light drizzle bathes the Galway Quays, but in bare feet, hemp shirt and cut-off baggies, Woody Harrelson doesn't seem to notice. He pads across the cobbles with a languorous cowboy amble, instantly at home in the bustling quayside. In West Ireland's legendary epicentre of the "craich" and sleepless partying, the perfect tan and healthy glow emanating from the Texan vegan make him almost luminous. "It's yer man from Cheers," a couple of elderly women whisper. Although Harrelson has been A List Hollywood for almost a decade, he is still known for his eight-year stint behind that mythical Boston bar as the dumb barman savant, Woody Boyd.

The guest of honour at the 12th Galway Film Fleadh, once a ramshackle footnote on the festival circuit but now the country's leading event, Harrelson has to be steered back to his hotel. Still shoeless, he stands on a low window sill staring at the damp trees, like a prisoner yearning to be outside. He is much lighter and leaner than the muscle-popping sports grunt magnified by the big screen. But the slow Texas drawl is genuine and calming as he asks: "Want some tea?"

While the kettle boils, Harrelson takes a teabag out of his pocket and explains: "I got a little blend here, it's herbs and roots from a rainforest in South America. It can get you off coffee." For 10 years, the 38-year-old Harrelson has been vegan, banishing coffee, sugar and all additives. Also aware that he is at the festival as the narrator of Ron Mann's docu-history of marijuana, I hesitantly take a sip, for herbal tea from Hollywood's hemp-advocating zen cowboy may be suffused with something more than just camomile. Like the man himself, it seems harmless, if fuzzy, and I ask how he got into the business.

"Elvis and girls," he drawls. "1978, Elvis Presley died and I was in high school in the dining hall. I was a pretty sensitive kid and I was ridiculed a lot. I was unusual, some would call me weird. So these guys asked me to do my Elvis impersonation; I got on the table and started singing All Shook Up, really getting into it, and one of the prettiest girls in school asked me to join the drama class. That's what did it."

While in Galway, he will also take an actors' masterclass for 25 local thesps. Although he is one of the very few to successfully cross the divide from TV screen to movie theatres, he is also one of the most underrated American actors since his idol, Sean Penn. Like Penn, he has acquired a reputation as a troublesome party animal that will no doubt be enhanced by Grass, which premiered at the Fleadh, a serio-comic documentary collage of archive footage about the use and prohibition of marijuana that Harrelson, as a self-proclaimed "grass activist," agreed to narrate.

"In the US, the government is very partial to telling you that you are living in the land of the free and the home of the brave - well, it sure ain't free," says Harrelson. "I believe that, in a truly free country, you should be able to choose the drug you want, as long as you are not harming anybody else. Now, everybody's a drug-addict, children are addicted to sugar, caffeine and pharmaceuticals, every one of those kids who shot up the schools in the US were on some kind of pills. My best friend, Danny Platner, died from the use of alcohol, pills and tobacco, all extremely addictive drugs. All legalised and freely available. Put him in the grave at age 32."

The delivery may be slow, but the sudden Harrelson diatribe is passionate and surprising, as if he had shifted emotional zones, as he puts it, "into the moment". But I am to find out that 24 hours with Woody is like veering between ashram purity and bacchanalian excess. He has been speaking out in support of cannabis for a long time, facing trial for planting hemp seeds in his Kentucky home in 1996, bailing out other marijuana activists and criticising American agricultural policy. He sees a deep government conspiracy which was, he says, historically based on "racism against Mexican and black workers" who brought marijuana into the US at the start of the century.

"The most destructive drugs are all condoned by the government," he continues, "yet they criminalise marijuana, a lot of my friends are in jail for smoking pot (and the prison system is one of the fastest-growing industries, by the way), which has no proven side-effects apart from making you feel euphoric. So what's wrong with that? Every year hundreds of thousands die from tobacco, alcohol and pharmaceutical use - I'm sorry, I get emotional about this. But to my knowledge, nobody's ever died from smoking marijuana. And, believe me, some nights I've tried and you can't do it."

Although Grass was the highest-grossing independent film on its release in the US, it was banned by the Canadian Film Censors soon after. A retrospective of Harrelson's work contains some of the most controversial studio films of the past decade; later he is to introduce a special Galway Fleadh screening of Natural Born Killers, starring Harrelson as the chilled psychotic, Mickey, which remains banned from public screening in the Republic.

"People think I'm some kind of trouble-maker, but I don't like trouble, it just seems to find me a lot," he says. "I have the unworthy distinction of having three of my films boycotted in the US. Money Train was supposed to have caused copycat violence, but that was proved wrong; Natural Born Killers was attacked by Bob Dole when he was running for president, and The People vs Larry Flynt was torn apart by a lot of the critics. I mean, I love comedies, I think good slapstick is rare and the Farrelly brothers are the best. But I also like movies that stir something in you and I've tried to go with that."

There is a strange, boyish innocence about him, but it seems that, beyond the controversial fiction of some of his films, a troubled reality dogs Harrelson, whose personal history is tabloid manna. His father, allegedly a contract killer, has been in jail since 1979 serving two life sentences for murder. He's now married with two daughters to his long-term partner Laura Louie, but American Rhapsody, a book by Basic Instinct screenwriter Joe Eszterhas, is due out this month in the US, and among its salacious tales from Hollywood it alleges a long clandestine affair between Harrelson and Glenn Close.

Harrelson admits that "early on I sold my soul a couple of times, but I haven't done it since," and that he "made a big mistake with Money Train" despite co-starring with his friend Wesley Snipes, from his 1992 breakthrough basketball film, White Men Can't Jump. "Luck has a lot to do with it. If Keanu Reeves had been able to play basketball, I'd never have got the part," he says. "I've been offered a ton of mindless action movies for huge amounts of money, but I turned them down." Many thought he could have been the next Bruce Willis, but he chose to pass on the megabucks and torn T-shirts.

In 1993, it looked like he had gone into the glossy mainstream as Demi Moore's husband in Indecent Proposal (a year later he turned his image on its head with Natural Born Killers). Lets face it, though, he never stood a chance against Robert Redford, even though he was the most believable thing in that film. The muscly jaw gives him a look like he's gunning for a fight or eternally chewing tobacco and the thin mouth occasionally slides open to reveal a gap-toothed grin and a slight lisp. He's always going to be more good-ol'-boy than romantic lead, the grunt in Malick's Thin Red Line, the cowboy in Frear's Hi-Lo Country, or - his finest hour - the mumbling, wounded and wounding mountain boy turned porn iconoclast in Milos Forman's The People vs Larry Flynt.

"Milos Forman probably said: "Get me the most white trash actor in Hollywood," laughs Harrelson, "but the beauty of that story, like a lot of roles I've done, is looking beyond what's in front of you. I mean the guy was a porn king and his partner [played by Courtney Love] was a drug-addict, but you got to the point where you felt compassion for them. It was also about freedom and the hypocrisy of the government."

Two years before that, he was "still trying to establish some distance from Cheers" with the stylised violence of Natural Born Killers, which proved too much for some fans and critics. Oliver Stone's film remains threatened by a lawsuit filed by writer John Grisham, who is suing on the grounds that it inspired violence against friends of his.

"Now there's a perfect example of a hypocrite," says Harrelson. "I was supposed to be in A Time to Kill [the film of Grisham's novel]. But after Natural Born Killers he said I could not be in his movie, which is fine. But he took money from Regency, who made Natural Born Killers, to make A Time to Kill. If he gets anywhere with this case it would be very scary for making films or any kind of art, because we'd all be held accountable to hypocrites like Grisham."

With Harrelson, what you see is what you get, and he says, almost uniquely for a Hollywood actor, exactly what he thinks. "It may not be the expedient thing to do for me personally or my career, but I don't sit muddling over reasons to be cautious, I have to do and say what feels right in my heart. And that includes the fact that marijuana is the most maligned plant on the planet, and the most loved," he says.

Later on, in one of the long Festival nights at the Galway Rowing Club, which yearly becomes the Fleadh Club, Harrelson mingles until 6am, wearing down the zen purity of his body, sharing Guinness, spliffs and jokes with the throng. Galway is his kind of town. I catch up with him by the river's edge. "I'm an environmental activist more than anything else," he says. Then a slow smile spreads. "And I'll always fight for the right to party."

fields.headline: Talking dirty
fields.body:
"I went a bit crazy. I was a loose cannon, out and about doing what single girls do. Everyone started saying I was a slag, but a man would have got away with it and that's not fair. I'd always been in relationships so it really winds me up when I get called a man-eater."

Melanie Sykes on the double standard she encountered following the end of her last relationship, The Sun

"What happens when a female shopper enters the shopping environment is that she offers herself up to a process of seduction . . . Success in this seduction, as in sexual seduction, will be facilitated by the woman's longing for admiration, approval, affection, comfort and intimacy, and her readiness to deceive herself and make believe that she has found them in a stranger. As she succumbs and spends £50 on a cream with which she may caress her lonely skin, she tells herself, as L'Oréal so brazenly says: 'I'm worth it'."

Germaine Greer on women's ambivalent relationship with shopping, Express

"It might not be like that in fucking Middle England, but in Margate it's only a matter of time. It's not called rape. It is called losing your virginity. You got broke into. Germaine Greer got into terrible trouble for saying this, but someone who is 18, who's been walking you home, that's been snogging you, then pushed you to the ground and forcibly puts themselves inside you and you cry and you didn't want it to happen and it's the first person you've had in your life, and you keep quiet about it - it's still actually somewhat different from, well, I'm not going to go into any violent scenarios, but you can imagine."

Tracey Emin, London Evening Standard

"On the outside it seems like everyone in England is uptight, but actually they're not, they're a bunch of dirty wankers. My God, all you have is naked people in newspapers here! I can't get used to the naked Page Three girl, no matter how hard I try ... You know, I'm having my cup of coffee and I'm opening a newspaper and ... Uh! I mean, tits are everywhere here ... but really!"

Madonna on living in Britain, The Face

fields.headline: On leaks
fields.trailText: If Tony Blair is worried about the recent spate of leaked memos (Labour stung by new leak, July 19), he should take comfort from the Norwegian name for this time of year, agurktiden, or cucumber time.
fields.body:
If Tony Blair is worried about the recent spate of leaked memos (Labour stung by new leak, July 19), he should take comfort from the Norwegian name for this time of year, agurktiden, or cucumber time.

In Norway, everyone is on holiday and the only news is that the cucumbers are ripening as expected.
Judith Jesch
Nottingham
judith.jesch@britishlibrary.net

 So a No 10 insider fears that "the New Labour brand has been badly contaminated". No fears that part of the problem may be that they think of the party as a brand?
Nigel Blake
Byfleet, Surrey Letter

fields.headline: Love in an older climate
fields.standfirst: The recent claim that we hit our sexual peak in our 50s seems to be borne out by the likes of Honor Blackman and Jerry Hall.  Clare Boylan  on the joys of choosing nooky over knitting
fields.trailText: The recent claim that we hit our sexual peak in our 50s seems to be borne out by the likes of Honor Blackman and Jerry Hall.  Clare Boylan  on the joys of choosing nooky over knitting.
fields.body:
When asked what age a woman ceases to feel the torments of the flesh the Princess Metternich replied: "I do not know. I am only 65."

Last week Marj Thoburn, a 60-year-old marriage guidance consultant, rocked a youth-obsessed boat by stating at a conference that people over 50 were more likely to be at their sexual peak than those in their 30s. "Sex is not just for the young and beautiful," said Thoburn, who is co-author of The Relate Guide to Loving in Later Life.

Dear Marj! Surely not. Of course those high on oestrogen supplements or Viagra will be getting a second wind, but isn't it a bit like trying to use a tea bag twice?

"A mature wine is more rounded and full bodied than this year's pressing," Thoburn argues. But surely, with the exception of long-standing happy couples and lovely continentals with their baggy bedroom eyes, most middle-aged people have been pressed too hard and too long. Germaine Greer recently wrote that she now gets as much pleasure from her solitary bed as she once got from sharing it when young. One might think that for older people, sex would be an occasional and delicate plateful.

And one might be wrong. I recently met someone who returned from a Saga holiday to report that it was "hooching with sex", the clients having discovered the joys of a good time without the threat of pregnancy. In Elizabeth Jane Howard's splendid new novel, Falling, a 60-year-old woman has a wildly erotic affair with a man of 65.

Suddenly I am getting that strange feeling I got when, aged 16 and disguised as a woman in a thick tweed suit, I discovered that in another part of the world there was a wonderful new invention called a teenager. Here am I with one eye on the pleasures (and increasingly, on the psychology) of sensuality and another on the comforts of the thermal sock, but elsewhere, it seems, there are vast numbers of women of grandmother age, who are only getting to grips with their sex lives.

Of course, it isn't the same as for the young. The grannies are not in pursuit of love. They are gleefully gallivanting. One middle-aged woman described her amorous pursuits (conducted in teamwork, just like a teenager) as "rooting and tearing".

But what about the men? As middle-aged women grow restless and rowdy, middle-aged men become wistful and sentimental. Even those notorious old boys who are never without a babe usually want her more to testify to their sexual power than to test it.

For the women, it's not just a question of sex. Primarily they want some fun. Secondly, they are curious. They have grown up in an age in which - the 70s notwithstanding - many have limited sexual experience. Jerry Hall, just about to take over the role of Mrs Robinson in the West End production of The Graduate, admitted in an interview that in spite of having been married to the sex idol Mick Jagger, she herself had little sexual experience, having only had one boyfriend before she was married. "I'm dating men for the first time in my life and having a wonderful time," she said. Her new boyfriend is closer in age to Benjamin in the play (22) than her own age, which is 44. "I think women are in their sexual prime in their 40s and men are supposed to hit it in their 20s."

Honor Blackman, a startlingly radiant 74, is also sporting a sexy little number in the shape of a younger boyfriend. "Sexuality is either there or it isn't," she maintains, but the fact remains that older women can and do mainline on the hormonal munificence of a seductive youth and that boys enjoy the confidence and wit of older women. "I've always been told that I'm sexy," Honor Blackman says without an ounce of false modesty or doubt. "I like flirting and I hope I still will when I'm 90."

For older women, the pursuit of men is, in part, an education. Having used the vagina as a path to the womb, they want to see how it operates as a solo performer. In my short story, That Bad Woman, the central character, Jude, seeks a lover because: "I wanted my body and my mind to keep pace. It seems to me that the relationship is between them now, rather than with another person. They've been on different paths all their lives, bickering miserably with each other. I wanted them to make it up, and then to get on with things."

The sexuality of the mature woman is also based on redressing a power balance. Young women are vulnerable; older women are powerful and like trying out their sexual authority.

The American journalist Deborah Gimmelson wrote about this in The New York Times magazine in an article called "Forget equality - I liked it on top". Gimmelson picked up a youthful fitness trainer for her middle-aged treat. "There is power for a woman involved with a younger, less-educated, open man," she asserted, "power the way it has always existed for men in similar circumstances." She added that it was almost as heady as sex, introducing her lover to good restaurants, Broadway plays, important people whom he would never have met without her.

A friend of mine in her middle 50s, took herself off to the other side of the world to explore her creativity. While doing so, she embarked on a two-year affair with a boy of 19, describing it as the only relationship in her life in which she was wholly sexually uninhibited. Although it ended, she did not view it as trivial. "He was able to introduce me to a side of myself that had been repressed all my life, and I enabled his intellectual development. We had something to offer one another that no one else could have given." Nor did she feel in any way favoured by his attentions. "A young man feels privileged when an older woman chooses him."

This echoes the experience of 18th-century French writer and intellectual Mme de Stäel who, when over 45, chose very young men, who were "overwhelmed by her prestige".

But isn't there likely to be a horrible hangover of humiliation? Colette wrote a gut-wrenching story called The Kepi, in which a passionate affair between a young man and an older woman ends when she rakishly tips his little army cap over her aging forehead.

One woman friend of mine left her adoring young lover because he was too possessive. Grandes dames fatales want their freedom as well as their fun. The feminist Cynthia Heimel kept emotional distance from a juvenile admirer by referring to him only as "El Fabulo". The reality, it seems, is that true recreational sex is almost exclusively the preserve of the older woman. As Jerry Hall put it, "I'm in extra time now and I'm enjoying every minute."

There is much less at stake than for the young - no hungry womb begging to be filled, no susceptibility to manipulative or untruthful men, no domestic hankerings. And if the affair comes to an end, well, it would, wouldn't it?

© Clare Boylan 2000

"Sex is not just for the young and beautiful," said Thoburn, who is co-author of The Relate Guide to Loving in Later Life. Dear Marj! Surely not. Of course those high on oestrogen supplements or Viagra will be getting a second wind, but isn't it a bit like trying to use a tea bag twice? "A mature wine is more rounded and full bodied than this year's pressing," Thoburn argues. But surely, with the exception of long-standing happy couples and lovely continentals with their baggy bedroom eyes, most middle-aged people have been pressed too hard and too long. Germaine Greer recently wrote that she now gets as much pleasure from her solitary bed as she once got from sharing it when young. One might think that for older people, sex would be an occasional and delicate plateful. And one might be wrong. I recently met someone who returned from a Saga holiday to report that it was "hooching with sex", the clients having discovered the joys of a good time without the threat of pregnancy. In Elizabeth Jane Howard's splendid new novel, Falling, a 60-year-old woman has a wildly erotic affair with a man of 65. Suddenly I am getting that strange feeling I got when, aged 16 and disguised as a woman in a thick tweed suit, I discovered that in another part of the world there was a wonderful new invention called a teenager. Here am I with one eye on the pleasures (and increasingly, on the psychology) of sensuality and another on the comforts of the thermal sock, but elsewhere, it seems, there are vast numbers of women of grandmother age, who are only getting to grips with their sex lives. Of course, it isn't the same as for the young. The grannies are not in pursuit of love. They are gleefully gallivanting. One middle-aged woman described her amorous pursuits (conducted in teamwork, just like a teenager) as "rooting and tearing". But what about the men? As middle-aged women grow restless and rowdy, middle-aged men become wistful and sentimental. Even those notorious old boys who are never without a babe usually want her more to testify to their sexual power than to test it. For the women, it's not just a question of sex. Primarily they want some fun. Secondly, they are curious. They have grown up in an age in which - the 70s notwithstanding - many have limited sexual experience. Jerry Hall, just about to take over the role of Mrs Robinson in the West End production of The Graduate, admitted in an interview that in spite of having been married to the sex idol Mick Jagger, she herself had little sexual experience, having only had one boyfriend before she was married. "I'm dating men for the first time in my life and having a wonderful time," she said. Her new boyfriend is closer in age to Benjamin in the play (22) than her own age, which is 44. "I think women are in their sexual prime in their 40s and men are supposed to hit it in their 20s." Honor Blackman, a startlingly radiant 74, is also sporting a sexy little number in the shape of a younger boyfriend. "Sexuality is either there or it isn't," she maintains, but the fact remains that older women can and do mainline on the hormonal munificence of a seductive youth and that boys enjoy the confidence and wit of older women. "I've always been told that I'm sexy," Honor Blackman says without an ounce of false modesty or doubt. "I like flirting and I hope I still will when I'm 90." For older women, the pursuit of men is, in part, an education. Having used the vagina as a path to the womb, they want to see how it operates as a solo performer. In my short story, That Bad Woman, the central character, Jude, seeks a lover because: "I wanted my body and my mind to keep pace. It seems to me that the relationship is between them now, rather than with another person. They've been on different paths all their lives, bickering miserably with each other. I wanted them to make it up, and then to get on with things." The sexuality of the mature woman is also based on redressing a power balance. Young women are vulnerable; older women are powerful and like trying out their sexual authority. The American journalist Deborah Gimmelson wrote about this in The New York Times magazine in an article called "Forget equality - I liked it on top". Gimmelson picked up a youthful fitness trainer for her middle-aged treat. "There is power for a woman involved with a younger, less-educated, open man," she asserted, "power the way it has always existed for men in similar circumstances." She added that it was almost as heady as sex, introducing her lover to good restaurants, Broadway plays, important people whom he would never have met without her. A friend of mine in her middle 50s, took herself off to the other side of the world to explore her creativity. While doing so, she embarked on a two-year affair with a boy of 19, describing it as the only relationship in her life in which she was wholly sexually uninhibited. Although it ended, she did not view it as trivial. "He was able to introduce me to a side of myself that had been repressed all my life, and I enabled his intellectual development. We had something to offer one another that no one else could have given." Nor did she feel in any way favoured by his attentions. "A young man feels privileged when an older woman chooses him." This echoes the experience of 18th-century French writer and intellectual Mme de Stäel who, when over 45, chose very young men, who were "overwhelmed by her prestige". But isn't there likely to be a horrible hangover of humiliation? Colette wrote a gut-wrenching story called The Kepi, in which a passionate affair between a young man and an older woman ends when she rakishly tips his little army cap over her aging forehead. One woman friend of mine left her adoring young lover because he was too possessive. Grandes dames fatales want their freedom as well as their fun. The feminist Cynthia Heimel kept emotional distance from a juvenile admirer by referring to him only as "El Fabulo". The reality, it seems, is that true recreational sex is almost exclusively the preserve of the older woman. As Jerry Hall put it, "I'm in extra time now and I'm enjoying every minute." There is much less at stake than for the young - no hungry womb begging to be filled, no susceptibility to manipulative or untruthful men, no domestic hankerings. And if the affair comes to an end, well, it would, wouldn't it? © Clare Boylan 2000

webTitle: Delight at ban on war diamonds

fields.headline: Delight at ban on war diamonds
fields.standfirst: Special report: Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: Campaigners against the illicit trade in "conflict diamonds" - which is known to be funding at least three African wars - were yesterday celebrating after the diamond industry signed up to a radical plan to tackle the problem.
fields.body:
Campaigners against the illicit trade in "conflict diamonds" - which is known to be funding at least three African wars - were yesterday celebrating after the diamond industry signed up to a radical plan to tackle the problem.

The plan was endorsed by the world's two largest diamond trade groups and should see a global certification system for parcels of rough diamonds put in place by the end of the year.

The move is likely to cut off one of the biggest sources of funding for rebels such as the Revolutionary United Front in Sierra Leone and Unita in Angola.

Once the plan is implemented every package of rough diamonds will have to be shipped in a sealed bag and its contents entered into an international database. This will allow a new body, provisionally named the International Diamond Council, to ensure that only diamonds from legitimate sources are traded.

The plan, which won the backing of the International Diamond Manufacturers' Association (IDMA) and the World Federation of Diamond Bourses, has real teeth. Any trader or country found to be knowingly dealing in "blood diamonds" will face expulsion from the trade and criminal sanctions.

A joint statement claimed that the scheme "will immediately close off all the legal loopholes by which conflict diamonds may currently be entering the trade", and declared that it needed to be put in place "sooner rather than later".

The scheme will be funded by charging a minimal levy on the import and export of all rough diamonds.

"We don't want these people and we don't need them," Peter Meeus, general manager of Antwerp's Diamond High Council, which oversees the world's biggest trading centre, said. "Anyone who breaks the embargo will be banned from the trade."

The issue of conflict diamonds has dominated the three-day meeting of this most secretive of industries which has, until now, been singularly reluctant to admit that there is a problem. But intense, behind-the-scenes pressure from the US and British governments, which say they are determined to put an end to savage African wars fuelled by diamonds, has finally yielded results.

Earlier this week Robert Fowler, the Canadian ambassador to the UN, issued a stark warning to the industry and predicted that it would face commercial catastrophe unless it cleaned up its act.

The human rights group Global Witness which has campaigned along with other non-governmental organisations to stamp out the trade, was yesterday in buoyant mood.

"This is very, very important, since we've got the two main industry bodies working on the problem. The industry has been dragged kicking and screaming into the 21st century and has taken a real leap of imagination," a spokesman, Alex Yearsley, said.

"We are optimistically upbeat and believe that this is a step in the right direction."

The ground-breaking resolution, which was adopted at the industry's congress in Antwerp, was also welcomed by a broad coalition of non-governmental organisations which said they were confident that it would go a long way to breaking the illicit trade.

They were at pains to stress, however, that the scheme would need to be independently monitored, and that there should be solid progress on implementing the plan by mid-September.

Sean Cohen, IDMA's president and a key figure in drafting the plan, said that individual governments needed to enact legislation stipulating that they would only accept diamonds officially sealed and registered in the exporting country.

Crucially, the scheme also has the backing of De Beers, the South African diamond giant which controls 60% of the world's diamond supply.

The industry produces £4.5bn worth of diamonds each year, which feeds into a jewellery market worth some £37bn.

webTitle: Letters: Adam Mars-Jones responds to de Bono

fields.headline: Oh, de Bono
fields.trailText: I'm thrilled to learn (The thinker, July 19), that Edward de Bono remembers me after all these years - "some silly little idiot, trying to be clever". I myself hug the memory of de Bono's rationality.
fields.body:
I'm thrilled to learn (The thinker, July 19), that Edward de Bono remembers me after all these years - "some silly little idiot, trying to be clever". I myself hug the memory of de Bono's rationality.

When my review of Six Thinking Hats appeared, he wrote to the editor, suggesting that it was written under a pseudonym by someone who had never understood his work. Also that he was entitled to compensation for the loss of earnings which my comments had inflicted on his lecture tours (which he assessed at £200,000). He seemed less taken with my proposal that he pay a dividend to every journalist who, by taking him seriously, had inflated his earning power.
Adam Mars-Jones
London

fields.headline: Justice now
fields.trailText: Since the International Criminal Court will only have jurisdiction to prosecute future crimes (America won't help, July 18), many past violations will go unpunished.
fields.body:
Since the International Criminal Court will only have jurisdiction to prosecute future crimes (America won't help, July 18), many past violations will go unpunished.

Following the Indonesian military-backed massacres last year, a UN Commission of Inquiry recommended the establishment of an international tribunal for East Timor. If it is to be consistent, the British government must press the UN for such a tribunal.
Paul Barber
Tapol, the Indonesia Human Rights Campaign plovers@gn.apc.org

webTitle: Paris celebrates centenary of the metro

fields.headline: Paris celebrates centenary of the metro
fields.standfirst: The world's most admired underground system is still going strong
fields.trailText: "I fear no one will avail themselves of this new metropolitan", predicted a sceptical but unidentified alderman at a Paris city council meeting in 1896, "because no one has anything to gain by availing themselves of it."
fields.body:
"I fear no one will avail themselves of this new metropolitan", predicted a sceptical but unidentified alderman at a Paris city council meeting in 1896, "because no one has anything to gain by availing themselves of it."

He was wrong. Four years later, at 1pm on July 19 1900, without fanfare or speechmaking, the first carriage transported one lone passenger from Porte Maillot to Porte de Vincennes - but by the end of that year the number of journeys had reached 17m.

And celebrating its 100th birthday yesterday, the Paris underground - for many foreigners as much a part of the French experience as baguettes, bidets and Bordeaux wine - could make a fair claim to being the world's most loved, most efficient and least expensive city transport system.

Asked why visitors from London in particular tend to cite the metro as one of their abiding memories of the French capital, one senior city transport official, Vincent Relave, said bluntly: "Because it works."

But the metro is also cheap. A book of 10 tickets costs £5.50, while a monthly pass costs £26.90. The system's 14 lines, used by some 4.4m passengers daily, also have far more stations than rivals like London, New York and Tokyo. And the stations are clean and comparatively stylishly designed.

Even their characteristic aroma - a heady mix of singed rubber, day-old sweat, urine and Gauloise smoke - has a certain appeal.

"The metro is really something for this city to be proud of," said Robert Reyneau, 90, a retired driver who joined the service in 1937. "It's always been efficient. When I worked on line 4, Porte d'Orléans to Porte de Clignancourt, we had exactly 30 minutes and 15 seconds to complete the journey. If it took any longer, they docked our pay."

It took 20 years of wrangling between city and central government before work finally started on the Paris metro, considerably later than London, where the first line opened in 1863, New York (1868) or Budapest (1896).

The project was placed in the capable hand of the city's one-armed chief engineer, Fulgence Bienvenue, who oversaw the network's rapid expansion until 1932, when he retired aged 80.

When challenged to build the first line under the Seine, he came up with the novel idea of freezing the ground to allow tunnelling.

The early metro's other leading light was Hector Guimard, one of the creators of Art Nouveau, who designed the curvaceous, cast-iron "dragonfly wing" entrances to scores of the new metro stations. As part of its centenary celebrations, the Paris transport authority, RATP, is restoring 86 of his remaining masterpieces.

Other projects include a new exhibition of slides, videos and old rolling stock at the RATP's headquarters near the Gare de Lyon.

Nine stations are also mounting special displays on great themes of the century.

The station of Saint-Germain-des-Près is to be turned into a literary fair featuring the work of Left Bank luminaries like Sartre and de Beauvoir, while sports will be celebrated at Villejuif Léo Lagrange, the French film industry at Bonne Nouvelle, and the countries of the EU at Europe.

All summer, the RATP will run nostalgia trips for underground buffs, using the network's legendary Sprague rolling stock which served from 1908 to 1983.

And in a special gesture to Parisians, more than 1,000 of the capital's inhabitants who were born on July 19 were invited yesterday to a birthday party at Montparnasse-Bienvenue station. Proving either the metro's enduring popularity or Parisians' love of champagne, 2,500 turned up.

Route to success

Lines: 14

Length: 211.3km (131.3 miles)

Stations: 297

Budget (1998): £780m

Staff: 9,100, including 3,000 drivers

Ticket price: 8 francs (75p) or a carnet of 10 for 58 francs (£5.50)

Total journeys (1998): 1.3bn

Average number of daily departures: 5,500

Average number of daily users (1998): 4.4m

Deepest station: Abbesses (36 metres)

Busiest station: Saint-Lazare (32m passengers a year)

1903: fire kills 84 at Couronnes station; wooden benches replaced with metal ones

1910: Seine overflows, flooding most of network and affecting services for three months

1943: Allied air raid blows in roof of Porte de Saint-Cloud station, killing 403 people

1955: first pneumatic tyres

1968: first magnetic ticket-machines

1982: first woman metro driver

1991: first-class carriages abandoned

1992: Smoking banned - allegedly

1999: First unmanned line (No 14) opened

fields.headline: Volatile textile workers shake the calm of a French minister's summer
fields.trailText: It had been bubbling away for two weeks and hardly anyone took notice. The smell of burning rubber and the sight of 153 grim faces ensconced behind iron bars and barricades did not fit with France's new-found sense of well-being.
fields.body:
It had been bubbling away for two weeks and hardly anyone took notice. The smell of burning rubber and the sight of 153 grim faces ensconced behind iron bars and barricades did not fit with France's new-found sense of well-being.

Why should a small, bankrupt textile mill, built in an industrial no-man's land on the Belgian border and abandoned by a succession of owners, interrupt a cabinet minister's peaceful summer routine? The angry workers of Collatex were not deemed worthy of attention.

That was until someone decided to pour 5,000 litres of sulphuric acid into the stream under the factory which drains into the Meuse. And there was more to come: 46 tonnes of explosive carbon sulphide and 56,000 litres of acid. The Collatex workers wanted everyone to know they were sitting on a powder keg.

The acid never reached the Meuse but it did burn a hole through the headlines. The polluters of Collatex coined a new phrase to describe themselves: jusqu'a bout-ists - people who would go "to the very end" to push their point.

The industrial alchemy worked. As the world's media began to arrive, the local union official placed two yellow balloons filled with liquid on the burning embers of last night's fire. There was a loud thunderclap which knocked out the windows of the gatehouse. "Attention! That's just 15 grams of carbon sulphide. We have another 46 tonnes inside," he said.

The riot police were nowhere to be seen, and with an arsenal like that inside, they would have been outgunned. The union official conducted the rest of the interview from behind the red splattered bars of a window he had just smashed. "Of course we in the CGT [Confédération Générale du Travail] knew what was happening here for nine years. They bled the place to death. The last owners - Austrians they were - took off with all our customers. Now there's not a penny left," said the 42-year-old technician who was strangely coy about giving his name.

So there was no business to defend? "Oh no. I mean, who can compete against Korean or Greek viscose thread at 15 francs a kilo, when we in this factory can only produce it at 20 francs a kilo?" the union official said. A circle of comrades nodded sagely. "We are just here to make sure we get properly paid off. And if we don't, we'll blow the place up."

As he was putting the finishing touch to an argument as to why Collatex should close, pushing unemployment in Givet - already twice the national average - from 22% to 30%, a group of barricaded workers decided it was time for lunch, opened the gates and went home.

A smell of rotten eggs wafted over the building which everyone seemed happy to leave: "Look," said one. "I am a colourist. I have been working here 37 years. At my peak I took home between 8,000 and 9,000 francs [£754 to £848] a month. It wasn't bad. But now that it's bankrupt, the owners have left, and no one knows who owns the place, I just want a pay off. If the owners aren't here the state should pay."

There was every sign last night that it would. The employment minister, Martine Aubry, who said "one can't leave people without hope", was working on a package approaching the textile workers' demands of two years' salary plus a lump sum of 150,000 francs (£14,000) for everyone. Everyone from the préfet of Ardennes, Jean-Claude Vacher, on was said to be eager to parley with the Collatex workers.

The union man, still at his broken window, was more than pleased: "They didn't think the Ardennes was part of France. Someone phoned me up to ask me where we were. Well we showed them."

webTitle: US lends Africa $1bn to fight Aids

fields.headline: US lends Africa $1bn to fight Aids
fields.trailText: The United States will offer $1bn (£667m) in loans to sub-Saharan African countries to finance the purchase of American-made anti-Aids drugs at discounted prices.
fields.body:
The United States will offer $1bn (£667m) in loans to sub-Saharan African countries to finance the purchase of American-made anti-Aids drugs at discounted prices.

The move comes in response to sustained international criticism that African countries battling the epidemic are unable to acquire Aids-suppressing medicines developed in the US because of their excessive cost.

The new programme was due to be announced in Washington yesterday by James Harmon, the president of the congressionally funded US Export-Import Bank. It involves five-year loans to 24 eligible countries at interest rates of about 7% a year.

"This is at least a first step in showing the world that Africa is important to the United States and that we can make a dent in this terrible problem," Mr Harmon told the New York Times before the official announcement.

The European Union and Japan are likely to match the US announcement, Mr Harmon said, with the issue expected to be addressed at this weekend's G8 economic summit of the world's wealthiest countries in Okinawa. International loans of up to $3bn - the annual target set by the United Nations - could become available to African countries soon, he said.

The Clinton administration is reportedly divided about the wisdom of the move; some officials are apparently opposed to making fresh loans to Africa at a time when the White House is pressing a reluctant Republican-controlled Congress to write off up to $100bn in past lending to the world's most heavily indebted countries.

The move comes two months after five major multinational drugs companies agreed to cut the prices that they charge for drugs to combat Aids and the HIV virus in Africa.

"I think what the US is doing is laudable," the Ghanaian ambassador to Washington, Koby Koomson, said yesterday. "But the pharmaceutical companies need to come around and see that the only way to fight this pandemic is to donate whatever is necessary."

webTitle: UN warns of catastrophe threatening Eritrea

fields.headline: UN warns of catastrophe threatening Eritrea
fields.standfirst: Emergency aid appeal for more than a million people devastated by war and drought
fields.trailText: The United Nations is appealing for $87m (£58m) for more than 1.1m Eritreans displaced by the recent war with Ethiopia and ravaged by drought - a combination which the UN says has left the country facing "potential catastrophe".
fields.body:
The United Nations is appealing for $87m (£58m) for more than 1.1m Eritreans displaced by the recent war with Ethiopia and ravaged by drought - a combination which the UN says has left the country facing "potential catastrophe".

Eritrea is one of six countries in the Horn of Africa where the UN says 13m people are at risk of starvation as the result of this year's drought, part of a widespread famine which has remained largely invisible. Only in Ethiopia, where international aid was speeded up after the UN raised the alarm earlier in the year, has rain fallen in some regions.

Last week the UN's food and agriculture organisation reported "starvation-related deaths, especially among children" in Kenya's arid north.

Fighting between Ethiopia and Eritrea began on May 12, forcing more than a million Eritreans to flee their homes and sending nearly 100,000 people into refugee camps in neighbouring Sudan, Djibouti and Yemen.

"The total impact has been enormous - they've had a two-year war, some people have been displaced two, or even three, times," one UN official said yesterday.

A massive displacement of the population, particularly in Eritrea's western lowlands, disrupted farming just as the planting season was beginning. "The first planting season will be a year from now, and the harvest then some months down the line," said Ivo Freijsen of the UN's humanitarian affairs office .

"Eritrea is facing a potentially catastrophic situation, with large-scale population displacement and increasing impoverishment," said the UN humanitarian coordinator, Simon Nhongo.

"This humanitarian appeal will help to meet the country's most critical humanitarian needs through [to] the end of the year, but the disruption to agriculture and to the country's coping mechanisms means that Eritrea will need humanitarian assistance well into 2001."

The UN earlier in the year requested $42m for more than half a million Eritreans affected by war and drought, but the potentially disastrous humanitarian situation since the fighting in May forced the organisation's relief agencies to call for a doubling of the funds.

However, only 39% of the earlier appeal was met by the donor community, despite praise from the UN for the Eritrean government for hav ing done "an outstanding job" in trying to meet its people's needs. "It is rare to see a government so much involved and trying so hard," said Mr Freijsen.

People are beginning to return home from refugee camps, but they still face problems including demolished houses and a ruined infrastructure, as well as difficulties with food supplies.

Under the new $87m appeal, which covers several UN agencies, the world food programme (WFP) is focusing on some 750,000 Eritreans who will need more than 63,000 tonnes of food aid until the end of the year.

The WFP is requesting more than $40m for food, logistic requirements and improvements to the port of Massawa to ensure that food supplies move smoothly into Eritrea.

Other agencies involved in the appeal include the UN development programme, which needs $15.4m to provide tents, blankets and other household items. The UN high commissioner for refugees needs $13.3m to stabilise displaced populations and help them to return home.

Unicef needs $10.7m to provide water and sanitation, health, immunisation, nutrition, education and awareness programmes to the million-plus affected by the war. The UN population fund's $3.9m programme will provide maternal health care and aid general reproductive health.

Some $1.2m is needed by the world health organisation. The food and agriculture organisation needs $1m to provide aid, including seeds and tools, to farmers, while the UN office for the coordination of humanitarian affairs is appealing for $892,000.

fields.headline: The slimy slayer
fields.standfirst: An African relative of a garden pest has become a ruthless killer, reports  Maxine-Fay Miller
fields.trailText: An African relative of a garden pest has become a ruthless killer, reports Maxine-Fay Miller
fields.body:
Slugs are slimy, unpleasant and unwanted garden visitors. Worst of all they have a nasty habit of turning up where they are most unwelcome - on crisp lettuce, ripening strawberries and prize marrows.

In the forests of South Africa there lurk slugs far more menacing. No longer satisfied with a succulent leaf or an occasional taste of carrion, these beasts have transformed into ferocious killers.

Researcher Dr Dai Herbert from the Natal Museum reports in the Journal of Zoology that these killer slugs can attack, kill and feed on the well-armoured South African giant pill millipede.

This is no mean feat. This shiny armoured millipede can reach up to 4cm in length and owing to its bulk certainly out-sizes the slender slug despite its 6cm length when extended.

Pill millipedes have a superb defence mechanism. When threatened they roll up into a tight sphere to conceal their vulnerable head and legs. This rolling habit is only shared with a few other creatures including the pangolins, armadillos and pill woodlice (common garden visitors in Britain).

Furthermore, giant pill millipedes are covered with a tough outer skeleton or exoskeleton, which is hardened with calcite and forms a barrier to would-be-predators. The smoothness of the shell also prevents predators from getting a grip on them.

All other predatory creatures, save one, have tried in vain to pierce this hardened smooth coat of armour. Blue jays peck repeatedly at the rolled pill millipede and despite their sharp bills they cannot get inside.

Grasshopper mice, which readily feed on grasshoppers of their own size, take the millipede in their front paws but are unable to bite into the smooth shell.

Ants swarm over the surface and attempt to sting the shiny ball but with the millipede's head and legs safely tucked away the ants cannot secure a hold.

Only one other creature has been successful on feasting on this giant millipede. The strong and fast banded mongoose has a unique feeding strategy.

It picks up the giant millipede in its forepaws and throws it between its hind legs thereby smashing it on a rock. The millipede is fatally injured and its body parts are torn apart allowing the mongoose to feed on this tasty creature.

So, how does the slender, harmless-looking, slow-moving Southern African chlamydephorid slug prey on this well-armoured giant?

These forest slugs lie in wait under logs or stones or within forest soils. When a giant pill millipede passes nearby in its search for fragments of vegetation on the forest floor, the hiding slugs crawl onto their backs. They grip on for dear life like a cowboy riding bareback at a rodeo show. Instead of rolling into a tight ball, the pill millipede rolls over and over again desperately trying to throw the slug off its back.

During this 'Bronco Bill' display the slug uses dagger- like teeth on its radula (rasping tongue) to cut through a thin membrane between the segments of the jointed millipede. Presumably these are readily revealed as the millipede twists and turns in its battle to remove its jockey.

Once the tissue has been cut the slug injects a toxin from a special mucous gland to paralyse its prey. After a long drawn out battle lasting some 20 minutes the giant no longer struggles and is finally dead.

The victor slug slithers onto the soft belly of the millipede and penetrates the thin ventral (lower body) exoskeleton using its sharp teeth. Over the next few hours the slug feeds leisurely on the fleshy interior of its prey.

Now we can view our harmless garden slug with a new respect: their distant cousins in South Africa have developed into formidable carnivores displaying an incredible hunt-and-kill strategy to devour the tasty giant pill millipede.

We can be grateful that our slimy garden visitors haven't yet developed a taste for flesh.
