fields.headline: Science update
fields.trailText: Spider spins out of control | Moondust in the balance
fields.body:
Spider spins out of control
A parasitic wasp larva, growing hidden within a live spider, can control its host's behaviour with unprecedented precision, says William Eberhard at the University of Costa Rica, in Nature today. The larva feeds on the spider for days while it continues weaving webs and catching prey; but, when the larva is fully grown, it produces a chemical that compels the spider to spin a unique cocoon web - a tiny silk frame suspended by lines. The spider is then forced to the hub of the web, where the larva kills and consumes it before spinning its own cocoon, from which it will emerge as an adult wasp.

Moondust in the balance
In 1968, a tenuous, barely-visible layer of dust was spotted floating a few feet above the surface of the moon. Amanda Sickafoose at the University of Colorado reports in Physics Review Letters that the sun's ultra- violet light is knocking electrons off moonrock and dust, giving them a positive charge. Because like charges repel, the dust is pushed away from the rocks and hovers at the point where the moon's feeble gravity just balances the electric charge. Her experiment simulates the lunar surface with mineral grains in a vacuum chamber bathed in UV light.

Magnetic trout follows its nose
Auckland zoologist Carol Diebel has discovered how trout navigate back to their home rivers: they have tiny crystals of iron ore in their noses, she reports in today's Nature. The crystals, made of lodestone are magnetised and arranged in chains within single cells in the sensitive cells of the trout's olfactory organ, normally used to detect chemical traces in water, which trout also use for direction-finding. Many other organisms use magnetism to navigate, from bacteria to bees, lobsters and pigeons, but the exact mechanism is still unclear.

Adultery is good for the kids
Adultery is rife among birds. Some studies show that a quarter of all chicks are the result of a dangerous liaison. Now Arild Johnsen of the University of Oslo and his team report in Nature that bastard chicks have better immune systems than their legitimate half-brothers and sisters. He suspects that females pick illicit lovers with different immune system genes, thus increasing the genetic variation in their chicks and keeping them one step ahead of disease. The next step is to work out how the females can tell what genes males carry.

fields.headline: Teach for the sky
fields.standfirst: British schoolchildren are soon to get their own big telescope in Hawaii, writes  Duncan Steel
fields.trailText: British schoolchildren are soon to get their own big telescope in Hawaii, writes Duncan Steel
fields.body:
"What did you do at school today? "Steered a huge telescope to get the spectrum of a quasar, dad." That could soon be an evening exchange between parent and child, as school science projects move into a whole new stratum.

Planned for opening next year is the Faulkes Telescope, at the Haleakala observatory on the island of Maui in Hawaii. Sharing a mountain top with surveillance systems used by the US Air Force to keep an eye on spy satellites and the like, this telescope has a mirror two metres (80 inches) across. It is big enough for professional astronomers to be vying to use it in their research. But British secondary school education is its main purpose.

Dill Faulkes is an entrepreneur who made his fortune in the United States, but has long appreciated his education in the UK. To put something back, he set up the Faulkes Foundation, which is funding this new telescope.

Why Hawaii? When it's time for school in Britain, the sky over Hawaii is dark. After lunch, your children could be looking at the night sky on the opposite side of the globe and taking a trip through the Milky Way.

The Faulkes Telescope is designed as a robotic system. Instructions about where to point it will go via satellite to Hawaii from mission control, in this case the National Maritime Museum in London. All schools should be able to arrange access via the net.

This is not the only telescope of its type planned for British schools to use. The Faulkes Telescope is being built on Merseyside by Telescope Technologies Limited, a venture set up a couple of years ago by Liverpool John Moores University (LJMU). Three such telescopes are nearing completion on the factory floor in Birkenhead. One is for the government of India, to be installed near Pune. The second is for Hawaii.

The first off the line is the Liverpool Robotic Telescope (LRT), which will shortly be installed on La Palma, in the Canary Islands, where Britain and other European nations already operate a suite of telescopes.

Professor Mike Bode, director of the Astrophysics Research Institute at LJMU, has long dreamed of having available a good-sized robotic telescope that could quickly be pressed into action when the stars he studies suddenly flare brighter. These are called novae. The problem is that observing time on large telescopes is at a premium, with applications from professional astronomers far outstripping the number of nights available. Schedules are set months ahead, as they must be for the observers to book their flights to the Canaries, Chile or Australia.

What Bode needed was rapid response and continued monitoring, rather than just a handful of nights of observing time allocated months earlier. The obvious answer is a robotic telescope, which can be controlled remotely. That makes the operations much cheaper. The technology - including the Internet for transferring data - has only recently become available.

The design of these telescopes is compact and flexible, requiring little maintenance. Just as well if the astronomers are thousands of miles away. By having a tight design the building enclosing the telescope can be small, again cutting costs.

Rather than the conventional dome with an opening slit for the telescope to peek out, the whole roof folds down, meaning that the entire sky can be accessed, moving quickly from one spot to another. Sound like a good idea for an impatient group of school kids?

For the LRT, mission control will be on Merseyside, 2,000 miles from the telescope itself, although astronomers at other universities will also be able to use the LRT from their own offices. There will also be time allocated for projects nominated by schools, amateur astronomical societies and the like. Sure beats lining up to take a quick glimpse at the stars through a backyard telescope.

In principle, the Faulkes and Liverpool telescopes can be linked together, on opposite sides of the globe, and that would provide for near-continuous coverage, a feature which would be of great use to astronomers trying to follow the behaviour of an exploded star, say.

Realistically, to get continuous monitoring of a star you would need three telescopes spaced in longitude, so that it is always night time for at least one of them. And from the north we can only see half the sky, so a similar group of three would also be required in the southern hemisphere.

This leads to Bode's plan for RoboNet, a network of six similar robotic telescopes that could be operated individually, but when the opportunity arises they could be centrally controlled to provide uninterrupted monitoring of some celestial event.

When a supernova was spotted in the Large Magellanic Cloud (the closest galaxy to our own) in 1987 there was a scramble to try to correlate data collection amongst astronomers worldwide, with the result that some things were missed. RoboNet would make it feasible to keep tabs on the next such episode, or such transient phenomena as gamma ray bursters, and microlensing events (when an unseen object drifts across a brighter star and betrays its presence by altering the latter's brightness).

Much frontline astrophysical research requires very large telescopes, collecting the faint light from very distant objects. Although eight to 10 metre apertures are the current limit, there is already talk of much larger ground-based systems, and a new generation of telescopes in space. Currently there is debate concerning whether Britain should join the European Southern Observatory, a consortium of nations building a chain of four eight-metre telescopes in Chile.

The Liverpool Robotic Telescope and its siblings being constructed on Merseyside fulfill a different need. For the professionals, they will provide prompt observations of targets of opportunity as they arise, and longer-term coverage not feasible with the very largest systems.

They will give schoolchildren an opportunity to collect their own images of planets, comets, galaxies and distant quasars, bringing the universe of big science right into the classroom. For many British children, 2001 might well herald a space odyssey.

 Duncan Steel teaches astronomy and space science at the University of Salford.

The Liverpool Robotic Telescope and its siblings being constructed on Merseyside fulfill a different need. For the professionals, they will provide prompt observations of targets of opportunity as they arise, and longer-term coverage not feasible with the very largest systems. They will give schoolchildren an opportunity to collect their own images of planets, comets, galaxies and distant quasars, bringing the universe of big science right into the classroom. For many British children, 2001 might well herald a space odyssey.  Duncan Steel teaches astronomy and space science at the University of Salford.

fields.headline: What's new
fields.trailText:
Sony's palmalikes

Sony will launch its first Palm-compatible handheld computers in Japan in September - one with a colour screen, one mono -but they won't work as MP3 music players. The Sony devices are much like current Palm machines except that will take Sony Memory Sticks. However, they will not play music from Sticks used in the MS Walkman because they don't support the copyright protection system used. Sony's "personal entertainment organisers" also have faster processors, running at 20MHz. This will enable them to run video sequences, using Generic Media's player, at 4-10 frames per second. Sony is not saying when it might offer its palmtops outside Japan. However, rival "Windows-powered" (ie CE3 powered) PocketPCs from Hewlett-Packard, Coimpaq and Casio come with MP3-playing software built in.

Sony is not saying when it might offer its palmtops outside Japan. However, rival "Windows-powered" (ie CE3 powered) PocketPCs from Hewlett-Packard, Coimpaq and Casio come with MP3-playing software built in.

Ultimate video
Could the humble VHS video recorder follow almost every other type of device and go digital? Philips hopes so. It plans to unveil its first D-VHS recorder, the VR20D, at the IFA sound and video show in Berlin next month. Digital recording will provide a much better picture, Philips says, and up to 21 hours of video on a single tape. (Useful for those long holidays, perhaps?) The system should also appeal to digital videocamera users who will be able to make perfect transfers from their tiny tapes.

The little matter about which Philips remains strangely silent is, of course, the price.

Tiny transmitter

Tiny, the PC manufacturer, has launched a system that can distribute DVD movies around the house. The DigiCast gizmo consists of a transmitter, which is attached to a PC with DVD drive, and a receiver, which is attached to your TV set. The idea is that you can run a DVD movie on a PC in the study, say, and watch it in the comfort of a living room up to 50m away. It could also be a boon for families who aren't talking to one another...

Gateway leads

Gateway is now the brand of PC most commonly found in US homes, having finally overtaken Packard Bell, according to a survey by the American research firm Media Metrix. But Gateway, with 10.3% of the installed base of 55m PCs, is only a whisker ahead of Compaq, the world's largest PC manufacturer. Packard Bell, Hewlett-Packard, Dell and IBM follow on behind. In a separate survey, Media Metrix research shows a decline in Apple Macintosh ownership in homes from a high of 4.9 million house holds in January 1996 down to 3.8 million households in January 2000.

Lovely Clio

Two years after being unveiled at the Comdex computer show in Las Vegas, the award-winning Clio notebook computer is heading for the UK. The distribution of the latest Windows-powered version (ie it runs Microsoft's Windows CE3 operating system) has been taken on by A2000 Distribution (see www.pocketpc.uk.com). The unique selling feature is a SwingTop (sic) screen: it swivels so the Clio can either be used conventionally or as a pen-operated tablet computer.

fields.headline: Games watch
fields.trailText: Game Boy Gambit | Soldier Blue?
fields.body:
Game Boy Gambit
Palm organiser users can now run Nintendo Game Boy games, thanks to the $16.95 Liberty emulator launched on the web by Gambit Studios. The tricky bit is transferring the games from a Game Boy cartridge to a personal computer and from there to the Palm, which is undoubtedly beyond virtually all the program's potential users. As a result, pirated Game Boy cartridge code is likely to be circulated illegally on the internet, as is already the case with some other Nintendo systems. However, Gambit is keen to license games from software houses and make them available for a fee.

While the Palm has a bigger, better screen than the 10 year old Game Boy, it makes a poor emulator because of the key arrangement (it lacks a directional control pad), lack of sound and lack of speed. Gambit Studios therefore "recommends and sells Afterburner 3.0", an over-clocking utility that makes the Palm processor run faster.

Gambit says Liberty runs on most Palm OS 2.0 devices from Palm, Handspring, TRG, Symbol and IBM, if they have at least 16K of memory. Exceptions are the Pilot 1000, Pilot 5000, Palm Personal and Palm Professional "due to operating system display limitations".

Soldier Blue?
Soldier of Fortune, an ultraviolent PC game, has been classified as an adult movie in British Columbia, Canada, making it illegal to sell or rent it to anyone under 18. Mary-Louise McCausland, the provincial director of film classification, said that this was because the game's "depictions of violence against persons and animals are brutal and portrayed realistically and explicitly".

Hello Sydney
Eidos Interactive is publishing the official video game of the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games for the PC, Sony PlayStation and Sega Dreamcast. The game is being produced by Warwick-based software house Attention To Detail (ATD), which started the project with a fact finding mission two years ago. The game will include 12 sports from the 100m sprint to the Kayak K1 slalom via skeet shooting, superheavyweight weight lifting and 10m platform diving.

Class goals
Next term, more British schoolchildren will benefit from playing fantasy football in class, with Schoolmaster.net, an internet service and educational content provider, supporting the Schools Fantasy League. Manou Marzban says that "besides developing worksheets on player statistics and performance testing mathematical knowledge, Schoolmaster.net will provide worksheets that address journalism, language prose, geography and history." It will also provide supporting online services including email, chat and discussion groups. See www.schoolmaster.net and www.fantasyleague.com

fields.headline: E-booker
fields.standfirst: David Sefton is head of contemporary culture at the Royal Festival Hall on London's South Bank
fields.trailText: David Sefton is head of contemporary culture at the Royal Festival Hall on London's South Bank
fields.body:
In the last four years I've realised that the net to me is an incredibly useful phone book. I've been amazed at some of the people I've been able to track down via the net. People like Yma Sumac the legendary mock Inca performer, and Severed Heads, an Australian proto-techno band.

How do you use the net? I use it to buy records, find artists and as a way of accessing hard to find information. Recently I traced some obscure Luis Bunuel films through American video sites ( http://members.xoom.com/scatt/bunuel.html ). It took about three clicks to get there. I think I spend more money on the internet now than I do in shops!

Is e-commerce taking over the net?

One of the things that really annoys me is the junk email. The amount of stuff I filter out now is ridiculous - Lastminute.com I save a special place in hell for.

Are you in favour of regulation of the net in general? I am always reluctant to go down on the side of regulation of any kind. I wouldn't ever advocate any kind of censorship but I do still want to punch the guy that writes the Lastminute.com copy.

How vital has the net become to your lifestyle? Email is now the primary point of communication between myself and the people I work with. I hardly ever send faxes and I'll avoid picking up the phone whenever possible. I've put gigs on at the Festival Hall where the entire negotiation, technical and contract process has taken place via email.

Any favourite places on the net? Finding Severed Heads' homepage at www.sevcom.com was a joy. There's a great Simpsons site www.geocities.com/SoHo/Workshop/3255 where some guy's drawn his versions and scanned them in. I also like the work of John Kricfalusi at www.spumco.com who did Ren & Stimpy but gave it up because he felt he had more freedom for a cartoon site on the net. Credit where it's due, I'm a big fan of the Guardian Fiver newsletter. I think the NME is very good but I wonder why anyone buys the NME anymore as all the information is there two days before it comes out.

Where do you see the net going? This idea of the internet being the death of recorded and live music is similar to what people said about cinema when video came along. I actually think it will encourage more interest in the music. I've been very keen to welcome people in to do web casting and recently iGig ( www.igig.com filmed Blur for their site. I remain sceptical about the idea of truly interactive live entertainment but it will come.

Do you like the anarchy of the net? I do like the idea of all the biggest companies in the world sweating because 17-year-old kids are developing technologies in their bedrooms that could destroy their profit margins! I'd hate to see the net taken over by the multinationals so you had to start paying for everything. I don't want to see the net stop worrying people.

fields.headline: Games reviews
fields.trailText: Fur Fighters | Tomb Raider
fields.body:
Soft toys with hard centres

Fur Fighters Sega Dreamcast £39.99 Bizarre/Acclaim ***
This is more Quack than Quake, but Fur Fighters solves the problem of gore in third-person shooters: you just have to knock the stuffing out of your opponents.

The idea behind Bizarre Creations' game is simple enough: put serious fire-power in the hands of some furry toys. This is carried through in Rayman-like 3D cartoon graphics and punning humour. The more difficult aspect of the game is that you have to play all six characters - Roofus the hound, Bungalow the kangaroo etc - choosing the correct one for the task in hand. It's all a bit tricksy.

But this isn't just a shooter. It's also a 3D action/adventure game, and you have to solve lots of puzzles to get around the six game zones. Some of them are compli cated, so finishing the game could take a long time.

The worst thing about the game is the opening "train ing" sequence, which also fills in the back story. It goes on far too long. The best thing is the split-screen Fluff Match, which provides an arena where you can go fur-to-fur with a friend. Wicked. (JS)

Little Lara

Tomb Raider
Game Boy Colour £24.99 THQ ***
While a date with Britney Spears or a goal at Wembley remain largely unfulfilled teenage dreams, one fantasy has now become reality.

Lara Croft is finally in the palm of your hand. The PlayStation heroine has arrived on the Game Boy and is set to introduce a new format to the frustrating, yet satisfying Tomb Raider series.

Bearing in mind the limitations of the hardware, the game has gorgeous visuals with some high-quality stills for scene setting. Lara is particularly well animated and far bigger than a typical Game Boy character. She can jump, vault, swim and climb ledges without catching her breath.

Unfortunately the same can't be said for you. In their brave attempt to enable Lara to do everything, the developers have forgotten that mere mortals will be playing the game. The myriad scorpions, snakes and bats will cause little more than annoyance, especially as medi-packs are everywhere. No, the real problems are caused by spikes and gaping pits, which regularly scupper you after another unsuccessful tussle with the horribly stubborn controls.

These can be blamed on the ancient platform game, Prince of Persia. On the PlayStation Lara always was Prince of Persia 3D and now the series has gone to back to its 2D roots with predictably frustrating consequences.

Nevertheless, if you can master those controls, the graphics and rewarding plot twists make this a classy Game Boy title. So, until Britney returns your call, handheld Lara will do nicely. (GH)

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst:
Send letters to: online.feedback@guardian.co.uk
Please include a full postal address and telephone number. Short letters stand a better chance of being published. No attachments, please
fields.trailText: Your mail
fields.body:
Hanging on
It was interesting to read the letter from William Allen (July 13) and the methods to "junk" your sensitive email.

If you send emails from work it is likely that copies will be retained on their mail or other server(s). If you email from home your email will be stored on your internet service provider's (ISP) server. Copies are also kept on the recipient's server(s)/computers (ISP, work, home).

ISPs also keep backup copies of servers. So even if the data is deleted from the server, there is no guarantee that it has been eradicated entirely.

For those wishing to retrieve information there are many copies out there. Just because you can't see it does not mean it is no longer there.

A sobering thought!

Philip Keogh

PhilipK@pathology.leeds.ac.uk

Mock Opera
John Purser (Online, July 6) writes about Opera's ability to pretend to web servers that it is Netscape or Internet Explorer. While this allows its users to get around poorly coded websites that deny them access, it is also incredibly annoying for web developers.

If a browser is pretending to be something which it is not, then it makes it impossible to deal with any differences between it and other browsers in an intelligent way. This type of hack does nothing positive to solve the problem.

Stephen Dunn

stephen@cuica.demon.co.uk.

Threat to net

Richard Wild (Feedback, July 13) thinks some of the fears raised in Bill Thompson's article (July 6) "will not be realised" because the internet already exists, and "the standards cannot be changed".

The web was born in the early 1990s and to transport the data, a new protocol was invented called HTTP (hypertext transfer protocol). But TCP/IP and other protocols date back to the 1970s.

Microsoft and others have tried to gain a foothold with various new "standards" that layer themselves over existing protocols. One example is the failed "channels" scheme that was launched with Internet Explorer 4 and closely tied into the Windows 9x operating systems. "Channels" were an early attempt at an XML (rather than HTML) platform. XML standards are still to be finally and formally agreed, but all are open standards. Wap is not.

Yes, corporations could steal "the web" from us. They just have to invent something new on top (eg Flash from Macromedia). Case closed, job done. Luckily, it is the inertia of the existing data on the web that may just halt such attempts, and HTML may be a computer virus whose progress is unstoppable!

Gordon Joly

gordon.joly@gordo.uklinux.net

If, as Richard Wild says, it is impossible for a single corporation to "steal" the internet, then I might feel more relaxed about not being able to use First Direct's online banking service from Netscape, Opera or any browser other than IE running on Windows. To say nothing of the other "Internet Explorer Only" sites.

Microsoft is possibly the one corporation that could steal the web. The anti-trust case bought to light an internal email from Bill Gates on January 28, 1997, instructing staff that it would be the wrong strategy not to force Office users to use IE and to make unilateral extensions to HTML. He told them to patent elements of Microsoft's HTML rendering engine and make it extremely hard to clone. (See www.theregister.co.uk/content/archive/10603.html.

I assume that Microsoft's tenacious efforts to ensure that Internet Explorer is the only browser shipped with new PCs are directed at a wider goal of controlling both the browser and the server software used on the web.

Jim Hague

jim.hague@insignia.com

webTitle: UN rescues hostages in Sierra Leone

fields.headline: UN rescues hostages in Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: Backed by helicopter gunships, hundreds of United Nations troops mounted a rescue operation last weekend and freed 222 Indian peacekeepers and 11 military observers held by rebels in eastern Sierra Leone since May 1, UN officials and diplomats said.
fields.byline: By Douglas Farah in Abidjan, Ivory Coast
fields.body:
Backed by helicopter gunships, hundreds of United Nations troops mounted a rescue operation last weekend and freed 222 Indian peacekeepers and 11 military observers held by rebels in eastern Sierra Leone since May 1, UN officials and diplomats said.

UN officials said the international forces met no resistance in releasing the prisoners from a compound at the eastern town of Kailahun, a stronghold of the Revolutionary United Front (RUF). But, they added, a convoy carrying the soldiers and observers to freedom was later ambushed, leaving two UN soldiers slightly wounded.

The early-morning operation, involving as many as 1,000 UN troops, constituted an unusual show of force for the beleaguered peacekeeping mission in Sierra Leone, the largest such operation in the world. Reinforcements brought in since RUF rebels threatened to overwhelm the UN force in April have brought the number of peacekeepers to 13,500.

"At around 6am, the United Nations launched a military operation to free 222 peacekeepers and 11 military observers from the Revolutionary United Front," said a UN spokesman, Hirut Befecadu. "The operation in and out was very fast and we got everyone out OK. The operation was a success."

RUF rebels took about 500 UN peacekeepers hostage in April, leading to a breakdown in the fragile ceasefire signed last June to end a brutal eight-year civil war. The RUF stripped the captives of their weapons and uniforms and commandeered 13 armoured personnel carriers and thousands of rounds of ammunition.

The 500 peacekeepers were freed last month through the mediation of President Charles Taylor of neighbouring Liberia, an RUF patron. But since May 1 the Indian peacekeepers and unarmed military observers had been held in the Kailahun compound. The Indian troops, unlike previous hostages, were not forced to give up their weapons and uniforms. The UN was allowed to send the detainees food and medicine regularly, but in recent weeks the RUF cut off supplies. Somehow the detainees alerted the UN to their deteriorating condition, UN officials said.

Diplomats in Freetown said they hoped the operation signals a new assertiveness by UN peacekeeping authorities in dealing with the RUF, which is widely blamed for the breakdown of the peace process and the return to conflict in Sierra Leone.

"They had to do something and they finally did," said one diplomat. "They had been planning this for some time and now have a reinforced strength, so they moved."

fields.headline: Total elimination for Welsh hopefuls
fields.trailText: Welsh dreams in the Champions League were shattered yesterday as Total Network Solutions Llansantffraid were beaten 4-0 by Levadia Maardu of Estonia in the Tallinn national stadium.
fields.body:
Welsh dreams in the Champions League were shattered yesterday as Total Network Solutions Llansantffraid were beaten 4-0 by Levadia Maardu of Estonia in the Tallinn national stadium.

The League of Wales champions held Levadia to a 2-2 draw at Wrexham in the opening leg of this first qualifying-round tie. But the Estonians proved too strong in the return and were worthy of their 6-2 aggregate success.

Three goals in quick succession around the hour completed another night of failure for Welsh football.

The team from Powys showed their fighting spirit by holding the hosts until stoppage time in the first half when the Levadia striker Tomas Krom took full advantage of a misjudged Steve Evans clearance and coolly beat the overworked Lee Williams in goal.

It took 14 second-half minutes for Levadia to get a second, Juri Fenin pouncing on a Williams parry from a free-kick. Two minutes later the substitute Vladimir Tshelnokov hit a ferocious shot past the startled goalkeeper.

Further embarrassment followed as the TNS captain Tim Edwards sent a miskicked clearance past Williams in the 64th minute.

Rangers will meet Zalgiris Kaunas of Lithuania in the Champions League second qualifying round with the first leg at Ibrox next Wednesday.

Last night the Lithuanians lost 3-0 at Brotnjo Citluk of Bosnia but go through 4-3 on aggregate. They will entertain the Scottish champions in the return on August 2.

Wales's Fulham captain Chris Coleman has signed an extension to his contract that will keep him at the ambitious London club until 2004.

fields.headline: City's £6m Ehiogu bid hits snag
fields.trailText: Manchester City yesterday made a club record £6m offer for Aston Villa's Ugo Ehiogu only to find they might have to pay much more to secure the defender.
fields.body:
Manchester City yesterday made a club record £6m offer for Aston Villa's Ugo Ehiogu only to find they might have to pay much more to secure the defender.

Joe Royle is ready to double City's record buying fee but the stumbling block could be a sell-on clause inserted in the centre-back's deal when he joined Villa from West Bromwich as a youngster.

Although Ehiogu, 27, left Albion nine years ago after making only two league appearances, they reportedly stand to receive 50% of any subsequent transfer fee.

Last night Royle said: "We can only deal with the player as he stands. We've made our bid. Hopefully it will be accepted."

City's most expensive signing is Lee Bradbury, who cost £3m from Portsmouth in 1997. The offer for Ehiogu signals Royle's determination that their return to the Premiership will not be a brief visit.

Despite the contract complication, City may still face competition for the unsettled defender, although Sunderland are unlikely to be drawn into an expensive auction.

Peter Reid remains interested but may well opt for the Slovakian Stanislav Varga. The Slovan Bratislava centre-back impressed during a week's training with Sunderland, and would cost around £1.5m.

Meanwhile, Royle has pulled out of a move for Daniel Amokachi after a scan revealed the former Everton striker has a knee cartilage problem.

Nick Barmby, responding to the furore over his £6m transfer from Everton to Liverpool, insists he has no regrets.

"Yes, I can understand why the Everton fans are upset but I feel they have been wound up a bit. People have been stirring it," said the England midfielder.

"I have supported Liverpool since I was a boy, so this does represent a great opportunity for me. This is a professional and emotional decision. I know that tension is high in the area but I just have to get on with it now. I have never ducked a challenge in my life."

Gérard Houllier was similarly unimpressed by accusations that Barmby had in some way behaved dishonourably. "Are we talking about a change of religion here?" asked the Liverpool manager.

Liverpool confirmed that Houllier and his assistant Phil Thompson have now signed improved five-year contracts.

David Pleat, Spurs' director of football, has denied that David Ginola is moving to Marseille, who were said to be willing to pay £2.5m for the Frenchman. "We haven't spoken directly to anyone at Marseille. David Ginola will leave this club only if we receive £3m for him."

fields.headline: Brazil's coach feels the heat
fields.trailText: Pressure is mounting on Brazil's coach Wanderley Luxemburgo after his side suffered only their second defeat in a World Cup qualifier, losing 2-1 in Paraguay. The home substitute Jorge Campos scored a spectacular winner seven minutes from time after Rivaldo had equalised against the run of play.
fields.byline: Alex Bellos  in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
Pressure is mounting on Brazil's coach Wanderley Luxemburgo after his side suffered only their second defeat in a World Cup qualifier, losing 2-1 in Paraguay. The home substitute Jorge Campos scored a spectacular winner seven minutes from time after Rivaldo had equalised against the run of play.

The Brazil team, including the World Cup veterans Roberto Carlos, Cesar Sampaio and Cafu, were dominated by their modest neighbours for most of the match and are now an embarrassing fourth in their group behind Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay.

Luxemburgo had already been under fire after a poor 1-1 draw with Uruguay last month and a big question mark will surround his future if Brazil fail on Wednesday against the runaway leaders Argentina.

Luxemburgo, criticised at home for being arrogant and out of touch, had made five changes to the team that drew with Uruguay. But Carlos Paredes rose to head in a corner in the sixth minute, stunning Brazil and causing disbelief among delirious Paraguayan fans in the capital Asuncion.

Brazil were unable to find any rhythm and Luxemburgo changed his two strikers Franca and Djalminha for Guilherme and Marques at half-time. Even so, Brazil still stuttered until Roberto Carlos crossed to Rivaldo who scored with a 74th-minute header.

Campos left the crowd delirious with joy when he latched on to a long kick from his goalkeeper Jose Luis Chilavert, fended off two defenders and swept the ball past Brazil's goalkeeper Dida. But it left another nation in a state of trauma. "When will we get better? The team is still mediocre" ran the headline in the Brazilian paper O Globo yesterday.

fields.headline: Country cousins
fields.trailText:
Kasey Chambers
Borderline, London
* * *
fields.body:
Kasey Chambers
Borderline, London
* * *

Kasey Chambers is a 23-year-old New Country artist, from New South Wales rather than Nashville. She has already sold 70,000 copies of her debut album, The Captain, in Australia; now signed to Virgin UK, she's hoping to shift similar amounts here. For a star in the making, she has a reassuringly earthy presence, accompanied onstage by a four piece that includes her guitarist father Bill (referred to throughout as Dad) and brother Nash. Tonight she gazes over the packed crowd and gulps: "There's so many people here. I thought nobody knew me in Britain." When it becomes clear that most of the crowd is made up of raucous fellow Antipodeans, she begins to relax.

Sound problems bedevil the first few numbers, and a nervous Chambers starts her rural lament, These Pines, in too high a key. She then plays too slow and loud, until frenetic fiddle player Mick Albeck lifts the mood. The crowd is generous. "After all those stuff-ups you still clap," says Chambers. By the time she sings Southern Kind of Life, an ballad about growing up in a town "you could pass right through in 20 seconds flat", she has settled down.

Chambers has a clear-eyed, quirky take on country music, with none of the schmaltzy tendencies of her US peers. Her rich voice is alternately piercing and soothing, ranging from the unembellished country rock of Mr Baylis to the honky tonk hoedown We're All Gonna Die Someday. Assisted by Dad on a mean steel guitar, she does Woody Guthrie, bluegrass and even jazz swing, but her most resonant songs are the ballads.

This is where she comes into her own, when proceedings feel less like an urban barn dance, or Dolly Parton meets grunge. She performs Water in the Fuel, a heart-stopping song about a depressed truck driver, and The Captain, a shimmering ballad with an Irish lilt. "I thought I'd become unglued," she sings, of some unnamed trauma, "But I've got older now/I've got no time to cry." Even the noisy tequila drinkers at the back are silent.

At the Adelphi, Preston, tonight. Box office: 01772 897961.

webTitle: Dutch target Europe with 10bn euros offer

fields.headline: Dutch target Europe with 10bn euros offer
fields.trailText: Dutch telecoms group KPN Telecom will launch a 10bn euros (£6.2bn) share offer by December to raise funds for its expansion across Europe, according to industry sources.
fields.body:
Dutch telecoms group KPN Telecom will launch a 10bn euros (£6.2bn) share offer by December to raise funds for its expansion across Europe, according to industry sources.

KPN has stated its strategy to become one of the main European players in mobile phones, internet and data markets.

It is looking at buying out the remaining 50% of Belgian mobile group KPN Orange it does not own for about 1bn euros, according to analysts.

France Telecom inherited the 50% stake in KPN Orange, when it bought British mobile phone company Orange.

Regulatory requirements insist that France Telecom divest that half share because it owns a competing Belgian mobile phone operator.

KPN is also planning to splash out at least 4bn euros for a clutch of third generation mobile licences in Germany, the Netherlands and Belgium.

The group said it would also list its mobile telephone arm by next year. KPN Mobile is 15% owned by Japanese mobile phone firm NTT DoCoMo.

The listing of KPN Mobile was delayed after merger talks between KPN and Spain's Telefonica began in May. Those talks collapsed after Telefonica raised concerns about the Dutch government's 43.5% stake in KPN.

However, yesterday's announcement of a share issue, that may also include convertible bonds, should cut that government holding.

Dutch finance ministry spokesman Stephan Schrover said it was impossible to say immediately what percentage of the government's holding would be sold in the issue.

"We are going to participate in the offering because we have said in the long-term we would get rid of our stake," he said.

Further details of the share issue will be released on August 30. But analysts believe that the Dutch government would have to relinquish at least half of its 43.5% stake in the telecoms company.

The Netherlands has said it would sell its entire KPN stake by 2004 - but has so far refused to set a timetable for the disposal. The proposed share sale brought some speculation among analysts that it may reignite talks between KPN and Telefonica.

KPN has said it remains open to a deal with Telefonica. Yet the alliance KPN struck last week with NTT DoCoMo and Hong Kong conglomerate Hutchison Whampoa may complicate a future merger.

The alliance is aimed at pursuing and acquiring third generation mobile phone licences across Europe.

KPN shares tumbled on the share sales news yesterday. The stock fell 7.2% to 42.87 euros as investors feared an overhang of shares in the market that would depress the price.

The share issue will be aimed at institutional investors around the world and at private investors in the Netherlands, Germany and the US. ABN Amro Rothschild, Goldman Sachs International and Schroder Salomon Smith Barney will act as joint global coordinators.

webTitle: Equitable Life on sale after £1.5bn case

fields.headline: Equitable Life on sale after £1.5bn case
fields.standfirst: Equitable Life
fields.trailText: Equitable Life, the world's oldest mutual, has put itself up for sale after losing a £1.5bn House of Lords ruling this morning.
fields.body:
Equitable Life, the world's oldest mutual, has put itself up for sale after losing a £1.5bn House of Lords ruling this morning.

The giant insurer, which has more than 600,000 policyholders and £33bn under management, was forced by the Law Lords this morning to stand by guarantees made to 90,000 policyholders which will see their pensions increased by around 25%.

But in a shock announcement, Equitable Life says the cost will force it to sell the company. Equitable spokesman Nigel Webb said: "As a result of the ruling and in order to redress the balance to those policyholders without guarantees, we are going to seek a business partner to sell the business to and redress than balance. We have no choice."

In the final round of a three-year legal battle, the Law Lords ruled 5-0 against Equitable, forcing it to stand by promises made in policies sold in the 1970s and 1980s which promised them of a guaranteed minimum income in retirement.

Equitable policyholder Michael Simmons, a key figure in the legal battle, said this morning that the ruling will boost his pension payout from £90,000 to £115,000. "It's a great pleasure and relief, but sadness that the directors of Equitable Life have made such a pig's ear of the whole thing. I trusted them but was betrayed by them."

But the victory could spell lower payouts for the 500,000 Equitable policyholders without the disputed guarantees. Independent life insurance analyst Ned Cazalet said: "Santa Claus has not pitched up five months early. The guaranteed policyholders will receive higher annuities, but terminal bonuses will have to come down. There has to be an impact in terms of lower bonuses."

The court battle focused on 'guaranteed annuities' which were sold as part of pension plans between 1957 and 1988. The plans promised annuity rates of 11% a year, compared to the 8-9% common today. While other companies, such as Scottish Amicable, have paid out hundreds of millions of pounds to meet the guarantees, Equitable Life cut the valuable final bonuses of the policyholders instead.

This morning the Law Lords ruled that move was illegal, arguing that Equitable could not pay out differential final bonuses. It also refused to allow Equitable to ringfence the guaranteed policyholders from the rest of its customers.

The ruling will intensify speculation that Equitable, which has £33bn under management, will now be forced into a demutualisation and takeover by a white knight. The company has reinsured its guaranteed liabilities through ERC Frankona, but analysts point to its weak financial strength compared to other life insurance offices. Mr Cazalet said: "This could be a big issue for Equitable's solvency. It will make it weaker, but it can probably take the hit."

The company has reinsured its guaranteed liabilities through ERC Frankona, but analysts point to its weak financial strength compared to other life insurance offices. Mr Cazalet said: "This could be a big issue for Equitable's solvency. It will make it weaker, but it can probably take the hit."

webTitle: G8 seeks roadmap for digital divide

fields.headline: G8 seeks roadmap for digital divide
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: IT entrepreneurs yesterday presented world leaders with a so-called roadmap to bridge the digital divide between rich and poor countries.
fields.body:
IT entrepreneurs yesterday presented world leaders with a so-called roadmap to bridge the digital divide between rich and poor countries.

Amid concern that restricted access to information technology would widen the wage gap between developed and developing nations, businessmen presented a plan to the Japanese prime minister Yoshiri Mori, chair of this year's Group of Eight summit, which begins tomorrow in Okinawa. The document contains recommendations such as more funds to link up schools and libraries in the developing world.

The businessmen's blueprint - to ensure the benefits of IT are evenly spread around the globe - was drawn up by a task force created by the Davos-based World Economic Forum. Members include representatives of around 100 IT companies, think tanks and financial institutions such as the World Bank.

Mr Mori, a self-confessed computer novice, has already said he will announce $15bn (£10bn) in aid at the summit to train engineers and information technology planners.

Speaking in Tokyo John Chambers, president of Cisco Systems, said: "A commitment in action means a commitment in resources. The G8 certainly has to take the lead and I think the next two to three days will provide a very good opportunity to do that."

John Gage, chief researcher and director of Sun Microsystems, said many lives in the developing world could be saved if vital information about nutrition and health care could be distributed to the people by new technology.

WEF president and founder Klaus Schwab said IT could enable developing countries to catch up with the industrialised world. Richard Li, chairman and chief executive of Pacific Century Group, the third largest internet company in the world, said governments in the developed world had their own problems - they needed policies to close the digital divide within and between their own countries. It was announced earlier that Tokyo and Washington had agreed to spur competition in Japan's telecommunications market by lowering the interconnection fees that the state-owned Nippon Telegraph and Telephone company charges foreign telecoms companies to use its lines.

Four of the six industrialised countries that are above the OECD average in terms of internet hosts and secure servers - the United States, Canada, Australia and New Zealand - all have unmetered local internet access. Japan, with limited unmetered access, scores well below the average.

But with the subject of IT set to dominate the three-day meeting campaigners from the developing world were concerned that more pressing issues such as debt cancellation in Africa could be forgotten.

Pointing out that only one in 20 people around the world are online and that close to 60% of them are in the United States, Jubilee 2000, the network of charities, said that poor nations lacked the infrastructure, literacy and policies to support an IT revolution.

Ann Pettifor, director of Jubilee 2000, said: " To the thousands of children in the poorest countries who die each day of hunger IT training is irrelevant. They cannot eat cybercake. The G8 are in danger of insulting African leaders who have travelled from the other side of the wealth divide to tackle the cause of that divide - which is debt."

fields.headline: Alliance sees rivals closing branches
fields.standfirst: Post office banking 'makes extensive networks redundant'
fields.trailText: Thousands of bank branches face closure as a result of moves by the high street banks to offer more services through post offices, if predictions by the new head of Alliance & Leicester are borne out.
fields.body:
Thousands of bank branches face closure as a result of moves by the high street banks to offer more services through post offices, if predictions by the new head of Alliance & Leicester are borne out.

Peter McNamara, newly appointed managing director of A&L, calculates that banks needed no more than 600 or 700 branches if they were also offering services through the nation's 18,000 post offices. This calculation appears to have serious implications for banks such as Lloyds TSB and Barclays which have more than 1,500 branches each and are offering services through post offices.

Lloyds TSB and Barclays insisted yesterday that extensive closures were not on the cards.

Mr McNamara's calculation is based on retail customers and in situations where banks also offer business customers services in post offices.

Mr McNamara, who joined A&L in June from Lloyds TSB, used the calculation to justify his assertion that A&L did not have plans for sweeping closures to its 300-strong network or big job cuts, as part of the strategic review it unveiled yesterday to contain costs and improve profits by reshuffling its management.

A&L has now embarked on a programme to cut costs, further details of which will be revealed in October. It is due to report profits figures tomorrow which analysts believe will show it is feeling the competitive pressure in the mortgage market.

A&L has close links with the Post Office since buying the postal bank Girobank in 1990.

Under its strategic announcement yesterday, A&L said that small business customer accounts were to be rebranded "Alliance" - the name it uses in the retail market - rather than Girobank as part of its attempt to boost its 3% share of small businesses banking market.

The bank, whose new management team yesterday set out to woo the stock market with a new strategy, also intends to boost its share of the current account market, where it has 1.6m customers.

The announcement, just two days ahead of its interim profits figures, left the bank's shares 16.5p lower at 491p by the end of trading.

Marking the first strategic announcement since the sudden departure of chief executive Peter White last year, the bank is to start managing its business according to three customer groups rather than along product lines.

It also emerged that board member Trevor Hilliard, managing director of retail financial services will retire at the end of the year while Graham Pilkington will join from Lloyds TSB as director of personal customer services.

webTitle: Big spend may bring rate rise, says MPC

fields.headline: Big spend may bring rate rise, says MPC
fields.standfirst:
Brown's three-year plan: Bank of England warns chancellor against pre-election tax giveaways

Special report: the comprehensive spending review
fields.trailText: The Bank of England yesterday issued a veiled warning to the chancellor, Gordon Brown, that after Tuesday's bumper boost to public spending any pre-election tax giveaways would be met with higher interest rates.
fields.body:
The Bank of England yesterday issued a veiled warning to the chancellor, Gordon Brown, that after Tuesday's bumper boost to public spending any pre-election tax giveaways would be met with higher interest rates.

Threadneedle Street's rate-setting committee voted unanimously to keep interest rates on hold earlier this month.

However, the minutes of the monetary policy committee's meeting, published yesterday, revealed that the committee believes that private sector spending will have to slow down to offset the large increase in public spending if the Bank is to meet its 2.5% target inflation.

The nine-member panel had been given a sneak preview of the chancellor's public spending plans, and the minutes of its meeting revealed that some members feared higher government spending could increase inflationary pressures.

"Looking forward, given the likely increases in public spending over the next two years, private sector spending needed to slow further if the inflation target were to be met," the minutes noted.

Opposition parties said this was a signal that the MPC would respond to any demand boosting tax cuts with higher borrowing costs.

"Their comments make it clear that any budget tax cuts before the election on top of the existing spending plans would force up interest rates and hit jobs," said Matthew Taylor, economics spokesman for the Liberal Democrats.

But the Treasury denied the minutes amounted to a warning, noting that the MPC had pencilled in a slowdown in its forecasts when it was already aware of the overall impact of Mr Brown's spending plans.

"The MPC recorded their view in the last quarterly inflation report that the macro-economic effect of the Budget was unlikely to be large," a Treasury spokesman said.

Interest rates could also be forced up by rising spending. Yesterday's retail sales figures for June, released by the Office for National Statistics, showed that sales jumped by 0.7% during the month - a far higher level than City analysts had been expecting.

"These data provide ammunition for those MPC members who felt further increases in the repo rate would ultimately be necessary to press for another policy tightening at the August MPC meeting," said James Carrick at ABN-Amro.

But the ONS said underlying growth in retail sales was "much the same" as that recorded in May.

Sales were up 0.3% in the three months to June compared with the previous three - a figure which smoothes erratic monthly movements. That was only slightly higher than the 0.2% trend rate recorded in May.

But some City economists thought rates might be cut - thanks to the MPC's doves.

"For the first time we are getting suggestions that interest rates should perhaps be coming down," said Ciaran Barr at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell.

Signs that the world's largest oil producer, Saudi Arabia, has jumped the gun and started leaking some of the production increase of 500,000 barrels that the oil producers' club Opec has promised the west should also help ease the fears of the monetary policy committee's hawks.

Higher petrol prices have a been a major factor pushing up inflation in recent months.

The news pushed down oil prices on both sides of the Atlantic. In late trading yesterday the September contract for Brent Crude was off 30 cents at $29.02 a barrel, while August Nymex crude was down 44 cents at $31.50.

Industry sources said on Wednesday that Saudi Arabia was making good on its unilateral pledge to lift oil output by 500,000 barrels per day by already opening the taps by half that amount.

"The extra 250,000 are available for customers right now," said an industry source familiar with Saudi oil policy.

webTitle: Reveiw: The Witches of Eastwick, Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, London, * * *

fields.headline: Devilishly good fun
fields.trailText:
The Witches of Eastwick
Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, London
* * *
fields.body:
The Witches of Eastwick
Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, London
* * *

After a string of truly diabolical musicals, it good to find one that deals wittily and engagingly with the Devil. Based on the John Updike novel and the 1987 George Miller movie, this is an upbeat sexual fantasy about three smalltown women who sup and tup with an imagined Satan, and thereby find themselves strangely empowered.

What is most surprising is that this is really an old- fashioned book musical, in which Dana P Rowe's tunes grow logically out of John Dempsey's story. In fact, Dempsey and Rowe take some care to establish Eastwick as a gossip-ridden Rhode Island town seething with female sexual frustration. A sculptor, a cellist and a journalist are all longing for a man and find their prayers answered by Darryl Van Horne. But, though they fall under his spell and turn to witchcraft, they end up despatching the diabolical Darryl and discovering themselves anew.

A wild first half, which climaxes with the three women flying out over the heads of the audience like a trio of delirious Peter Pans, turns a touch mushy later on: lyrics like "Now I see everything I needed was inside of me" have a right-on correctness that sits oddly with the story's satirical verve. But, at their best, Dempsey's book and lyrics have a nice snap and crackle that evoke the lost art of musical comedy. "Jennifer Gabriel is a virgin," one of the Eastwick wives remarks of a local goody-goody. "I imagine her mother is too," comes the retort.

It may not be Oscar Wilde but it is a hundred times better than the verbal Polyfilla we have lately had to endure in musicals. But what really gives this show its style are Bob Crowley's superb designs and Eric Schaeffer's crisp direction. Crowley has created an American pastoral in the style of Saturday Evening Post, full of diminutive white houses and picket fences. Into this he inserts Horne's diabolical mansion - painted Rhode Island red and replete with Hugh Hefnerish fantasy beds.

And the ultimate collapse of the steepled church is in the great tradition of Drury Lane spectacle dating back to the Novello musicals and beyond.

The performances also possess the right buoyancy. Ian McShane as the devil may not have all the best tunes but, after a long absence from the stage, he overflows with energy and a leering, saloon bar smuttiness. And, amongst the three sex-hungry women, Maria Friedman is outstanding as the shy journo who finds her tongue unlocked by Darryl and who delivers her big number with the staccato speed of Danny Kaye. Joanna Riding is also sharply funny as the liberated cellist and Lucie Arnaz cracks wise as the leggy sculptor.

Rowe's music may be amiable rather than instantly memorable. But, in a genre that has become top heavy with portentous spectacle, this show gaily reminds us of the musical's traditional mission to delight and divert. Though it may fall off a bit in the second half, it is the best devil invoking musical since Damn Yankees.

Booking to March 2001. Box office: 020-7494 5000.

webTitle: Review: Proms - BBC National Orchestra of Wales/ Benjamin, Royal Albert Hall, * * *

fields.headline: Baroque moderne
fields.trailText:
BBC National Orchestra of Wales/Benjamin
Royal Albert Hall, London
* * *
fields.body:
BBC National Orchestra of Wales/Benjamin
Royal Albert Hall, London
* * *

The Proms are celebrating the 250th anniversary of Bach's death not only in performances of his music but in some of the commissioned works too. Julian Yu's Not a Stream but an Ocean, borrowing Beethoven's punning description of his great predecessor for its title and given its premiere in the Welsh orchestra's first appearance of the season, was designed as an explicit homage; the final section of this 17-minute work is a mélange of Bachian themes - from the Art of Fugue, the Musical Offering, among many other works - to surmount an argument that is based upon the quintessentially baroque form of the passacaglia.

Yu, born in China in 1957 but now an Australian resident, is clearly an expert orchestrator. His music bears few traces of his oriental origins, though the wispy, shimmering opening of this piece suggests that Takemitsu at least is part of his stylistic background. It began very promisingly, and though not earth-shatteringly original, it was well paced and proportioned, with the workings of the theme easy to follow. It was, however, self-sufficient; the sudden influx of Bach seemed just to have been added on rather than integrated.

George Benjamin conducted the premiere, placed in a programme that also included a second London performance of his own Palimpsest, and otherwise very much reflected his own musical allegiances. There was Debussy to begin and Stravinsky to end, with a dazzling performance of Messiaen's Oiseaux Exotiques in between.

webTitle: Vindication for Dye as P&D fund wins top spot

fields.headline: Vindication for Dye as P&D fund wins top spot
fields.trailText: Phillips & Drew reclaimed its position at the top of the pension fund performance tables yesterday, in a bitter twist of irony for Tony Dye, the firm's investment head who endured the criticism for its poor performance over recent years before leaving in March.
fields.body:
Phillips & Drew reclaimed its position at the top of the pension fund performance tables yesterday, in a bitter twist of irony for Tony Dye, the firm's investment head who endured the criticism for its poor performance over recent years before leaving in March.

Mr Dye was one of the first City investment managers to call the market's peak - more than three years ago - and be a strong sceptic of the sharp rises in technology and dot.com stocks in recent months.

Yesterday P&D explained its rise to pole position in the three months to June with a 6.4% return for investors as a result of the improving fortunes of the "old economy stocks" and the "collapse" of the technology sector. As an example, it avoided the troubled stock market flotation of Lastminute.com but instead snapped shares in "old economy" travel agent Thomson Travel which later received a takeover bid, boosting its shares.

The improving fortunes of P&D, part of Swiss bank UBS, came as pension funds suf fered their worst performance period for more than five years in the first half of 2000, raising fears that companies will have to dig into their pockets to bolster final salary schemes.

According to the much-watched figures compiled by combined actuarial performance services (Caps), the average company pension fund produced a return of -0.6% in the second quarter of this year, hard on the heels of a 0.4% decline in the first quarter.

The last time that pension funds saw two successive negative quarters was in the first half of 1994, the worst year in the 1990s for investment returns.

A Caps spokeswoman said: "There has been a reversal in the fortunes of the top performers. Nine of the top 10 funds from quarter one appear in the bottom third in quarter two."

The drop in second quarter returns comes after five years in which gains for the £700bn pension fund industry have averaged 14%-15% per annum. As a result, nearly one-third of pension funds are enjoying large surpluses, allowing them to take "pension holidays", saving employers millions of pounds in contributions.

webTitle: Britain may lose power base in Fifa

fields.headline: Britain may lose power base in Fifa
fields.trailText: Britain's influence in world football may be further eroded by a move to restructure Fifa's executive commitee.
fields.body:
Britain's influence in world football may be further eroded by a move to restructure Fifa's executive commitee.

The automatic right to have a British representative among the seven vice-presidents on the world governing body's executive will be challenged at next month's annual congress in Zurich.

The privilege, rotated among the four home associations and currently held by Scotland's David Will, has attracted growing resentment in recent years. Britain has traditionally held this right in recognition of its historic place in the sport. But many associations see the privilege as outdated.

Four Caribbean federations from the Concacaf region, ironically the only bloc to back England in the recent 2006 World Cup vote, have placed a proposal before the meeting on August 4-5 saying that British representation should be abolished and the vice-presidency should revert to Uefa, Europe's governing body.

The move is unlikely to win unanimous support among the 203 Fifa-affiliated national associations. But if it does go through it will further undermine the standing of the British associations within football's corridors of power.

Lack of influence within Fifa and Uefa was highlighted as one of the main reasons for England's dismal showing in the World Cup vote.

The Football Association chairman Geoff Thompson was recently elected to the executive committee of Uefa but the chances of building on that would suffer without automatic access to a position on the Fifa executive.

At the congress the Oceania confederation must find a replacement for Charles Dempsey, the New Zealander who resigned his post on the Fifa executive after abstaining from the crucial World Cup vote.

webTitle: Sergen turns to the mouth of the Tyne

fields.headline: Sergen turns to the mouth of the Tyne
fields.trailText: Bobby Robson's next signing for Newcastle will be Turkey's Sergen Yalcin, according to the chairman of the midfielder's current club.
fields.body:
Bobby Robson's next signing for Newcastle will be Turkey's Sergen Yalcin, according to the chairman of the midfielder's current club.

Sergen, an influential member of the Galatasaray team that overcame Arsenal to win the Uefa Cup, is reportedly on his way to Tyneside in a £4m deal after the fee was agreed with Newcastle officials yesterday.

Takiddin Yarayan, chairman of Sergen's club Jet-Pa Spor, who loaned him to Galatasaray, said last night: "We reached a consensus on the transfer after today's meeting."

Nevertheless there appear to be several complications to the projected deal, not least Sergen's long reputation for outspokenness.

Although the 27-year-old is still on loan to Galatasaray, he fell out with officials of the Uefa Cup winners and soon after their May triumph in Copenhagen returned to Jet-Pa, a team from Siirt in Turkey's impoverished south-east who will play in the first division next season.

Sergen, who appeared for his country in Euro 2000, then angered Turkey's coach Mustafa Denizli by publicly criticising his tactics during the championship.

Leicester's manager Peter Taylor is close to offsetting the loss of Emile Heskey with the power of Ade Akinbiyi after Wolves accepted the Premiership club's improved £5m offer for the striker.

Although the 25-year-old Akinbiyi has yet to agree personal terms, he hinted strongly that he would move across the Midlands and up a division. "I think anyone would be mad if they were not after Premiership football. That is one of my ambitions, to play in the Premiership."

If he joins Leicester, Akinbiyi will take Taylor's spending towards £11m after he signed Gary Rowett, Callum Davidson, Simon Royce and Trevor Benjamin since taking charge at Filbert Street last month.

Everton's manager Walter Smith will today make his third signing in six days when the Swedish international Niclas Alexandersson completes his £2.5m move from Sheffield Wednesday.

The midfielder admitted Smith's gamble on Paul Gascoigne was an added attraction about staying in the Premiership with Everton. He said: "Gazza is known all over the world. We have all seen what he can do at his best and we all hope he can do the same here. It will be very nice to play in the same team as him if he does."

Mark Viduka was left kicking his heels last night as a decision on his work permit appeal was delayed. Leeds have been told to expect a verdict by the end of the week, leaving the Australian striker's £6m move from Celtic still on hold.

Mark Draper has completed his £1.25m switch from Aston Villa to Southampton after passing a medical at the Dell. He has signed a four-year contract.

webTitle: Hussain ventures but fails to gain

fields.headline: Hussain ventures but fails to gain
fields.standfirst: The England captain would have been better off staying at home
fields.trailText: The England captain would have been better off staying at home, writes Paul Weaver.
fields.body:
It is not certain whether Nasser Hussain sells the Big Issue outside Waterloo station or has his name down for a council flat but in the course of this NatWest series he has worn the disconsolate expression of the homeless.

The England captain has been seen in London, Manchester and Durham but on each occasion, despite a plaintive countenance, he has had no success whatsoever in putting a dressing-room roof over his head.

Out of the side with a cracked thumb for almost four weeks, he has mooched about on the periphery and squatted on the balcony, his wan face pressed against the window to watch all the hearty cheer within led, invariably, by the former England captain Alec Stewart.

Yesterday, however, a fit-again Hussain led England once more. Perhaps this was a response to the news that a noise-abatement notice had been slapped on the owners of Edgbaston. You can rock your baby into the land of nod when Hussain is at the wicket.

He has proved a bright and determined captain and a vast improvement on the rather one-dimensional, unimaginative administrations that preceded his, including Stewart's.

The trouble is he is not a natural one-day player. Whenever he tries to increase the tempo he crashes the gears. He can be a brilliant fielder but as a batsman he should play at the top of the order. If he plays at all.

In South Africa and Zimbabwe in the winter he and Nick Knight looked a half-decent opening partnership. If the others can bat around him, as they once did around Michael Atherton, a case can be made for his inclusion.

But England's openers are playing well at the moment and here he had to be shoehorned into the team at the expense of Matthew Maynard. This England side is unusual in that its main strikers, Andrew Flintoff and Graeme Hick, bat at No3 and No4. It has the look of boom and bust.

Hussain came to the wicket when England were 166 for four in the 36th over, which is normally the time when the sloggers come into play, the Ealhams, Whites and Flintoffs. To be fair to Hussain he was no slouch on this occasion. He scored 34 from only 37 deliveries. At least, I think that's what he made. The new scoreboard at Edgbaston resembles some cheap new personal organiser. You don't know where to look for the information and when you find it you can't read it.

Hitting out for Hussain, though, often means getting out and he was fortunate to be dropped when he had scored seven and again on 20 before he was caught at long-off.

Hussain may have tossed up but Stewart remained The Gaffer, bossing the innings with his first one-day hundred since 1997. He is no tactical genius but Stewart has led from the front in this series.

Hussain is having an abysmal season with the bat and it is important that he gets as much time in the middle as possible before the Tests against West Indies resume at Old Trafford next month.

The England captain would have shown greater self-confidence in his job if he had told Stewart to carry on and win the one-day pot while he returned to Chelmsford, where he might have had more time to rediscover his form against Worcestershire in the championship match that starts today.

Duff county pitches may not be ideal for Test players to find their touch but Hussain needs as much time in the middle as possible. And in Chelmsford he will always have a roof over his head.

fields.headline: Stewart's one-man show fires England
fields.standfirst:
Zimbabwe outclassed as Hussain's men hit their straps at the right time
England 262 for 8 (50 overs)
Zimbabwe 210 for 9 (50 overs)
England won by 52 runs
fields.trailText: The adage "give a job to a busy man" might have been designed for Alec Stewart. To bail out England with a temporary return to the captaincy was impressive enough, but to hand back the role yesterday with his batting form enhanced, and Zimbabwe heading for an overwhelming defeat as a consequence, was extraordinary.
fields.body:
The adage "give a job to a busy man" might have been designed for Alec Stewart. To bail out England with a temporary return to the captaincy was impressive enough, but to hand back the role yesterday with his batting form enhanced, and Zimbabwe heading for an overwhelming defeat as a consequence, was extraordinary.

Stewart passed the first three weeks of the NatWest series loyally fulfilling the role as stop-gap England captain, a job from which he was dismissed last summer after taking the blame for a faulty World Cup campaign.

That England dared even ask him to help out after Nasser Hussain cracked a thumb was testimony to his unbending team ethic. That he should be invigorated enough, at 37, to rediscover his batting touch at the same time, exemplified by his third one-day hundred, was a bonus they dared not have imagined.

One day, deep into this century, a scientist will discover that Stewart is really a robot, a flawless prototype designed for a hectic sporting lifestyle.

To operate successfully, he needs tasks, and lots of them: wicketkeeper, opening batsman, captaincy. That plus lots of practice sessions, runs around the block and an annual change of oil. Stewart, as hard-pressed as he is, is best suited to one-day opening, for he is primarily a shot-maker. He was at his best yesterday when he subtly made room to strike Zimbabwe's seam bowlers through the offside. He scores runs as he talks: crisp, clipped and to the point.

His last one-day century came three years ago, against India in Sharjah. Heath Streak will vow that he was fortunate to add to it yesterday - Stewart was 16 when he edged Streak between a motionless wicketkeeper, Andy Flower, and first slip, Alistair Campbell - but the statistics will show 101 from 144 balls, an innings ended in the 46th over when Dirk Viljoen yorked him leg stump.

England's progress towards an overwhelming victory was fashioned in the field in one over by Graeme Hick. His 110 one-dayers have averaged a wicket every four games, which makes his fourth over quite a collector's item. When he last bowled against Zimbabwe in Harare at the end of England's winter tour, he took five against them.

Neil Johnson paddled his second ball over Stewart, who turned to catch it; Stewart then held a faint edge as Stuart Carlisle poked at the next, unerringly straight, delivery; and Murray Goodwin was run out on the last ball when Campbell shunned his call for a single to square leg.

Campbell's show of despair, as he flung his helmet and gloves to the floor and hung his head in his hands, encouraged a 14,000 crowd to adopt him as fall-guy. They were more delighted six overs later when he risked a dubious second to Mark Ealham at deep square and ran out Grant Flower.

Craig White, again operating around the wicket to the left-handers, then left Andy Flower and Viljoen off the wicket to leave Zimbabwe 123 for six, and Stewart happily occupied with two more catches.

Andy Flower's ropey wicketkeeping, so apparent in the Test series, has extended to the one-day matches. Andrew Flintoff also benefited from a Flower-Campbell still-life as another edge off Streak whistled between them without so much as a gesture. Add Neil Johnson's bad miss at slip when Flintoff edged Pommie Mbangwa and Zimbabwe, normally the slickest of fielding sides, had missed three opportunities in as many overs.

Flintoff, caught at the wicket after 24 from 28 balls, had been retained at No3 and had ridden his luck. Hick fell second ball for nought, and Graham Thorpe stabilised matters before Hussain made a delayed reappearance at No6.

There was time enough for him to discover a semblance of form with 34 from 37 balls, although even that was assisted by two further let-offs in the field, both difficult catches in the ring to Carlisle. The chances of Zimbabwe fielding as badly again in Saturday's final at Lord's are virtually non-existent.

Hussain was on hand at the non-striker's end, suitably, as exuberant applause rang out for Stewart's hundred. He responded with a dutiful and precise thank-you to all corners of the ground - even this was done meticulously.
