webTitle: In the Heart of the Sea: the Epic True Story that Inspired Moby Dick by Nathaniel Philbrick

fields.headline: In the Heart of the Sea: the Epic True Story that Inspired Moby Dick by Nathaniel Philbrick
fields.trailText: It was, he later remembered, "the most pleasing moment of my life" - the moment he stepped aboard the whaleship Essex for the first time. He was fourteen years old, with a broad nose and an open, eager face, and like every other Nantucket boy, he'd been taught to "idolize the form of a ship." The Essex might not look like much, stripped of her rigging and chained to the wharf, but for Thomas Nickerson she was a vessel of opportunity. Finally, after what had seemed an endless wait, Nickerson was going to sea.
fields.body:
Chapter one: Nantucket (part one)

It was, he later remembered, "the most pleasing moment of my life" - the moment he stepped aboard the whaleship Essex for the first time. He was fourteen years old, with a broad nose and an open, eager face, and like every other Nantucket boy, he'd been taught to "idolize the form of a ship." The Essex might not look like much, stripped of her rigging and chained to the wharf, but for Thomas Nickerson she was a vessel of opportunity. Finally, after what had seemed an endless wait, Nickerson was going to sea.
The hot July sun beat down on her old, oil-soaked timbers until the temperature below was infernal, but Nickerson explored every cranny, from the brick altar of the tryworks being assembled on deck to the lightless depths of the empty hold. In between was a creaking, compartmentalized world, a living thing of oak and pine that reeked of oil, blood, tobacco juice, food, salt, mildew, tar, and smoke. "[B]lack and ugly as she was," Nickerson wrote, "I would not have exchanged her for a palace."
In July of 1819 the Essex was one of a fleet of more than seventy Nantucket whaleships in the Pacific and Atlantic Oceans. With whale-oil prices steadily climbing and the rest of the world's economy sunk in depression, the village of Nantucket was on its way to becoming one of the richest towns in America.
The community of about seven thousand people lived on a gently sloping hill crowded with houses and topped by windmills and church towers. It resembled, some said, the elegant and established port of Salem-a remarkable compliment for an island more than twenty miles out into the Atlantic, below Cape Cod. But if the town, high on its hill, radiated an almost ethereal quality of calm, the waterfront below bustled with activity. Sprouting from among the long, low warehouses and ropewalks, four solid-fill wharves reached out more than a hundred yards into the harbor. Tethered to the wharves or anchored in the harbor were, typically, fifteen to twenty whaleships, along with dozens of smaller vessels, mainly sloops and schooners, that brought trade goods to and from the island. Each wharf, a labyrinth of anchors, try-pots, spars, and oil casks, was thronged with sailors, stevedores, and artisans. Two-wheeled, horse-drawn carts known as calashes continually came and went.
It was a scene already familiar to Thomas Nickerson. The children of Nantucket had long used the waterfront as their playground. They rowed decrepit whaleboats up and down the harbor and clambered up into the rigging of the ships. To off-islanders it was clear that these children were a "distinctive class of juveniles, accustomed to consider themselves as predestined mariners.... They climbed ratlines like monkeys-little fellows of ten or twelve years-and laid out on the yardarms with the most perfect nonchalance." The Essex might be Nickerson's first ship, but he had been preparing for the voyage almost his entire life.
He wasn't going alone. His friends Barzillai Ray, Owen Coffin, and Charles Ramsdell, all between the ages of fifteen and eighteen, were also sailing on the Essex. Owen Coffin was the cousin of the Essex's new captain and probably steered his three friends to his kinsman's ship. Nickerson was the youngest of the group.
The Essex was old and, at 87 feet long and 238 tons displacement, quite small, but she had a reputation on Nantucket as a lucky ship. Over the last decade and a half, she had done well by her Quaker owners, regularly returning at two-year intervals with enough oil to make them wealthy men. Daniel Russell, her previous captain, had been successful enough over the course of four voyages to be given command of a new and larger ship, the Aurora. Russell's promotion allowed the former first mate, George Pollard, Jr., to take over command of the Essex, and one of the boatsteerers (or harpooners), Owen Chase, to move up to first mate. Three other crew members were elevated to the rank of boatsteerer. Not only a lucky but apparently a happy vessel, the Essex was, according to Nickerson, "on the whole rather a desirable ship than otherwise."
Since Nantucket was, like any seafaring town of the period, a community obsessed with omens and signs, such a reputation counted for much. Still, there was talk among the men on the wharves when earlier that July, as the Essex was being repaired and outfitted, a comet appeared in the night sky. Nantucket was a town of roof dwellers. Nearly every house, its shingles painted red or left to weather into gray, had a roof-mounted platform known as a walk. While its intended use was to facilitate putting out chimney fires with buckets of sand, the walk was also an excellent place to look out to sea with a spyglass, to search for the sails of returning ships. At night, the spyglasses of Nantucket were often directed toward the heavens, and in July of 1819, islanders were looking toward the northwest sky. The Quaker merchant Obed Macy, who kept meticulous records of what he determined were the "most extraordinary events" in the life of his island, watched the night sky from his house on Pleasant Street. "The comet (which appears every clear night) is thought to be very large from its uncommonly long tail," he wrote, "which extends upward in opposition to the sun in an almost perpendicular direction and heaves off to the eastward and nearly points for the North Star."
From earliest times, the appearance of a comet was interpreted as a sign that something unusual was about to happen. The New Bedford Mercury, the newspaper Nantucketers read for lack of one of their own, commented, "True it is, that the appearance of these eccentric visitors have always preceded some remarkable event." But Macy resisted such speculation: "[T]he philosophical reasoning we leave to the scientific part of the community, still it is beyond a doubt that the most learned is possessed of very little undoubted knowledge of the subject of cometicks."
At the wharves and shipping offices there was much speculation, and not just about the comet. All spring and summer there had been sightings up and down the New England coast of what the Mercury described as "an extraordinary sea animal"-a serpent with black, horselike eyes and a fifty-foot body resembling a string of barrels floating on the water. Any sailor, especially if he was young and impressionable like Thomas Nickerson, must have wondered, if only fleetingly, if this was, in fact, the best time to be heading out on a voyage around Cape Horn.
Nantucketers had good reason to be superstitious. Their lives were governed by a force of terrifying unpredictability-the sea. Due to a constantly shifting network of shoals, including the Nantucket Bar just off the harbor mouth, the simple act of coming to and from the island was an often harrowing and sometimes catastrophic lesson in seamanship. Particularly in winter, when storms were the most violent, wrecks occurred almost weekly. Buried throughout the island were the corpses of anonymous seamen who had washed up on its wave-thrashed shores. Nantucket, which means "faraway land" in the language of the island's native inhabitants, the Wampanoag, was a mound of sand eroding into an inexorable ocean, and all its residents, even if they had never left the island, were all too aware of the inhumanity of the sea.
Nantucket's English settlers, who began arriving in 1659, had been mindful of the sea's dangers. They had hoped to support themselves not as fishermen but as farmers and sheepherders on this grassy, pond-speckled crescent without wolves. But as the increasing size of the livestock herds, combined with the growing number of farms, threatened to transform the island into a wind-blown wasteland, Nantucketers inevitably looked seaward.
Every fall, hundreds of "right whales" appeared to the south of the island and remained until the early spring. So named because they were "the right whale to kill," right whales grazed the waters off Nantucket much like seagoing cattle, straining the nutrient-rich surface of the ocean through the bushy plates of baleen in their perpetually grinning mouths. While English settlers at Cape Cod and eastern Long Island had already been hunting right whales for decades, no one on Nantucket had had the courage to pursue the whales in boats. Instead they left the harvesting of whales that washed up onto the shore (known as drift whales) to the Wampanoag.
Around 1690, a group of Nantucketers was standing on a hill overlooking the ocean where some whales were spouting and playing with one another. One of the onlookers nodded toward the whales and the ocean beyond. "There," he asserted, "is a green pasture where our children's grandchildren will go for bread." In fulfillment of his prophecy, a Cape Codder by the name of Ichabod Paddock was soon thereafter lured across Nantucket Sound to instruct the islanders in the art of killing whales.

Now, since it would not need to return to port as often to deliver bulky blubber, their fleet had a far greater range. By the outbreak of the American Revolution, Nantucketers had made it to the verge of the Arctic Circle, to the west coast of Africa, the east coast of South America, and as far south as the Falkland Islands.

Fortunately, Nantucketers possessed enough capital and inherent whaling expertise to survive these trials. Never before had the division between Nantucket's whalemen and their people been so great. Long gone were the days when Nantucketers could watch from shore as the men and boys of the island pursued the whale. Nantucket was now the whaling capital of the world, but there were more than a few islanders who had never even seen a whale.

A crowd gathered on shore to watch in fascination as two whales were killed and towed back into the harbor. For the people of Nantucket, it was an epiphany. Here at last were two of the creatures they had heard so much about, creatures upon which their livelihood depended. One of the whales was pulled up onto the wharf, and before the day was out, thousands of people-including, perhaps, the five-year-old Thomas Nickerson-had come to see it. One can only imagine the intensity of the Nantucketers' curiosity as they peered at the giant creature, and poked and prodded it, and said to themselves, "So this is it."
Nantucket had created an economic system that no longer depended on the island's natural resources. The island's soil had long since been exhausted by overfarming. Nantucket's large Wampanoag population had been reduced to a handful by epidemics, forcing shipowners to look to the mainland for crew. Whales had almost completely disappeared from local waters. And still the Nantucketers prospered. As one visitor observed, the island had become a "barren sandbank, fertilized with whale-oil only."
Throughout the seventeenth century, English Nantucketers resisted all attempts to establish a church on the island, partly because a woman by the name of Mary Coffin Starbuck forbade it. It was said that nothing of consequence was done on Nantucket without Mary's approval. Mary Coffin and Nathaniel Starbuck had been the first English couple to be married on the island, in 1662, and had established a lucrative outpost for trading with the Wampanoag. Whenever an itinerant minister came to Nantucket looking to establish a congregation, he was firmly rebuffed by Mary Starbuck. Then, in 1702, Mary succumbed to a charismatic Quaker minister named John Richardson. Speaking before a group assembled in the Starbucks' living room, Richardson succeeded in moving Mary to tears. It was Mary Starbuck's conversion to Quakerism that established the unique fusion of spirituality and covetousness that would make possible Nantucket's rise as a whaling port.
Quakers or, more properly, members of the Society of Friends, depended on their own experience of God's presence, the "Inner Light," for guidance rather than relying on a Puritan minister's interpretation of scripture. But Nantucket's ever growing number of Quakers were hardly free-thinking individuals. Friends were expected to conform to rules of behavior determined during yearly meetings, encouraging a sense of community that was as carefully controlled as that of any New England society. If there was a difference, it was the Quaker belief in pacifism and a conscious spurning of worldly ostentation-two principles that were not intended to interfere, in any way, with a person's ability to make money. Instead of building fancy houses or buying fashionable clothes, Nantucket's Quakers reinvested their profits in the whale fishery. As a result, they were able to weather the downturns that laid to waste so many mainland whaling merchants, and Mary Starbuck's children, along with their Macy and Coffin cousins, quickly established a Quaker whaling dynasty.
Nantucketers saw no contradiction between their livelihood and their religion. God Himself had granted them dominion over the fishes of the sea. Peleg Folger, a Nantucket whaleman turned Quaker elder, expressed it in verse:

Thou didst, O Lord, create the mighty whale,
That wondrous monster of a mighty length;
Vast is his head and body, vast his tail,
Beyond conception his unmeasured strength.

But, everlasting God, thou dost ordain
That we, poor feeble mortals should engage
(Ourselves, our wives and children to maintain),
This dreadful monster with a martial rage.

Even if Nantucket's Quakers dominated the island economically and culturally, room was made for others, and by the early nineteenth century there were two Congregational church towers bracketing the town north and south. Yet all shared in a common, spiritually infused mission-to maintain a peaceful life on land while raising bloody havoc at sea. Pacifist killers, plain-dressed millionaires, the whalemen of Nantucket were simply fulfilling the Lord's will.

fields.headline: A-level playing field
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Students with top A-level grades should be selected for Oxbridge by lottery to improve the intake from state schools, an expert in education assessment has told MPs.
fields.body:
Students with top A-level grades should be selected for Oxbridge by lottery to improve the intake from state schools, an expert in education assessment has told MPs.

Researchers into university admissions also told the House of Commons education committee that the Oxbridge interview system should be abandoned to reduce bias.

The radical proposals came yesterday as the government unveiled £20m for university access initiatives as part of the comprehensive spending review.

The funds will pay for university summer schools for pupils from disadvantaged backgrounds, better links between academics and teachers, new recruitment officers and improvements to admissions programmes.

Universities which submit plans for annual improvements in accessibility will get more cash from the Higher Education Funding Council for England.

The new money for access and the MPs' inquiry into admissions have emerged in the wake of the Laura Spence controversy, when Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the exchequer, accused Oxford University of elitism after it turned down the state school sixth-former.

Yesterday, head of the education school at King's College, London, Professor Dylan Wiliam, told the MPs that unless universities could show that admissions procedures were fair, they should pick well-qualified students at random. Professor Wiliam said that entrants would be chosen from a pool of students with high grades but state school students would not need to show such high grades - a reflection of their propensity to secure better degrees.

Wiliam's research has shown that grades often bear little resemblance to the true academic abilities of students measured by continuous assessment. He also told the committee that other research suggests that state school students with three Bs at A-level have the same academic ability as private school pupils with three As who benefit from extra resources and learning alongside other bright pupils. In the US, universities place more onus on a student's final school grades, irrespective of how they compare to national scores.

Meanwhile, Dr Gerry McCrum told the MPs that Oxford University "is not doing as well as it ought" in attracting students from all backgrounds. "My solution would be to do away with the interview and just use A-levels," he said. His research has shown that pupils from private schools are twice as likely as state school students to secure places at Oxford and Cambridge even with comparable grades. Dr McCrum described the final stages of the Oxford selection process as a 'black art'.

Cambridge has overtaken Oxford as the most socially exclusive university in the country, according to the latest breakdown of figures for student admissions unveiled in the Guardian this week.

In 1998-99, over 80% of Cambridge undergraduate admissions comprised students from the upper and middle classes.

fields.headline: 100 years of platitudes
fields.standfirst: Francis Wheen's cut-out-and-keep Queen Mum birthday tribute
fields.trailText: Francis Wheen's cut-out-and-keep Queen Mum birthday tribute
fields.body:
The Queen Mother's longevity is impressive, but not half so impressive as the Stakhanovite work rate of her hagio-graphers.

Last weekend's output alone included a 12-page supplement in the Sunday Times, a "definitive" 16-page pullout in the Sunday Telegraph, and a Mail on Sunday partwork running to more than 50 pages. Seldom in the history of hackery have so many column inches been filled with so little information.

According to Walter Bagehot, the monarchy has two distinct parts to play in the tragicomedy of British life - a "dignified" role and an "efficient" role. In the former - which can be summarised as smiling, waving and wearing extravagant hats - the Queen Mum is clearly an Oscar-winner, but this doesn't make the task of her word-churning idolaters any easier. Once you've used up every synonym in the thesaurus for "serene" and "diaphanous", what more can be said?

The prolific Paul Johnson lists her finest achievements thus: "opening things and saying a few well-chosen words, fishing, remembering faces, singing in church". Perhaps sensing that these humdrum accomplishments scarcely justify his claims for her historical significance, he adds that the Queen Mum "benefits from a deep-rooted veneration the British have - it is more manly than deference, akin rather to admiration - for the landed aristocracy". Speak for yourself, matey.

Nevertheless, let's accept that she is indeed a serene and diaphanous figure whose presence would enhance any church fete. What of her political or "efficient" duties? The birthday tributes are astonishingly coy on this subject. "Not giving interviews - it's a brilliant ploy," Lord Bell of Belgravia writes in the Sunday Times. "Absolutely nobody knows what she thinks about anything."

What codswallop. Thanks to the recently published diaries of her friend Woodrow Wyatt, we know many of the Queen Mother's opinions. In March 1986, for instance, she tells Wyatt that when the royal family are alone together they "often drink a toast at the end of dinner to Mrs Thatcher. She adores Mrs Thatcher." She also adores President PW Botha of South Africa, and "thinks it is awful how the BBC and media misrepresent everything that Botha is trying to do".

That summer, while lunching at Clarence House with Wyatt and Douglas Fairbanks Jr, Her Majesty delivers an unprompted rant against black Commonwealth countries which have been pressing for sanctions against South Africa. Would she mind, Wyatt wonders, if some black countries resigned from the Commonwealth in protest against Thatcher's line? "Not at all, if that's what they want to do," the Queen Mother replies, briskly denouncing President Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia as "an idiot".

A few months before the 1987 election, a nervous Queen Mum asks Wyatt for reassurance that the Tories will stay in power. As he writes, "she is much more pro-Conservative than the Queen or the Prince of Wales". She is also opposed to female ordination, since "the women who wanted to be priests all seem so aggressive".

After a discussion on the war crimes bill, Wyatt records, "We talked about Jews for a bit and she said she liked them very much but they were a separate people and a strange people, keeping to themselves and their own ways. She clearly has some reservations about Jews in her old-fashioned English way."

Referring to the war, she added: "You did all in your power to stave off such agony and you were right."

webTitle: Blair wins money v memos battle - but only just

fields.headline: Blair wins money v memos battle - but only just
fields.standfirst: While William Hague taunted the prime minister over leaked memos, the Labour leader attempted to put a positive spin on yesterday's spending review, writes Julian Glover
fields.trailText: While William Hague taunted the prime minister over leaked memos, the Labour leader attempted to put a positive spin on yesterday's spending review, writes Julian Glover
fields.body:
Prime minister's questions this afternoon saw the battle of the money against the memos as Tony Blair sought to keep attention on the spending review while the opposition attempted to taunt him over the string of Downing Street leaks.

The money won - just - though Mr Blair did little to hide his embarrassment over the leaked memos.

Confident of his ground and equipped with a ready supply of quotations from the documents, William Hague attacked early in the session and peppered all six of his questions with references to the them.

Accusing the prime minister of presiding over "three failed years in office" he mocked him over his concern for his public image. "Can anyone think of anything more pathetic than a prime minister who sends a memo around asking for 'eye-catching initiatives?'" Hague asked. "We and the British people will make him part of our history far sooner than he ever expected."

"Winston Churchill did not ask for blood, sweat and 'eye-catching initiatives'," he went on.

"Isn't it a disgrace that you are commissioning memos ludicrously entitled 'Getting the right place in history,' - even Napoleon didn't commission memos called that - when many people are struggling to get the right place in hospital thanks to the incompetence of your administration?"

The prime minister chose to shrug off the leaks and instead turned on the opposition over its attitude to yesterday's spending review. In a foretaste of what will probably become a routine as the general election draws near, Tony Blair said the Conservatives' planned £16bn of public spending cuts were the nearest thing to committing "political hara-kiri" ever undertaken by a political leader.

To loud Labour cheers, he said the dividing line for the election had been set, with his party willing to invest in public services and the Tories making cuts.

Citing commitments made by the shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, the prime minister said: "We all know where the spending cuts are going to fall." He claimed that a Conservative government would cost every constituency £24m.

"Let me tell you what the first CSR delivered in the health service," Blair continued. "Thirty-eight new hospital developments under way, over 6,000 more qualified nurses, 5,000 more doctors, every accident and emergency department modernised."

He challenged the Tory leader to say what his party's "£16 billion worth of spending cuts would deliver".

fields.headline: Protesters limber up for Olympics
fields.standfirst: Cyber threat to opening of Sydney Games
fields.trailText: A diverse series of protests coordinated over the internet threatens to disrupt the opening of the Olympics in Sydney in September.
fields.body:
A diverse series of protests coordinated over the internet threatens to disrupt the opening of the Olympics in Sydney in September.

Internet activists are passing on the tactics and techniques developed during the successful cyber protests against the World Trade Organisation in Seattle last year and against the World Bank in Washington in April.

The Sydney Alternative Media Centre, which is being launched this week, is the latest radical Australian website modelled on those used to plan and publicise the protests in Seattle and Washington, as well as the recent demonstration in Whitehall.

The parliament of New South Wales has passed temporary laws to try to keep tight control of the Olympic stadiums. The regulations outlaw the unauthorised assembly of people and give controversial "temporary enforcement officers" police powers to instantly remove from the designated Olympic areas people deemed to be causing "annoyance". But the control of cyberspace may prove more difficult.

Groups including aborigines, anarchists and local people protesting about recent rent increases, as landlords cash in on the anticipated 340,000 tourists visiting the city for the Games, plan to use the internet to help organise an unauthorised demonstration during the opening ceremony on September 15.

Four days before that, ambitious "S11" demonstrations against a World Economic Forum meeting in Melbourne will provide a test for many anti-capitalist activists - and for the Australian police.

Meanwhile, activist sites are urging protesters to target many of the Olympic sponsors, including Coca-Cola, McDonald's, Unilever and IBM. And it was reported last week that hackers also plan to sabotage the official Olympic website, which has three servers in the US and one in Australia.

On Sunday, the Sydney branch of the Independent Media Centre, one of the most successful Seattle sites, is to train volunteers to upload video and audio footage, and photographs, on to its website, to enable instant, unofficial coverage of potential protests.

"We'll be a reality channel you can turn on," said an activist calling himself Predator, who claimed to represent the Independent Media Centre. "Want to post stories about the Olympics, but with a different take to the blind praise and glorification dished out by CNN/MSN? Welcome aboard."

Protesters see the Games as an embodiment of the excesses of global capitalism. "The International Olympic Committee is the final stage of corporate evolution," said Predator. "They don't produce anything, they redirect local resources to further their own ends, they ignore the needs of the global citizenry and they use the corporate media to distribute their aims."

"The anti-Olympic movement has been able to broaden its appeal through the use of the internet," said Helen Jefferson Lenskyj, professor of sociology at the University of Toronto, who has spent five months in Sydney researching the Olympic industry.

Most of the demonstrations at the Sydney Olympics are likely to focus on the failure of the Australian government to complete a reconciliation with the aboriginal community, Prof Lenskyj said. "Many groups want to put the world spotlight on white Australia's record of racism, so the radical left are more than happy to put that at the top of their agenda," she said. "But it is the local housing issues that obviously affect low-income people - aborigines, immigrants and the homeless - more."

Ray Jackson, a spokesman for the Indigenous Social Justice Association, said that although a group called the Anti-Olympic Alliance was trying to provide an umbrella organisation, overall control of the protests was impossible.

"What action takes place depends entirely on the security forces who will be lined up against us in an effort to prevent us from entering the Olympic site and camping in Bicentennial Park for the duration of the Games," he said.

fields.headline: Reality bites back
fields.standfirst: A new review claims Birmingham's social services are failing
fields.trailText: A new review claims Birmingham's social services are failing.
fields.body:
Social services in Birmingham, the biggest local authority in England and Wales, are "patchy with some giving cause for concern", a joint review team reported yesterday. Services for children in particular require urgent improvement.

The verdict is an embarrassing blow to a Labour authority that presented a modernising profile long before the government told it to. In the words of the review report, "surface image is sometimes greater than substance". Social services in Birmingham reflects a "gap between policy and procedures and the reality of practice on the ground". Clarity of vision and a sense of direction are both lacking.

The review was one of a series being carried out by the audit commission and the government's social services inspectorate. Although the report is by no means the most damning produced so far, the size of Birmingham (a £223m social services budget last year) and the consistency of Labour control (unchanged since 1984) give the findings special significance.

The city council, which received a draft of yesterday's report in April and had verbal feedback from the review team last December, is pointing to a series of changes being made under the leadership of Sandra Taylor, appointed social services director late last year.

Sir Michael Lyons, the council's chief executive, says: "We accept that there is a big job to do within the authority: it is one of the most important facing us over the next two years. The report acknowledges the strong, corporate framework within the authority, which will ensure the social services department can rely on the full support of myself and other senior colleagues to work together to achieve change."

The review was carried out last November and December and the team was led by Dennis Simpson, former social services director of Southwark, south London. Quality of services was found to be highly variable, with some rated very good and others giving "serious concern", although a questionnaire sent to more than 400 users and carers found that 72% thought services excellent or very good and only 6% thought them poor - one of the most positive scores of any joint review to date.

According to the review team, the commitment of frontline staff is not in doubt. The authority needs to harness the undoubted energy of the majority in order better to focus their skills and achieve more consistent results. While services for people with mental health problems are relatively robust, and those for elderly people have been the subject of much policy initiative, services for people with learning disabilities have "lost focus" and those for children and families demand "instant attention and quick corrective action".

At the time of the review, 175 children in care - one in 10 of all those "looked after" - were unallocated to a social worker. Thirty had been unallocated for more than a year. Some 25% of those in care did not have a care plan and 30% were overdue for a statutory six-month case review.

Child protection has wrongly been given priority over looked-after children, the report says. Birmingham has proportionally fewer children in foster care than any comparable authority and more children in residential care than all but one. The quality of care in children's homes is "questionable". Even so, child protection work is "still less than robust".

What typifies the council's problems, the report argues, is the length of time often taken to translate policies into practice: although consultants were commissioned in 1994 to review the social services computer strategy, the new system they recommended is still being piloted; similarly, concerns about children's homes were raised in the early 1990s, yet a strategy has emerged only in the past year.

The review team notes that Taylor, who moved from the equivalent post in Leicester, agreed with much of its analysis. She's promising a "dramatic" increase in numbers of staff in child protection teams; "major work" to reshape children's residential services; improved training and greater oversight of practice on the ground, including development of a peripatetic expert team. There will also be a raft of new senior staff for the social services department, including a head of performance.

"It is a challenging agenda and cannot be achieved overnight," says Taylor. "I am nevertheless convinced that the necessary changes can be made."

The joint review team is evidently less convinced. Its report refers cautiously to "initial signs of optimism" and warns: "On the basis of the fieldwork, there are some reservations about the department's capacity to make the necessary changes across a wide front."

 A report of the Joint Review of Social Services in Birmingham is available at £15 from Audit Commission Publications (0800 502030).

fields.headline: Corporate Dad
fields.standfirst: Quality Protects is beginning to deliver improved council services for children, reports  David Brindle
fields.trailText: Quality Protects is beginning to deliver improved council services for children, reports David Brindle.
fields.body:
And now for the good news. Quality Protects, the government's programme aimed at "transforming" services for children, is starting to deliver. That's the official verdict of a national overview report published today, based on returns from all 150 English social services authorities.

John Hutton, social care minister, writes in a foreword to the report that "significant improvements" have been made over the past year in areas such as collection and use of management information. "And there is evidence that this is beginning to translate into improved experiences and outcomes for children."

Progress, however, is relative. Today's report comes hard on the heels of findings by the government's social services inspectorate (SSI) that children from ethnic minorities are failing to get services that meet their needs. Of a sample eight authorities inspected, only one had "taken race equality issues seriously".

The answer to this apparent para dox, it seems, is that authorities are heading in the right direction but that, in many places, this is manifest in terms of process rather than practice. As Diana Robbins, author of the Quality Protects (QP) report, puts it: "The year two evaluation of QP has been described as producing a mountain of paper. But the top of the mountain provides the clearest possible view of councils moving, with their partners, towards providing better services for children and their families."

Though the evaluation is the second of its kind, it covers the first year of QP funding through the children's services grant worth £375m over three years. All 150 returns, known as management action plans (Maps), have been approved - qualifying the authorities for their share of next year's funding - and eight singled out as being of particularly high quality: Blackpool, Manchester, Portsmouth, Stockton-on-Tees, Suffolk, Tameside in Greater Manchester and Wandsworth and Westminster in London. Each of the eight achieved an overall "very good" rating of three on a four-point scale.

At Blackpool, QP co-ordinator Sue White says having to address the agenda has given the authority an opportunity to go back to basics and take a hard look at children's services across the board. As a new, unitary council created in 1998, it had the distinct advantage of no "history", but the disadvantage of having lost a lot of key staff who had stayed with Lancashire. It also had the special challenge of a transient population including many vulnerable families.

"We started off with a clean slate and we set out to work together from day one," says White. "The key thing was that we had an assistant director for children's services, Daphne Sanders, who had a clear vision of how we should deliver QP and everybody bought into that vision. It's had an effect on every aspect of children's services and led into other areas of the department as well."

Blackpool is praised in the report for staging a strategy conference to draw everybody into the QP process. Implementation has included greatly improving the council's own children's homes; boosting recruitment and quality control of foster carers, while introducing a fostering payment scheme; and applying fresh approaches to adoption, services for disabled children and use of private sector placements.

Overall, the report, Tracking Progress in Children's Services, finds "huge" improvement in authorities' capacity to monitor and report performance on children's services. This, among other things, means that the report can make the first national estimate of the number of young people receiving services under the Children Act - 330,000. The report also notes marked progress in involving children themselves in the design, delivery and evaluation of services, and in the involvement of councillors in strategic thinking and governance.

The indifference to children's services shown by many councillors came as a shock to officials and ministers involved in the planning of QP. A series of seminars has been staged to tackle this, but an unpublished survey for the Department of Health by research group Mori is believed to show that a huge impact was made by a letter to councils from Frank Dobson, when he was health secretary, reminding elected members in no uncertain terms of their responsibilities as corporate parents of children in care.

On the down side, the report finds less progress in involving children in decisions about their own care. Only a quarter of councils are said to be making good ground in this area. Robbins, an independent consultant, warns that "until an approach to looked after children based on partnership with them becomes more entrenched in the day-to-day practice of social work with children, the most earnest aspirations set by councils could be subverted by non-compliance or, more simply, by reliance on traditional methods".

Disappointment is also expressed at the "slippage" in QP programmes, amounting to almost 4% of budgeted expenditure in 1999-2000. A key fac tor in this was the trouble experienced by authorities in recruiting staff: the report comments on "the difficulty experienced everywhere in finding the right people to fill all the new posts which QP plans required".

Summing up, Robbins concludes: "Progress is real, and in the most advanced councils this progress is being seen and measured." She admits, however, that many achievements remain concerned with process, rather than demonstrable improvement in children's lives. "Few councils have yet reached the point of both being able to identify, implement and monitor a strategy for change, and then demonstrate the effect of that change in terms of outcomes."

So the SSI, inspecting services for ethnic minority children between April and November last year, found that most authorities were still not well placed to deliver care and support appropriate to their needs. While councils did have anti-racist and equal opportunities policies and strategies, there was "little evidence" of their implementation. "Many authorities," says the inspection report, "talked about 'mainstreaming' the issues, but in practice this often meant that they were ignored".

The report, Excellence Not Excuses, looks at services in Buckinghamshire, Leicestershire, Liverpool, Sheffield, Wolverhampton and three authorities in London - Islington, Southwark and Hammersmith and Fulham. It says that "in some instances, the safety of ethnic minority children was being compromised because physical and sexual abuse had not been identified and properly dealt with as a child protection issue".

Hutton is warning that, in the wake of the Stephen Lawrence inquiry and the subsequent Macpherson report, the government expects authorities to be acutely sensitive to the challenges of meeting the needs of ethnic minority children and families. "This report has flagged up some very serious issues that must be addressed," he says. "We need to see real improvement in services in these areas."

fields.headline: Another defeat by the Spartans
fields.standfirst: For the next two weeks we will be carrying reports from the Dragon School's cricket tour to Barbados. Find out how the First XI and the Under-12s get on by reading regular updates from James Schneider, captain of cricket, on wisden.com
fields.trailText:
Day 4
First XI v Spartans U-13s
fields.body:
Day 4
First XI v Spartans U-13s

Spartans are one of the very old clubs on the island. We were playing at Harrison's College, which is the Eton or Winchester of Barbados. The boundaries were small. As expected it was wet but it dried out quickly. We were inserted.

After two wides to start the match, Bertie Conibear nicked the next ball to the keeper. Two balls later, Lochie Dewar was caught at silly mid off. At 2-2 this looked a bad toss to lose. Rupert Haddon and Adam Hall rebuilt the innings to 80-3. Adam was stumped and calamity struck as the middle order fell to pieces. At 90-7 things were looking dicey but again we rebuilt with Rupert and me until he was caught at slip for 47. I played down the wrong line and in came Archie Franks at 126-9.

He belted it around as Shaz Richardson found the gaps. They boosted our score to 197.

I decided to open the bowling with Archie, because he was fired up, and myself, because leg spin wouldn't be what they were expecting. Archie bowled well and I picked up two early wickets, but we dropped four catches. The two batsmen at the crease were such good players, but they soon found themselves behind the rate.

With 12 overs remaining they needed eight an over but they conjured up some big hitting (and we lost three balls). They kept calm despite losing three quick wickets (one of them to an amazing catch by Tom Turney at extra cover) and won by five wickets in the last over.

As I was walking round the ground later I saw on the War Memorial two Walcotts and a Worrell. It is after all only a game.

fields.headline: Knowledge Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Who are the England bad boys? Just how good was Alfredo Di Stefano? And did Chris Nicholl really score all four goals in a 2-2 draw?
fields.trailText: The players who've been sent off playing for England: who are they, when were they sent off, and why? asks Derek Baldwinson
fields.body:
The players who've been sent off playing for England: who are they, when were they sent off, and why? asks Derek Baldwinson

Alan Mullery was the first player to be sent off playing for England. The Spurs player was sent packing for two terrible challenges on Yugoslavian hard man Dobrivoje Trivic in England's 1968 European championship semi-final defeat.

A late-tackling, ranting Alan Ball was the next to go five years later, for two bookable offences against Poland, and in 1977, Trevor Cherry was similarly dismissed against Argentina in Buenos Aires.

Only one English international would be dismissed during the next 21 years, when Ray Wilkins lost his cool under the Monterrey sun, threw the ball at the referee after being pulled up for a dubious foul, and saw his Mexico 86 campaign come to a premature end.

It was 12 years until a fifth England international saw red - you'll possibly remember David Beckham's petulant kick at Argentina's Diego Simeone in France 98 - but only one more match until a sixth one did, when Paul Ince took an early bath in Sweden for two trademark late tackles.

The following June, Paul Scholes went against Sweden for two bookable challenges, although he should have walked for hacking Stefan Schwarz's leg to shreds with the first one. David Batty is the last player to have been sent off in the white shirt (so far) - he was dismissed against Poland towards the end of last year, presumably just for being David Batty.

Tommy Gemmell of Celtic has scored goals in more than one European Cup final. I suspect other players have also achieved this feat - do you have details? asks Des Callaghan

Nine other men have managed this. (For the record, Gemmell scored in Celtic's win over Internazionale in 1967 and their defeat against Feyenoord in 1970.)

By far and away the greatest goalscorer in European Cup finals was Real Madrid's Alfredo Di Stefano, who scored in the first five finals, beginning in 1955 and saving the best for last with a hat-trick against Eintracht Frankfurt in 1960. Di Stefano was incredibly outscored in that classic match by his team-mate Ferenc Puskas, who got the other four in Real's 7-3 victory. Puskas didn't do so well in Real's 1962 defeat at the hands of Benfica, mind you - he only managed a hat-trick.

Di Stefano and Puskas weren't the only Real players to achieve this feat during Real's late-50s pomp, either. Rial (two goals in 1956, one in 1959) and Gento (in 1957 and 1958) also managed it.

As for other teams? Two Benfica players managed it during their club's early-60s heyday: Aguas scored in the 1961 and 1962 finals; the great Eusebio notched two in 1962 and another a year later. Internazionale's Alessandro Mazzola, who scored but came away a loser against Celtic, had better luck in 1964 with a winning hat-trick against Real Madrid. And Franz Roth hit the net in consecutive finals during the mid-70s for Bayern Munich.

The last player to score in two finals is also the only other British player to do so. Phil Neal converted a penalty in Liverpool's first European Cup success (against Borussia Monchengladbach in 1977) and scored the opener in their last (against Roma in 1984). Will Teddy Sheringham or Steve McManaman join Neal and Gemmell's elite British club next May?

Somewhere in the back of my brain, I seem to recall Chris Nicholl scoring all four goals in a 2-2 draw between Aston Villa and Leicester City. Is my memory failing me? asked Nick Evans.

Martin Blogg writes: "Chris Nicholl did score all four goals in a 2-2 draw between Leicester and Villa at Filbert Street, on 20th March 1976. I remember seeing a picture of him being congratulated by, I think, Andy Gray, following his second equaliser for Villa."

Last week we set out on the trail of vegetarian footballers and you've served up a few more suggestions.

Stephen Ryan thinks Robbie Earle of Wimbledon lives his life meat-free, and Terry Land is sure West Ham's Ian Pearce's vegetarianism has been "documented in several articles in programmes and magazines". Meanwhile, Aiden Glendinning writes: "I thought Les Ferdinand was a veggie. But I haven't read his autobiography, as everyone says it's crap."

Can you help?

"I am aware that Manchester is divided on sectarian lines: United are catholic; City are protestant. Are there any other such divisions in the English leagues?" asks cbobt.

"Thanks for your explanation of why the Italian kit is blue [see last week's Knowledge]. Can anyone then explain why the German away strip is green?" asks Clayton Fossett.

Any questions?

Send your football asks to the.boss@theguardian.com and we'll do our best to give you some answers.

webTitle: Bad buy, Bad time and Bad idea

fields.headline: Bad buy, Bad time and Bad idea
fields.trailText: REWRITING HISTORY THE CITY WAY
fields.body:
REWRITING HISTORY THE CITY WAY

Manchester City. A proud club with a proud history. Or so you'd think. But if you take a close look at their record book, you'll find that their most expensive purchase is Lee Bradbury. At £3m. For Lee Bradbury. That's enough to make even the most diehard Maine Road regular rip up their roll of honour in disgust and rush off for a much-needed hose down with some Ryan Giggs shower gel.

So thank God for Joe Royle, who is set to erase Frank Clark's folly from the record books. He's tabled a £6m bid for Aston Villa defender Ugo Ehiogu, which, if successful, will easily get rid of all trace of Badbuy and let everyone concerned get on with their lives. "We've made our bid and hopefully it will be accepted," said Royle today, deliberately standing in front of the 1997-8 team photo.

The only possible stumbling block to erasing City's shameful shame could be Sunderland's interest in Ehiogu, but the player is reluctant to move too far north from his London-based family. So City look in the box seat, unless Spurs quickly flog Sol Campbell to the highest bidder and come in with a late bid - but that'll never happen, of course.

In a totally unconnected event, ex-Everton carthorse Daniel Amokachi's move to City came apart today when he failed a medical. "Don't get me wrong, his knee is not a write-off," insisted Royle as he announced the death of the deal, "but because of the money involved with paying players these days, I will have to tell Daniel the bad news." But what's bad news for some...

SHOTGUN MARIC

So farewell then, Silvio Maric. According to reports in Portuguese sports daily O Jogo (Portuguese for The Water Holding Receptacle), Maric will definitely be signing for Porto in the near future for a surprisingly high fee of £2m. Heck, they even printed pictures of him dining in a Porto restaurant to prove it. However, given the nature of the Croat's stay on Tyneside, Newcastle fans might be forgiven for not counting their chickens until they've hatched. Or deep-fried in batter, even.

Maric arrived at St James' Park 18 months ago for £3.3m. Basically bought by Ruud Gullit as a replacement for Rob Lee, Maric managed to start only 17 games in a season and a half, scoring two goals (both against FC Zurich). Maric has spent most of his time outside the first team squad, and has been up for sale since January - when a return to Croatia Zagreb fell through because the club couldn't afford him. He then bunked Newcastle's post-season trip to the Caribbean, and stuck his neck into the whole transport debate by declaring that Britons drive on the wrong side of the road.

Maric has, in fact, made such an indelible contribution to the North East that it's a wonder they don't put up a statue in his honour. But it looks like selling him on for a transfer fee will have to do instead. According to a Portuguese source -mmm, madeira - "The player arrived yesterday and the deal is done. It's now just a matter of him passing his medical." So let's just hope that Silvio flourishes in Portugal once more. You never know, he might earn himself a move back to the Premiership.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"They have visas for six months and if they want to see England, they will see it. I am sure they will come back within six months. They have done nothing wrong" - The president of Bradford's Intertoto Cup opponents, FC Atlantas of Lithuania, on 22 fans who have disappeared since last week's match at Valley Parade. The Daily Mail are believed to have someone on the case already.

FOR FERG'S SAKE

The Imperial Lord Ferg has always been a fount of ideas. Signing Ralph Milne was one. As was playing Ryan Giggs on the right wing in Big Cup final. As was bitching about former friends and colleagues in his autobiography. So why he would need to call on his sons for advice on his retirement plans is anyone's guess. But he did, and you, the valiant Fiver readership, have not been shy in suggesting what they were suggesting. If you see what we're saying.

According to a man rummaging through rubbish on Bournemouth pier - brought to the Fiver by way of Andrew Palmer - Ferg will plough all his spare hours into a new dotcom venture. Scotfree.com will be a database of "convincing excuses for those accused of traffic and minor criminal offences". Which sounds great.

Elsewhere, W Clayton believes that the High Lord will help out Britain's over-stretched air traffic control industry by "standing on top of high structures to warn away aeroplanes with his red face". Brendan Higgins, meanwhile, foresees a venture into another troubled industry, as Ferg helps out farmers by "milking bulls".

Surely the options are endless, especially if Ferg doesn't decide to become the new Taggart (as suggested by x number of readers). But it's not all japes, as some readers believe those pesky kids could be up to something. "They're going to steal his face and pass it around themselves in order to do anything they want," warns Ric Bradley, while Neil Gage is convinced that young Darren Ferg "is patenting his idea of working his nuts off when coming up to contract negotiations and then doing bugger all for the next two years".

Only (an infinitely-prolonged period of injury) time will tell, we guess.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Spurs have denied that David Ginola is set for a move back to France with Marseille. "It is not true. We haven't spoken to anyone directly at Marseille," said David Pleat earlier today.

Wimbledon have put Paul Merson at the top of their summer shopping list. The club's owner Bjorn Rune Gjelsten said: "Terry [Burton, the Dons' manager] has given me a list of names and Paul Merson is one of them."

Aston Villa are believed to be interested in signing Juninho, 18 months after a prospective move to the club fell apart over the Brazilian's wage demands.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Juventus have denied that Zinedine Zidane is about to join Real Madrid or Barcelona. A club spokesman said: "Zidane belongs to Juve. He is still under contract and will begin the season with us."

Steve Archibald is on the verge of completing his takeover of Airdrie after provisional liquidators KPMG confirmed him as preferred bidder for the club.

The FA have passed on information to the fraud squad to help with an investigation into the financial affairs of Hull City.

Giorgi Kinkladze is expected to miss Derby's first two Premiership matches of the season against Southampton and Newcastle after successfully undergoing a hernia operation yesterday.

Bolton have signed Birmingham full-back Simon Charlton under the Bosman ruling. Charlton, 29, has agreed a two-year deal.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mundial (7pm)
Games and boats and planes.

Six-a-side Football - Live (7.30pm, 1.30am)
The Manchester Masters. No, we don't know, either.

Sky Sports 3: Brian Moore Interviews (11pm)
The old commentator has a chat with Neil Young, who will either talk about his 1969 FA Cup-winning goal or sing a selection of songs from Harvest.

He's tabled a £6m bid for Aston Villa defender Ugo Ehiogu, which, if successful, will easily get rid of all trace of Badbuy and let everyone concerned get on with their lives. "We've made our bid and hopefully it will be accepted," said Royle today, deliberately standing in front of the 1997-8 team photo. The only possible stumbling block to erasing City's shameful shame could be Sunderland's interest in Ehiogu, but the player is reluctant to move too far north from his London-based family. So City look in the box seat, unless Spurs quickly flog Sol Campbell to the highest bidder and come in with a late bid - but that'll never happen, of course. In a totally unconnected event, ex-Everton carthorse Daniel Amokachi's move to City came apart today when he failed a medical. "Don't get me wrong, his knee is not a write-off," insisted Royle as he announced the death of the deal, "but because of the money involved with paying players these days, I will have to tell Daniel the bad news." But what's bad news for some... SHOTGUN MARIC So farewell then, Silvio Maric. According to reports in Portuguese sports daily O Jogo (Portuguese for The Water Holding Receptacle), Maric will definitely be signing for Porto in the near future for a surprisingly high fee of £2m. Heck, they even printed pictures of him dining in a Porto restaurant to prove it. However, given the nature of the Croat's stay on Tyneside, Newcastle fans might be forgiven for not counting their chickens until they've hatched. Or deep-fried in batter, even. Maric arrived at St James' Park 18 months ago for £3.3m. Basically bought by Ruud Gullit as a replacement for Rob Lee, Maric managed to start only 17 games in a season and a half, scoring two goals (both against FC Zurich). Maric has spent most of his time outside the first team squad, and has been up for sale since January - when a return to Croatia Zagreb fell through because the club couldn't afford him. He then bunked Newcastle's post-season trip to the Caribbean, and stuck his neck into the whole transport debate by declaring that Britons drive on the wrong side of the road. Maric has, in fact, made such an indelible contribution to the North East that it's a wonder they don't put up a statue in his honour. But it looks like selling him on for a transfer fee will have to do instead. According to a Portuguese source -mmm, madeira - "The player arrived yesterday and the deal is done. It's now just a matter of him passing his medical." So let's just hope that Silvio flourishes in Portugal once more. You never know, he might earn himself a move back to the Premiership. QUOTE OF THE DAY "They have visas for six months and if they want to see England, they will see it. I am sure they will come back within six months. They have done nothing wrong" - The president of Bradford's Intertoto Cup opponents, FC Atlantas of Lithuania, on 22 fans who have disappeared since last week's match at Valley Parade. The Daily Mail are believed to have someone on the case already. FOR FERG'S SAKE The Imperial Lord Ferg has always been a fount of ideas. Signing Ralph Milne was one. As was playing Ryan Giggs on the right wing in Big Cup final. As was bitching about former friends and colleagues in his autobiography. So why he would need to call on his sons for advice on his retirement plans is anyone's guess. But he did, and you, the valiant Fiver readership, have not been shy in suggesting what they were suggesting. If you see what we're saying. According to a man rummaging through rubbish on Bournemouth pier - brought to the Fiver by way of Andrew Palmer - Ferg will plough all his spare hours into a new dotcom venture. Scotfree.com will be a database of "convincing excuses for those accused of traffic and minor criminal offences". Which sounds great. Elsewhere, W Clayton believes that the High Lord will help out Britain's over-stretched air traffic control industry by "standing on top of high structures to warn away aeroplanes with his red face". Brendan Higgins, meanwhile, foresees a venture into another troubled industry, as Ferg helps out farmers by "milking bulls". Surely the options are endless, especially if Ferg doesn't decide to become the new Taggart (as suggested by x number of readers). But it's not all japes, as some readers believe those pesky kids could be up to something. "They're going to steal his face and pass it around themselves in order to do anything they want," warns Ric Bradley, while Neil Gage is convinced that young Darren Ferg "is patenting his idea of working his nuts off when coming up to contract negotiations and then doing bugger all for the next two years". Only (an infinitely-prolonged period of injury) time will tell, we guess. THE RUMOUR MILL Spurs have denied that David Ginola is set for a move back to France with Marseille. "It is not true. We haven't spoken to anyone directly at Marseille," said David Pleat earlier today. Wimbledon have put Paul Merson at the top of their summer shopping list. The club's owner Bjorn Rune Gjelsten said: "Terry [Burton, the Dons' manager] has given me a list of names and Paul Merson is one of them." Aston Villa are believed to be interested in signing Juninho, 18 months after a prospective move to the club fell apart over the Brazilian's wage demands. NEWS IN BRIEF Juventus have denied that Zinedine Zidane is about to join Real Madrid or Barcelona. A club spokesman said: "Zidane belongs to Juve. He is still under contract and will begin the season with us." Steve Archibald is on the verge of completing his takeover of Airdrie after provisional liquidators KPMG confirmed him as preferred bidder for the club. The FA have passed on information to the fraud squad to help with an investigation into the financial affairs of Hull City. Giorgi Kinkladze is expected to miss Derby's first two Premiership matches of the season against Southampton and Newcastle after successfully undergoing a hernia operation yesterday. Bolton have signed Birmingham full-back Simon Charlton under the Bosman ruling. Charlton, 29, has agreed a two-year deal. TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mundial (7pm) Games and boats and planes. Six-a-side Football - Live (7.30pm, 1.30am) The Manchester Masters. No, we don't know, either. Sky Sports 3: Brian Moore Interviews (11pm) The old commentator has a chat with Neil Young, who will either talk about his 1969 FA Cup-winning goal or sing a selection of songs from Harvest.

webTitle: Under-12s bat like millionaires against Spartans

fields.headline: Under-12s bat like millionaires against Spartans
fields.standfirst: For the next two weeks we will be carrying reports from the Dragon School's cricket tour to Barbados. Find out how the First XI and the Under-12s get on by reading regular updates from James Schneider, captain of cricket, on wisden.com
fields.trailText:
Day 3
U-12s v Spartans U-12s
fields.body:
Day 3
U-12s v Spartans U-12s

While I was teeing off on the first at Royal Westmoreland, our U-12 skipper James (Fulsome) Fuller was preparing to meet a junior side of one of Barbados' oldest clubs, Spartans. Dragon lost the toss and were inserted. By the time I had reached the 15th hole, Fulsome had scored 80 out of a total of 130, which came, sadly, before time - the U-12s had committed the No. 1 sin in one-day cricket of not batting out their overs (in this case 35). In response, Spartan knocked off the target in 28 overs. Cue lengthy talk with Fuller about pitch and outfield conditions, and the standard of opposition.

After this I turned my mind to thoughts for the next day, when we would face a side fielded by the same club. Supper was a mixed blessing: the food was great but we had to wait for what felt like a lifetime. At the tour meeting we all commend Fulsome on his batting and decide to nominate a dunce of the day who has to wear a very loud red ladies' Ascot hat. Your correspondent will draw a veil over his round of golf.

fields.headline: Part 2: Duchess of York
fields.trailText: Shortly after her engagement to Prince Albert, Elizabeth gave an interview to the press. She talked to a journalist about her engagement ring and said how she enjoyed tennis and hunting. This proved too much for the palace and she was reminded that such openness was not proper. She has not spoken to the papers since. The wedding, too, remained a private affair when the Archbishop of Canterbury put a bar on its broadcast. He was apparently concerned that men would listen to it in the pubs with their hats on.
fields.body:
Shortly after her engagement to Prince Albert, Elizabeth gave an interview to the press. She talked to a journalist about her engagement ring and said how she enjoyed tennis and hunting. This proved too much for the palace and she was reminded that such openness was not proper. She has not spoken to the papers since. The wedding, too, remained a private affair when the Archbishop of Canterbury put a bar on its broadcast. He was apparently concerned that men would listen to it in the pubs with their hats on.

On her wedding day Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon became Duchess of York and from that day undertook the royal duties that she has carried out ever since. Much of the couple's time was taken up representing the Windsors on visits to the imperial royal households of Europe - alliances created as a result of the marriages Queen Victoria had arranged for her many children. The royal newly-weds attended the christenings and family functions of, among others, the Balkan house of Karageorgevitch.

In 1926 the duchess gave birth to Elizabeth, who was to become the future queen. Nine months later she accompanied her husband on a royal tour of New Zealand and Australia. Then, in 1928, she gave birth to a second daughter, Margaret.

Prince Albert's father, King George V, died in 1936 and the throne passed to his eldest son Edward. By the time he became king, Edward had married neither a British aristocrat nor a European royal. Instead he fell for the American actress and divorcee Wallis Simpson. As a result of this "unsuitable" relationship, the new king came under enormous pressure to renounce the throne. The Duchess of York's role in the abdication crisis is uncertain (papers which are thought to throw more light on her involvement have been suppressed until 2037) but it is widely known that Elizabeth did not like the glamorous American. Neither did the Anglican clergy, who considered it improper that a woman should join the King of England on the throne when she had been married to another man.

Edward's affair was kept out of the British press, despite the fact that American and continental papers ran stories announcing that the couple were to wed. Censors took their scissors to all mention of Mrs Simpson in publications that reached British shores, but in private the government, opposition and civil service had come to the conclusion that the king must choose between his lover and the throne. Before the news became public, Edward had decided. The crown passed to his younger brother, Albert, who became King George V1, and the duchess became Queen.

Now plain Mr Edward Windsor, the former king left the country. He was later made HRH the Duke of Windsor but his wife was forbidden to take the royal title. The couple were ostracised from family life. As her sister-in-law lay dying in the early 1970s, Elizabeth, by then the Queen Mother, made the conciliatory gesture of sending a representative to visit her in Paris every six months.

fields.headline: The flight and the safari
fields.standfirst: For the next two weeks we will be carrying reports from the Dragon School's cricket tour to Barbados. Find out how the First XI and the Under-12s get on by reading regular updates from James Schneider, captain of cricket, on wisden.com
fields.trailText:
Day 1
Flight to Barbados
fields.body:
Day 1
Flight to Barbados

The flight is delayed for six hours. The plane had to come from Mexico via Glasgow. Nobody rules themselves out of the tour by injuring themselves with a bread knife on the flight. I told one lad that there was a signpost visible out of the plane window showing the way. He looked and said "where?" We get to our hotel at 10pm and somehow we are all fed. No nonsense of a quick five-mile run to work off the jet lag. I spent the flight thinking up new cliches for this column, to avoid the old ones.

Day 2
Safari

We prepare for tomorrow's match, which is now put back a day, by going on a safari of the island. Highlights include a 4x4 rollercoaster drive through the hills of Little Scotland and snorkelling with turtles. Training takes the form of beach cricket and rugby. My parents and brother (Timothy, aged eight) arrive. Tim, a county colt, has his kit and bemoans our lack of practice at which he makes Boycott look like a dilettante. RAK and I discuss tactics for the match. We must bowl them out for fewer runs than we score. Much discussion of drinks intervals and sun-tan lotion. I tell Fuller, the U-12 captain, to bowl if he wins the toss because of the overnight rain.

webTitle: Republic terrorists blamed for bomb scare

fields.headline: Republic terrorists blamed for bomb scare
fields.trailText: Dissident Irish republican terrorists were blamed today for bringing gridlock to parts of London with a railway bomb on the day of the Queen Mother's centenary pageant.
fields.body:
Dissident Irish republican terrorists were blamed today for bringing gridlock to parts of London with a railway bomb on the day of the Queen Mother's centenary pageant.

The Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, told MPs that the bombers had delivered a warning using the same code word as was used in an attack on a railway line at Newry in Northern Ireland recently.

He was commenting after organisers of this evening's pageant said that the bombers had clearly been attempting to disrupt the event.

"I deeply regret the inconvenience to rail and underground travellers today," Mr Mandelson said. "The main paramilitary groups are maintaining their ceasefires. There remains, though, a threat from dissident paramilitaries who are opposed to the Good Friday Agreement. I utterly condemn this threat and the disruption caused by the incidents today."

The alert began after a bomb was spotted on a rail line near Ealing Broadway tube station following calls made in the Dublin area to a number of organisations. Police shut the London Underground line and carried out a controlled explosion.

The alert later spread to central London, with Victoria and Westminster tube stations paralysed just hours before crowds were due to flood into the area for the Queen Mother's centenary pageant.

Major John Petrie, one of the organisers of the Queen Mother's pageant, said the security alerts were designed to disrupt the event. "There's no question that the bomb alerts are intended to disrupt the pageant," he said.

Police had feared further attacks by breakaway Irish republican terrorists since Hammersmith Bridge, west London, was damaged by a bomb on June 1.

Today's Ealing rail bomb was spotted just as the rush hour was beginning. Residents living near the site of the controlled explosion were evacuated from their homes and traffic was diverted from surrounding roads.

The alert brought chaos to tens of thousands of rail travellers as commuter trains and services to and from the west of England, south Wales and the Heathrow Express - which also travel through Ealing Broadway - were hit. Services to and from Paddington station were effectively halted while the busy Piccadilly, Central and District tube lines in the area were also affected, London Underground said.

London-bound Great Western passengers had to take South West Trains services from Reading into London's Waterloo station, while Heathrow Express services were suspended. Passengers trying to get to Heathrow airport were further affected by suspension of the Piccadilly Tube line in the west of London. here were no District line services between Acton Town and Ealing Broadway and no services on the Central line between North Acton and Ealing Broadway.

Scotland Yard has appealed for information about who may have been responsible for today's device.

fields.headline: Part 3: Queen Elizabeth
fields.trailText: The abdication did not make for a smooth transition between monarchs.
fields.body:
The abdication did not make for a smooth transition between monarchs.

Outside Buckingham Palace, souvenir shops marked down plaster busts of the old king to clear.

In the Commons, several members suggested Britain should become a republic whereas some politicians, such as Winston Churchill, openly supported Edward.

With an impending war, the coronation of Albert, who became King George VI, was a dull affair. Despite the King's frustrated efforts to avert the crisis by writing to Hitler man-to-man, the monarch had no power over his own politicians. War was declared in September 1939.

The new Queen, who with her husband had supported appeasement of Hitler and made the very unconstitutional decision to laud prime minister Neville Chamberlain on the balcony of Buckingham Palace in thanks for the Munich agreement, soon switched tack and became determined to do all she could for the war effort. She made the astonishing declaration that neither she nor her children would leave the country.

"The princesses would never leave without me, and I couldn't leave without the King, and the King will never leave," she said. She put Buckingham Palace on the same rations as the rest of the country, sent a copy of Mein Kampf to the foreign secretary Lord Halifax (in case he was unclear what the country was fighting for), toured air-raid shelters and visited the bombed industrial cities.

When a Nazi bomber flew down the Mall and dropped its load in the forecourt of Buckingham Palace, the Queen said: "It makes me feel as if I can look the East End in the face."

The war did, however, seal a powerful alliance between herself, Churchill and the King that did much to cement the monarchy in the years that followed. During the victory celebrations, she looked down from a balcony at the crowds on the Mall.

In 1947 her eldest daughter, Elizabeth, married Prince Philip. As a member of the Greek and Danish royal House of Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg-Gluksburg Philip did not have a family name and after much deliberation he was permitted to call himself Mountbatten - an anglicisation of Battenburg, a name already held by some members of the family.

In 1952 Philip and his wife, now the Duke and Duchess of Edinburgh, found themselves thrust to the head of the family and the state. The King, who had long been ill with lung cancer, suffered a coronary thrombosis and died in his bed.

The Queen blamed the throne - George had been a sickly child and an ill-equipped prince - but he had also been a chain smoker all his adult life.


Queen Mother

fields.headline: An introduction
fields.standfirst: For the next two weeks we will be carrying reports from the Dragon School's cricket tour to Barbados. Find out how the First XI and the Under-12s get on by reading regular updates from James Schneider, captain of cricket, on wisden.com
fields.trailText: The Dragon School in Oxford is a preparatory school of about 700 pupils split roughly 50/50 between day pupils and boarders and 70/30 between boys and girls.
fields.body:
The Dragon School in Oxford is a preparatory school of about 700 pupils split roughly 50/50 between day pupils and boarders and 70/30 between boys and girls.

The school has something of a reputation for expeditions and tours. This one to Barbados is for the First XI and an Under-12 side. There are 28 players and, counting staff, parents and other camp followers, about 50 people in all. We are in Barbados for two weeks and both sides will be playing about six games each. So far this season our results have been mixed with the English summer the clear winner.

There are many famous Old Dragons. Tim Henman comes immediately to mind. As a journalist and ambassador, perhaps one thinks of Peter Jay. I would like to think that this column will put you in mind of John Betjeman.

My name is James Schneider. I am captain of cricket. About half of us left school last Saturday, so this is very much a valedictory tour. The next sighting will be at Old Dragons functions and, come September, we all become new boys all over again.

The problem with selection for this tour (and the reason why Richard Keeble, aka RAK, and Noll Jenkins, the masters in charge, laugh at David Graveney's problems) is that the squad was selected a year ago. Like Steve Waugh, I had no input into selection. Let me hope I do not say, as A.C. Maclaren famously did "Look who they have sent me now!"

To learn more about the school click here

fields.headline: Part 1: Lady Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon
fields.trailText: Lady Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon was born in London, in the hot summer of 1900, to the Bowes-Lyons, one of Scotland's leading aristocratic families. She enjoyed a privileged Edwardian childhood, split between the West End for the "London season", Glamis castle in Scotland (the fictional home of Macbeth) and the family home near Hitchin, Hertfordshire.
fields.body:
Lady Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon was born in London, in the hot summer of 1900, to the Bowes-Lyons, one of Scotland's leading aristocratic families. She enjoyed a privileged Edwardian childhood, split between the West End for the "London season", Glamis castle in Scotland (the fictional home of Macbeth) and the family home near Hitchin, Hertfordshire.

Family entertaining taught her to listen to the most distinguished elderly aristocrats and led one observer to remark that she was "the most extraordinary child for knowing the right thing to say." She attended a private academy on Sloane Street for eight months until her mother decided it was taking too much time out of the day and appointed a German-born tutor, Kathie Kuebler, to guide her through everything a young lady was expected to learn.

The first world war put an end to her education, when Fraulein Kuebler was told her services were no longer required. Elizabeth's elder brother, Fergus, was killed at the battle of Loos while she spent the war years in Glamis caring for wounded soldiers.

When peace returned, Elizabeth came out at society balls and functions as, according to some, a flirtatious young debutante. fields.headline: Hollywood husbandry
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about which movie stars are backing whom in the US presidential election campaign
fields.trailText: All you need to know about which movie stars are backing whom in the US presidential election campaign
fields.body:
1. George W Bush may have more money in his presidential campaign fund than Al Gore, but the vice president has cornered the market in donations and endorsements from Hollywood celebrities.

2. The vice president is backed by some of the biggest names in showbiz, including Robert De Niro, Harrison Ford, Gwyneth Paltrow, and Sharon Stone.

3. No fewer than 17 Oscar winners have given $1000 (£670) to the Gore campaign - the maximum legal individual donation.

4. The best Bush can boast by way of stellar support, comes from the likes of songstress Loretta Lynn and tough-guy Chuck Norris.

5. The gallant but doomed campaign of eco-crusader Ralph Nader is also attracting some of Hollywood's surplus cash, including donations from Paul Newman and Sarah Sarandon. But third party candidates, in general, do not have star appeal.

6. Hollywood endorsements are held to be invaluable by presidential runners, who hope that some of the glamour will rub off on them. Glamour is an especially precious commodity in the Democrat camp. Their candidate is, inevitably, known as Al Bore.

7. Bore - whoops, Gore - enjoys celeb-association. His roommate at Harvard was Tommy Lee Jones, who was the inspiration for the lead character in the 1970 blockbuster novel Love Story. The vice president got into a bit of bother for suggesting that he, not his thespian roommate, was the inspiration for author Erich Segal.

8. Bush, whose opinion poll lead is shrinking, also has his detractors. They call him Dubya because of the way he pronounces his middle initial (say it out loud and all will become clear).

9. Bush has a war chest of more than $88m. Gore has just over $51m, while rightwing maverick Pat Buchanan has a measly $10m, and veteran eco-crusader Ralph Nader has just $675,000.

10. The most successful Hollywood endorsement of all time was that of fading matinee idol and commie-basher Ronald Reagan, who backed himself to win, and did.
