fields.headline: Straw boost for police
fields.trailText: Jack Straw pledged today to boost police numbers to record levels, with 9,000 new recruits funded by chancellor Gordon Brown's £43bn spending settlement.
fields.body:
Jack Straw pledged today to boost police numbers to record levels, with 9,000 new recruits funded by chancellor Gordon Brown's £43bn spending settlement.

The home secretary told the House of Commons that the bulk of the £1.6bn extra money granted by the chancellor of the exchequer yesterday would be spent on recruiting officers and investing in the latest police equipment and new anti-crime technology.

"The major investment outlined today will ensure that the police are better funded and better equipped than they have ever been before," Mr Straw said.

Police funding will increase by more than 20% by 2003-4, making spending on police in that year total £9.3bn.

Mr Straw acknowledged that police numbers in England and Wales have fallen by 1,678 in the past year to 124,418 and conceded that "predicting future numbers is very difficult".

But he forecast he would successfully reverse eight years of decline. He said he had already provided new money to pay for 5,000 more recruits and announced funding for a further 4,000, making 9,000 extra recruits by 2003.

New police technology will include the public safety radio communications system, a new police radio network the government will back with £500m, and information technology systems. The Home Office will also make additional investment in the police DNA database.

Mr Straw promised £300m each year for programmes targeting vehicle crime, domestic burglary, robbery and violent crime, and drugs offending.

The home secretary said the new settlement would fund a dedicated national confiscation agency which would deprive organised criminals of their assets and a new building programme to provide 2,660 more prison places.

fields.headline: Part 4: Queen Mother
fields.trailText: Queen Mary, the wife of George V, had been widowed many years earlier and taken the title of Queen Dowager.
fields.body:
Queen Mary, the wife of George V, had been widowed many years earlier and taken the title of Queen Dowager.

The newly crowned Queen Elizabeth II disliked it and let her mother call herself Queen Elizabeth, the Queen Mother. It was decided that she should move to Clarence House (a comparatively small residence she openly detested) so the new monarch and her consort could take their place at the palace.

Being a widow did not suit the 51-year-old Queen Mother. She had lost not only her husband but also his many royal houses - Buckingham Palace, Windsor, Sandringham and Balmoral - along with her role in national life.

The Queen Mother consoled herself with the purchase of a dilapidated pile on the Scottish west coast which she intended to use as her retirement home after renovation. Churchill visited her that summer at Balmoral and insisted that she could not shrink away from public life as Queen Victoria had done after the death of Prince Albert. He said she had to support her daughter, who at that time was still a young Queen.

In 1954 she flew to America to collect a cheque for a George VI memorial fund and began the round of official duties, functions and openings that have become her occupation.

As a widow she became the president or patron of 312 organisations. She made history too: the Queen Mother was the first woman to be chancellor of London university and, later, the first female lord warden and admiral of the cinque ports.

However, the family was her true sphere of influence: when Queen Mary died in 1953 the Queen Mother became the royal family's matriarch.

She was an obstacle to reform: a fan of pomp and circumstance who bitterly opposed the notion that members of the royal family should pay tax. Her closeness to her grandson, Charles, embroiled her in the family's biggest crisis since the abdication.

When it became clear that Diana would not behave as she believed a royal should, the Queen Mother became the princess's greatest enemy (a mutual hatred recorded in Andrew Morton's Diana: her true story, in her own words). Diana believed that the Queen Mother saw her as a second Wallis Simpson and that she had persuaded other family members that the princess was out to undermine all that the Windsors stood for. Such revelations momentarily took the shine off the Queen Mother's status as the "nation's favourite grandmother". Although she is known for her smile, for a long time only her closest companions knew what lay behind it.

In 1998 Woodrow Wyatt's diaries confirmed what many former courtiers had said. The Queen Mother was portrayed as an elderly woman who adored Margaret Thatcher and apartheid-supporting South African PW Botha, disliked Europe, the unions and middle classes, was against immigration and regretted the loss of imperial possessions in Africa.

The Queen Mother believes that it is the duty of a royal to behave like a royal. To this end she lives in almost Edwardian splendour at Clarence House; with six cars, three chauffeurs, five chefs, two pages, three footmen, two dressers and 30 more assorted secretaries, maids, treasurers and housekeepers. As a hobby she breeds racehorses.

The Queen Mother receives £ 643,000 a year from the civil list but this goes only a very short way to covering her running costs and she is subsidised by her daughter. Nevertheless, her lavish tastes have still seen her £4m overdrawn at the royal bank, Coutts.

She is also a keen drinker, often enjoying a triple gin before eating and a glass of champagne with her meal. Entertainment comes high on her list of priorities. On her 98th birthday she went to parties, took in a show, had dinner and turned into bed at 1.30am.

Her life has followed this pattern from the 1920s, when she had been a society girl and during her time as Queen Consort, through to her later years as an elderly member of the royal family.

fields.headline: Summer on a shoestring
fields.standfirst: Fifty things to do with your children for £5 or under during the holidays. By  Angelique Chrisafis
fields.trailText: Fifty things to do with your children for £5 or under during the holidays.
fields.body:
Ages 3-5

London area

July 31-August 4: Pizzazz. Interactive children's entertainment. Clowns and cabaret. 11am, 1pm and 3pm. Free. Bushy Park, Hampton Court Road, Middlesex . Tel: 020 8979 1586.

July 31-August 4: Wally! Children's entertainer performs slapstick stunts. 11am, 1pm and 3pm. Playground, Greenwich Park, Blackheath Gate, London SE10. Tel: 020 8858 2608 for prices. Throughout July and August:

Bethnal Green Museum of Childhood art workshops. Saturdays 11am, 12noon, 2pm and 3pm. Free. Cambridge Heath Road, London E2. Tel: 020 8983 5200. Throughout July and August.

Tate Britain art trolley activities. Sundays 2-5pm. Free. Millbank, London SW1. Tel: 020 7887 8000.

Around Britain

July 27: Teddy bears' picnic. Lunch, magicians, storytellers and best-dressed teddy contest. 2pm-4.30pm. Adults £2.50. Children £2. Charlecote Park, Wellesbourne, Warwickshire. Tel: 01789 470277.

July 22-23: Summer fair weekend, Paxton House. Fundraising weekend with stalls, children's entertainers and teddy bear auction. From 11am. Adults £2.50, children £1. Paxton House, Berwick-upon-Tweed, Northumberland. Tel: 01289 386291.

August 3: Children's day, Penhryn Castle. Mr Bimbamboozle and his puppet workshop followed by Punch and Judy. Noon-4pm. Adults £3, children £2. Free for National Trust members. Penhryn Castle, Bangor, Gwynedd, Wales. Tel: 01248 353084.

August 6: Tameside teddy bears' picnic. Entertainers and stories. 1pm-4pm. Free. Park Bridge visitors' centre, Park Bridge, Tameside. Tel: 0161 342 3006.

August 2 and 9: Family beachcombing with the National Trust. Children build sand and shell creations with their finds. From 2pm. Donations welcome. Sandscale Haws, near Barrow, Cumbria. Tel: 015394 35599.

August 19-20: Teddy bears' picnic. Fun and games with Blossom the Clown. Bring a picnic. From 2pm. Adults £2.50, children £1.30. St Mawes Castle, Cornwall. Tel: 01326 270526.

Ages 5-8

London area

Throughout July: Shadow puppet workshops. Put on your own puppet show. Daily at 12.30pm and 3pm. Children free. Adults £4.50. Theatre Museum, Russell Street, London WC2. Tel: 020 7943 4700.

Throughout July and August: Medieval brass rubbing. Create knights, kings and beasts. Monday - Saturday 10am-6pm. Sunday 12noon-6pm. Entrance free. To make your own metre-tall image costs £3. London Brass Rubbing Centre, St Martin-in-the-Fields Church, Trafalgar Square, London WC2. Tel: 020 7930 9306.

July 24-August 3: Curious quest Art adventures, Tate Britain. Families solve a mysterious quest by exploring clues and signs in artworks on display. Monday - Thursday 11am-12.30pm and 2pm-5pm. £3 per child. Adults free. Tate Britain, Millbank SW1. Tel: 020 7887 8000.

July 25, August 1, 8, 15, 22: Tales from around the world. African and native American theatre and folk tales. 2pm. £1 per child. Horniman Gardens, 100 London Road, Forest Hill, London SE23. Tel: 020 8699 1872.

Around Britain

July 26-August 30: Ugly bug safari. Creepy crawlies exploration. Daily from 10am. £2. Berrington Hall, near Leominster, Herefordshire. Tel: 01568 615721.

July 26. Mini beast safari. Environmental project for children. Bring a jam jar and magnifying glass. 10am. Free but booking is essential. Marton Mere Nature Reserve, Blackpool. Tel: 01253 830805. (Big insect and bat safaris continue throughout August. Call for details.)

August 9: Reptile celebrities. Children can meet and learn about large, live reptiles. 10.30am-11.30am, 2pm-3pm and 3:30pm-4.30pm. £3. Booth Museum of Natural History, 194 Dyke Road, Brighton. Tel: 01273 292777.

August 12-13: More skulduggery! Pirate show and buried treasure. From noon. Adults £1.70. Children 90p. Whitby Abbey, North Yorkshire. Tel: 01947 603568.

August 28: The Curious eyebrows family show. Performers teach children how to juggle and walk a tightrope. Noon-4pm. Adults £3.50 and children £1.80. East Riddleden Hall, Keighley, Yorkshire. Tel: 01535 607075.

Ages 8-11

London area

Throughout July: Circuswurx. Unicycling, juggling, stiltwalking classes. Thursdays, 7pm-9pm. £1.50 per child. The Hawth, Hawth Avenue, Crawley, West Sussex. Tel: 01293 553636.

Throughout July and August: Explorers and viewpoints. Time capsule trails around Tate Modern. Go to the information desk in Turbine Hall, and Levels three and five. Daily, from 10am. Free. Tate Modern, 25, Sumner Street, London SE1. Tel: 020 7887 8000.

July 23: Flower power. Turn trash into wild beasts in this scrap-modelling workshop. 12.30pm and 5.30pm. Free. £1 parking fee. Bedfont Lakes Country Park, Middlesex. Tel: 01784 423556.

July 31-August 4: Zogg circus workshop. Learn the skills of the big top. Noon and 2pm. Free. Richmond Park, Pembroke Lodge, Surrey. Tel: 020 8948 3209.

Around Britain

July 22-23: Medieval siege. A 15th-century siege with skirmishes and assaults. From noon. £4. Barnard Castle, County Durham. Tel: 01833 638212.

23 July: Giant kite display. With kite specialist Phil Womack. 9.30am-11.30am. Free. Blackpool beach between North and Central Piers. Tel: 01253 478222.

July and August: Artworks. Interactive exhibition where children fill rooms with sound, by moving their bodies near hidden sensors and finger painting with light. Sunday - Wednesday 10am-5pm. Thursday - Saturday 10am-8pm. £3.75. Free for under fours. The Lowry, Pier 8, Salford Quays. Tel: 0161 876 2000.

July 30, August 6, 20: Bat and owl safari. Explore the woods armed with bat detectors. Bring a torch. Adults £2.50, children £1. RSPB Lake Vyrnwy Nature Reserve, Llanwyddn, Shropshire. Tel: 01691 870278 for times.

August 19-20: Roman kitchen. Make and taste Roman cuisine. From noon. Adults £3. Children £1.50. Lullingstone Roman Villa, Kent. Tel: 01322 863467.

Ages 11+

London area

July 29-August 13: Portobello festival breakdance events. Featuring Feet Per Minute (as seen on Da Ali G show). Free. Call 020 8964 4419 for times or www.portobellofestival.com

Around Britain

27 July: Poetry and pictures workshops. Write and paint with artist John Siddique, writer in residence at the Lowry. 11am-1pm, 2pm-4pm. £3 (£2.50 for Salford residents). The Lowry, Pier 8, Salford Quays. Tel: 0161 876 2000.

July 27, 28, 29: Romeo and Juliet. Brazilian street theatre adaptation from Grupo Galpao, with stilt walkers, mime and puppeteers. 7.30pm. Free. Great Northern Square, Manchester. Tel: 0161 234 1964 or www.the-manchester-festival.org.uk

July 29-30. Have a go archery. 14th-century bowmen teach the art of firing an arrow. From noon. Adults £2.60. Children £1.80. Mount Grace Priory, North Yorkshire. Tel: 01609 883494.

August 13: Wild alive day: Up close. RSPB's wildlife photography workshop for 11-16 year-olds. 10am-3pm. £3.75. Bring a camera. Fairburn Ings Nature Reserve, Castleford, West Yorkshire. Tel: 01767 680551.

All ages

London area

Throughout July and August: Australia dreaming. Themed activities from boomerang lessons to digeridoo workshops. Tuesday-Sunday, 10am-5pm. Free. Commonwealth Institute, Kensington, London W8. Tel: 020 7603 4535 or www.commonwealth.org.uk

July 14-August 13: Ealing summer festival. Stalls and performers, including a beach camp - a water-proof beach in a tent with end-of-pier shows, rides and workshops. Prices and times vary. Walpole Park, Ealing. Tel: 020 8579 5436 or www.ealing.gov.uk/summer

July-August: Coin Street carnival. Community celebration including puppet shows, face painting and a parade. From 11am. Free. Bernie Spain Gardens, Upper Ground, South Bank, London SE1. Tel: 020 7401 2255.

July 22-23: East London mela. South Asian bazaar, crafts fair, children's events, storytelling and kite displays. From 11am. Free. Wanstead Flats, London E11. Tel: 020 8430 2000.

August 26-28: Notting Hill Carnival. Children's carnival day is August 27 with stalls and floats. From 11am. Free. Tel: 020 8964 0544.

Until September 1: annual summer festival of events at Theatre Square and terraces of National Theatre. Includes magic, street theatre, acrobatics, comedians. Free. Tel: 020 7452 3327 for times.

Around Britain

29 July: Fireworks fantasia. Fireworks and live music. 7pm. £5 or group ticket at £2 per person. Cannon Hill Park, Edgbaston. Tel: 0121 464 2000.

August 1-4: Play Village 2000. Daily activities include painting, sculpture, sport and drama, rides and nature trails. 10am-5pm. £1 per session. Cannon Hill Park, Edgbaston. Tel: 0121 464 2000.

August 2: National play day, Tameside. Arts in the park. Arts and crafs activities and a waterborne pageant. From 2pm. Free. Oxford Park, Ashton-under-Lyme, Tameside. Tel: 0161 342 3311.

August 2: National play day, Hove. Bouncy castles, face painting, drumming, workshops. 11am-3pm. Free. Hove Park, Old Shoreham Road, Hove, Sussex. Tel: 01273 292724.

August 2-6: Merseyside international street festival. Dancers, acrobats, puppeteers, workshops and more. Free. Albert Dock, Liverpool and Bluecoat Arts Centre, School Lane, Liverpool. Tel: 0151 709 3334 for details.

August 4-7: Beccles carnival. Clowns, music, drawings, stalls. From 10am. Free. The Quay, Beccles, Suffolk. Tel: 01502 712627.

August 11 and 12. Street biz. Street theatre, comedy and circus. 11.30am-5.30pm. Free. Victoria Square, Chamberlain Square and New Street, Birmingham. Tel: 0121 464 2000.

August 12-13: Summertime spectacular weekend. Themed nature activities included guided walks and the chance to see seabird chicks being fed by their parents. From 11am. Adults £3, children £1.50. RSPB Bempton Cliffs Nature Reserve, Bridlington, East Yorkshire. Tel: 01262 851179.

fields.headline: Boiled eggs and guilt trips
fields.standfirst: Trying:  Leah Wild's IVF diary
fields.trailText: Trying: Leah Wild's IVF diary
fields.body:
I've become obsessed with eggs. I cook them up by the half-dozen, hardboiled, and keep them in the fridge. I eat two for breakfast. When I get home from work, I pop another one in my mouth, smeared with mayonnaise. If I'm peckish later on, I might even have a fourth, with a sprinkle of salt, before I go to bed.

My obsession began many weeks ago when I was travelling down in the lift from an appointment at the assisted conception unit. My boyfriend and I had been briefed about the pre-implantation genetic diagnosis procedure, and the necessity to harvest a good batch of my eggs, in the hope that at least a few would be unaffected. On the floor below, a woman wearing a white overall, her hair covered with a white net cap, entered the lift. She was carrying a large white bucket, the sort you need to mop the floor with, and on the bucket was written just two words - READY EGGS. My God, I thought, some lucky infertile woman has produced a whole bucketload of them! And they carry them around like that, without even a lid on!

I leaned over to peer at the fine batch. I saw dozens of hardboiled eggs bobbing up and down in salted water. I had mistaken the woman's uniform. She wasn't a doctor; she worked in the canteen. She was on her way to slap together some egg mayonnaise sandwiches. Since then, all and any eggs have become symbolic of my eggs.

There's a strong connection between food and sex. Babette's Feast, one of the most erotic films of all time, is, as far as I can remember, totally devoid of any naked flesh. The film's sensuality comes entirely from the consumption of gargantuan meals with greasy fingers. Sex and oral consumption are even confused at the infertility clinic. Just by the reception desk there's a blue icebox, the sort designed to keep beer and egg mayonnaise sandwiches cool, with "semen samples" written on top.

Yet, ironically, when trying to get pregnant the simple act of eating becomes hugely problematic. We are bombarded with advice and warnings until the only thing it seems safe to swallow is a daily capsule of folic acid. I believe this heavy emphasis on a wholesome mother producing a wholesome full-term child is misguided. What you eat doesn't cause autism, what you drink doesn't cause cerebral palsy, and whatever else you do doesn't cause Down's syndrome. Despite claims of books with titles such as Planning for a Healthy Baby, there's no guarantee that little Benjamin will turn out even with all four limbs intact. But what this plethora of advice does promise is to make most early pregnancies extremely stressful. And it erroneously places the blame for any difference or disability in a child on the mother and her behaviour.

I am still waiting to hear about intensive investigations into things outside a potential mother's control, such as my own chromosomal condition, which causes frequent miscarriages and is utterly unaffected by what I imbibe. Or into the father-to-be who must, even in the majority of IVF conceptions, provide half of the raw material. Yet the latest research project into miscarriages continues to focus on women. A national lottery grant has enabled the Miscarriage Association to commission a two-year research project to ascertain whether certain things - such as smoking, caffeine, alcohol, stress and air travel - can influence the outcome of a pregnancy. It seems that every little piece of pleasure for a would-be mother - from a glass of Chardonnay to going on holiday - is potentially harmful to her child. Better to stay home and stay sober. The only thing you are permitted to indulge in is self-blame.

But while we have to monitor every mouthful of double espresso, it's deemed perfectly acceptable for us IVF patients to take vast amounts of drugs that make us feel nauseous. The notes accompanying my daily injection of FSH, a natural hormone, warn it makes some women suffer morning sickness. Morning sickness? But I'm not pregnant - I'm infertile and trying to get pregnant. Throughout my four pregnancies that ended in miscarriage, I vomited each morning. Now I've got morning sickness when I'm not even pregnant. Sometimes life seems very unfair.

But generally the news is good. I had my ovaries scanned a couple of days ago, and the follicles are measuring up nicely, which suggests they're plump with eggs. In a few days time, I'm booked in for "retrieval", when any eggs in my fattened ovaries will be removed. I must remember to have some boiled eggs the night before, for luck. And I may well wash them down with a nice strong cup of coffee.

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: As yet another study shows an apparent genetic difference between boys and girls (this time that girls are programmed to speak earlier), we ask: is there any point even trying to bring up boys and girls the same?
fields.trailText: The Question: As yet another study shows an apparent genetic difference between boys and girls (this time that girls are programmed to speak earlier), we ask: is there any point even trying to bring up boys and girls the same?
fields.body:
Angela Neustatter Writer and feminist and mother of two sons

It's not about bringing them up identically, it's about bringing them up appropriately. I don't think you can bring them up the same, and it's a mistake to assume you can. You should give them the same opportunities, but you've got to recognise that men get particular messages, and you've got to be responsive to that. It's very important to give the message that both are equally good - in the 70s there was this fear among some feminist mothers of male children over what they would grow up to be. I think you should talk to boys about empathy and to give them permission to have feelings. Verdict: No.

Mary Walton Mother of four, including twins Matilda and Edward

My twins don't fit into the stereotypes. Edward's speech is better than Matilda's, and he was ahead in potty-training, too. The main difference I notice is in physical energy. Edward has lots of it, and I definitely feel I have to take him out several times every day, just so he can run around. I know some people would have bought him guns and weapon toys, but I've made it clear it's not something I want. I don't think we're bringing up Edward any differently from Matilda, although I think it's very important always to respond to your children individually. Verdict: Yes.

Maria Pizzoni Mother of five, including twins Martha and Ned

There's definitely an inbuilt difference between Ned and Martha - he's a lot more physical than her, and throws himself around in a way she doesn't. Martha is more articulate: she was able to call herself by her name before he could. Our older children are girls, and the twins have their toys. Ned does sometimes play with them in a different way. We got him a few toys with wheels, but he doesn't seem particularly interested. Apart from that, we don't treat him any differently from the girls. There's no sense of any toys in the house being "just for boys" or "just for girls". Verdict: Yes.

Professor Philip Dale Researcher into twins and language published this week

Research in which I was involved shows that, when you compare boy-girl twins, girls seem to have an advantage. But the difference between fast girls and slow girls, or fast boys and slow boys, is far greater than the difference between boys and girls. What matters most is to respond to the individual child, following the child's lead. Drop stereotypes if they get in the way, don't let your preconceived ideas of the sort of dressing up a young child does, for example, get in the way of self-expression. But you don't need to treat every child the same, either. Verdict: No.

Wendy Scott Of the British Association for Early Childhood Education

I think it's very important to recognise that we have a cultural favouritism for girls, and that we need to be aware of it and to challenge it. We're too quick to regard boys as problems because they're often more physical and need more space, whereas girls may be more biddable and easier to control. But boys need to be included rather than defined as difficult, and it's actually cutting off learning for them if we don't understand that, because children learn in different ways. We need to change our perceptions on this, and there will be benefits for girls as well as boys if we do. Verdict: Yes

fields.headline: Truth hurts
fields.standfirst:
Sean Stone didn't tell his six-year-old about the brutal murder of Sarah Payne, but she found out anyway. Everyone at school, she says, is talking about it. Which leaves him with a problem: how do you explain the inexplicable?

More about the Sarah Payne case
fields.trailText: Sean Stone didn't tell his six-year-old about the brutal murder of Sarah Payne, but she found out anyway. Everyone at school, she says, is talking about it. Which leaves him with a problem: how do you explain the inexplicable?
fields.body:
It is the baldness of her statement that disturbs me. For a second, it almost seems funny. I am sitting on the steps of our house, reading the paper, as our youngest daughter waltzes up and down the pavement on her bike. "Daddy, don't read," she says. "You've got to watch me all the time. You know what happened to Sarah Payne."

She's six years old, and not noticeably in touch with reality. I've never heard her referring to a news story before. There is no panic in her voice. Just a matter of factness. "Someone may come and take me away if you don't watch." When I was her age, I was riding my bike down to the local shops, doing all sorts of messages for my mum.

I ask her who Sarah Payne is. "She's a little girl who was taken away, kidnapped." What does kidnapped mean? "Taken away when you don't want to be, by a man." By now she is bored with my questioning, and hops back on her bike.

Perhaps I'm becoming rose-tinted, but I thought it was parents who told their children about the dangers they had to be aware of, rather than the other way round. Now she's providing the information and setting out the rules. How do I respond? What if I disagree with what she says I must do to keep her safe?

A few minutes later she tells me a bit more about Sarah - how she'd been taken away by a man in a white van, and how everyone at school is looking out for white vans driven by an odd-looking strangers. Then she is off down the street again.

Next day I phone the Anna Freud Centre, which is chock-a-block with child psychotherapists. I have never done anything like this before, and I feel uneasy. "Yes," says Julia Fabricius, the director, "it's a tricky one isn't it? Can I ask you what you said to your daughter?" She admits she's struggling for an answer, and isn't sure if there is one. I tell her I'm not sure what the question is. What made me feel most troubled was how calm, how clinical, my daughter's response was. Fabricius says this may well be because she doesn't understand the full enormity of it.

"I guess I'd try to find out where she got the information from, what she actually knows. Her version of the story may be far from the truth. Listening to what children have heard is very important."

When I was a child my fears were rooted in fiction and movies - Chitty Chitty Bang Bang, Oliver Twist. The fate of children who were taken and abused scared me, but I always knew they were stories. Perhaps we were more immune to the everyday horrors of the world because we weren't so saturated in media. TV was new, special, more controlled. There was a clear distinction between children's telly and adult telly, and we followed the rules. Playschool didn't segue into the news, or maybe it's that we knew to turn it off when it did.

Steve Biddulph, psychologist and childcare expert, believes it is unhealthy for children to read, watch or listen to news until they are nine: "Constant exposure to things they can do nothing about can create emotional agitation and even mental illness." He argues that it gives them a skewed vision of life because it focuses on horrors they're not equipped to deal with. Which is fair enough - but surely it gives you just as twisted a perspective if you think that life is one long lovefest. And if you're prepared to lock up your sons and daughters for their first decade, you may censor the life out of them.

Jan Parker, co-author of Raising Happy Children, tells me of the time her then four-year-old twins were riding the roundabout at Ikea as a post-traumatic shopping treat. Halfway through the ride, Capital Radio turned into the news - the chilling court report on the trial of Fred West, detailing the murders he committed. Parker says she tried to take the kids off the roundabout, asked herself how the hell she was going to answer the children's questions. As it happens, she needn't have worried. "They'd not taken any of it in. Because it was so far beyond their comprehension, it went straight over their heads," she says.

Parker thinks the case of Sarah Payne is different: "Most children of school age can relate to the story of another child who has been taken away." She says that a young girl has just knocked on the door to play with her kids, and the child's opening gambit was: "They've found the body." The children talked about it, and it soon became clear they didn't really understand what this meant. One suggested the doctors could still make her better.

Parker feels the important thing is to talk to them, set them straight, tell them enough to enable them to feel safe and to counter playground rumour: "It helps to stress that these are extremely rare incidents and to talk with them about what they can do to if they feel threatened." The thing you don't want to do, says Parker, is tell them more information than they need or have requested, or suggest that behind every hedge hides a bogeyman.

Many children will have seen yesterday's tabloids. They were almost as brutal and terrifying as Sarah's death. "NAIL THE BASTARD", screamed the Sun's front page. The Mirror ran a sensationalist spread picturing 22 kids who had been killed. Under the headline "How can we stop this despicable slaughter of young children?", Brian Reade wrote: "I want whoever killed little Sarah to spend his life dodging razor blades in his food, needing an armed guard when he takes a shower and fearing his throat being slashed every night. Hanging these bastards really is too good for them."

Now there seem to be two problems. First, how do we explain Sarah's death and, second, how do we explain the violence of the media's response? I suppose we shouldn't assume that children understand news in the way we do. They need to be told that when an incident is splashed all over the papers it is because it is unusual rather than the norm, although sometimes children seem more aware of this than we do.

When I arrive home my daughter has more news about Sarah. "She's dead," she says. "It's really sad isn't it Daddy?" she says. Yes, I say, it's horrible, and prepare for one of those painful conversations about why anyone could do this. But she walks off. A couple of minutes later she calls me back. "Daddy, have you seen the fairy house I made?" she asks.

Then she is off down the street again. Next day I phone the Anna Freud Centre, which is chock-a-block with child psychotherapists. I have never done anything like this before, and I feel uneasy. "Yes," says Julia Fabricius, the director, "it's a tricky one isn't it? Can I ask you what you said to your daughter?" She admits she's struggling for an answer, and isn't sure if there is one. I tell her I'm not sure what the question is. What made me feel most troubled was how calm, how clinical, my daughter's response was. Fabricius says this may well be because she doesn't understand the full enormity of it. "I guess I'd try to find out where she got the information from, what she actually knows. Her version of the story may be far from the truth. Listening to what children have heard is very important." When I was a child my fears were rooted in fiction and movies - Chitty Chitty Bang Bang, Oliver Twist. The fate of children who were taken and abused scared me, but I always knew they were stories. Perhaps we were more immune to the everyday horrors of the world because we weren't so saturated in media. TV was new, special, more controlled. There was a clear distinction between children's telly and adult telly, and we followed the rules. Playschool didn't segue into the news, or maybe it's that we knew to turn it off when it did. Steve Biddulph, psychologist and childcare expert, believes it is unhealthy for children to read, watch or listen to news until they are nine: "Constant exposure to things they can do nothing about can create emotional agitation and even mental illness." He argues that it gives them a skewed vision of life because it focuses on horrors they're not equipped to deal with. Which is fair enough - but surely it gives you just as twisted a perspective if you think that life is one long lovefest. And if you're prepared to lock up your sons and daughters for their first decade, you may censor the life out of them. Jan Parker, co-author of Raising Happy Children, tells me of the time her then four-year-old twins were riding the roundabout at Ikea as a post-traumatic shopping treat. Halfway through the ride, Capital Radio turned into the news - the chilling court report on the trial of Fred West, detailing the murders he committed. Parker says she tried to take the kids off the roundabout, asked herself how the hell she was going to answer the children's questions. As it happens, she needn't have worried. "They'd not taken any of it in. Because it was so far beyond their comprehension, it went straight over their heads," she says. Parker thinks the case of Sarah Payne is different: "Most children of school age can relate to the story of another child who has been taken away." She says that a young girl has just knocked on the door to play with her kids, and the child's opening gambit was: "They've found the body." The children talked about it, and it soon became clear they didn't really understand what this meant. One suggested the doctors could still make her better. Parker feels the important thing is to talk to them, set them straight, tell them enough to enable them to feel safe and to counter playground rumour: "It helps to stress that these are extremely rare incidents and to talk with them about what they can do to if they feel threatened." The thing you don't want to do, says Parker, is tell them more information than they need or have requested, or suggest that behind every hedge hides a bogeyman. Many children will have seen yesterday's tabloids. They were almost as brutal and terrifying as Sarah's death. "NAIL THE BASTARD", screamed the Sun's front page. The Mirror ran a sensationalist spread picturing 22 kids who had been killed. Under the headline "How can we stop this despicable slaughter of young children?", Brian Reade wrote: "I want whoever killed little Sarah to spend his life dodging razor blades in his food, needing an armed guard when he takes a shower and fearing his throat being slashed every night. Hanging these bastards really is too good for them." Now there seem to be two problems. First, how do we explain Sarah's death and, second, how do we explain the violence of the media's response? I suppose we shouldn't assume that children understand news in the way we do. They need to be told that when an incident is splashed all over the papers it is because it is unusual rather than the norm, although sometimes children seem more aware of this than we do. When I arrive home my daughter has more news about Sarah. "She's dead," she says. "It's really sad isn't it Daddy?" she says. Yes, I say, it's horrible, and prepare for one of those painful conversations about why anyone could do this. But she walks off. A couple of minutes later she calls me back. "Daddy, have you seen the fairy house I made?" she asks.

fields.headline: Water works wonders
fields.standfirst: Restoring a canal in Calcutta could ease the city's congestion
fields.trailText: Restoring a canal in Calcutta could ease the city's congestion.
fields.body:
British Waterways, itself recovering from a century of decline, is exporting its expertise and developing a plan to revive a canal built in Calcutta in the heyday of the British raj.

The North Calcutta Canal, a 30-mile stretch of derelict waterway, could become a new passenger and trade route in what is one of the most crowded and congested cities on earth.

The canal connects the River Hooghly in Calcutta to the River Bidyadhari in Kulti but is badly silted and has 8,000 people living in shanties on its banks.

For as little as £15m the canal could be restored to full working order. First priority for the West Bengal authorities to relieve the city roads is to provide a high-speed passenger shuttle service six miles from the edge of the city to the centre, for up to 40,000 people a day. A small, high-speed water taxi service would be provided for business travellers.

New vessels would be needed to take between 30,000 and 50,000 tonnes of freight a week off the city roads with the aim of reopening the river canal network to bring 2m tonnes of freight a year into the city.

For Mark Bensted, London regional director of the waterways, this is just the beginning. He wants to develop Calcutta's canal for tourism and has advised Jyoti Basu, chief minister of West Bengal to provide "hand-crafted" hotel barges to carry up to six passengers; begin canoe safaris into the Sunderbans, the mangrove forest which is the last stronghold of the Bengal tiger; and organise tailored wedding and honeymoon trips. For the less adventurous, he suggests floating Orient Express-style accommodation with heritage tours of Calcutta and nearby Darjeeling.

The government is proposing a new town on the banks of the canal at Rajarhat and are hoping that the waterfront will provide a focal point for restaurants and other leisure activities. Bensted said: "The restored canal will help alleviate Calcutta's chronic transport problems, while providing substantial opportunities for boosting property development and tourism."

fields.headline: A question of survival
fields.standfirst: Immunising possums is proving effective against bovine TB
fields.trailText: Immunising possums is proving effective against bovine TB.
fields.body:
Imagine a countryside filled with badger traps, that were not prisons designed to hold animals until they could be shot, but revolving doors through which wildlife could be enticed for a quick facial spray to vaccinate them against bovine TB.

It is not that fanciful. Tests in New Zealand are well under way to treat possums, blamed for spreading bovine TB in cattle, just as badgers are prime suspects for infecting herds in the UK.

Possums are regarded as pests by most Kiwis, whereas in the UK badgers are protected and even fondly regarded by many farmers, some of whom are now diversifying into badger-watching activities.

Next month, Professor Roger Morris, from Massey University, Palmerston North, in New Zealand, a leading researcher in the vaccine field, will speak at an international conference in Cambridge. He will detail his progress and further stir debate on whether the British government, enmeshed in a bruising public relations battle defending its controversial, if limited, £7m a year badger cull, is really doing enough with its other research spending - £4m last year - into investigating other ways of combating the disease.

Morris said: "If you could eradicate the bovine TB problem in possums, the cattle problem would be solved quickly. The same could be true of the badger bovine TB problem in the UK, from the evidence of extensive scientific data available. We believe that a powerful tool in achieving control is aerosol vaccination of wildlife, using the standard BCG vaccine you and I got as kids."

Researchers at Massey have just completed an extensive field trial on a commercial farm where they have been studying bovine TB for a decade. "When we vaccinated possums over two years, we got 70% reductions in the number of bovine TB cases in the vaccinated ones, and for the last 15 months we appear to have stopped the disease spreading, even in unvaccinated possums. You don't need to vaccinate every animal to stop a disease such as bovine TB."

Morris's team has also been developing a self-vaccinator, with a lure to tempt possums into the equipment which puffs vaccine into the animal's face. Over four nights, 40% of possums on the research site were net into the vaccinator at least once, so it seems to work. "It is looking very promising. It is also very cheap. The approach would seem worth trying in Britain, because it would benefit both badgers and cattle, and progress can be made much faster than by attempting a cattle vaccine, which is 10-20 years away and would be very costly to use."

Morris says terminally ill possums spread bovine TB by wandering round during daytime, when they should be asleep, looking dazed, almost drunk. The curious cattle and deer then investigate any such animal "sniffing it, licking it, and doing everything they can to catch bovine TB from it".

It used to be thought that badgers and possums were quite different but it looks now, Morris says, that bovine TB may spread in the same way. "Cattle have been shown to investigate a stuffed badger just as they do a dizzy possum!"

The government here insists it is interested in Morris's work, which it describes as in its early days. Officials still believe, however, that most hope lies in developing a cattle vaccine, and that is where most of the £1.4m a year vaccine research is going. They warn there could be difficulties in reliably vaccinating wildlife. Using BCG vaccine would present similar problems as it would in cattle, namely that it could interfere with the skin tests currently used to monitor cows for bovine TB.

Baroness Hayman , the deputy agriculture minister, confesses her dearest wish would be "getting a vaccine that is effective tomorrow" and is anxious to learn from abroad. "We would certainly not have a 'not invented here' policy if there was something that was applicable."

fields.headline: Peace talks
fields.standfirst: Patrick Weir reports on how intensive counselling is working for violent prisoners on probation
fields.trailText: Patrick Weir reports on how intensive counselling is working for violent prisoners on probation.
fields.body:
Crime is on the increase and violent crime is rising most of all, official figures yesterday suggested. But a pilot probation scheme aimed specifically at violent offenders has shown such encouraging results that it could soon be introduced nationally.

The scheme, commissioned by the Home Office's "pathfinder" unit, which works on effective approaches to violent crime, was developed by Derbyshire probation service. It draws on extensive research in north America, showing positive effects of intensive counselling. And, unprecedentedly, it involves women offenders as well as men.

Peter Connor, senior probation officer and programme manager, says: "Research into criminology in Canada and the US was found to be significantly ahead of ours. Applying aspects of their systems to an effective practice agenda for our services seemed a logical step to take. Our pilot is the result of this overall push."

A team of counsellors was set up and trained under the guidance of Clive Hollin, professor of psychology at Leicester University, who has worked with violent offenders in the prison service. "Originally, the probation service tended to replicate the work undertaken in prisons," says Connor. "We are still following some of their principles, but linking them with our own work allows for a more intensive approach."

The scheme entails 16, two-hour counselling sessions held twice a week, which can be hard both on staff and offenders. Firstly offenders, who are directed by the courts to attend as a condition of their probation orders, are asked to fill in a questionnaire.

"We want them to try to explain their attitude towards violence," says Connor. "In this way we can evaluate any change in their attitude at the end of the programme. We then ask them to talk about their offence, how responsible they feel, and their thoughts on the victim."

Counselled separately, women offenders are generally liable to be more emotionally open than men and to feel greater compassion for their victims. However, analysing the extent to which crime is a pattern of their behaviour, plus their motivation not to reoffend, applies equally.

"The impact their act of violence has on families and the community, is discussed," Connor says. How they react in potentially violent circumstances will depend on the consequences of previous violent acts. "Accordingly, it can be good or bad as attitude and behaviour become reinforced."

Paul Kenny, programme coordinator responsible for the counselling of male offenders, attests to their initial resentment and macho posturing. But he says he has seen men break down. "When they join the programme they are determined to save face and tend to play to the gallery," he says. "And even when you have gained their respect, many are reluctant to talk about their emotions. One 25-year-old actually admitted that he had never thought about his feelings. He had a lot of emotional baggage which he had bottled up for years. When he eventually felt able to articulate this, you could see how cathartic it was."

In less extreme cases, male offenders have admitted to Kenny that there have been moments in their lives when they have felt insecure or frightened. "I might ask them how they felt while awaiting sentencing," he says. "By deconstructing their feelings, they learn how to express themselves more appropriately."

Offenders are also asked to keep "trigger diaries", noting what makes them feel violent - and to study examples of violence on television. Connor says: "Most of the people we see have committed acts of expressive violence. This involves loss of emotional control and often unplanned acts of aggression. Offenders can learn to recognise and think more objectively about testing situations, whether real or on the screen."

Those who miss two counselling sessions are returned to court for breaching their probation order. Of 44 men and 16 women who joined the first pilot programme, called Focus on Violence, 33 and 12 respectively completed it. "This group all found it helpful and expressed the wish that it was longer," says Connor.

Any convictions incurred within two years of leaving the programme will be logged by the Home Office's research and statistics department. Connor says: "A reasonable figure in terms of those not reoffending has been set at between 10 and 15%. I'm confident that we can achieve that."

fields.headline: Awake to the danger
fields.standfirst: The image of sleepy rural towns is being shattered by a pervasive rise in drug and alcohol abuse.  John Cunningham  visits a local project with national significance
fields.trailText: The image of sleepy rural towns is being shattered by a pervasive rise in drug and alcohol abuse. John Cunningham visits a local project with national significance..
fields.body:
Busy morning for Barbara Jones: almost 20 drug users now on methadone maintenance drop by for urine samples and monthly health checks. The afternoon gets quieter: by teatime, there's just a fortysomething mother being counselled for binge drinking.

Jones, a substance abuse worker, isn't based in a crack-and-crisis inner city. Her patch, in green and billowy Shropshire, is Oswestry - a farming town quickened, you might suppose, only by market days, summer fetes and pub brawls.

Wrong. Sleepy Shropshire is firmly fixed on the national grid set up by drug dealers who've staked out every bit of Britain as efficiently as fast-food chains. Alcohol and drug misuse is pervasive in a population of around 280,000, scattered in small towns and rural communities. To cope with the problem, the county council and the county health authority set up a multi-disciplinary substance abuse team two years ago. It's now showing high success rates, which home secretary Jack Straw no doubt hopes the government's proposed national drug treatment agency will match.

New cases in the six months to March this year totalled 162 for alcohol, 120 for drugs, plus 27 people treated in both categories. Team manager Jon Aston says that, using the Maudsley addiction profile to monitor outcomes, 22% of drinkers quit alcohol totally and 69% cut down their intake. With drug referrals, 41% stopped using their main drug completely (47% of needle-users stopped injecting) while all the rest reduced their usage.

At a time when local authorities are pondering a gloomy long-term future in which cutbacks could leave them with nothing more than the provision of core social services, Shropshire is showing that it pays to be bold: its scheme is innovative, entrepreneurial and expansionist.

John Weeks, the local authority's director of social care and health, points out that while lip service is often paid to the notion of partnerships between public sector bodies, their community substance abuse team is an example of how it can work in practice. What's more, Weeks argues, it proves to a doubting Downing Street that local authorities can be trusted to implement key ministerial policies across the country.

It shows, too, that a good commu nity scheme can be sold, literally, to other agencies: Shropshire has won a contract to provide Shrewsbury prison with specialist drug workers.

The significant number of prisoners asking for help justified the contract, but the team went one better. Other counties might shrug off drunkenness as a traditional part of rural life; they might deny that their villages are being infiltrated by drug pushers. In Shropshire, they know different. It receives between six and 12 calls a day: from parents coming across suspicious substances in their children's bedrooms, drug users seeking help or GPs ringing mostly about patients with drink problems. "We've got more calls as we've got more known, more credible," says Aston.

The success of the mixed discipline approach is gradually giving the team confidence to expand into other areas. There are plans to recruit a specialist mental health worker on the basis that a third of people with psychiatric problems are misusing drink or drugs. "We're also thinking of doing work with the children of parents who abuse," says Aston.

Perhaps it's the innovative nature of the project, or the fact that several bodies and agencies are providing funding, but traditional barriers between professionals have dissolved pretty easily. Consultant psychiatrist Dr Keron Fletcher points out that it's far more usual for such teams to be health-led. He believes Shropshire has made its social services-led team work because it makes the most of everyone's training: social work, medical and psychological.

Barbara Jones, who trained as a nurse, testifies that's just what happens. "If we had one set of professional beliefs, it wouldn't be helpful," she says. "But we have many different approaches. We don't always agree, but that's vital for the way we develop as a team. The dynamics are always changing, but the core values are the same; it's what we're about as human beings."

Considering the workload that builds up - and the distances to be covered between centres in a sparsely-populated area - the team manages to offer a wide range of care: advice over the phone, counselling, agreeing realistic targets for quitting or reducing dependence on drugs or alcohol; working with young people; sharing care with GPs; supervising the detoxification of heavy drinkers in their own homes over a 10-day period; running a needle exchange. And when cases demand it, referrals for hospital treatment and residential care are arranged.

Resources are stretched, but complaints about that are cheerful, not resentful, and don't open up rivalries between colleagues of different disciplines. On the drugs front, the pressure comes from easy availability creating more users.

Tucked away in its corner, near the border with Wales, Oswestry is not immune. Drug abuse has become as common an occurrence as excessive drinking in this town of 30 pubs.

That fortysomething binge drinker - let's call her June - says her 19-year-old son reckons it's easy to buy drugs in almost any bar. And Jones adds that most of her clients are or have been heroin users, while some are admitting that they also use crack and cocaine. "The gap is narrowing between cannabis and heroin," says Jones. The lure is Liverpool: it's only an hour or so away, and some locals buy their heroin there more cheaply.

Availability may be "rife", as June says, yet there's no panic. Jones says of her methadone patients: "Drug use is only a tiny part of their lives. They work, they have families, they play a part in the community. They are incredibly stable people."

However, there's one glitch in the co-operation between professionals. While shared care with GPs works very well in the rest of the county, there's a no-go situation in Oswestry, with family doctors refusing to put patients on methadone because of rogue prescribing some time ago. So a Shrewsbury doctor has to make weekly trips to patients at the team's Oswestry centre. "There is a lot of room for development with the GPs," concedes Jones, "but they are hugely helpful on the alcohol detox side."

fields.headline: Leading from the front
fields.standfirst: Stephen Bubb, new head of charity chief executives
fields.trailText: Profile: Stephen Bubb, new head of charity chief executives.
fields.body:
Leaving one of the largest grant makers in Europe to head a relatively small organisation for charity chief executives may not sound like an obvious career move. But Stephen Bubb has big plans for his new role at Acevo, the Association of Chief Executives of Voluntary Organisations. By the time he gets behind his desk in September, Bubb will have begun putting some flesh on the bones of his three-year plan aimed at increasing the profile and membership of the 13-year-old organisation.

About time too, according to some in the sector. While Acevo's activities - training, mentoring initiatives and publications, to name a few - offer support to chief executives, the organisation has yet to fulfil its potential of championing leadership within the sector. Bubb's brief will be to exploit this potential to the full. "The charity chief executive role can be difficult, they are often out front on their own," he says. "The important thing is to provide them with leadership support which is actually going to make a real contribution to the sector."

Providing people with the tools they need to make a difference has been a core part of Bubb's role as director of personnel and administration at the National Lottery Charities Board (NLCB), the body established in 1994 to distribute lottery funds to voluntary organisations across the UK. He was there from day one, recruiting senior management, setting up the admin and human resource systems, finding and fitting out 17 offices across the country and establishing a grant application system. Bubb also established a leadership programme for senior managers.

"Having been involved right at the start of the charities board, there is a sense of pride and achievement from establishing an organisation of national renown," he says. "But after five years, I was looking for another challenge. Leadership is a bit of a buzzword, but for me it sums up the drive for a greater professionalism in the voluntary sector."

Ideally he would like to create a leadership academy for the voluntary sector. "There are plenty of people around who will fund a business school at Oxford. Why not a leadership school? And it would probably be a virtual one, because it's not about courses but certain core messages and individuals' specific needs."

One of the hurdles Bubb knows he has to overcome is achieving his aims on limited resources. His budget at the NLCB is £5m, while Acevo's turnover is around a tenth of that. He moves from having a staff of 25 to a team of nine. "Funding at the charities board hasn't been a problem because it comes from the lottery. The resource issue is going to be a real challenge and Acevo will be looking for sponsorship and other funding to deliver its goals."

Increasing membership levels is one idea. Acevo currently has 1,200 members, but its recent shift in emphasis from national to all voluntary organisations provides a bigger pool in which to fish.

Bubb's route to Acevo has been a varied one. After reading PPE at Oxford in the early 1970s (contemporaries included Tony Blair and Ann Widdecombe), he worked briefly in the civil service ("so tedious that I couldn't wait to get out") before taking a job as research officer for Jack Jones, then general secretary of the Transport and General Workers' Union. Bubb worked closely with Jones on shaping employment legislation and the social contract under the 1974 Labour government. "It was fantastic experience and I got involved with the nitty gritty negotiations," he enthuses.

After the 1979 general election, he went to the National Union of Teachers as a negotiations officer, a job that involved helping to resolve teachers' pay disputes but also developing training for union staff. Bubb then "swapped sides", taking a post as head of personnel at the Association of Metropolitan Authorities (now merged into the Local Government Association). While there, he helped set up the "single status" pay for local government staff which replaced the separate blue and white collar systems.

Bubb, 47, believes his experience and networks will help Acevo achieve a national platform for its work. Colleagues agree. "He spends a lot of time cultivating contacts and has very good political antennae," says one.

Partnership work is high on the agenda, particularly with other umbrella bodies in the sector. Bubb says: "There is no scope for jealousies and rivalries - the voluntary sector can do without that. Acevo has a specific role of representing chief executives and the issues around professional support, and how I want to take it further is through partnership." Bubb also intends to build on Acevo's links with business and the public sector.

Selling the benefits of the voluntary sector to others should come easy to him. In addition to serving as a trustee of HIV/Aids charity London Lighthouse, and an adviser to mental health charity Mind, he also set up The Landmark, a south London drop-in centre for people with HIV/Aids. "I wanted to do it through the voluntary sector because I didn't want to be stuck with the bureaucracy you get in the public sector," he says. "And the value is that it can be run by people who use the service, not by managers and bureaucrats."

Not that Bubb hasn't ever been in the latter group. He's worked in health authorities and was a Labour councillor in Lambeth, south London, during a high-profile controversy in the early 1980s when he and colleagues were personally surcharged.

"At the time there were major clashes on setting budgets and making cuts," he says. "There was a strong feeling in Lambeth, especially after the Brixton riots, that this would have a major impact on council services and particularly the voluntary sector. We took the view that we could not make cuts - looking back it was probably the wrong decision but at the time it seemed like the right thing to do."

Bubb's ambition now is to set his sights high and give Acevo the identity it deserves. "We're a small organisation but potentially huge, because we represent the chief executives of organisations that represent a significant part of the UK economy."

fields.headline: Trees of life
fields.standfirst: In or around England's big conurbations are some of the best-kept secrets.  David Nicholson-Lord  on the beauty of community forests
fields.trailText: In or around England's big conurbations are some of the best-kept secrets. David Nicholson-Lord on the beauty of community forests.
fields.body:
It's not easy finding the headquarters of Thames Chase on the eastern outskirts of London. Along small countryish lanes decorated with burnt-out cars, along a bumpy track through fields being dug for a golf course, you end up in a collection of farm buildings that have seen better days. Visitors have suggested to John Meehan that he knocks them down and starts again. But for Meehan, who has spent much of his life with Thames Chase in Portakabins, the farm HQ is "luxury". Meehan, born in the East End, is the director of Thames Chase, one of London's two community forests.

There are 12 such forests in and around England's main conurbations. Planted 10 years ago, they are one of Britain's most successful environmental projects. With the national forest, which stretches over 200 sq miles on the old Midlands coalfield west of Leicester, the forests are also Britain's biggest environ mental project. But they're a reasonably well-kept secret.

Urban forestry has become increasingly popular with governments in the 90s but the good news has yet to filter out much to the public.

Given the scope and ambitions of the community forests, this is somewhat surprising. In total, they cover over 450,000 hectares - an area bigger than Suffolk; Thames Chase is almost the size of the Isle of Wight. The aim is to increase woodland cover by 30%, in each community forest, by about 2030 - in contrast to the present miserable 7%, the second lowest in the European Union.

The Forestry Commission and the Countryside Agency which, as the Countryside Commission, pushed the idea forward in 1989, recently listed the gains since the forests were established: over 6,000 hectares of new woodland planted, an area 25 times that of Hyde Park; over 10,000 hectares opened up for access; 5,000km of public access routes, nearly 800km of new hedgerow.

In some areas - notably transport corridors where planners want to impress potential inward investors (or tourists) with a "green gateway" - gains have been remarkable. Along the A689 in the Tees Forest around Middlesbrough, tree cover has increased from 0.2% to 16%. But trees, and the effects they create, need time.

In Thames Chase, half a million trees have been planted, about 220 hectares of woodland, but tree cover has only climbed from 9-10% since 1990. It hasn't helped that farmers, wary of new public access and reluctant to commit their land to trees when there is, or was, more money to be made out of EU farming grants, have responded coolly.

Meehan acknowledges that the woodlands of Thames Chase have yet to reach the "critical mass" where people sit up and take notice. He thinks this is something to do with size and eye levels. "Trees don't really make an impact until you start looking up to them." But he believes that "we are beginning to see coalescence" - bits and pieces of new woodlands forming green chains across the landscape - and takes great comfort from the fact that several early plantings have achieved a kind of cartographic respectability. They are now "green blobs" on Ordnance Survey maps. "There will be a point at which it all feels part of a whole, whereas at the moment it's just fragmented improvements."

That moment may be sooner rather than later. National forestry strategy has undergone a sea-change in the late 90s. As Nerys Jones, director of the National Urban Forestry Unit (NUFU), points out, it has four main strands - rural development, regeneration, conservation and recreation. Timber production, in other words, is no longer the overriding objective.

As part of this rethink, the Forestry Commission, which under the last government was busy selling off woodlands, is now busy buying new land for planting - near the cities. In April, it was awarded £9m from the Treasury's capital modernisation fund for forest creation in three of the community forests areas, including Thames Chase, where new mixed woodlands of oak, larch, pine and willow are rising up on reclaimed rubbish dumps next to housing estates.

What, you might ask, have forests in Hornchurch and Havering got to do with capital modernisation? According to Joe Watts, the commission's officer in Thames Chase, it's all to do with efficiency. Mixed forests in derelict areas near lots of people - 26m people live within 20km of the community forests - are better at delivering access, recreation and economic development and regeneration than the notorious serried ranks of conifers once planted in the remoter areas of Scotland or Norfolk. A Treasury approved cost-benefit analysis has concluded that overall, between 1990 and 2030, benefits will outweigh costs by £265m.

That could be a conservative figure. It's always been loosely appreciated, for example, that greenery in cities has economic spin-offs, promoting liveability, raising property values and attracting inward investment. But what sort of greenery? And what about the fear of crime that has often accompanied tree planting in cities?

The last decade has shown that a few simple design ideas can radically increase public acceptability. These include thinning out dense stands of trees and removing shrubs to improve sight lines; leaving uncluttered margins along paths; if necessary, introducing lights; and improving what planners call "interpretation", anything from signposts to guided walks, art festivals and poetry days. The result, says Meehan, is that forests become busy and, thus, self-policing. "People no longer feel threatened because these places are so popular and well-used," he says.

Urban forests were undoubtedly seen as something of an oddity when they were launched - what place does a forest have in a city? Fast forward to November, 1999, however, and here is Tony Blair commending them as "a model and inpiration for others".

Jones says there is a new appreciation that trees provide a robust and cheap-to-maintain landscape - cheaper than parks and mown grassland - that can absorb noise and crowds and yet provide a sense of intimacy. There is evidence of their therapeutic role, too; research has shown that a tree-filled view cuts hospital drugs bills and reduces commuting stress.

Add to that their capacity to soak up the carbon dioxide that generates global warming, provide shade from harmful solar radiation and combat traffic pollution linked to the rise in asthma, and, says Jones, "people are beginning to see that trees in cities don't just look nice. They're functional, too. The challenge is to get across the message that the urban forest isn't just an amenity landscape - an added extra that's going to cost more. It is a net contributor to the quality of life in cities".

 Forest Fever Fortnight of Fun, two weeks' of activities in community forests throughout England, starts on Saturday. Further information www.communityforest.org.uk

The result, says Meehan, is that forests become busy and, thus, self-policing. "People no longer feel threatened because these places are so popular and well-used," he says. Urban forests were undoubtedly seen as something of an oddity when they were launched - what place does a forest have in a city? Fast forward to November, 1999, however, and here is Tony Blair commending them as "a model and inpiration for others". Jones says there is a new appreciation that trees provide a robust and cheap-to-maintain landscape - cheaper than parks and mown grassland - that can absorb noise and crowds and yet provide a sense of intimacy. There is evidence of their therapeutic role, too; research has shown that a tree-filled view cuts hospital drugs bills and reduces commuting stress. Add to that their capacity to soak up the carbon dioxide that generates global warming, provide shade from harmful solar radiation and combat traffic pollution linked to the rise in asthma, and, says Jones, "people are beginning to see that trees in cities don't just look nice. fields.headline: Readers' letters
fields.trailText: Landlord boycott
fields.body:
Landlord boycott

The chaos around housing benefit processing since the verification framework came in last year (Chaos rules, July 12) has seen many landlords refusing to accept prospective tenants who need help to pay their rent by housing benefit, be they unemployed or in part-time work or low waged jobs.

We introduced a very successful rent deposit bond guarantee scheme some four years ago. To induce landlords to accept the scheme, as no actual cash changes hands, we agreed a fast track system with the local authority-run housing benefit section, which worked really well until the verification framework was introduced. We know small landlords, who offer good accommodation, with thousands of pounds of outstanding housing benefit.

In practice, regulations place a duty on local authorities to ensure housing benefit is processed and paid in two weeks!

Dan Draper
Isle of Wight Independent Housing Advice Centre.

More than one language

Wendy Barnes's letter (July 12) displayed very little knowledge of issues relating to deaf people. First, we are not "the deaf". As someone working in deaf education, Ms Barnes should not be using terms which we find offensive.

Second, I challenge her assumption that the oralist approach necessarily provides maximum choices and opportunities for young deaf people. Does she have any idea of the tremendous amount of effort we have to put into lipreading and communicating with hearing people? As a severely deaf person working in arts management, I am often exhausted at the end of a working day after struggling to lipread and "keep up" with hearing people who very often make little or no attempt to speak clearly.

Barnes is also wrong to assume that to use BSL (British sign language) is to reject the hearing world. What utter nonsense! Communicating in the language many deaf people find most accessible is perfectly natural and normal, and should not exclude anybody.

Maggie Hampton
Pontypridd
Rhondda Cynon Taff.

Scapegoating the badger

Here in west Cornwall, the Ministry of Agriculture (Maff) is preparing for the experimental badger cull (The culling fields, July 5), hiding traps in the hedgerows with a view to starting shooting - at close range through the bars of the trap - in the very near future.

We are all playing our part in the fight to save the badgers, from carrying banners in the streets of St Just, through hasty telephone calls when Maff Land-Rovers have been spotted driving around the fields, to direct action to disable badger traps.

Your article states that the National Farmers' Union intends to run a campaign in the autumn to persuade people that they can catch TB directly from badgers, although there is as yet still no proof that badgers even transmit it to cattle. This seems not so much spin as a blatant untruth and could backfire in that the pro-badger lobby will undoubtedly promote fresh publicity about the connection between cattle and human disease, from dairy allergies to CJD.

Jane Rosendale
St Buryan.

On the move

Congratulations on being the first newspaper to bring to the fore the problems - amounting in some cases to suffering - of many mobile home residents (Mobile phoney, July 12).

However, as one of the marchers who took to the streets on July 3, as you mention, I must point out that it was not to 10 Downing Street that we wended our way, but first to the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions to present a letter to the office of Nick Raynsford, the housing minister, and then to parliament to discuss the situation with Hilton Dawson MP. His move to put mobile homes under housing legislation has attracted the support of over 90 of his colleagues. Only one of those is a Conservative.

I have written to William Hague asking why the Conservatives are declining this opportunity of bringing about reform. In a marginal constituency, a few hundred or even a couple of dozen votes might make a lot of difference.

Margaret Brown
Reading.

Caring without training

In Melanie Henwood's article, (A helping hand, June 28) she states of social care that "it is not a career path which young people aspire to follow". On the contrary, the project for adults with learning disabilities where my son works has at least half a dozen graduates in their 20s working on it at any one time. They all seem very keen to remain with this client group, but in the absence of appropriate training, and with poor remuneration, many look elsewhere.

If only the training needs of this group of young people were met, perhaps they could help raise the status of "care work" to the level we should expect in a civilised society.

Kate Warner
Claybrooke Parva
Leicestershire.

Confronting trauma

I was astonished to read Raj Persaud's opinion that psychologists tend to avoid challenging areas of mental health work, preferring to deal with middle-class angst (It's good to talk, June 28).

Like all my NHS clinical psychology colleagues, my work is overwhelmingly with people with cognitive and physical disability or serious mental health problems, the majority of whom are vulnerable and living in adversity.

If anyone has chosen a job exposing themselves to the concerns of the chattering classes, it is not the clinical psychologist but the middle-class media psychiatrist.

Hilary Husband
Norwich

fields.headline: Relatively successful
fields.standfirst: Laurie  Taylor
fields.trailText: Laurie Taylor.
fields.body:
For many years now, sociologists of all shapes, sizes and ideological persuasion have been queuing up to announce that the family is either in terminal decline or about to mutate into a very different kind of institution. But even as the funeral rites are being prepared, there comes news that the family is still fulfilling one of its most traditional functions.

Evidence compiled by Adam Kuper, professor of social anthropology at Brunel University, shows that the majority of businesses in Europe are family based. Family farms, corner shops and restaurants feature heavily in the list, but there are also a significant number of medium-size enterprises and some famous multinational companies.

Kuper, currently building up a European network to examine this phenomenon, wonders how, in the face of such evidence, it is still possible for management experts to maintain there is something backward, even irrational about the family business. Perhaps, such experts might be better employed in seeking to establish the strengths of this production unit.

There is, for example, good evidence that family businesses are particularly willing to make long-term investments. They also score heavily on flexibility of labour and avoid the problems of having to train new workers by the simple expedient of ensuring that children acquire an inside knowledge of the business at an early age.

But the most significant advantage may lie in the special element of trust between family members. This not only reduces the need for formal contracts but also ensures that capital can be readily raised from members of the wider family.

Kuper is anxious to discover whether some groups are more likely than others to establish family businesses. Preliminary evidence suggests that the proportion is particularly high among immigrant populations, where the pattern of migration is often based upon kinship chains. Might there also be family reasons behind the greater success enjoyed by some immigrant groups? Could the close family structure of Jews and Asians be responsible for the advantage they enjoy in business compared to those from West Indian backgrounds?

Family businesses do, however, suffer from one, often fatal, flaw: the problem of succession. In Scotland, research has shown that only 30% of family businesses survive the transition from first to second generation and only 14% from second to third generation. However valuable an asset trust may be in life, it seems it does not always outlast the grave.

 Laurie Taylor talks to Adam Kuper about family business on Radio 4's Thinking Allowed, 4pm today

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: Nuclear rubbish | Yuppies scuppered | Smell of success
fields.body:
Nuclear rubbish

The government's unkept promise to produce a nuclear waste management document "by the spring" left the junior environment minister, Lord Whitty, in difficulty answering questions in the Lords. His excuse was that "drafting proved more complicated than expected". Lord Peyton responded: "Is it too much to hope that the army of draftsmen who are employed in producing loads and loads of rubbish from government sources could be better employed simply responding slightly more quickly?" The truth, which Lord Whitty could not reveal, is that the government is dithering and divided on the future of reprocessing - whether to reclassify plutonium as a waste, as the Lords recommended, and, the most difficult of all, how to find somewhere to put the waste that already exists. Lord Jenkin waded in with a remark about Tony Blair hoping to put the whole issue off until after the election because there were no votes in it - something that happened three times under the Tories. Lord Whitty expressed shock that anyone should suggest such a thing.

Yuppies scuppered
Better news from another long battleground - Rainham Marshes, in east London. The RSPB, with the backing of new mayor, Ken Livingstone, has finally acquired the capital's largest nature reserve after a 20-year campaign. This has prevented the place becoming another yuppie riverside development on the Thames. The reserve is a medieval marshland system. The MoD, which for almost a hundred years used the area as a rifle range, played a role in preserving it because it is still littered with unexploded ordnance, hand grenades and mortars, which will not be fully removed for a further 15 years. Still, the birds won't mind.

Smell of success
More cheering news, from south London. Around 1900, blue fields of lavender could be seen all over Wallington, Carshalton, Beddington, Waddon and Sutton. It was used for scented bags, floor and furniture washes, as a disinfectant, to preserve linen from moths, and for remedies. BioRegional, a local eco-project, using prisoners from HMP Downview, took cuttings of the traditional varieties of the area still surviving in local gardens. Prisoners on day-release helped to clear and plant disused allotments in Carshalton Beeches. This Sunday, for one day only, the lavender buffs will be able to go to the allotments and pick their own.
