fields.headline: Junk dealers
fields.standfirst: Mike George on the problems caused when collecting becomes a serious obsession
fields.trailText: Mike George on the problems caused when collecting becomes a serious obsession.
fields.body:
Most of us admit to hoarding stuff from time to time. We have stacks of reports in our office which we think we should examine at some point, the piles of magazines at home we delude ourselves into thinking might be useful. But at what point could this become a problem?

No one knows how many people fill their homes with what we would regard as junk, but it's sufficiently common for many health and social care professionals to be familiar with the phenomenon. The behaviour even has a name, Diogenes' syndrome, though some prefer to view it as an obsessive-compulsive behaviour, and others refer to it as syllogomania.

Psychiatrists maintain that what they're addressing is different to the general neglect that professionals encounter among older people, in particular, who are suffering from some form of dementia.

For not only is the condition not restricted to older people, those who do collect and hoard are extraordinarily resistant to the efforts of professionals to encourage them to stop doing it. And when the situation impinges on neighbours and environmental health officers are called in to clear houses or flats, the event is always tremendously traumatic for the person involved.

Such a case was seen by TV viewers when Edmund Trebus, a reclusive Polish war veteran, was featured in the BBC fly-on-the-wall series, A Life of Grime; it was shown that he had spent 35 years building a network of rat-infested tunnels of rubbish to dissuade people calling on him at home.

Some people who collect and hoard in this way are otherwise presentable, by no means neglectful of their personal hygiene and appearance. Among several examples cited by mental health professionals there is a successful architect, a high-flier in the City and a musicologist. Nor is the behaviour associated with any specific mental health problem, though in certain cases some form of personality disorder or mental illness is present.

Colm Cooney, a consultant old age psychiatrist at Vincent's Hospital in Dublin, and one of the relatively few professionals who have studied the condition in depth, maintains that there are certain factors which tend to be present. He points out that there appears to be no correlation between the behaviour and physical health or level of income. But he, and others, suggest that some element of eccentricity may often have been present before the condition has developed; social isolation is another fairly common precondition (perhaps for obvious reasons), and it is thought that very stressful life events, such as bereavement, could be implicated.

Others have suggested that among older people the condition may hark back to the privations and rationing experienced during the second world war, so that insecurities in later life may trigger serious hoarding as an attempt to regain a sense of security.

Should professionals be doing any thing about someone with Diogenes' syndrome unless the behaviour affects other people or puts their own health at risk? And even then, provided that people are aware of the risks they're taking, what rights should professionals have to intervene?

Roger Parke, a mental health social worker in Dorset, has been working with twin brothers in their early 50s, who picked up rubbish from the streets to store in their house and garden. Not surprisingly, neighbours complained to the council about the smell and the danger of vermin. Environmental health officers had repeatedly sent them notices to clear the garden and house, but these had been ignored. Parke had a duty to intervene, and found that their living conditions were very unsafe and unhygienic.

The brothers refused to talk to him about the risks and it was decided eventually that a warrant had to be sought from a magistrates' court giving the council powers under the Mental Health Act compulsorily to remove the twins to a place of safety, while environmental health officers cleared the house and garden. This was done, and other housing was subsequently found for them.

Although the immediate problem was dealt with, the brothers have resumed their rubbish-collecting activities. Parke feels frustrated that he was unable to work with them to manage the risks they were taking with their health and safety. He asks: "If the risks had been reduced, would their eccentric behaviour really have mattered?"

So while the 1983 act can be used under certain circumstances temporarily to remove people from a risky situation, few, if any, mental health professionals feel comfortable about using the compulsory powers provided by the act with people exhibiting Diogenes' syndrome.

Roland Powell, manager of the mental health central team in Sefton, Merseyside, argues: "The issue of vulnerable adults such as these is not addressed by any social policy, and we're left with old mental illness legislation which simply doesn't meet the needs of social services staff who are trying to protect people in the community. As a result, we are in danger of leaving too much to the judgment of health or social care professionals, of violating people's human rights, and also furthering the social exclusion of those, who through their vulnerability or mental incapacity are already at risk of exclusion."

Kerry Stevens, who is a former care manager in Slough's social services department, expresses the unease that many feel about the value judgments they're forced to use. arguing that many people with Diogenes' syndrome may find comfort in hoarding, and so the behaviour obviously plays an important role in their lives. "Yet some professionals think it's all right to go in and remove their treasured possessions. But would we even consider doing that to other people with psychological problems, or who otherwise don't seem to us to be acceptable?" he asks.

The government will next week be urged to give people with mental health problems the same rights as others who get community care services. The Mental Health Alliance aims to persuade ministers to include in a new mental health act a better framework of rights and responsibilities for service users and providers.

Many fear that the current review of the 1983 Mental Health Act could focus too much on compulsory treatment because of concerns about the relatively few, but highly-publicised, cases where mental illness is linked to violence. In a report, published next Tuesday, which details the case for equal rights to an assessment of needs and access to services, the alliance will argue that a better statutory framework should reduce the need to use compulsory powers.

The proposed rights would mean that far fewer mental health staff would have to get involved just at "crisis point", when the only option may be compulsory admission to hospital. An assessment of needs and rights to a service, required of agencies by law, could prove a more effective route.

The alliance, which comprises 50 organisations representing service users, professionals, trade unions and service provider agencies, will also call for more effective discharge planning for people who have spent time in psychiatric units, backed up by stronger statutory responsibilities for hospital and community based mental health staff. This would help prevent the well-known "revolving door" syndrome, where patients repeatedly en ter hospital care, leave it, and return again shortly after.

Other measures proposed in the report, Access to Services, will include provision for each patient of a free independent advocate; stronger measures to ensure that people who can do so are able to have more say in treatment decisions; and more protection under the law if they are incapable of doing so. The consortium will also call for systems which are more sensitive to cultural differences, to deal with the continuing over-representation of people from ethnic communities in the mental health services.

 Access to Services will be available at £10 plus £1.80p&p from next Tuesday from the Mental Health Foundation (020-7535 7441).

The alliance, which comprises 50 organisations representing service users, professionals, trade unions and service provider agencies, will also call for more effective discharge planning for people who have spent time in psychiatric units, backed up by stronger statutory responsibilities for hospital and community based mental health staff. This would help prevent the well-known "revolving door" syndrome, where patients repeatedly en ter hospital care, leave it, and return again shortly after. Other measures proposed in the report, Access to Services, will include provision for each patient of a free independent advocate; stronger measures to ensure that people who can do so are able to have more say in treatment decisions; and more protection under the law if they are incapable of doing so. The consortium will also call for systems which are more sensitive to cultural differences, to deal with the continuing over-representation of people from ethnic communities in the mental health services.  Access to Services will be available at £10 plus £1.80p&p from next Tuesday from the Mental Health Foundation (020-7535 7441).

fields.headline: A degree of dedication
fields.standfirst: Plans to improve training and raise status of social workers
fields.trailText: Plans to improve training and raise status of social workers.
fields.body:
Radical measures to upgrade the status and quality of social work were proposed on Monday by John Hutton, the social care minister. At a conference in London organised by the Guardian and the National Institute for Social Work, he disclosed the main ingredients of a consultation paper on raising standards in social care, due for publication next month.

One of the most far-reaching proposals was an overhaul of training. Hutton said Department of Health consultants had recommended raising the entry qualification for social work from a two-year diploma to a three-year undergraduate degree. They urged a "significant upgrading of several aspects of the qualifying education, with greater focus on field experience based on a single national curriculum for social work training."

Instead of 80 diploma providers offering courses of variable quality, there should be a much smaller number of centres of excellence offering courses of degree standard.

Although the consultation paper will present these ideas neutrally as options for reform, Hutton left little doubt that he was sympathetic to the idea. "We need to encourage people to come forward for a degree in social care," he said, before adding a warning. "But who would do it today? We have to be careful about the language we use to describe social care. Yes, we do let people down too often in too many parts of the country. But we also have to be rigorous about out successes. . . We need to encourage people to think they can come in and really make a difference."

The report, by JM Consulting, was influenced by evidence of declining demand for the social work diploma course. Last year, about 6,000 applied for 6,000 places, compared to about 11,000 applications the year before. The diploma is not recognised as a qualification by other EU countries.

The consultants' other recommendations include continuing professional training for practising social workers and a revalidation procedure to ensure that all staff are up to the job - similar to the five-year MoT that has been suggested for directors.

More generally across the whole field of social care, Hutton is concerned that 80% of the 1m staff employed have no qualification. This will be addressed by national occupational standards for staff throughout the sector, including care homes, day centres and the home help service.

The consultation paper will make local authorities more accountable for the standard of social services - whether or not these are provided directly by the council or commissioned elsewhere. "We want to provide councils, and particularly their statutory director of social services, with a means of ensuring the quality of services," Hutton said.

His third main strand of reform will be to establish a Social Care Institute of Excellence (Scie) to give authoritative guidance on good practice. It will be modelled on the National Institute for Clinical Excellence (Nice) that advises the health service on the cost-effectiveness of drugs and treatments.

"The institute will draw up new guidelines on high quality social care practice and models of service delivery," Hutton said. "These will then form the basis for inspection and best value reviews."

First impressions of the proposals were positive. Daphne Statham, director of the National Institute for Social Work, welcomed the proposal for a three-year degree qualification. "It is quite impossible for people to know everything they need to learn and do in a two-year programme," she said.

Jo Williams, president of the Association of Directors of Social Services, said the three-year degree would be "a more credible qualification" that should attract more students. Although it would take a year longer, it should produce a more confident workforce.

John Ransford, head of social care at the Local Government Association, said the Scie proposal was an essential part of establishing a proper framework for social care. "I have been part of a campaign for three-year training since the early 1980s," he said. "The arguments are as strong now as then."

fields.headline: Survival of the fittest
fields.standfirst: One in five Aids charities is set to close within two years
fields.trailText: One in five Aids charities is set to close within two years
fields.body:
People with HIV and Aids are living dramatically longer and healthier lives, but the days look numbered for many of the 160 voluntary organisations striving to meet their needs in London. According to a forthcoming report, one in five will go to the wall within the next two years.

The HIV epidemic has changed radically in nature since the earliest cases in Britain in the 1980s. Thanks to new combination therapy, many people with the condition are surviving longer, feeling fitter and even returning to work. But the ever-increasing cost of medication, as London's population of an estimated 25,000 people with HIV rises by 10% each year, means less funds for voluntary providers.

The forthcoming Starfish report, commissioned by health authorities and local councils which fund the capital's voluntary HIV services, is expected to call for a "significant reduction" in voluntary providers, closure of several buildings and an end to open-access drop-ins. Some job losses will be inevitable.

The study will argue that, currently, many services are duplicated, models of care "outmoded", organisations inefficient and contracts un clear. Drop-in centres come in for particular criticism as being badly attended and poorly focused. Without radical surgery to streamline services, the report will warn, the whole HIV voluntary sector could suffer a "slow and painful collapse".

The study has been prompted by long-running concerns over the number of HIV voluntary organisations competing for dwindling funds in London. Cutbacks have already forced several to close their doors. Voluntary bodies were particularly shaken in May at the sudden closure of the highly respected charity Body Positive, after 15 years. Many now want clear-cut decisions on the future rather than lingering death by a thousand cuts.

Tough decisions will have to be made, says Will Huxter, who chairs the group which commissioned the report. He predicts that "easily" 20% of voluntary organisations will have to shut their doors or merge with others - although other services could expand to cater for unmet needs.

Most voluntary bodies will welcome the study, according to Gary Alessio, director of the pan-London HIV/Aids providers' consortium. He says they accept that services are inefficient and duplicated, although there are concerns that the trend towards mergers could create a monopoly.

The merger movement is being led by the Terrence Higgins Trust THT), already Europe's largest voluntary HIV service provider and now consulting on its eighth merger, with London Lighthouse. Andrew Ridley, the trust's director of operations, describes the existing duplication of services as a "grotesque waste of resources". The charity is keen for further mergers, he says, but he denies suggestions of a monopoly. Even with the latest expansion, THT takes only 6% of London's HIV voluntary sector funds.

fields.headline: Queue applause
fields.standfirst: It's endemic, not genetic. The DNA label - 'did not attend' - plagues attempts to cut NHS out-patient waiting lists.  David Brindle visits a pilot system that offers a cure
fields.trailText: It's endemic, not genetic. The DNA label - 'did not attend' - plagues attempts to cut NHS out-patient waiting lists. David Brindle visits a pilot system that offers a cure.
fields.body:
You visit the GP and you are told you need to see a specialist. A little later, the hospital writes to you with a date months away. You wait patiently, perhaps in pain, and then just days before your appointment you get an urgent work assignment and have to cancel. You go to the back of the queue again.

They call it "churning" and it is the single biggest cause of dissatisfaction with NHS out-patient treatment. Sometimes the hospital cancels; sometimes - the wait being so long - the patient simply forgets. "We've found a case of a man who was churned round the system for three years," says Sue Jennings, leader of the government's national patients' access team.

All that may be about to change. Between now and next spring, every English NHS hospital trust with a waiting time of 13 weeks or more for an out-patient clinic will have to introduce a "partial booking" system piloted at two sites over the past year. Results have been striking.

"It is a great improvement on the traditional fixed appointment system," says Michael Catterall, consultant dermatologist and clinical director for out-patients at the Basildon and Thurrock hospitals trust in Essex. "It has demonstrated to me, beyond any doubt, that it virtually wipes out DNAs."

The "DNA" is the bane of the life of every out-patient doctor, nurse and clerk. The initals stand for "did not attend" and they end up being put against the name of at least one in 10 patients supposed to be attending for the first time. In an average hospital seeing 50,000 new patients a year, that means 5,000 wasted slots.

At the two pilot sites, Basildon and Chesterfield, the DNA rate has been cut from 10-11% to as little as 2-3% in the specialties concerned. Waiting times have shortened dramatically, even in notoriously problematic areas such as orthopaedics. "When we started, we were running at 40-45% [of orthopaedics patients] seen within 13 weeks," says Catterall. "Now it's 86%."

How is it done? Very simply. Instead of receiving an appointment date from the hospital, the new patient gets a letter saying they are on the waiting list and will be contacted again shortly before they can be seen. At that point, three or four weeks ahead of the dates being booked, the patient receives a second letter asking them to telephone the hospital and arrange a convenient time.

Booking is carried out by teams in mini call centres. Basildon's is currently open from 8am to 7pm, Monday to Friday, with plans to extend to Saturday mornings. The staff are trained to negotiate appointments that suit patients - not just because it is customer friendly to do so, but because the patients will keep them.

Dot Wheatley, the out-patient appointment co-ordinator at Basildon, says patients call with their shift patterns in front of them. "Then there's the mums arranging their times around school hours, so they can pick up the children, and the old ladies round their hair appointments. That's very important."

Wheatley confesses to having been won over by the system after being extremely doubtful. Catterall, though himself an early enthusiast, admits his fellow consultants were "generally sceptical" and hints at continued resistance from local GPs. "It has not been understood quite so well by our colleagues in general practice," he says diplomatically.

Catterall's own specialism, dermatology, is largely out-patient based. The DNA rate was running up to 14% at Basildon and can be 20%, or even higher, in some London hospitals. Under partial booking, it is down to 4-5%. It is a similar picture in rheumatology, where DNAs are sharply down and all new patients are now seen within 13 weeks, compared to just 54% before the pilot started.

So far, partial booking has been used by only one of the trust's six orthopaedics consultants. Although it is now being introduced into the ear, nose and throat specialism, extending it further is likely to depend on adaptation of the trust's computerised patient administration system - standard in much of the NHS - which has been promised by the supplier this autumn.

More fundamental obstacles to national implementation of partial booking may come in areas where people are less able to follow the system. At Basildon, a reminder is sent two weeks after the second letter but then, if the patient has not phoned in within a further fortnight, the referral goes back to the GP.

There have been fewer problems than expected - perhaps because people with communication difficulties are by now accustomed to getting help with telephone based public services and commerce - but the picture could be different in some inner-city areas.

Sara Coles, Basildon's director of planning and service development, says: "The only issue is that we don't have a large ethnic mix of patients here, and nor does Chesterfield. When the politicians roll it out to areas such as Hackney it is something that will need to be monitored."

The national patients' access team will be overseeing development of partial booking across the country over the next eight months. Where there are difficulties, a central team will be on standby to go in to assist. There will, however, be no special funding for the scheme: as at Basildon, which has recruited two extra appointment staff, the approach is designed to be self-funding through its greater efficiency.

Initially, the scheme will apply only to new, routine referrals - and to longer waits at that.

But the potential is enormous: as well as 50,000 new appointments, the average hospital handles up to 200,000 follow-ups each year. So why did such a simple idea not emerge before?

Access team leader Sue Jennings, formerly chief executive at Basildon, says: "Coming from a trust, I think the real problem is that people don't have time to raise their heads from the ground to see what's happening and think about it. One of the advantages of having a team like ours is that we can go and give them the benefit of that thinking time."

A partial solution

Partial booking represents a half way house between traditional referral and fully booked admission systems, whereby patients are able to arrange appointment dates at point of referral and operation dates while attending as an out-patient. Piloting of fully booked systems began in 1998 and it is planned that every English NHS hospital trust will have them in place in at least two clinical specialties by 2002. Evaluation of the first 24 fully booked schemes has been positive, but some experts believe longer waiting times need to be cut significantly before full booking is introduced. Michael Catterall, at Basildon, says: "I think you have got to have out-patient waiting time down to a handful of weeks for it to work."

fields.headline: Roof racket
fields.standfirst: London's need for affordable housing
fields.trailText: London's need for affordable housing.
fields.body:
London's new mayor must set clear targets for delivering more affordable homes in the capital, says a report today from Shelter and the Peabody Trust. On the day Ken Livingstone launches his promised commission of inquiry into the capital's accommodation needs, the charities argue that 24,000 dwellings a year are needed to staunch the capital's deepening crisis.

There has been no London-wide body to take an overview of housing since the abolition of the GLC, and the elected mayor's powers in this area are limited to intervening in major planning applications and approving or amending borough district plans. But these, along with the fact that the mayor can inquire into issues affecting the capital, are enough to re-start broad thinking about housing, say the charities.

Their report lays bare the situation: Londoners are twice as likely to be homeless as people in any other city, and 196,000 households are on council waiting lists. In March this year, almost 37,000 homeless households were in temporary accommodation - a 40% increase over two years.

The housing shortage is affecting key workers also - and having a damaging effect on the capital's economy and public services as police, nurses and teachers move further from their place of work.

A London housing forum should be set up to co-ordinate ideas for tackling the problems, and the report's author, Steve Hilditch, makes many suggestions. Among them: housing associations should be helped to acquire more converted office blocks; councils should not, as they are tending to do, go for lower densities when they regenerate estates. And councils which are giving priority to economically active households, or those without dependents, should be discouraged, as this pushes the more deprived down the ladder.

Recalling the co-operative spirit between councils in the era of the London County Council and the GLC, the report calls for the restoration of assistance for boroughs with the greatest housing stress from those where the problem is less acute.

fields.headline: Suffering in silence
fields.standfirst: Broken noses, cuts and bruises... how can health workers turn a blind eye to such frequent signs of domestic violence?  Wendy Moore investigates
fields.trailText: Broken noses, cuts and bruises... how can health workers turn a blind eye to such frequent signs of domestic violence? Wendy Moore investigates.
fields.body:
One in four women suffers domestic violence at some time during their lives. Almost all have contact with health services.

A government campaign, Living Without Fear, designed to tackle rape and violence against women, aims to promote "zero tolerance" of domestic violence. As part of this initiative, the Department of Health, in March, launched a manual which calls for all health staff to receive training to identify domestic abuse and offer practical help. Typical injuries, which it says health staff may encounter, include fractured bones, lost teeth and missing hair, although non-physical signs - such as depression and frequently missed appointments - may also be a clue.

Abuse often begins or worsens during pregnancy. This may include injuries to breasts, abdomen or chest, leading to miscarriage and other foetal problems. The manual says staff should encourage women to disclose violence and help them access agencies such as women's refuges. The woman's safety must be paramount and all information should be treated in confidence.

Last week, five NHS schemes were among 34 projects backed in a Home Office drive against rape and domestic violence. The schemes include:

 Training for doctors and nurses in casualty departments at Charing Cross and Hammersmith hospitals, London, to recognise domestic violence and offer referral channels to police and other agencies.

 Four pilot schemes in GP practices in Salford, Greater Manchester, where women who suffer domestic violence will be asked whether they want their injuries photographed and kept on file for use in a future court cases.

 A scheme placing Victim Support volunteers in the casualty department of North Devon hospital, Barnstaple, to offer practical help to victims of domestic violence.

Samantha was well known to health professionals in her home town. Over nine years, she saw her GP, health visitor and staff in the local casualty department with a succession of injuries to her face, arms and legs - all caused by her violent partner. Although her GP eventually advised her to leave home - after her boyfriend kicked her in the head with a steel-capped boot - no health worker offered support or information to help her escape. Finally, 18 months ago, when her partner threatened to kill her, she ran away with her three children to a women's refuge.

"They assume if you are in that situation you don't want to get out," says 30-year-old Samantha (not her real name), who is now living independently away from her home area.

Hers is a common tale in women's refuges up and down the country. Professional bodies have for several years been urging health staff to take domestic violence seriously. As part of a £7m Home Office initiative, five NHS projects were last week awarded grants for their work with domestic violence, rape and sexual assault. But critics say this is little more than token recognition.

Studies and anecdotal evidence show that many NHS workers still turn a blind eye to domestic violence. Often, they are ill-equipped to respond. They are untrained in detecting signs of abuse and, if they do, are reluctant to get involved or have no idea how to help.

Almost one in four women suffers domestic violence at some point in their lives and every three days a woman is killed by a partner or ex-partner, according to Home Office figures. Every day women walk into doctors' surgeries, health centres and casualty departments with black eyes, cuts and other tell-tale signs of violent relationships. Such abuse is often at its worst during pregnancy, when almost every woman has health service contact. And the NHS is ideally placed to detect and help combat it.

Yet health professionals often fail to help, according to research. While the Department of Health recently issued a manual on spotting and dealing with domestic violence, experts are concerned that the guidelines are not backed up with sufficient resources or political clout.

"What we have got is a critical point in a change of consciousness among quite a lot of health profes sionals," says Nicola Harwin, coordinator of the Women's Aid Federation. "What we haven't got is practical changes."

Helly Langley, who runs Canterbury women's refuge, agrees. Health workers' response to domestic violence is "ad hoc and arbitrary", she says. One woman recently fled to the refuge after attending casualty with two broken hands - slammed in a door by her former partner - yet nobody queried her claim that it was an accident. Catrina Sheard, who later lived for a time at the Canterbury refuge, was offered sympathy but nothing more when she told staff at a casualty department that her ex-boyfriend broke her nose.

The rest were not questioned. Often, she says, women are "waiting to be asked" - a comment repeated in similar studies. Yet of 58% of women in the study who did report violence to GPs, 67% said the doctor was unsympathetic or unresponsive. A total 65% of the women were assaulted during pregnancy.

As pregnancy is often a trigger point for abuse, the role of midwives and health visitors is critical. The Royal College of Midwives has already produced guidance on domestic violence and the Community Practitioners' and Health Visitors' Association is about to follow suit.

"There is increasing evidence exploding the myth that pregnancy is a haven of peace and bliss for women," says Tara Kaufmann, the RCM's head of policy.

Having a baby can impose huge emotional and financial stress on families, and that may prompt or exacerbate violence. Midwives often see signs of abuse, such as bruising, injuries to the genitals or missing clumps of hair, as well as emotional symptoms, such as depression, Kaufmann says. Since almost every pregnant woman has ante-natal care, midwives have "an incredible opportunity" to help. Yet while she believes midwives are more aware of the issue, not all feel able to act. Often they are just too busy to ask questions - or, if they do, they are afraid of "opening the floodgates".

Midwives in Leeds, however, have helped several women escape violent relationships since they introduced a mandatory three-day training session last year, teaching them to identify domestic violence, question women sympathetically and offer help, such as referral to a refuge. The midwives, working for the Leeds Teaching Hospitals trust, now routinely ask patients whether they have suffered violence, and they give everybody cards detailing emergency information.

Some women hide the cards in the soles of their shoes, says midwife Mary Steen, who helped to design the project. One woman, who revealed after questioning that she had been kicked downstairs, was found an immediate place in a refuge. An Asian woman, having her fourth baby, was helped to find a refuge after she disclosed, through an interpreter, that she had been beaten by her husband through every pregnancy. Previously, he had acted as the interpreter.

But such programmes are still a rarity and not always successful. A two-year project training midwives at Guy's and St Thomas' hospitals, London, uncovered unprecedented levels of abuse. In all, 6% of women patients revealed that they had been attacked in their current or previous pregnancy, whereas only one case had been identified in the previous two years, says Gillian Mezey, consultant psychiatrist at St George's hospital, London, who helped to run the study. But, despite the training, many midwives were unwilling to broach the topic - and on the day the project ended in April this year, the routine questioning stopped.

"I think a lot of midwives, in their head, understand this is a problem," Mezey says. "But because many of them, and many doctors and nurses generally, feel domestic violence doesn't have a solution - it is not something we can do anything about as health professionals - there is a sense that we should not be asked to get involved."

Health visitor Sue Peckover found similar ambivalence in her profession in a study she presented earlier this year. While a third of health visitors demonstrated good practice in handling domestic violence, the other two-thirds were largely unaware of the problem. One health visitor estimated that a quarter of her case load suffered domestic abuse, while another said she had come across only one case in her entire career. A minority of women survivors of abuse said health staff had helped them. While Peckover believes awareness has improved since her interviews in 1996-97, she says the picture is still varied.

John Ryan, consultant in accident and emergency medicine at the Royal Sussex County hospital, Brighton, sees evidence of domestic violence daily in his department and argues that staff take cases "very seriously". Victims are offered referrals to police or social services, although these are often refused. But Ryan, who speaks for the British Association for Accident and Emergency Medicine, which has also produced guidance on the issue, admits that rising demands restrict training time on domestic violence.

One training scheme for health staff in Camden, north London, ran into difficulties during last winter's beds crisis, when nurses could not be released for courses.

Suzanne Watts, research fellow at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, who helped to run the Camden project, says: "I think there is lots of willingness in the health service, but there are a lot of constraints too."

webTitle: Cash for crime, drugs and asylum backlog

fields.headline: Cash for crime, drugs and asylum backlog
fields.standfirst:
 £1.6bn to beat car theft and burglary
'Vigorous' enforcement of entry refusals

Special report: the comprehensive spending review
Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: The Home Office gets money to tackle crime and drug abuse. But hidden in the detail are plans to return at least 30,000 failed asylum seekers every year by "enforcing refusals of asylum more vigorously".
fields.body:
The Home Office gets money to tackle crime and drug abuse. But hidden in the detail are plans to return at least 30,000 failed asylum seekers every year by "enforcing refusals of asylum more vigorously".

The immigration service is to receive an extra £400m for each of the next three years to deal with the crisis backlog of nearly 100,000 cases and to get decision times down from 18 to six months.

However, the extra money - far more than was expected to be saved by scrapping welfare benefits for asylum seekers - comes with the Treasury's expectation that the annual removals of "those with unfounded claims" will rise from the 7,650 who left last year to "at least 30,000 a year".

The Home Office already plans to build three more immigration detention centres, and the places available to hold failed asylum seekers pending deportation are to increase in two stages from 900 places to 2,700, and then to a capacity of 4,000 secure spaces.

Overall the increase in the Home Office budget from £8.1bn this year to £10.6bn in 2003-04 represents a real terms increase of 6.4% a year. Most of the extra money, £1.6bn, will go into the police to give them a 3.8% annual funding increase to help meet targets to reduce car crime and burglary. In the light of the latest violent crime figures, they are to get a new target to reduce robbery in "our principal cities" by 14% by 2005.

The extra money will also buy computers to analyse crime data and share it with health, education and social services. Each police force is to be set a target detailing the improvements it has to make to match performance of the best forces. The best-performing local police divisions are to share in a £5m reward fund.

The number of extra officers to be recruited is to be announced today.

At least £160m a year for each of three years is to be spent on crime reduction to help meet targets of cutting car crime by 30% by 2004, burglary by 25% by 2005, and the robbery target.

The Treasury documents also promise the long awaited "national strategy on alcohol misuse" will be published. A national treatment agency is to be set up to give help to the 200,000 problem drug addicts, funded by the Home Office and the Department of Health. Money on drug treatment will rise from £234m to £401m in three years' time. There is also to be extra money for child, adolescent and adult mental health services.

While police and the anti-drugs initiatives are well funded, the Treasury expects the prison and probation services to find 3% a year "efficiency savings" from their budgets. Extra will be available to increase the 70,000 capacity of the prisons, and help is to be given the prisons with literacy and numeracy classes for inmates.

The effectiveness of community punishment is to be increased on a "what works" principle, with targets set for reducing the rate of reconvictions of those sentenced to probation, community service and other orders.

The cross-departmental review on crime reduction has also produced targets to reduce school truancy and exclusions, and for literacy of school children. A target is set to tackle the crime rate for children in care, three times higher than the child average.

Ministers have decided that, once they have achieved the 1997 election pledge of cutting the time to get a young offender to court from arrest from an average of 142 days to 71, they will try to "maintain the level thereafter". But a target will be set by March next year to cut the time it takes to get all defendants to court.

The courts and police are also to be asked to improve by 5% within two years the satisfaction levels of victims and witnesses with their treatment, and to increase the proportion of recorded crime for which an offender is brought to justice.

Targets

 Remove 30,000 asylum seekers each year.

 Reduce robbery by 14% in principal cities by 2005.

 Increase detection rates for recorded crime.

 Cut reconviction rates by 5% by 2004.

webTitle: US-UK split halts bid for Sierra Leone war crimes court

fields.headline: US-UK split halts bid for Sierra Leone war crimes court
fields.trailText: Efforts to create a special court for war criminals in Sierra Leone have been stymied by disagreements between the United States and Britain over the scope held by such a court.
fields.body:
Efforts to create a special court for war criminals in Sierra Leone have been stymied by disagreements between the United States and Britain over the scope held by such a court.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, and the US ambassador to the UN, Richard Holbrooke, have held several discussions on the issue, but have been unable to bridge their differences.

In a UN security council meeting last week Britain was described by a source as "refusing to budge" as members swapped ideas on the court. Given the inability of these two allies to agree, Sierra Leone's hopes for the speedy establishment of a special court appear illusory.

Horrific atrocities have marked the eight-year civil war that has blighted the former British colony. Revolutionary United Front (RUF) rebels led by Foday Sankoh have committed most, but not all of the abuses. RUF rebels have terrorised the civilian population with their gruesome trademark - hacking limbs off men, women and children.

Mr Sankoh was arrested by pro-government forces in May, days after gunmen protecting him at his Freetown home opened fire on a crowd of demonstrators outside, killing at least 19 people. Since his capture, made possible because of the intervention of British forces, Britain and other nations have called for the rebel leader to be tried for war crimes.

Earlier this month, the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, said nothing should stand in the way of a full trial, and that the possibility of trying Mr Sankoh was under serious discussion. But these discussions have run to ground amid conflicting British and American views.

The Foreign Office is keen to see a court with minimum input from the UN to avoid bureaucratic snarls. Wary of repeating the experience of the UN's Rwanda tribunal, which was dogged by incompetence and corruption, British officials want the court to be run by Sierra Leonans with some help from the Commonwealth rather than the UN.

"We want a swift and simple system that builds on Sierra Leonean structures and is owned by them," said a Foreign Office official. "It is the subject of discussion between various UN security council members."

But the US, on the other hand, wants to fold a special Sierra Leonean court into the UN system, to the point of sharing the appeals chamber of the international tribunals for the former Yugoslavia and Rwanda. A US draft resolution circulating at the UN calls on the secretary general to appoint an appropriate number of trial judges and one pre-trial judge, and says qualified prosecutors should be appointed through a joint process agreed upon between the UN and the government of Sierra Leone.

The government in Sierra Leone, which is receiving military support from Britain, favours the British model. In a letter to Mr Annan sent in June, President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah appealed to the UN for help in setting up a court with a narrow mandate to prosecute the most responsible violators and the leadership of the RUF. "This could result in the number being limited to dozens," President Kabbah wrote. "This will allow the court to be quick and efficient in its tasks of doing justice."

Mr Kabbah's desire for a court that focuses on Mr Sankoh and senior RUF figures is understandable, as some of the people implicated in atrocities are fighting for him and command large numbers of soldiers at company level and at brigade level in one case.

"Many human rights violations are being committee by pro-government forces, including the armed forces revolutionary council (AFRC)," said Corinne Dufka of Human Rights Watch in Sierra Leone. Led by former military ruler Johnny Paul Koroma, the AFRC or West Side Boys have been accused of committing many abuses.

Moreover, Mr Kabbah wants the court to be structured so that Sierra Leone's attorney general is the chief or co-chief prosecutor of the court. "This structure will allow the government of Sierra Leone to play a lead role in the prosecution while receiving international assistance and expertise," the president wrote, leading to concerns from human rights groups as to whether Mr Sankoh would ever receive a fair trail in Sierra Leone.

"The UN could not support in any way a court that limited jurisdiction to post-Lome [the 1999 peace accord which included a blanket amnesty for those who committed atrocities] and only the RUF," said Ms Dufka. Human Rights Watch favours a court more within the UN system, rather than Britain's more pragmatic quick-fix approach.

While differences between the US and Britain have blocked the creation of a special court, the effort has also been impeded by disagreement on the wider UN mandate for Sierra Leone. The US is reluctant to approve an additional 3,500 troops to the present force of 12,000 unless UN forces are allowed to be more aggressive - to the extent of retaking the diamond mines from the rebels. The US favours the deployment of Nigerian troops, who have fought in Sierra Leone before, a move opposed by Britain because of alleged Nigerian corruption.

webTitle: Let the music play (at least a bit)

fields.headline: Let the music play (at least a bit)
fields.trailText: West Indies fans can console themselves with the thought that, from now on, no-one will stop them banging their drums, blowing their whistles and waving their flags. Thanks to a team that's gone as flat as a beer in the Caribbean sun, they will not be returning this summer to Lord's, the one ground that puts a clamp on their noisy exuberance.
fields.body:
West Indies fans can console themselves with the thought that, from now on, no-one will stop them banging their drums, blowing their whistles and waving their flags. Thanks to a team that's gone as flat as a beer in the Caribbean sun, they will not be returning this summer to Lord's, the one ground that puts a clamp on their noisy exuberance.

They're free to make as much music as they want at Trent Bridge on Thursday (when the Windies meet England in the meaningless final match of the triangular one-day competition), Old Trafford, Headingley, and their favourite venue, The Oval. The fans will be happy to be able to gee up their suddenly lethargic team in a way they're used to, but they are still smarting from being silenced by MCC.

The last time they were at Lord's, two weekends ago for the first West Indies-England match of the triangular competition, rain spoilt everything. They sat there huddled in the cold and the gloom, miserable and unable to cheer themselves up with a little music. Moses, a Barbadian/Guyanese, was bitterly disappointed. "Cricket without noise and atmosphere is like cornflakes without milk", he declared. "Ah'm going to get a drum, and ah bet you ah'll get arrested. We used to have a much better atmosphere in the '70s and '80s".

Marjorie who'd travelled all the way from Jamaica pronounced the proceedings funereal, promptly turned up the collar on her coat and slumped back into her seat. London-born Pauline had been making noise at West Indies games for 20 years, and wistfully recalled the days when the fans could bring horns into Lord's; now she says they're seizing even the flags. She told me she risked arrest by defiantly continuing to wave her Trinidad and Tobago flag.

This column has criticised MCC's ban, arguing that it contradicts efforts by the ECB and Channel 4 to make the game more multicultural. I still feel that MCC are out of touch with modern Britain. But when I talked to the club's spokesman, Chris Rea, he resolutely stood his ground. "Lord's has its own atmosphere. It may not be the atmosphere of the Caribbean, South Africa or Australia. Music is part of the Caribbean tradition: it's not part of the tradition at Lord's".

A day at the game has a different meaning for Graham from Surrey, than it does for Bert from Antigua. According to Rea, it's a more genteel affair for the typical England fan at Lord's, and they want to make themselves heard when they're chatting with the person next to them. Some members even objected to the small concession to multiculturalism that MCC did make. They complained about the din when Third World - one of the best and most cultured of reggae bands - played at lunchtime on day one of the second Test.

This attitude ignores certain changes taking place at cricket matches. The England fans in particular are becoming more, shall we say, working-class. They raise the roof instead of offering polite applause. Richie Benaud goes purple with indignation every time they start a Mexican wave, but even he realises that's just one of the waves the traditionalists cannot roll back. They've taken to their hearts a down-to-earth Barnsley boy named Darren Gough, and he has in turn publicly praised the Barmy Army. The bars do far brisker business in lager than in dry white. Wigs and silly sunglasses are in, and flags with the names of obscure football clubs are now commonplace. Yet it's not disruptive. Windies supporters, for example, always stop the music when a bowler gets into his delivery stride and pipe up again once the shot has been played.

And a curious interaction is taking place between the fans. In the Edrich Stand on the third afternoon of the second Test, I saw England supporters giving as good as they got from West Indians. Not like the football hooligans did at Charleroi, but in a very friendly way. The jibes flew thick and fast as Cork and Gough edged towards the target, but not once did it feel threatening. At the end when England had won, one of the noisiest Windies supporters stood near the exit and shook the hand of every England supporter who was filing out.

I wish our friend Graham who complained about the "noise" Third World made could see that. It wouldn't change decades of set ideas about Lord's tradition, but it might just make him see that allowing the musical instruments in would be a small step in cultural broadening. The country needs it. So does Lord's.

Orin Gordon, born and brought up in Guyana, has lived in London for six years and currently works as a broadcast journalist. To read his previous Anglo-Caribbean View, on how the West Indies second string blew it at the Lord's Test, click here

webTitle: Hollywood sues website to stop copying of films

fields.headline: Hollywood sues website to stop copying of films
fields.trailText: Hollywood joined the music industry in the battle against digital downloads this week, with a legal battle against a website operator for alleged copyright infringement.
fields.body:
Hollywood joined the music industry in the battle against digital downloads this week, with a legal battle against a website operator for alleged copyright infringement.

The Motion Picture Association of America, an industry trade group, has filed a lawsuit against Eric Corley, the publisher of 2600, a quarterly hackers' magazine and website, in a move that is being eagerly watched by online businesses, lawyers and computer users in the US.

Mr Corley's website has distributed software that unscrambles the encryption on DVDs, thereby allowing computer users to download movies on to high-quality discs and send films across the internet. In addition, it provides links to other websites which contain the same information.

At issue in the case, which came to court on Monday, is a 1998 law on copyright in the US which has already pitched the music industry against listeners citing the First Amendment of the US constitution, which protects the right to free speech.

Leon Gold, a leading lawyer for the film studios, told the court: "The threat of world copying is here and the process has begun. It will become an avalanche unless this court acts."

Martin Garbus, the First Amendment lawyer who has represented the author Salman Rushdie, is acting for Mr Corley, who calls himself Emmanuel Goldstein, in a reference to George Orwell's novel 1984.

Mr Garbus argued in court that the technology at the heart of the case is covered by the "fair use" freedoms awarded by the First Amendment. Such arguments are also being put forward to defend online music downloads under the Digital Millennium Copyright Act.

The unscrambling software is thought to have been downloaded from a website owned by Microsoft, the world's biggest software group, by a Norwegian teenager.

It has been largely used to allow people who already own DVDs to watch their movies on computers using Linux, the freely available alternative to Microsoft Windows.

The eight major film studios originally filed a suit against three defendants in January. Following an earlier order by the judge presiding over the case, two of the defendants settled. At the time, Mr Corley agreed to take the DeCSS software which breaks the encryption code off his site, but then continued to provide more than 400 links to sites where the code could be found, citing journalistic freedom of speech.

Mr Corley is a self-confessed hacker and his website is devoted to fighting against what it calls "the failing of our modern technical era... and corporate abuse of power".

The film industry argues that the links on the website blatantly evade the spirit of the prior injunction. It also says that the Copyright Act's language, prohibiting the provision of or "trafficking" in a circumvention device, includes linking.

US district court judge Lewis Kaplan could rule on the case as early as next week.

webTitle: In the Heart of the Sea: part three

fields.headline: In the Heart of the Sea: the Epic True Story that Inspired Moby Dick by Nathaniel Philbrick
fields.trailText: Chapter one: Nantucket (part three)
fields.body:
Chapter one: Nantucket (part three)

Although he wasn't black, Addison Pratt came to Nantucket under circumstances similar to the ones that brought seven African Americans to the island and to service on the Essex. In 1820, Pratt found himself in Boston, looking for a ship:

I soon commenced hunting for a voyage, but it was dull times with commerce as seamen's wages were but ten dollars per month, and there were more sailors than ships in port, and I found it dull times for green hands. But after looking around for a few days I heard there were hands wanted to go on a whaling voyage to the Pacific Ocean. I made no delay, but hastened to the office and put down my name and received twelve dollars of advance money, which I laid out in sea clothes.... Six more hands were shipped for the same vessel, and we were all sent on board of a packet bound to Nantucket.

As Pratt's account suggests, a whaling voyage was the lowest rung on the maritime ladder for a seaman. Nantucketers like Thomas Nickerson and his friends might look to their first voyage as a necessary step in the beginning of a long and profitable career. But for the men who were typically rounded up by shipping agents in cities such as Boston, it was a different story. Instead of the beginning of something, shipping out on a whaling voyage was often a last and desperate resort.
The seven black sailors who agreed to sign on for a voyage aboard the Essex-Samuel Reed, Richard Peterson, Lawson Thomas, Charles Shorter, Isaiah Sheppard, William Bond, and Henry Dewitt-had even fewer choices than Addison Pratt would in 1820. None of their names appear in Boston or New York directories from this period, indicating that they were not landowners. Whether or not they called Boston home, most of them had probably spent more than a few nights in the boardinghouses in the waterfront area of the North End of the city-a place notorious as a gathering place for itinerant seamen, black and white, looking for a berth.
As they boarded the packet for Nantucket, the seven African Americans knew at least one thing: they might not be paid well for their time aboard a Nantucket whaler, but they were assured of being paid no less than a white person with the same qualifications. Since the time when Native Americans had made up the majority of Nantucket's labor force, the island's shipowners had always paid men according to their rank, not their color. Some of this had to do with the Quakers' antislavery leanings, but much of it also had to do with the harsh realities of shipboard life. In a tight spot, a captain didn't care if a seaman was white or black; he just wanted to know he could count on the man to complete his appointed task.
Still, black sailors who were delivered to the island as green hands were never regarded as equals by Nantucketers. In 1807, a visitor to the island reported:

[T]he Indians having disappeared, Negroes are now substituted in their place. Seamen of color are more submissive than the whites; but as they are more addicted to frolicking, it is difficult to get them aboard the ship, when it is about to sail, and to keep them aboard, after it has arrived. The Negroes, though they are to be prized for their habits of obedience, are not as intelligent as the Indians; and none of them attain the rank of [boatsteerer or mate].

It wasn't lofty social ideals that brought black sailors to this Quaker island, but rather the whale fishery's insatiable and often exploitative hunger for labor. "[A]n African is treated like a brute by the officers of their ship," reported William Comstock, who had much to say about the evils of Nantucket's Quaker shipowners. "Should these pages fall into the hands of any of my colored brethren, let me advise them to fly Nantucket as they would the Norway Maelstrom." Even Nickerson admitted that Nantucket whaling captains had a reputation as "Negro drivers." Significantly, Nantucketers referred to the packet that delivered green hands from New York City as the "Slaver."
By the evening of Wednesday, August 11, all save for Captain Pollard were safely aboard the Essex. Anchored beside her, just off the Nantucket Bar, was another whaleship, the Chili. Commanded by Absalom Coffin, the Chili was also to leave the following day. It was an opportunity for what whalemen referred to as a "gam"-a visit between two ships' crews. Without the captains to inhibit the revelry (and with the Bar between them and town), they may have seized this chance for a final, uproarious fling before the grinding discipline of shipboard life took control of their lives.
At some point that evening, Thomas Nickerson made his way down to his bunk and its mattress full of mildewed corn husks. As he faded off to sleep on the gently rocking ship, he surely felt what one young whaleman described as a great, almost overwhelming "pride in my floating home."
That night he was probably unaware of the latest bit of gossip circulating through town-of the strange goings-on out on the Commons. Swarms of grasshoppers had begun to appear in the turnip fields. "[T]he whole face of the earth has been spotted with them ...," Obed Macy would write. "[N]o person living ever knew them so numerous." A comet in July and now a plague of locusts?
As it turned out, things would end up badly for the two ships anchored off the Nantucket Bar on the evening of August 11, 1819. The Chili would not return for another three and a half years, and then with only five hundred barrels of sperm oil, about a quarter of what was needed to fill a ship her size. For Captain Coffin and his men, it would be a disastrous voyage.
But nothing could compare to what fate had in store for the twenty-one men of the Essex.
