webTitle: Sarah's parents' plea to catch killer

fields.headline: Sarah's parents' plea to catch killer
fields.standfirst: More about the Sarah Payne case
fields.trailText: Murdered schoolgirl Sarah Payne's parents pleaded with the public today to help them catch their child's killer, giving their first press conference since their eight-year-old daughter's body was found in a West Sussex field.
fields.body:
Murdered schoolgirl Sarah Payne's parents pleaded with the public today to help them catch their child's killer, giving their first press conference since their eight-year-old daughter's body was found in a West Sussex field.

Sara and Michael Payne told a news conference at Littlehampton, West Sussex: "We've got a job and that's to catch this person."

Sara, 31, told reporters: "The family is devastated. It hasn't really sunk in yet."

Michael, also 31, added: "The whole thing was senseless. To take a little girl like that for whatever reason, to do that to someone and watch us go through all this."

Sara said: "Whoever it is has got to be caught and stopped. We can do that by being here, talking to the police to keep all of us together, to keep our faces in the newspapers, to make people remember.

"We still need information on this white Transit-type van, obviously we can put it in a more defined area now."

Sara, from Hersham, Surrey, said the van may have been seen travelling between Kingston Gorse on the Sussex coast where her daughter was last seen alive in a country lane near her grandparents' home on July 1 and Pulborough, 12 miles to the north where her body was dumped that same weekend in a field ten yards from the A29.

Sara continued: "We need information to catch these people. Man, woman, whoever. They must never be allowed to put people through this again. They have watched us suffer."

Sara said the heartbreak the family felt was more difficult because they had not been able to say goodbye to Sarah properly.

"We can't even see her because it is too hard and it's not our Sarah. I don't believe anybody should be allowed to do that to anyone.

"Justice is too good for this person. We haven't been able to say goodbye to her, it's so unfair."

fields.headline: Mannerisms maketh the TV man
fields.trailText: Last night we watched a group of people bored out of their minds, doing boring things. It was a good thing for them but a bad thing for telly.
fields.body:
Last night we watched a group of people bored out of their minds, doing boring things. It was a good thing for them but a bad thing for telly.

From the start of Big Brother, we got the hype: "There will be full nudity from the beginning", said the continuity announcer. We got Mercedes, sepulchre voices, the whole star treatment. But it was phoney from the start.

There was, for example, Sadie, the blonde with the rubber penis and the hyena laugh. But why did she bring the penis? Would she use it? Would she lend it? Straight away, I felt manipulated by others than those I was watching.

Early in the episode, the contestants played a truth game, where they had to reveal secrets. Nicholas, the stockbroker's pieces to camera were rehearsed, orchestrated and performed. More manipulation. This showed itself more clearly when Anna, the nun, was used as a clever come on. Of course we already know she was a lesbian but the question was: would she develop a crush on the other women?

Early on nothing was intriguing. Then, thankfully, back in the house, Big Brother gave the contestents their first challenge: "Your task is to make your own mug." I was then forced to ask: which programme am I watching? Aren't these the words and commands from Bare Necessities, seen an hour earlier on another channel?

Then an interesting variable came into the programme: Thomas, the Irishman, was called to speak with Big Brother. But as we were about to hear something original from him, we were whisked away to a prepared biography. Eventually, back with Tom, we heard him talking about things we could not judge because we had not seen them. Once again, it was the evidence we needed to understand their condition. We were told who to like.

Then the blonde hyena laughed and laughed. If we had to endure their reality, we would have had to suffer their fate and we'd have switched off.

So the hand of Christo, the god-like presence in the film, the Truman Show, came on to spare our feelings. Another maniuplative edit.

If these were the edited highlights, what must the outtakes have been like? Any attempt at psychological understanding was denied us. That was my big complaint. The girls talked about Darren but we didn't know Darren well enough to make a judgment. Nor could we remember which one he was.

We were denied enough evidence to make decisions about the individuals. And all the time, the suspicion that somebody was manipulating them became more obvious. Why did the women go to the door to find the clay penis made by the men?

Were they told to? Could we believe what little we saw? Even this early on, could the controllers avoid controlling, or will a Christo emerge?

And suddenly I was interested: Nicholas started asking fellow competitors questions. Very late into the first episode we knew why Big Brother was going to be a hit. "Will you win?" he asked Darren, his co-inmate. Was he asked to ask that or was it just a piece of luck for the film-makers? We could see that for wily Nicholas, the prize money was already in his sights. Was I seduced, traduced or just another weak-willed watcher? Yes, I will continue watching because there are two people I want to confirm my suspicions about.

But in the end, it was anodyne, safe reality. Has documentary really come to this?

 Paul Watson's documentaries include The Family, Sylvania Waters, and The Dinner Party.

fields.headline: Polanski sued for 'pocketing' VAT refunds
fields.trailText: Roman Polanski is being sued by the production house that released The Ninth Gate. Artisan Entertainment alleges that the Polish director pocketed more than $1m in VAT refunds last year, instead of returning the money to the banks which funded the film
fields.body:
Roman Polanski is being sued by the production house that released his last film, The Ninth Gate. Artisan Entertainment, the team behind The Blair Witch Project, filed a lawsuit on July 11, alleging that the Polish director pocketed more than $1m in VAT refunds last year, instead of returning the money to the banks which funded the film.

The director's RP Productions has already received $619,000 in refunds (because the film was made in, and then exported from, France) and is due to receive a further $577,000. According to Artisan, the Chinatown director has "brazenly deposited the money in a private account" and "has refused all requests to return the money".

The complaint has been filed with the US district court in Los Angeles. Polanski is unlikely to make a personal appearance for the case - there's still a warrant out for his arrest dating from the 1970s, when he fled America while on bail for a statutory rape charge, amid claims that he'd had sex with an underage girl.

fields.headline: Gloom, hope and spinning opinions
fields.standfirst:
Gould memo on more Labour failings

Full text: Philip Gould's leaked memo
fields.trailText: Halfway through the mournful leaked memorandum written by Labour's pollster, Philip Gould, comes the upbeat admission that "it is entirely within our power to win another magnificent victory. But this will only happen if we change trajectory now."
fields.body:
Halfway through the mournful leaked memorandum written by Labour's pollster, Philip Gould, comes the upbeat admission that "it is entirely within our power to win another magnificent victory. But this will only happen if we change trajectory now."

Those words were written in early May, according to today's Sun, shortly after Tony Blair wrote his own anguished memo about Labour's weakness to the charge that it is out of touch with the "gut instincts" of the British people over core issues like crime, patriotism and the asylum crisis.

Both leaks are over two months old, as Downing St was quick to point out last night. And Labour loyalists have been saying that ministers - led by Mr Blair - have already adjusted their "trajectory" in response to setbacks last spring that culminated in local election defeats and Ken Livingstone's mayoral triumph.

Mr Gould himself lists changes which the prime minister already seems determined to try to put into effect: crossing what his pollster calls "a threshold of voter trust" by delivering competently on Labour's 1997 election promises, but also conveying "instinct, endeavour, values" - above all the "right instinct" - on core issues like health, education and crime.

Mr Gould, a key moderniser since Neil Kinnock's leadership days, studies polls and conducts focus group sessions.

But his own gloom - evident before Mr Blair's 1997 election triumph when he wrote that Labour was not yet ready for government - again shines through a memo which should never have been circulated beyond the inner circle, let alone allowed to fall into the hands of disaffected junior officials or outside computer hackers.

Perhaps it should never have been committed to paper at all. "There is currently now a chance that our majority will fall dramatically following the pattern of 1945 and 1964 (he means 1966) _ there is growing evidence that the settled pattern of Labour's poll lead has been broken by recent events," Mr Gould concedes.

As with Mr Blair's Chequers memo of April 29 - also leaked to the Murdoch-owned "New Labour" Sun and Times - the context was William Hague's spate of law and order speeches, the row over repeal of Section 28 and "unpopularity" over the euro.

Mr Gould complains that the government seems to be drifting, "growing almost monthly weaker and more diffuse" unable to tackle issues it could have anticipated, but seems "powerless to turn into effective preventative action".

Flaying the government, he warns of "constant criticism and, worse, even ridicule" and he talks despairingly of "spin, lack of conviction and apparent lack of integrity, manifested by the mayoral election process". Such loose talk will offend many Labour activists Frank Dobson supporters.

Mr Gould implicitly admits that attacks from the left - for betrayal - are part of what "progressive governments" must endure, not least because the media is conservative and "the leftwing press is pretty feeble".

He even wonders if Labour lacks "politicians genuinely in tune with the people.

In his memo - spread across two pages of today's Sun - he candidly admits weaknesses but goes on to argue that, provided Labour resorts to "utmost clarity" and not "confusing and abstract third way messages", it can win again.

webTitle: Full text: Philip Gould's leaked memo

fields.headline: Full text: Philip Gould's leaked memo
fields.standfirst:
Labour pollster Philip Gould wrote this memo in early May to outline where he believes the party is losing his way. Headed "Getting the right place in history and not the wrong one" it was yesterday leaked to the press.

Political editor Michael White on the leak's background
fields.trailText: I am unable to attend tomorrow's meeting as                         I am in the US. But I wanted to put down my                         current thinking.
fields.body:
I am unable to attend tomorrow's meeting as I am in the US. But I wanted to put down my current thinking.

Where are we?

I think our current situation is serious. There is absolutely no room for complacency.

There is currently now a chance that our majority will fall dramatically, following the pattern of 1945 and 1964. This is not just pessimism on my part. SG [Stan Greenberg], is now projecting a share of vote at the General Election that is something like 37 per cent to the Tories, 42 per cent to us - much too close for comfort.

There is growing evidence that the settled pattern of Labour's poll lead has been broken by recent events.

But it is not opinion polls alone that lead to anxiety about the future. It is much more a sense that for much of the last 18 months, the Government has been drifting, growing almost monthly weaker and more diffuse. Above all else, I have a sense of government which started with great strength but has seen that strength ebb away and erode as the months and years have passed.

Almost every issue that has caused us difficulty has been anticipated but we have been powerless to turn foreknowledge into effective preventative action.

We are the opposite of Clinton. He started badly but got a grip and developed eventually an easy comfortable rhythm of government. We have been the opposite, starting with great momentum but have been unable to sustain this into the latter part of the Parliament.

The cost of all this has been high. We are outflanked on patriotism and crime; we are suffering from disconnection; we have been assailed for spin and broken promises; we are not believed to have delivered; we are believed by a huge margin to be slowing down rather than speeding up; we are disliked on the left for being right wing, on the right for being politically correct.

Perhaps worst of all, as PH [Peter Hyman], the adviser who invented Labour's election pledge card) lays out in an excellent note he is preparing, the New Labour brand has been badly contaminated. It is the object of constant criticism and, even worse, ridicule. Undermined by a combination of spin, lack of conviction and apparent lack of integrity, manifested by the Mayoral election process.

But the paradox of our position is that while it is possible that our majority will be badly cut, it is also possible for us to return to power with another huge majority. It is entirely within our power to win another magnificent victory. But this will only happen if we change trajectory now.

How did we get here?

PM [Peter Mandelson] said the other day: "Something has gone seriously wrong but what is it?" That is much of our problem. We don't know what is the real root cause of the difficulties we face. Here are some suggestions.

There is something about the nature of progressive governments that leads to this kind of erosion and weakening. It may be that right-wing governments are more successful at sustaining governing coalitions because the British press are instinctively Conservative; because they get the support of the press; because the right-wing press and commentators do not generally attack the right in government, while the left-wing press are pretty feeble at it; because the right like to govern and are competent and confident in doing it.

Conversely, progressive governments are attacked by the left for betrayal and by the right because they do not believe in our right to govern; we lack confidence in power; we have no proselytising press to rely on; we lack politicians genuinely in tune with the people. (How many ministers, for example, genuinely want to be tough on crime?)

The conditions of government have changed so dramatically that holding and sustaining power is far more difficult. This is the view I put forward one year ago in one note on the New Incumbency. It is also the view of Dick Morris in his book The New Machiavelli.

He argues politics has now moved from representational democracy to direct democracy, in which there is a need to win a daily mandate, in which strength comes from popularity and in which the public is much more fickle and discerning and the media far more hostile. This is the opposite of the old model in which you took tough mid-term decisions, lost popularity but won it back at the end. I don't believe this model holds anymore and that we are competing in totally new political conditions and we really don't know how to handle them.

We are not strong enough at the centre. We have not proved strong enough to win enough battles, to get enough done.

We have lacked political coherence between our most senior politicians and this has at times immobilised us.

We have got our political strategy wrong. We were too late with the NHS; we raised expectations that could not be met in our first two years; we concentrated too much on competence and delivery in isolation, neglecting the values, messages, instincts and empathy that served us so well in Opposition.

We have not fully modernised as a party.

We have been New Labour on the economy but we have appeared soft on crime, not pro-family, lacking in gut patriotic instincts.

We quickly seem to have grown out of touch.

Our ministers simply do not seem as in touch as they were in Opposition.

There has been no shared agreement about what is the New Labour project for the government.

How do we move on to win a large majority?

None of these explanations are adequate in themselves and there are others. What has gone wrong is some kind of accumulation of all of the above. What is certain is that we have to agree on what the problem is and move decisively to resolve it.

What should we do?

We must cross a threshhold of voter trust and acceptability. Put another way, we must keep the implicit contract we made with the electorate in 1997.

This concept of threshhold is very important. Unless we achieve this, we cannot move on. The bold, radical second term requires that we pass the threshhold requirements of the first.

But we must be absolutely confident what threshhold means.

It does not mean just governing with competence and delivery at a reasonable level of improvement.

The threshhold is as much about instinct, endeavour, values as it is about what we have done.

It is vital that we understand this.

This means that in all the core areas - NHS, economy, crime, education, patriotism, social inclusion and community, family - we have not just delivered workable policies but have shown the right instincts and the right level of commitment and endeavour.

In government, virtue will not reap its own reward. Delivery alone will not produce, in DA's [Douglas Alexander] phrase, deliverance. We have to win hearts as well as minds in every single one of our core areas.

Our contract with the British people is as much emotional as it is rational.

We must move from third way to one way.

We must build a one way pattern from a mosaic of uncompromising and single-minded positions in all of the policy and issue areas rather than a whole raft of often confusing and abstract third way messages.

This means that on the economy we are for stability, on education we are for standards and, for example, on crime we are tough or for zero tolerance; on the NHS we are for consumers; on Britain for patriotism; on poverty we will end it for children, etc. (These words are not right, they are examples.)

If we can do this, it will give us absolute clarity in each policy area but it will enable us to have the confidence to be both for business and for ending child poverty; for saving the NHS while also being tough on crime. It will free us up to have a real voice in all areas.

We need to build the government around two central pillars: economic stability and security and cultural stability and security.

But this message of security must be set out in context of change.

We provide security (an opportunity in a world of change); the Conservatives offer neither.

Dealing with change is going to be the dominant issue of the next year and is the crucial dividing line between the parties.

We need to be far simpler and more professional. We need to get back in touch. We need to reinvent the New Labour brand.

PM [Peter Mandelson] said the other day: "Something has gone seriously wrong but what is it?" That is much of our problem. We don't know what is the real root cause of the difficulties we face. Here are some suggestions. There is something about the nature of progressive governments that leads to this kind of erosion and weakening. It may be that right-wing governments are more successful at sustaining governing coalitions because the British press are instinctively Conservative; because they get the support of the press; because the right-wing press and commentators do not generally attack the right in government, while the left-wing press are pretty feeble at it; because the right like to govern and are competent and confident in doing it. Conversely, progressive governments are attacked by the left for betrayal and by the right because they do not believe in our right to govern; we lack confidence in power; we have no proselytising press to rely on; we lack politicians genuinely in tune with the people. (How many ministers, for example, genuinely want to be tough on crime?) The conditions of government have changed so dramatically that holding and sustaining power is far more difficult. This is the view I put forward one year ago in one note on the New Incumbency. It is also the view of Dick Morris in his book The New Machiavelli. He argues politics has now moved from representational democracy to direct democracy, in which there is a need to win a daily mandate, in which strength comes from popularity and in which the public is much more fickle and discerning and the media far more hostile. This is the opposite of the old model in which you took tough mid-term decisions, lost popularity but won it back at the end. I don't believe this model holds anymore and that we are competing in totally new political conditions and we really don't know how to handle them. We are not strong enough at the centre. We have not proved strong enough to win enough battles, to get enough done. We have lacked political coherence between our most senior politicians and this has at times immobilised us. We have got our political strategy wrong. We were too late with the NHS; we raised expectations that could not be met in our first two years; we concentrated too much on competence and delivery in isolation, neglecting the values, messages, instincts and empathy that served us so well in Opposition. We have not fully modernised as a party. We have been New Labour on the economy but we have appeared soft on crime, not pro-family, lacking in gut patriotic instincts. We quickly seem to have grown out of touch. Our ministers simply do not seem as in touch as they were in Opposition. There has been no shared agreement about what is the New Labour project for the government. How do we move on to win a large majority? None of these explanations are adequate in themselves and there are others. What has gone wrong is some kind of accumulation of all of the above. What is certain is that we have to agree on what the problem is and move decisively to resolve it. What should we do? We must cross a threshhold of voter trust and acceptability. Put another way, we must keep the implicit contract we made with the electorate in 1997. This concept of threshhold is very important. Unless we achieve this, we cannot move on. The bold, radical second term requires that we pass the threshhold requirements of the first. But we must be absolutely confident what threshhold means. It does not mean just governing with competence and delivery at a reasonable level of improvement. The threshhold is as much about instinct, endeavour, values as it is about what we have done. It is vital that we understand this. This means that in all the core areas - NHS, economy, crime, education, patriotism, social inclusion and community, family - we have not just delivered workable policies but have shown the right instincts and the right level of commitment and endeavour. In government, virtue will not reap its own reward. Delivery alone will not produce, in DA's [Douglas Alexander] phrase, deliverance. We have to win hearts as well as minds in every single one of our core areas. Our contract with the British people is as much emotional as it is rational. We must move from third way to one way. We must build a one way pattern from a mosaic of uncompromising and single-minded positions in all of the policy and issue areas rather than a whole raft of often confusing and abstract third way messages. This means that on the economy we are for stability, on education we are for standards and, for example, on crime we are tough or for zero tolerance; on the NHS we are for consumers; on Britain for patriotism; on poverty we will end it for children, etc. (These words are not right, they are examples.) If we can do this, it will give us absolute clarity in each policy area but it will enable us to have the confidence to be both for business and for ending child poverty; for saving the NHS while also being tough on crime. It will free us up to have a real voice in all areas. We need to build the government around two central pillars: economic stability and security and cultural stability and security. But this message of security must be set out in context of change. We provide security (an opportunity in a world of change); the Conservatives offer neither. Dealing with change is going to be the dominant issue of the next year and is the crucial dividing line between the parties. We need to be far simpler and more professional. We need to get back in touch. We need to reinvent the New Labour brand.

webTitle: Sarah Payne: turning a tragedy into a sales opportunity

fields.headline: Sarah Payne: turning a tragedy into a sales opportunity
fields.standfirst:
Hypocritical and titillating tabloid coverage of the eight-year-old's murder masks a lack of genuine concern for child welfare, argues the clinical psychologist and author Oliver James

Parents' plea for killer to be caught
More about the Sarah Payne case
fields.trailText:
Hypocritical and titillating tabloid coverage of the eight-year-old's murder masks a lack of genuine concern for child welfare, argues the clinical psychologist and author Oliver James.
Parents' plea for killer to be caught
More about the Sarah Payne case
fields.body:
For the third summer in a row the arrival of the holidays has been accompanied by gruelling, grisly coverage in all media of a child's murder, probably by a paedophile.

Parents are understandably very concerned by the story. Their kids are charging about enjoying the sunshine (at least today) and freedom from teachers. How could I live with myself, they wonder, if something happened?

This is what is so hideous for a parent of a murdered child - almost whatever the circumstances, the parent is bound to find some way in which they could have prevented it happening and therefore, is bound to be plagued with guilt, in most cases for the rest of their lives.

The trouble with all this is that, although it is a hideous prospect, it is utterly absurd for parents to be worrying about the safety of their children. They are at no greater danger than they have ever been in recent times.

The only reason that they are worrying so is because the tabloids, followed sheepishly by the broadcast media, have realised that playing on parents' fears sells newspapers. For the unforgivably hypocritical likes of the Daily Mail, who make themselves out to be concerned about families and piously against crime, this story is a cynical method for increasing circulation.

The reality of child murder is as follows. About 80 children are murdered every year. Of these, an average of just seven are killed by someone with whom they were not previously acquainted. The vast majority of victims are killed by their parents and of these, the majority have a low income.

If the Daily Mail really wanted to draw attention to an important social problem they would focus on this latter: the fact that one quarter of children are still being raised in low-income homes as a result of the economic policies of the Mrs Thatcher that the Mail so vigorously supported.

But that is hardly likely to be their focus. Instead, they devote huge space and energy to turning a real life horror story into an episode of Cracker or Inspector Morse. For the awful truth is that there is a huge market for these ghastly stories because we, including me and including you, are completely gripped by the unfolding saga. We do want to hear the perverse detail that Sarah was found naked, that the murderer seems to have customised his van for committing the crime and so on. We do pay attention as the narrative is unpacked for us.

It begins with the child going missing. Then the parents are wheeled out to express their concern. Small clues emerge... Sarah last seen by sibling... man with white van seen nearby... police widening search, and so on. It becomes obvious that the child is dead and we find ourselves, mostly unconsciously, identifying with what it would be like to be sexually abused and murdered as a child, what it would be like to be living with the likelihood that this has happened to our child. And we do find this entertaining, just as we enjoy horror movies or crime fiction.

But most worrying of all, I believe we also must be identifying with what it would be like to be the perpetrator of this crime, if nothing else, at the level of being the man who is calling all the shots, leading the police a merry dance.

The awful truth is that we are fascinated and excited by these crimes. That is the only possible explanation for the massive and unrelenting success of the innumerable TV dramas which use these plotlines.

But the fact that humans are base and vile is no excuse for the annual charade of the child murder that is now played out every summer. We have to be protected from ourselves and it is most nauseating of all to see the Mail and its brethren both pretending to follow these stories in the public interest and actually using them to sustain sales.

One solution would be for them to exercise restraint but that is like expecting a paedophile to stop his perversions voluntarily. Paul Dacre (the Mail's sanctimonious editor) and Lynda Lee Potter must get their daily fix of nastiness dressed up as public interest.

The only hope is for government to control this more directly through the press regulator and by stopping the police from mounting an obscene annual show. There is absolutely no need to give so much detail: why do we have to be told whether the victim was fully clothed or not? Why are we informed that the parents were not allowed to see the body (implying it had been deformed)?

If the Mail were even slightly sincere in its claims of public interest, it would focus on the real dangers for children: of asthma, caused by 20 years of Mail-backed Tory failure to curb car use; of grossly unhealthy diets, leading to overweight children who will become heart attack victims in adulthood; above all, of having parents on a low income.

But the Mail cares nothing about these things. Far better to flog lots of copies by titillating us and terrifying parents with the story of the sexual murder of a small child.

 Oliver James is a clinical psycologist and author of Britain on the Couch: why we're unhappier compared with 1950 despite being richer
Buy Oliver James's book on BOL

fields.headline: Danish director launches pro-euro campaign
fields.trailText: Award-winning Danish director Lars von Trier is to shoot a campaign film to encourage his fellow countrymen to adopt the euro.
fields.body:
Award-winning Danish director and general oddball Lars von Trier is to shoot a campaign film to encourage his fellow countrymen to adopt the euro.

Denmark will hold a referendum in September on whether to join the European Monetary Union and accept a single currency. And the acclaimed director of Breaking The Waves, The Idiots and the Palme d'Or-winning musical Dancer In The Dark, wants Danes to vote "yes".

Von Trier and his film company, Zentropa, have dropped their fees for the film, which is being made for the pro-European Danish party Centrum Demokraterne.

"Trier and I find it important that Denmark's cultural scene participates in the euro debate," said Zentropa chief Peter Aalbaek. Euro-scepticism is strong in Denmark, with opinion polls showing more Danes against the common currency than in favour of it.

Von Trier's film will counter resistance by explaining that Danish euro currency will continue to bear a portrait of the country's monarch, Queen Margrethe.

fields.headline: The thinker
fields.standfirst: Edward de Bono is a leading authority on communication. So why is he so bad at conversation, asks  Emma Brockes
fields.trailText: Edward de Bono is a leading authority on communication. So why is he so bad at conversation, asks Emma Brockes
fields.body:
Edward de Bono, inventor of lateral thinking and a man who regards himself as a more powerful visionary than Plato, is outlining his plans for our interview. We are in his ground-floor flat in Albany, the millionaires' row off London's Piccadilly that can't be photographed due to the number of residents at risk from assassination. De Bono, at the low-risk end of the scale, has already strayed from his programme with a preamble about the time he told Sony to invent a dictaphone that records on two tapes at once. (They didn't.)

"It's the difference between value and technology," he says. "Anyway, I'll talk a little bit about that later. So, what I thought I would do is go through some of the things you couldn't possibly know about and then at various points, you can ..."

This does not sound promising. De Bono, frowning like Nixon through the gloom, is holding a piece of paper on which he has typed a list of topics. As he talks, these clarify as a list of his achievements. It is interesting that, despite the many books he has written on how to communicate, the 67-year-old disregards the first rule of exchange: namely that it is customary to allow the other person to speak occasionally.

"Now, for instance, there's a bunch of academics in South Africa who got together to make a CD on who had most contributed on the whole history of humanity. Anyway, I was one of the 50. Then the international astronomical union named a planet after me; again, someone suggested that they might.

"I have been told that on the internet there are so many references to my work that if you spent two minutes on each reference and you began work at nine in the morning and stopped at five in the afternoon, and you began aged 20, you'd not be finished by the time you were 80, doing nothing else." It is a statement inviting pedantry: when you put de Bono's name in one of the large search engines, it brings up 5,226 references, roughly the same number as those summoned for Michael Flatley, the star of Riverdance, and precisely half the number returned for the 1980s girl band Bananarama. Umberto Eco, by comparison, gets 27,899 mentions, Steven Hawking 28,399, Camille Paglia 14,900.

De Bono sweeps on. "These are other people's judgments, not my judgment. In other words, if the venture capitalists say, 'We want to hear from you,' it's their judgment. Now I'll tell you about some more direct things." This is the cue for another unprovoked, back-slapping anecdote. "I was coming back from Australia and the arrivals lounge at British Airways and I was going to have a shower. And the shower attendant, standing there, this very humble chap, heard my name and said, 'Are you Edward de Bono who writes the books?' I said yes. He said, 'Oh, I read all of them, so refreshing.' This is an ordinary shower attendant at Heathrow, not a chief executive and so on." And so on and so on.

The success on which de Bono's extraordinary self-regard is based came about in 1969 with the publication of his first important book, The Mechanism of Mind, in which he explored the neurological coding thought to form the basis of human perception. It was welcomed by physicists as a persuasive and authoritative study, based on years of high-level research. De Bono, born in Malta and a graduate in medicine from Malta University, won a Rhodes Scholarship to Christ Church, Oxford, where he gained an honours degree in psychology and physiology and then a DPhil in medicine.

He retains the vestige of a foreign accent, a lilting intonation that it is tempting to read as a device to minimise the chances of interruption. "We'll come back to that," says de Bono, when I break his flow. "Just remember that question and I'll talk about it all together."

With the 1970s, and the boom in the self-help book market, de Bono turned his attention to the more lucrative field of popular psychology. He coined the term "lateral thinking", and started putting out books on problem solving and creative thinking with titles such as I Am Right, You Are Wrong, and How to Be More Interesting.

In his book Six Thinking Hats, published in 1990, he suggested that business meetings might run more smoothly if members put on imaginary hats, colour-coded to encourage group synergy: the black hat for negative thoughts, the yellow for optimistic and so on. In this manner, says de Bono, everyone would be "thinking in the same direction", and "ego would be taken out of the situation".

He refers to himself as a "thinker", a loose term that allows him to move between disciplines. He "thinks" about politics: "I think the Northern Ireland situation could have been much better handled. I know most of the players - I know David Trimble, I know Gerry Adams and so on - and I've given talks on Northern Ireland; there's a lot of interest in my work."

He thinks about economics: "I suggested something that made a lot of sense: I said that, in a democracy, if your party lost the election, you should pay 10% less tax than the other party. They have the luxury of having their choice of government. It's very sensible."

And he thinks about foreign policy. De Bono once advised the Foreign Office that the Arab-Israeli conflict might in part be due to the low levels of zinc found in a people who eat unleavened bread, a known side effect of which is aggression. He suggested shipping out jars of Marmite.

Such is the pride de Bono takes in his work on conflict resolution ("I'm on the council in England for dispute resolutions") that it was noted with some amusement in the press recently that he lost a dispute with the Norfolk planning authorities after trying to stop a barn conversion from going ahead next door to his 18th century home. De Bono becomes quite agitated at the mention of this. "That again, unfortunately, is totally dishonest, because I haven't been involved in that at all. Not at all. My wife is very much interested in architecture. I haven't been involved at all. I've been away. But I'm afraid that's a typical example of ... I haven't been involved at all. Typical dishonesty."

Whilst he welcomes controversy as proof of the power of his work, de Bono tends to regard people who disagree with him as being either stupid or dishonest, although they leave a rather deep impression. "When my book Six Hats came out, Adam Mars-Jones of the Independent wrote a very silly little clever-clever piece. That book, we know, has saved $40m dollars and tens of thousands of man-hours. Now, some silly little idiot, trying to be clever, compared to the actual results, that just makes him look like a fool."

His next book is due out in September, and de Bono snaps out of his reverie and throws me a devilish look. "It will upset a lot of people," he says triumphantly. On his website, he predicts that the book "will upset those minds that are usually upset by my work. It will upset all the literary people who believe that language is wonderful and perfect. In the book I suggest that language is the biggest barrier to human progress because language is an encyclopaedia of ignorance. Old perceptions are frozen into language and force us to look at the world in an old-fashioned way." This is gibberish.

The de Bono Code Book, as it will be called, posits the idea that communication would be better served if we all spoke in numerical code. For example, instead of saying: "Mum, help me out, but don't lecture me," we might say: "Code six." He throws in a few references to his old stamping ground, the neuro-physiological impulse, but it remains a mixture of bad syntax, pseudo-intellectualism and the bleeding obvious.

It is a shame, because he has many sensible things to say, about education, about how children with hobbies develop faster than those without, about how to re-engage the long-term unemployed. To get to these, however, one must endure almost Swiftian heights of absurdity. As I'm leaving, I catch sight of a didgeridoo propped up against the door. De Bono picks it up and starts playing, badly. "Now, the point is," he says, "that the aborigines have been playing it wrong for 3,000 years ..."

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All the rumours teed up and hit nearly 400 yards down the fairway by an American
fields.trailText: Manchester United are planning to offer David Beckham a new deal worth £70,000 a week, according to Teamtalk. But that is still not guaranteed to keep the England player at Old Trafford, if reports on Planet Football are to be believed. According to them, AC Milan are prepared to double any offer United make to Beckham; such a huge contract would be sure to test the loyalty of the United-mad midfielder.
fields.body:
Manchester United are planning to offer David Beckham a new deal worth £70,000 a week, according to Teamtalk. But that is still not guaranteed to keep the England player at Old Trafford, if reports on Planet Football are to be believed. According to them, AC Milan are prepared to double any offer United make to Beckham; such a huge contract would be sure to test the loyalty of the United-mad midfielder.

Aston Villa have denied reports that Deportivo La Coruna have bid £6.5m for Gareth Southgate, adding that any bid below £10m would be doomed to failure anyway.

Liverpool will sign Middlesbrough's Christian Ziege this week, according to the Sun. The paper claims that Ziege has a clause in his contract allowing clubs who offer £5m to talk to him. Gerard Houllier wants the player - who is keen to join up with Germany team-mates Dietmar Hamann and Markus Babbe - on board before the club embarks on their pre-season tour.

Ugo Ehiogu is a club-record £6.5m target for Manchester City. Sunderland are also interested in the Aston Villa defender.

Coventry will make a £2.5m offer for Blackburn's want-away midfielder Lee Carsley.

Everton and Blackburn are interested in Liverpool third-choice keeper Brad Friedel, but the American keeper may favour a move to Mexican side Tigres.

Everton are following the progress of 19-year-old Nice striker Malek Cherrad. The £250,000-rated player will join the Toffees' training camp in Tuscany, according to the Star.

webTitle: Net users braced for new email virus

fields.headline: Net users braced for new email virus
fields.standfirst: A new virus is on its way which could disable a computer which receives a contaminated email. Simon Jeffery asks what can be done to protect computers from this menace
fields.trailText: 19 July, 1.45pm: A new virus is on its way which could disable a computer which receives a contaminated email. Simon Jeffery asks what can be done to protect computers from this menace.
fields.body:
Email users could soon be under attack from a new wave of computer viruses that are activated by merely receiving a message.

Unlike the "Love Bug", which caused an estimated £700m damage to industry in April and May this year, the new viruses would not require a computer user to open an email attachment.

A fault uncovered in Microsoft's popular Outlook and Outlook Express email packages raises the prospect of hackers taking control of thousands of computers with a single email. The intruder could then delete all the files on the hard drive or copy sensitive information on the computer and send a signal to email it back to him or herself.

A Microsoft draft security bulletin says that home users connected to the internet will be at a greater risk than businesses using Outlook in "corporate and workgroup mode". Underground Security Systems Research (USSR), which found and informed Microsoft of the fault, says it has been able to write a malicious code that executes as soon as the target computer begins to download the email.

A spokesman for the group said Microsoft had acted quickly to try to solve the problem, but said he was still concerned that the company does not take security seriously enough. "It appears it's more important for companies to make software and sell it," he said. "If they have problems later they will fix it."

Bug expert Russ Cooper, administrator of the NTBugTraq mailing list, says that the Outlook fault could become a major headache.

"I would say this problem is huge. "It's the 'Good Times virus' come true. If you heard about this, you would call it a hoax," Mr Cooper said, referring to an old computer myth that a single email could destroy a victim's computer.

Mr Cooper expects virus writers to begin sending malicious emails soon, but is hopeful that the home users who are most at risk from the fault will present a less interesting target for hackers than the large corporations.

Microsoft has made a remedy to the fault available on its Microsoft.com security website. USSR released its sample code simultaneously, so programmers will be aware of similar bugs. "It is the only way to make software companies pay attention," a spokesman said.

Underground Security Systems Research
Microsoft security bulletin
NT Bugtraq

webTitle: Clinton gives more time for Middle East peace

fields.headline: Clinton gives more time for Middle East peace
fields.trailText: President Clinton today delayed his departure to the G8 summit of industrialised nations in Japan for a day to give Middle East negotiators a last chance to forge a peace agreement.
fields.body:
President Clinton today delayed his departure to the G8 summit of industrialised nations in Japan for a day to give Middle East negotiators a last chance to forge a peace agreement.

The White House announced that Mr Clinton was putting off his departure until Thursday "in the best interests of the Middle East peace process.'' He had been scheduled to depart Wednesday morning.

"Clearly, the president is doing this so he can continue to work with the leaders through Wednesday,'' said a spokesman.

Even with the extra day there was pessimism from the Palestinians about prospects for reaching an agreement. Hanan Ashrawi, their unofficial spokeswoman, said it would take a ``miracle''.

The Israelis acknowledge that the issues are very difficult. A legislator allied with Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak said yesterday that there was "some room for flexibility'' on the ultra-sensitive subject of Jerusalem but repeated that sovereignty over the city could not be shared.

At Camp David, it has become the norm to work far into the night. Late on Tuesday, the president dined with members of his negotiating team on the back patio of Camp David's Laurel Cabin.

Since the summit began on July 11, Mr Clinton has been shuttling back and forth between the two sides, trying to shepherd them toward an accord on the most painful and divisive issues: the boundaries of a future Palestinian state, the fate of several million Palestinian refugees and - most explosive of all - the status of Jerusalem, which both sides claim as their capital.

A peace agreement struck at Camp David would likely provide Yasser Arafat with the Palestinian state he has fought for nearly all his life. But Mr Barak was said to be digging in his heels at giving the Palestinians sovereignty in east Jerusalem, the traditionally Arab sector of the city where they want to set up their capital.

Complicating the effort is Mr Barak's fast-deteriorating political situation. Just before he left for the talks, his governing coalition fell apart, and he barely beat back a no-confidence motion in parliament, and he faces another one.

Other than an absence of about eight hours on Thursday, Mr Clinton has been at Camp David throughout the talks, leading a marathon drive for an accord.

webTitle: Analysis: The EU has affected economic growth in Ireland

fields.headline: Emerald guile
fields.standfirst:
We need only look across the Irish Sea to establish the truth about eurosceptic claims that being in the eurozone would shackle our economy

Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown is free to spend. Would he be shackled if the UK were in the eurozone? For evidence we need only look westwards. The Irish Republic, growing at more than 7% a year since 1990, generating the highest inflation rate in the eurozone, is in the throes of a Lawson-style boom. In normal circumstances, the Irish central bank would raise rates to prevent the economy overheating. But control of monetary policy now lies with the European Central Bank (ECB). The Irish bank, its locker empty, is reduced   to exhorting commercial banks to be more careful about their lending practices.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown is free to spend. Would he be shackled if the UK were in the eurozone? For evidence we need only look westwards. The Irish Republic, growing at more than 7% a year since 1990, generating the highest inflation rate in the eurozone, is in the throes of a Lawson-style boom. In normal circumstances, the Irish central bank would raise rates to prevent the economy overheating. But control of monetary policy now lies with the European Central Bank (ECB). The Irish bank, its locker empty, is reduced to exhorting commercial banks to be more careful about their lending practices.

If the UK entered we too would be at the mercy of the ECB, which bases policy not on the circumstances in individual countries but on the eurozone as a whole. Goodbye monetary sovereignty; goodbye prosperity. Or so the argument goes.

The problem is that warnings have been sounded many times before and still the Irish tiger keeps roaring. After a decade of growth - the product of record levels of inward investment, low taxes, generous subsidies from Brussels, a highly educated workforce and Emu membership - the Irish economy continues to defy the doom-mongers. Growth last year was over 9%.

Part of the reason is that Ireland is still catching up. It can afford higher inflation without eroding competitiveness. Over time, wages, prices and living standards will be on a par with those in the richer Emu member states, such as Germany, and then foreign investors might decide to go elsewhere. Meanwhile, Ireland's position as the only English speaking country in the eurozone makes it an attractive place, particularly for American hi-tech companies.

The "catch up" argument suggests that, far from the boom ending in a spectacular bust, Ireland may just gradually slow down until it begins to grow at a similar rate to core eurozone countries. But it would be wise for the authorities not to bet on it. Inflation, once it gets a grip, has a habit of not letting go. Academic studies show consistently high inflation rates of 10% or more do damage growth.

To reassert some control over the economy, the authorities are being forced to consider using their other major macroeconomic tool - fiscal policy.

So far the Irish government has ignored the ECB's advice to put up taxes aggressively in order to slow demand. Under the terms of the social pact struck with the unions and employers, the government is committed to reducing taxes in exchange for responsible wage deals. Instead, it has sought to use legislative powers to cap the price of beer.

This may seem a pathetically inadequate response but it does highlight the need to reconsider options for controlling the economy inside a currency zone with a single interest rate.

It is one of the great eurosceptic myths that Britain will lose control over its ability to tax and spend if it joins the euro. The only constraint on its behaviour, imposed by the so-called stability pact, is that its borrowing must be kept within certain limits. In practice, the stability pact dictates that countries belonging to the eurozone must run balanced budgets, some thing which Gordon Brown is already doing.

However, it is doubtful whether Mr Brown's current approach to fiscal policy is ideal for joining. He believes that fiscal policy is too blunt a weapon for managing demand in the economy. Unlike interest rates, which can be changed monthly, or sooner in an emergency, fiscal policy is set once a year in the budget. Although Mr Brown believes the level of spending and taxation can support monetary policy, he thinks public services such as schools and hospitals should be well-funded irrespective of the macro economic climate. Active fiscal policy can influence the supply side of the economy by, for example, increasing the incentive to work. But Mr Brown has not yet shown any inclination to use fiscal policy in the same way as Finland, for example.

Like Ireland, Finland is too small to influence ECB decisions. But it too is growing rapidly and the authorities there are keeping a watchful eye on inflationary pressures. One of the solutions they have come up with is to put up employers' national insurance contributions in an economic upswing and reduce them in a downturn, as a way of smoothing the cycle. It's a long way from the Keynesian tax and spend policies that the former German finance minister Oskar Lafontaine was advocating before he resigned in a huff, but it's a start.

Iain Begg of South Bank University is undertaking an Economic and Social Research Council-sponsored project on adjustment mechanisms inside the eurozone. In the past, a floating exchange rate did play an important part in managing the Irish economy; but he dismisses the notion that Ireland is heading for economic disaster, pointing out that 10 years ago it was labelled a basket case. "Now it's problems are those of success." While others see parallels between Ireland and the UK, he highlights their differences. Ireland represents just 1% of the eurozone. If Britain joined it would represent almost a fifth. While the ECB may not pay much attention to Ireland when setting interest rates, it would not be able to ignore the UK. With the UK inside the eurozone, interest rates would certainly be higher than they are now - maybe not high enough for the Bank of England's liking. But how long is it that UK inflation has been below the government's target?

Mark Atkinson is our economics correspondent mark.atkinson@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Labour stung by new leak
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's government was last night shaken by further damaging disclosures about its internal strategy dilemmas when another memorandum written by Labour's pollster, Philip Gould, was leaked to the Murdoch press.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's government was last night shaken by further damaging disclosures about its internal strategy dilemmas when another memorandum written by Labour's pollster, Philip Gould, was leaked to the Murdoch press.

Written in early May, days after Mr Blair's newly leaked memo to senior colleagues, Mr Gould's assessment restated his familiar theme: "Our current situation is serious."

He quoted a Blair policy unit aide at No 10 saying: "Perhaps worst of all, the New Labour brand has been badly contaminated" and said that Peter Mandelson, Mr Gould's old ally, privately asked: "Something has gone seriously wrong - but what?"

Last night Labour MPs were divided between those who believe that the government is the victim of a "high politics" row within the Blairite kitchen cabinet and - the majority view - that the Conservatives are orchestrating a "job lot" of documents to cause maximum damage.

"All the recent leaks have one central theme: that Tony Blair is all spin and no substance," one senior Downing Street official said last night. "Since this is being said on the very day that Gordon Brown sets out substantial plans for the next three years some people will start thinking that something pretty unfair is going on."

Admitting that Labour's extra funding for the NHS may have come too late to meet expectations and that William Hague's populist offensive on law and order themes seems to have outflanked Labour, Mr Gould asked: "How many ministers genuinely want to be tough on crime?"

Though the contents of the memo printed in today's Times and Sun cover much of the same "out of touch" ground which their sister paper the Sunday Times reported last month, the timing was clearly intended to detract attention from Gordon Brown's spending review.

Senior Downing Street officials were angered by the leak and the cabinet secretary, Sir Richard Wilson, is expected to include it in the inquiry he is already mounting into Monday's publication - in the same papers - of Mr Blair's memo of April 29, fretting about public misperceptions of his government.

Mr Gould's memo, sent to a handful of key ministers and officials - by fax and, possibly, email - admitted that the likely Labour lead over the Tories, estimated at 42% to 37% (the Guardian's ICM poll this week put it at 42% to 35%) was "much too close for comfort".

It contrasted Bill Clinton's shaky start in 1992 - and strong finish - with Labour's early good luck which had led to 18 months of "drifting, growing almost monthly weaker and more diffuse".

Some Labour backbenchers and even ministers half-believe that the leaks are a symptom of internal conflict between senior Blair advisers within No 10.

That seems unlikely given the stakes and the risk that any leaker would face if caught damaging both the chancellor and the prime minister. Some evidence points to the Tories being used as go-between for a leaker whose motives are money rather than politics.

One fact supporting this view is that Tory officials last week boasted to journalists that they had a good story up their sleeves. Reporters who received the stolen memos admit they knew the person who handed them over.

fields.headline: That charter for snoopers
fields.standfirst: Special report: free speech on the net
fields.trailText: 19 July, Richard Norton-Taylor: Parliament today has its last opportunity to object to the government plan to give sweeping new powers for intelligence agencies.
fields.body:
Parliament today has its last opportunity to object to the government plan to give sweeping new powers for intelligence agencies - indeed, any public authority - to conduct covert surveillance, including intercepting emails and bugging property.

As Jonathan Freedland points out in his article today (The text that got away), the misleadingly friendly-sounding regulation of investigatory powers bill (RIP) is one of the more contentious measures even this government's Home Office has managed to produce.

This is not just because of its implications for civil liberties. The bill is also opposed by commercial groups because of the cost of setting up black boxes to link internet service providers to MI5.

While Tony Blair tries to find the person who hacked into his own communication network, companies are deeply concerned about the implications for their businesses and their privacy from the threat of having to hand over encryption keys or the text of emails. As we all should be. The libertarian Tory MP Richard Shepherd likens it to "giving to the police the keys to the doors to your homes".

The interests of business and civil liberties groups coalesced as they realised the full significance of the bill which MPs and peers describe as the most complicated ever - one says it is like "mapping in a fog".

Faced with opposition, Home Office ministers resort to the mantra they use to defend such other disturbing measures as the terrorism bill and the football (disorder) bill. "Trust the authorities and ministers to be sensible," they say, and they damn critics as paranoid conspiracy theorists.

But up to now, GCHQ, the government's electronic eavesdropping centre, has been authorised by ministerial warrant to intercept domestic communications only if there is suspicion of terrorist activity. Under RIP, for the first time, they will be able to trawl through domestic emails more or less at will.

Home Office minister Steve Bassam admitted as much in a letter last week to the Liberal Democrat peer, Andrew Phillips. GCHQ, MI5 and MI6 could also intercept emails between British citizens whether or not they are covered by warrants signed by ministers. Lord Bassam admits the agencies can lawfully intercept internal communications even when a warrant specifies only external ones.

Referring in particular to emails and mobile phones, he admits that "it is not possible to intercept the external communications... without intercepting internal communications as well".

Ministers will be able to issue interception warrants covering broad categories of information without naming specific addresses or individuals. Individuals or companies would have to hand over a key to their encrypted communications (or supply the plain text) "in the interests of national security", to prevent or detect serious crime, or in the interests of the UK's "economic well-being".

But this is not all. Keys would have to be disclosed if the information was "necessary for the effective performance of any public authority" in carrying out their statutory functions. (The government's original test was even vaguer than that.)

There is more in the RIP bill. While a ministerial warrant would be needed to read the contents of an email or any other form of communication, any "authorised person" will be allowed to intercept communications "data" - that is, the addresses of all emails (or phone calls for that matter) you send or receive.

The bill covers a wide range of intrusive surveillance techniques, including systematic targeting of an individual in order, as the Home Office puts it, "to obtain a picture of his life, activities and his associates". It includes the bugging of private property and cars, and the use of "covert human intelligence sources" - informants or undercover officers.

Ministers will be able to issue orders allowing many other agencies to undertake such covert surveillance. They include the departments of health and social security, and trade and industry, as well as local authorities. Authorisation for these forms of surveillance would be given by senior police officers or even local authority officials.

Concern about the bill was expressed last week by Elizabeth France, the data protection commissioner. "The routine long-term preservation of data by ISPs [internet service providers] for law enforcement purposes would be disproportionate general surveillance of communications," she said in her latest annual report.

As Jonathan Freedland points out in his article today (The text that got away), the misleadingly friendly-sounding regulation of investigatory powers bill (RIP) is one of the more contentious measures even this government's Home Office has managed to produce. This is not just because of its implications for civil liberties. The bill is also opposed by commercial groups because of the cost of setting up black boxes to link internet service providers to MI5. While Tony Blair tries to find the person who hacked into his own communication network, companies are deeply concerned about the implications for their businesses and their privacy from the threat of having to hand over encryption keys or the text of emails. As we all should be. The libertarian Tory MP Richard Shepherd likens it to "giving to the police the keys to the doors to your homes". webTitle: Verdict on Brown's billions from MPs in labour heartlands

fields.headline: Verdict on Brown's billions from MPs in labour heartlands
fields.standfirst: Special report: the comprehensive spending review
fields.trailText:
Peter Kilfoyle, former Labour minister and MP for Liverpool Walton
"Gordon has done the right thing for the economic stability of the country, but the political cycle demands a much shorter term return. This was an excellent CSR for the medium to longer term but the challenge is now going to be how we translate those huge sums into digestible chunks which can be understood and appreciated by the average citizen -- and converted into political capital. The money to schools will mean something real to people but the money on transport and for policing needs to be translated into clear facts such as the number of bobbies on the beat."
fields.body:
Peter Kilfoyle, former Labour minister and MP for Liverpool Walton
"Gordon has done the right thing for the economic stability of the country, but the political cycle demands a much shorter term return. This was an excellent CSR for the medium to longer term but the challenge is now going to be how we translate those huge sums into digestible chunks which can be understood and appreciated by the average citizen -- and converted into political capital. The money to schools will mean something real to people but the money on transport and for policing needs to be translated into clear facts such as the number of bobbies on the beat."

Alice Mahon, MP for Halifax
"There's a bit of Old Labour in this. It's cheered backbenchers like me up. This is a bundle of money that's being spent on things I'm concerned about in my constituency. I'm absolutely delighted about the extra money for schools and the extension of the New Deal on a permament basis - which is especially important for a deprived seat like mine. This is Gordon giving us real substance - although we won't feel completely reassured until the budget when we expect something pretty good on pensions."

Doug Henderson, former minister and MP for Newcastle-upon-Tyne North
"This was a good traditional Labour public expenditure budget. The money going to schools is something that every school in my constituency will see immediately as the kind of public services people voted for in 1997. The additional resources on education and on health in places like Newcastle, where there is greatest need for those improvements, are very welcome. The regional aid budget, the money for housing and the neighbourhood fund are going in the right direction but we're all still concerned about pensions."

Alan Simpson, MP for Nottingham South
"It would be quite wrong to present this as a spending bonanza or an excessive tax and spend budget. This just brings us pretty much to the level the Tories set. It is welcome but it's still catch-up investment and spending, getting us back to the starting line, not getting close to the finishing tape. And it leaves lots of questions still open. It would be crass not to celebrate the 20% increase in public transport but it's difficult to see at this stage where that money's going to go. And while the cash up front for schools is extremely positive - because that's at the sharp end in the places where we're going to be judged - the uncomfortable part is that schools with a disproportionate number of children with special needs or behavioural problems will get the same as those which do not."

Lynne Jones, MP for Birmingham Selly Oak
"I'm relatively happy - certainly with the revenue expenditure - but I feel that the chancellor is giving with one hand and then attaching so many strings with the other that he's making people jump through hoops to get the money. Where I'm a little concerned is over capital investment in things like transport and housing. It's a substantial sum but it still doesn't get us to the levels of past investment. I welcome the government's commitment to public spending, particularly in education, but I think people have become very cynical and they will want to see the text books being delivered to the schools before they trust in this."

webTitle: Gordon Brown speaks. And as they say, money talks

fields.headline: Gordon Brown speaks. And as they say, money talks
fields.standfirst:
Wisely, this time the chancellor let his figures tell their own story
Special report: the comprehensive spending review
fields.trailText: Wisely, this time the chancellor let his figures tell their own story.
fields.body:
Are the chancellor's coffers half full or half empty? That all depends on how you look at it. Optimists who look ahead will find the golden dawn painted out across the sky. Colossal sums are pouring into health and education, into transport and housing. Cascades of coins reach into every crevice, from new nurseries for hard pressed working mothers to the World Service. Year after year for four years ahead, the money rolls out: spend, spend, spend on everything.

Gloomier souls may look at it at first through different spectacles. The teachers, doctors and public service managers who have struggled through the austerity years may see this largesse with a rather more jaundiced eye. It was bought with prudence, it is the fruit of prudence, but for them prudence had been squeezed from their bone marrow in those two years that saw the lowest public spending in 35 years. The word prudence had the same threatening ring as John Major's fearful words, "If it isn't hurting it isn't working". It did hurt. The chancellor himself yesterday spoke of the "damage done by decades of under-investment", but the two worst years were his own, when public spending fell to 38.3% of GDP. (In 1976 it was 49.9% - not a fair analogy but telling nonetheless.)

Mindful of this ambivalence, the chancellor wisely spoke in solemn tones. Beyond the odd epithet flung across to the writhing benches opposite, there was no triumphalism. This is not quite the time for Rejoice! Rejoice! The lesson has been well-learned from the announcement of the last comprehensive spending review in July 1998, which pumped up public expectations that couldn't be delivered. In the midst of the hardest spending years in living memory, people suddenly expected to see signs of miracles everywhere around them. The spending didn't begin until nine months later. Even then, government agencies atrophied by years of cuts were unable to spend it all fast enough. So this time the chancellor spoke few words: he let the figures speak for themselves, which they did eloquently. Less was more.

Again, this money doesn't start until next April, one month before the expected election-day. Hospitals and schools will be spending, but there'll be no magic transformation. No doubt more bad-news figures will continue to trip up the government now and then - crime rising instead of falling, wrestling with the intractable hospital waiting lists and school class sizes. And yet the good signs are all there. Already good auguries abound: if every other programme works as well as the New Deal for the young unemployed, then an array of progressive social triumphs await. The New Deal is the first in a long history of unemployment schemes and projects (YTS, Yops and others) to pay for itself, covering its own costs so far in the numbers taken off benefits and found a job solely through its agency. As a totem, it's a hopeful omen for how well-spent all this money could be.

The mountain still to be climbed was there in last week's official poverty statistics. Some experts doubt anything the government can do will narrow the gap in earnings between richest and poorest, as all across the western world salaries at the top soar away in this boom time. What matters more is whether the government narrows the gap between the bottom and the middle, and they are starting to do that for families with children and for poor pensioners. But to hit the child-poverty abolition target, it will need more and more money from state top-up schemes to be added every year if their real incomes are to increase equally alongside general income rises. It's the most pressing case for a major increase in the minimum wage, pegging it to average earnings. Average incomes have risen 10% since Labour came in: it has taken a huge redistribution of money by the state to make sure the poorest families with children have also seen a rise of between 10% and 12%. Any slackening and many will start to fall back again.

Over there on the benches opposite, trying to look as if they weren't sucking lemons, the Conservatives watched this Midas at work. Which way would they go? Would they trash this as fairy money, spun-gold, not enough to make a difference to the schools and hospitals still looking much the same as ever? It would have been the more convincing route. Out there the public says in every opinion poll that they want more spending and they want results. According to a Mori analysis this week, grumbles about taxes come a very long way behind complaints that after three years, not enough has changed. Far easier in this climate for the Tories and their newspapers to persuade people that these telephone book numbers are all meaningless, it's not enough and most is wasted in bureaucracy and extra social workers.

So the government waited to see which way Portillo would jump. A sigh of satisfaction rippled down the front bench as Portillo opted for the good old position, one which suits both sides of the House so well as they settle back comfortably into their familiar roles. "Tax and spend!" he bellowed, pawing the ground. "Yes!" went the benches opposite, "And proud of it!" Here both sides are happy on their home turf.

At last the Tories are forcing Labour to define itself. Yes it has taxed, and yes it has spent. That is who they are. They have redistributed to the poor and their ambitious targets demand they do much more. Spending well on public services into the far future is what Labour does. Consider 20% more on public transport that will take far longer than this cabinet's political lifetime to show full results. There is a solidity about building trams and railways, a confident assumption that the future will continue to be high spending. Sure Start embodies a vision of a Labour future where babies starting now will mark a new cohort of Labour educational success. The increase in spending on education will be more than double John Major's, 3.8% over the parliament to 2002 compared to his 1.6%. This is now set fair to become the progressive government they have yet to declare themselves wholeheartedly to be.

After a rough summer as chill as the weather, they need to go away and decide who they really are. The Blair memo must mark the lowest ebb of self-doubt, dither and fear, a loss of identity and direction in a tired man in a panic. The Daily Mail is indeed frightening. But the only answer is success. Next year voters will still have to take this government on trust for lack of spectacular public service improvements. That trust can only be built on a clarity of image, a firmness of resolve and a message that abandons the hazy mystifications of the third way. Money talks, and it spoke loudly yesterday, a solid message better far than any words designed to please those who will never be appeased. The dark first two years are now well and truly over. The sun is almost up at last.
