webTitle: Politically and economically, it all adds up

fields.headline: Politically and economically, it all adds up
fields.standfirst: Special report: the comprehensive spending review
fields.trailText: After the famine comes the feast. The message from Gordon Brown yesterday was that the lean years are over and that from now on the government would do what the voters expected them to do 38 months ago: improve Britain's schools, roads, hospitals, inner cities and council estates.
fields.body:
After the famine comes the feast. The message from Gordon Brown yesterday was that the lean years are over and that from now on the government would do what the voters expected them to do 38 months ago: improve Britain's schools, roads, hospitals, inner cities and council estates.

The list of spending pledges went on and on. Just when it seemed that he was running out of presents, Santa Gordon found a little something tucked away in a corner of his sack. Rural post offices, farmers, the BBC world service: no body was forgotten. There were even some new toys for the generals and admirals.

Politically, the strategy behind the second comprehensive spending review stood out in neon letters 20ft high. The chancellor wanted to show those who have drifted out of Tony Blair's big tent that there was a point in voting Labour after all. His cabinet colleagues can now spend the next six months churning out press releases detailing exactly how the extra cash will be spent, while William Hague and Michael Portillo try to explain how and where they are going to trim back Mr Brown's plans to pay for their tax cuts.

The chancellor's aides could barely control their glee last night. "Either you vote Labour because you want public spending to rise for the next three years or you trust the Tories to cut taxes and spending. But we could only get here by doing what we did over the course of this parliament. It's a great moment. It is what it has all been about," they said.

In terms of the economy, there are two potential risks. The first is that the City takes fright at the enormous numbers involved in the three-year plan, believing that they are unaffordable and financially reckless. The second is that the biggest sustained increase in departmental spending since the Tony Barber boom of the early 1970s leads to the economy overheating and thus forces interest rates up.

Mr Brown is not a spend, spend, spend chancellor, and it was clear from the first part of his speech that the plans do add up. The spending curbs and tax increases in the first half of the parliament have meant that the Treasury has plenty of money in the bank, and in fact paid off £18.1bn of debt last year - more than any government since the second world war.

Although the increases for health, education, law and order, and transport sound enormous, what he has done is shift money from one part of government spending to another. Less is being spent on servicing the national debt and less is being spent on unemployment benefits, so more can be spent elsewhere.

One of Mr Brown's more impressive facts yesterday was that for every £1 spent under the Tories, 42p went on rising debt interest and the cost of mass unemployment. Over the next three years, those items will only account for 17p of every extra pound spent.

Moreover, the chancellor has surrounded himself with a thicket of fiscal codes and golden rules that impose binding limits on how much can be spent and borrowed. If the Tories are seeking to portray Mr Brown as a spendthrift, they are almost certain to fail.

Unless, of course, the economy blows up in the chancellor's face. This is possible, but at the moment looks unlikely. Certainly, there were few alarm bells ringing in the City. "It's a dull day for the economists, it's an exciting day for the politicians," said Robert Barrie at Credit Suisse First Boston. "There are some very meaningful increases going into key programmes. But when we look at implications for monetary policy, he's sticking pretty closely to the script he set out at Budget time."

Whether voters will be as easily impressed remains to be seen. In the real world, talk of 5.4% extra for education or a 20% increase in transport mean next to nothing, and ministers will only harvest a political dividend when improvements are felt in terms of fewer train cancellations and better-equipped schools.

The government is already paying a political price for the freeze on spending, and there have been economic costs as well. Net spending on Britain's infrastructure last year was a paltry £2.6bn and the big increases announced yesterday will only make good a small share of the damage caused by the cuts since the mid-1970s.

Labour is now trying to make the best of a bad job. Underspending in previous years means that Mr Brown is in the fortunate position of being able to increase departmental budgets by 6% this year and 5.25% in the following three.

Much of this was lost in Mr Brown's rather manic delivery yesterday. He might have been expected to savour every moment, like a connoisseur sipping a fine wine. Instead, he was more like a man trying to down a couple of swift pints before closing time.

In this respect, he was the polar opposite of Harold Wilson, a dull speaker who taught himself to be funny. Mr Brown, who was witty and funny in the 1980s, has taught himself to be boring. But there is another difference. At this point in Wilson's governments, a chancellor would have been outlining spending cuts, not increases. In the 60s and 70s, the announcement would have been the start of the slippery slope to election defeat. The mood could not have been more different yesterday.

This is possible, but at the moment looks unlikely. Certainly, there were few alarm bells ringing in the City. "It's a dull day for the economists, it's an exciting day for the politicians," said Robert Barrie at Credit Suisse First Boston. "There are some very meaningful increases going into key programmes. But when we look at implications for monetary policy, he's sticking pretty closely to the script he set out at Budget time." Whether voters will be as easily impressed remains to be seen. In the real world, talk of 5.4% extra for education or a 20% increase in transport mean next to nothing, and ministers will only harvest a political dividend when improvements are felt in terms of fewer train cancellations and better-equipped schools. The government is already paying a political price for the freeze on spending, and there have been economic costs as well. Net spending on Britain's infrastructure last year was a paltry £2.6bn and the big increases announced yesterday will only make good a small share of the damage caused by the cuts since the mid-1970s. Labour is now trying to make the best of a bad job. Underspending in previous years means that Mr Brown is in the fortunate position of being able to increase departmental budgets by 6% this year and 5.25% in the following three. Much of this was lost in Mr Brown's rather manic delivery yesterday. He might have been expected to savour every moment, like a connoisseur sipping a fine wine. Instead, he was more like a man trying to down a couple of swift pints before closing time. In this respect, he was the polar opposite of Harold Wilson, a dull speaker who taught himself to be funny. Mr Brown, who was witty and funny in the 1980s, has taught himself to be boring. But there is another difference. At this point in Wilson's governments, a chancellor would have been outlining spending cuts, not increases. In the 60s and 70s, the announcement would have been the start of the slippery slope to election defeat. The mood could not have been more different yesterday. fields.headline: Aid gets biggest boost
fields.standfirst: Special report: the comprehensive spending review
fields.trailText: The Department for International Development emerged yesterday as one of the biggest winners from the chancellor's spending review, receiving its largest ever allocation in real terms.
fields.body:
The Department for International Development emerged yesterday as one of the biggest winners from the chancellor's spending review, receiving its largest ever allocation in real terms.

In return for a 6.2% after inflation increase over the next three years, Clare Short, the international development secretary, has committed her department to speeding up international efforts to tackle extreme poverty and deliver debt relief. "This settlement will enable us to make substantial progress towards meeting key international development targets in relation to health, primary education and provision of other basic services," said Ms Short.

But aid agencies warned that the international debt forgiveness initiative was in danger of running into the sand, threatening Ms Short's chances of meeting her new target of getting all eligible countries through the process by 2004.

George Gelber, head of public policy at the Catholic Agency for Overseas Development, said that unless Tony Blair used the "historic opportunity" of the Okinawa summit to persuade fellow world leaders to deliver more debt relief, "we will remain off target in meeting the goal of halving world poverty by 2015".

The BBC World Service, which is funded by the foreign office, is to be given a real term increase of 3.8% annually to reverse drastic cuts imposed by John Major's government.

The World Service emerges as one of the winners from a foreign office budget that is to be increased overall by 1.9% above the rate of inflation, but lower than growth in the economy.

fields.headline: Paul Hatfield
fields.standfirst: Judge-turned-senator whose crucial vote surrendered the Panama canal, rescued a president and whipped up a political storm
fields.trailText: The Panama canal finally came under full Panamanian control on January 1 this year, but no one seemed to remember the man who made it possible. Judge Paul Hatfield, who has died aged 72, was the central figure in one of President Jimmy Carter's narrowest legislative shaves when, as the new senator for Montana, he voted to ratify the treaty which passed the canal's sovereignty to Panama.
fields.body:
The Panama canal finally came under full Panamanian control on January 1 this year, but no one seemed to remember the man who made it possible. Judge Paul Hatfield, who has died aged 72, was the central figure in one of President Jimmy Carter's narrowest legislative shaves when, as the new senator for Montana, he voted to ratify the treaty which passed the canal's sovereignty to Panama.

Carter came to office in 1977 proclaiming his determination to complete the task that his Democratic predecessor, Lyndon Johnson, had started in 1964, when he said he would abrogate the 1903 Panama canal treaty, negotiate a new pact recognising Panama's sovereignty over the canal zone, and make arrangements to pass ownership of the waterway to the Panamanians.

Johnson's plan made little progress because of the disastrous political climate of the Vietnam war. President Nixon got caught up in the Watergate crisis. Then the treaty revision resurfaced in the 1976 presidential campaign and popular hostility to the idea was revived.

Letters opposing the move poured into Capitol Hill. The result was a Republican amendment to the state department's appropriations bill, then going through the House of Representatives, stipulating that no money could be spent to "negotiate the surrender or relinquishment of any United States rights in the Panama canal zone". Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina tabled a parallel resolution in the Senate demanding that the US "should in no way cede, dilute, forfeit, negotiate or transfer any of rights, power, authority or jurisdiction" over the canal. This attracted 37 signatories and, since all treaties need a two-thirds vote in Senate for ratification, it was plain that any agreement was unlikely to attract the required 67 members.

But the newly elected President Carter forged ahead with negotiations. In September 1977 two related treaties were signed. There was increased uproar, with one of the president's most implacable opponents, the former governor of California, Ronald Reagan, commenting: "The canal is ours. We stole it fair and square."

Having signed the treaty, the Carter administration made a hopeless mess of the campaign to get it ratified. On January 12 1978, Senator Lee Metcalf of Montana died and the state governor exercised his right to appoint a temporary successor, another Democrat, Montana's chief justice Paul Hatfield. Suddenly Judge Hatfield found himself thrust into this extraordinary turmoil.

The only experience he had ever had of anything approaching politics was during the extremely gentlemanly 1960 campaign for his first judicial post. After that he had worked his way steadily up the legal ladder until elected to head Montana's supreme court in 1977. Apart from brief army service in the Korean war, his life had been spent administering the law in one of the country's least-populated states.

Hatfield arrived in Washington to find opponents of the treaty operating at full force, arranging for every senator to receive up to 4,000 denunciatory letters a week. Meanwhile President Carter kept postponing the televised address his staff thought might turn the tide. When he finally gave it in February 1978, it was so poor that the CBS network would only transmit excerpts.

In the face of this disaster, White House researchers found that 35 senators from both parties remained unyielding in their opposition to the treaty and reported that some normally reliable Democrats, particularly those from the west, were wavering because of public hostility in their own states.

With the treaty in increasing jeopardy the spotlight fell remorselessly on the new senator from Montana. Hatfield kept his own counsel throughout the spring of 1978. The crunch came in April when the treaty reached the Senate floor. It looked virtually certain to die until Senator Hatfield - an unelected member who had served just 53 days - cast the 67th vote for ratification. Amid the uproar, he maintained that the decision had been his alone and that no one had got to him. "That's what a judge's life is," he said, "making decisions."

The following evening, when he addressed an ex-servicemen's meeting in his home town, he was booed into silence. He was dubbed "Panama Paul", and a petition was launched to deprive him of his Senate seat, though it was eventually ruled legally invalid. Two months later, in the Democratic primary to select a Senate candidate for the November election, Hatfield attracted less than one-fifth of the vote.

In 1979 President Carter appointed him to the federal bench, where he remained until his death. His role in the Panama canal story is a reminder of how rocky the path of American foreign policy can sometimes be, especially if Hatfield had voted the other way.

Hatfield's wife Dorothy, whom he married in 1958, predeceased him. He is survived by their three children.

 Paul Gerhart Hatfield, lawyer, born April 29 1928; died July 3 2000

webTitle: Knutsford bosses back McGee music venture

fields.headline: Knutsford bosses back McGee music venture
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Alan McGee, the former head of Creation Records, is to float his new internet music venture with the backing of two directors from Knutsford, the high-profile former bidder.
fields.body:
Alan McGee, the former head of Creation Records, is to float his new internet music venture with the backing of two directors from Knutsford, the high-profile former bidder.

Mr. McGee, renowned for discovering the rock band Oasis and turning Creation into one of the UK's leading independent record labels, has appointed financial advisers to co-ordinate the AIM flotation of Poptones Records.

Knutsford directors Michael Edelson, also deputy chairman of Manchester United football club, and Julian Richer, the founder of the Richer Sounds hi-fi chain, will become non-executive directors. Shareholders include Robert Devereaux, the chairman of Virgin Film & Records. News of the float first broke on internet website Sharecast.com.

Mr McGee surprised the music world in November last year by announcing he was leaving Creation to launch his own net label. During his time at the head of Creation, the 39-year-old became one of the most influential people in the UK music industry and an adviser to Tony Blair - although he has since distanced himself from New Labour.

The bands he discovered included the Jesus and Mary Chain, Primal Scream, Super Furry Animals and Oasis.

Poptones Records will sell at traditional stores and via internet retailers. Mr McGee's decision to team up with Mr Richer and Mr Edelson will give him useful access to a wide pool of City investors.

However, it is unclear what support the venture will gain from retail investors who followed the Knutsford story. Shares in the company surged last autumn when Mr Edelson, the company chairman, recruited a team led by Mr Richer to launch a bid on a beleaguered high street retailer.

Knutsford's directors - including the Conservative minister Archie Norman and property entrepreneurs Nigel Wray and Nick Leslau - struggled to close a deal.

Shares fell, and the company reverted to its former role as an American financial information and marketing group.

When he quit Creation Mr McGee said: "The future for me is multimedia; the future is not being one-dimensional and having one record company. It's worked for the last 25 years but it doesn't make sense any more.

"You have to be in lots of different areas to give yourself leverage, if you're not in all these businesses at the same time you're going to be left behind."

fields.headline: Paul Young
fields.standfirst: Singer who made Manchester rock
fields.trailText: Paul Young of Mike and the Mechanics, who has died aged 53, was one of the most accomplished rock singers of his generation.
fields.body:
Paul Young of Mike and the Mechanics, who has died aged 53, was one of the most accomplished rock singers of his generation.

Through his work with the group Sad Café, he made a significant contribution to that Manchester tradition of melodic and witty pop whose leading lights include the Hollies and 10cc, a tradition which has been overshadowed by the more recent "Madchester" scene.

In the mid-60s Young was a member of the Toggery Five, one of the many Manchester beat groups who had a brief chance to achieve success in the wake of local heroes such as the Hollies and Herman's Hermits.

The Toggery Five played in Germany and secured a recording contract with EMI's Parlophone label, but their few singles such as the doom-laden I'm Gonna Jump made little impact.

After the group split up, Young remained on the Manchester music scene and by the mid-70s was the lead singer of a local band, Gyro. In 1976 he and Gyro guitarist Ian Wilson joined forces with members of another Manchester group, Mandala, to form Sad Café.

The new group caught the eye of Manchester music business entrepreneur Harvey Lisberg, who got them a recording contract with the RCA label. Their first album, Fanx Ta Ra, was a showcase for Young's dynamic singing and craftsmanlike songwriting.

The second album was Misplaced Ideals, and in 1979, following its success in America, the group made a 54-concert US tour. This was the group's peak year, as Every Little Hurts, featuring Young's impassioned singing and the group's complex harmonies, became a massive hit in Britain.

Like the hit album Facades, the track was produced by one of the stalwarts of Manchester pop, Eric Stewart of 10cc. Sad Café toured extensively and played three nights at Manchester's Apollo Theatre to capacity audiences, proof that classic rock music retained its appeal even in the heyday of punk, when Manchester was creating the Buzzcocks and the Factory record label.

The next album, La Di Da, was also a commercial success, but in the early 80s the group suffered from changing personnel and a split with their record company. By 1985, Young was almost penniless.

At this low point in his career he was asked to audition for a group being organised by the bass player of Genesis, Mike Rutherford. Mike and the Mechanics was to be a vehicle for Rutherford's songwriting, and Young was one of five singers hired to perform on the group's first album.

By 1988, the year of the multi-million selling The Living Years, only Young and Paul Carrack (formerly of Ace and Squeeze) remained as vocalists. Throughout the next decade, Rutherford, Young and Carrack were the nucleus of Mike and the Mechanics, recording four more albums and making several international tours.

According to Rutherford's songwriting partner, Chris Neil, the two Pauls were perfect foils for each other. "It's like beauty and the beast: we've got the rocker [Young] and the guy with the lovely R'n'B voice [Carrack]."

While working with Rutherford and Carrack, Young also retained his affiliation with the Sad Café era by recording, with Ian Wilson, in the 80s, two albums as Sad Café and by the inclusion of Every Little Hurts alongside Carrack's big hit How Long and the Genesis favourite You Can't Dance.

This medley became a highlight of Mike and the Mechanics concerts. The group was scheduled to perform in Europe later this summer, but Young collapsed at home in Altrincham with a suspected heart attack.

He is survived by his wife Pat and three children.

 Paul Young, singer and songwriter, born June 17 1947; died July 16 2000

fields.headline: Edward Bernds
fields.standfirst: The Three Stooges' favourite director, he also made enjoyably awful drive-in movies
fields.trailText: There have been no structuralist studies on the Three Stooges, nor retrospectives at the National Film Theatre, nor film festivals showing the work of the knockabout clowns' favourite director, Edward Bernds, who has died aged 94.
fields.body:
There have been no structuralist studies on the Three Stooges, nor retrospectives at the National Film Theatre, nor film festivals showing the work of the knockabout clowns' favourite director, Edward Bernds, who has died aged 94.

Since the essence of their low comedy, a crude relic of silent screen slapstick, consisted of eye-poking, nose-pinching, shin-kicking and head-walloping, it is hardly surprising.

Bernds directed 25 of the Stooges films in the longest running series of two-reel comedies in cinema, allowing Moe, Larry and Curly (or Shep) to do their "shtick" unimpeded. Unlike other comedians, they never sought to be lovable, being content to be three unprepossessing, unruly morons.

In fact, Bernds and his charges had their admirers among rational adults - from Jean Renoir to the Coen Brothers. But Bernds' oeuvre stretches wider, if not deeper, than the Three Stooges, and he could lay claim, more than most, to the title of "King of the Bs", with myriad followers of his dirt-cheap movies, the majority of which were made for Allied Artists.

It was for that poverty row studio that he directed two camp sci-fi classics, World Without End (1956) and Queen of Outer Space (1958). In these he recycled sets and leftover spacesuits from other films, but was allowed CinemaScope and DeLuxe Color.

In the former, astronauts find themselves in a time warp on 21st century Earth (post-nuclear war), battling a phoney giant spider, mutant cavemen and people in tights and tunics. In the latter, Zsa Zsa Gabor, in a slit skirt, is a rebel Venusian who falls in love with four earthmen whom her man-hating queen wants to destroy.

Aside from his directorial work Bernds (pronounced Burns) was also one of the pioneers of sound. A radio operator in Chicago, he was brought out to Hollywood by United Artists to help with the transition to talking pictures. He first worked on The Iron Mask (1929), a silent film to which was added a speech at the begin ning and end delivered by Douglas Fairbanks, the film's star.

After moving to Columbia Pictures, Bernds became Frank Capra's regular sound mixer, working on all but one of his films from 1930 to 1939, including It Happened One Night (1934), Mr Deeds Goes to Town (1936), and Mr Smith Goes to Washington (1939).

At the same time, he was writing for Three Stooges two-reelers. It was 1944 when he took over direction. Bernds' first features were the last five of the long-running Blondie series, based on Chic Young's popular cartoon strip. However, by the time he took over, the once delightful series, starring Penny Singleton and Arthur Lake as Blondie and Dagwood Bumstead, had run out of ideas, ending with Beware of Blondie (1950).

Bernds then directed two features derived from another comic strip, Gasoline Alley and Corky of Gasoline Alley (both 1951), about a young couple who run a diner, before moving on to the Bowery Boys series, seven years after it had started.

Among the eight formulaic kids' Saturday matinee pictures between 1953 and 1956, featuring the ageing juvenile delinquents, Bernds was responsible for Loose in London, in which tall and gormless Sach Jones (Huntz Hall) is thought to be related to a dying British earl; Clipped Wings, where Sach and pug-nosed little punk Slip Mahoney (Leo Gorcey) join the air force; The Bowery Boys Meet the Monsters, wherein Sach turns into a werewolf; and Bowery to Bagdad, with the lads spirited to Iraq by genie Eric Blore.

Bernds was also involved in other enjoyably bad drive-in fodder movies: Reform School Girl (1957) - baby-doll pyjamas and an idealistic shrink; Space Master X-7 (1958) - an alien fungus called "blood rust" brought back by astronauts from space; High School Hellcats (1959) - girl gets into bad company at tough reform school. He was also entrusted with Return of the Fly (1959), a competent sequel in which the son of the Fly follows in his father's droppings.

Ignoring the fact that the Three Stooges style of burlesque was more suited to a short film sketch than the cheapie feature, Bernds embarked on The Three Stooges Meet Hercules (1962), in which a time machine transports the trio to ancient Greece, where they wear togas with modern shoes and socks, and The Three Stooges in Orbit (1962), with Martians resembling Frankenstein monsters.

The affable Bernds retired in 1965, and in recent years appeared in the television documentaries Buster Keaton: A Hard Act to Follow and Frank Capra's American Dream.

He is survived by a son, two grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.

 Edward Bernds, film director, born July 12 1905; died May 20 2000

He first worked on The Iron Mask (1929), a silent film to which was added a speech at the begin ning and end delivered by Douglas Fairbanks, the film's star. After moving to Columbia Pictures, Bernds became Frank Capra's regular sound mixer, working on all but one of his films from 1930 to 1939, including It Happened One Night (1934), Mr Deeds Goes to Town (1936), and Mr Smith Goes to Washington (1939). At the same time, he was writing for Three Stooges two-reelers. It was 1944 when he took over direction. Bernds' first features were the last five of the long-running Blondie series, based on Chic Young's popular cartoon strip. However, by the time he took over, the once delightful series, starring Penny Singleton and Arthur Lake as Blondie and Dagwood Bumstead, had run out of ideas, ending with Beware of Blondie (1950). Bernds then directed two features derived from another comic strip, Gasoline Alley and Corky of Gasoline Alley (both 1951), about a young couple who run a diner, before moving on to the Bowery Boys series, seven years after it had started. Among the eight formulaic kids' Saturday matinee pictures between 1953 and 1956, featuring the ageing juvenile delinquents, Bernds was responsible for Loose in London, in which tall and gormless Sach Jones (Huntz Hall) is thought to be related to a dying British earl; Clipped Wings, where Sach and pug-nosed little punk Slip Mahoney (Leo Gorcey) join the air force; The Bowery Boys Meet the Monsters, wherein Sach turns into a werewolf; and Bowery to Bagdad, with the lads spirited to Iraq by genie Eric Blore. Bernds was also involved in other enjoyably bad drive-in fodder movies: Reform School Girl (1957) - baby-doll pyjamas and an idealistic shrink; Space Master X-7 (1958) - an alien fungus called "blood rust" brought back by astronauts from space; High School Hellcats (1959) - girl gets into bad company at tough reform school. He was also entrusted with Return of the Fly (1959), a competent sequel in which the son of the Fly follows in his father's droppings. Ignoring the fact that the Three Stooges style of burlesque was more suited to a short film sketch than the cheapie feature, Bernds embarked on The Three Stooges Meet Hercules (1962), in which a time machine transports the trio to ancient Greece, where they wear togas with modern shoes and socks, and The Three Stooges in Orbit (1962), with Martians resembling Frankenstein monsters. The affable Bernds retired in 1965, and in recent years appeared in the television documentaries Buster Keaton: A Hard Act to Follow and Frank Capra's American Dream. He is survived by a son, two grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.  Edward Bernds, film director, born July 12 1905; died May 20 2000

fields.headline: Excite Chello to span continents
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Netherlands-based broadband internet business Chello yesterday announced $5bn (£3bn) plans to merge with the international operations of American web portal ExciteAtHome to form a business which will span four continents.
fields.body:
Netherlands-based broadband internet business Chello yesterday announced $5bn (£3bn) plans to merge with the international operations of American web portal ExciteAtHome to form a business which will span four continents.

The companies claimed the agreement would see the formation of the largest cable-based internet service provider outside the US, drawing together distribution and content. The company, Excite Chello, will be floated in Amsterdam and on the Nasdaq in the US either later this year or early next.

The deal ends months of uncertainty over the future of Chello which abandoned a planned flotation in May after behind the scenes talks with Excite.

The combined business will be jointly owned by Chello's parent company, cable firm United Pan-Europe Communications, and Excite in the US.

George Bell, chairman and chief executive of Excite, said the combined operation would have 300,000 broadband subscribers in Europe, Asia, Australia and Latin America. With the roll-out of digital set-top boxes, web services will be blended into mainstream broadcasting.

Mr Bell said: "This deal creates global scale in the internet's most dynamic growth area - broadband. We have watched Chello broadband's growth and success in Europe and believe that the combination of assets in our new venture cannot be easily replicated."

Chello has the exclusive rights to deliver broadband internet services to over 30m homes including customers of UPC, Europe's second largest cable company.

Geographic holes in countries including Britain and Brazil would be plugged by agreeing deals with local cable companies, Mr Bell added. Excite in Britain has a joint venture with British Telecom. There was speculation earlier this year that Chello was close to agreeing a deal with Telewest.

John Malone's AT&T Liberty Media which has a controlling stake in UPC's parent UnitedGlobalCom will invest €200m (£120m) into the business. Mr Malone was a pioneer of the cable industry in the US and is becoming an increasingly powerful global presence. Liberty also has a 25% holding in Telewest which is expected to be folded into UPC. Mr Malone will join the board of Excite Chello which will be run by Roger Lynch, president and chief executive of Chello.

Mr Malone said: "We are delighted to have the opportunity to invest in a company that we believe will be the international leader in the burgeoning broadband market. This strategic investment complements our other broadband and media interests and further strengthens our already close relationship with the United Group."

Cable as a distribution method gives access to higher broadband services than rivals rushing to distribute over ADSL - the technology that upgrades copper telephone wires for broadband use.

The company said yesterday, however, that it would pursue a strategy of developing broadband services across delivery platforms including ADSL, wireless and satellite as well as cable. It aims to target both consumers and business customers and will place strong emphasis on the development of new content.

Chello's existing broadband service is available in countries including Austria, Norway, Sweden and Australia.

fields.headline: At this price?  M&S
fields.trailText: Hopes of a significant revival in the share performance of Marks & Spencer are expected to be dashed today when new chairman Luc Vandevelde tells the annual shareholders' meeting that the vital clothes side is struggling to grow.
fields.body:
Hopes of a significant revival in the share performance of Marks & Spencer are expected to be dashed today when new chairman Luc Vandevelde tells the annual shareholders' meeting that the vital clothes side is struggling to grow.

This bit of news will not be highlighted, of course. It will be hidden among a barrage of positive spin surrounding an upturn in food sales and new plans to upgrade stores and increase customer choice.

But top analysts expect like for like sales of clothes to be down, in another setback to the M&S recovery story. Investors are already wary of the stock except as a long-term play.

Shares in M&S were down 0.5p at 235.75p last night, pitifully close to their 52-week low and a long shopping aisle away from the 650p mark they hit in 1997, when pre-tax profits reached £1.1bn.

If, as expected, the sales figures are poor, the more optimistic pre-tax profit estimates from the City are likely to be cut from the £600m level closer to £550m.

The sense of failure to shift shirts and skirts can only be enhanced by the performance of rival Debenhams. Yesterday it announced a 6.6% growth in clothing.

The chance of a major turnaround in clothing sales at M&S later this year also appears unlikely, given the poor reception from the fashion press to the group's autumn collection.

The best performance is likely to be in food sales - which should be up by around 3.5%. Shares in the company are still on a forward multiple of 19 or 20 times earnings; by contrast, Boots - a firm in not such a bad shape - commands almost half this figure.

The interest in a takeover, encouraged by entrepreneur Philip Green's manoeuvres earlier this year, has partly underpinned the M&S stock price at its present level.

But if you want an investment without holes in it, buy another pair of M&S socks, not its shares.

Terry Macalister

fields.headline: C&W spends £100m on web growth
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Cable & Wireless yesterday staked its claim to being the third largest provider of internet services to the burgeoning European business-to-business sector after it spent £100m buying up web companies.
fields.body:
Cable & Wireless yesterday staked its claim to being the third largest provider of internet services to the burgeoning European business-to-business sector after it spent £100m buying up web companies.

C&W bought five internet-related businesses in Europe where it has been aggressively building a portfolio of companies that provide services including web hosting and design, network integration, e-commerce and the delivery of application services where businesses can rent software over the net.

In 18 months C&W has spent £650m transforming itself from a traditional telecoms operator, that derived most of its revenue from voice traffic, to an organisation that is increasing its investment in data and internet protocol services. Internet protocal is the language that allows computers to share resources across a network.

In that time it has bought 21 internet companies, including yesterday's acquisitions of two internet service providers in France and Germany, two "network integrators" in Holland and Spain, and a web hosting company in Holland. They are expected to add $40m (£24m) annually to C&W's revenues and a further 30,000 customers including blue chip clients such as Microsoft, Compaq, Virgin and Warner Bros.

Mike McTighe, chief executive of C&W's global operations, said yesterday's purchases would be the last big internet acquisitions as the company now had the flexible staff base and geographical coverage to serve its business customers.

"I would say we are number three in the business-to-business environment in continental Europe," said Mr McTighe, ranking C&W behind UUNet and PSINetinternet. European business was slightly ahead of plan but the group was only three months into the new financial year.

C&W will co-brand the companies it acquires for the first 12 months, after which they adopt the name of the London-based company. It has internet operations in Britain, Germany, Holland, Spain, Sweden, Italy, Switzerland, France, Austria and Belgium.

In 2000, 40% of the group's revenues were sourced from data and internet protocol services and the remainder from voice.

C&W has said it will spend $3.5bn by 2001 boosting its network coverage as well as its customer and traffic acquisition.

The company last week opened one of Europe's largest web hosting facilities in Swindon and has recently completed a partnership with Nokia to deliver an internet platform for mobile phones.

fields.headline: Argonaut still in game
fields.trailText: Shares in Argonaut Games, the computer games designer, mounted a spirited recovery yesterday, rising 8p to 42.5p after an upbeat note from Beeson Gregory analyst Julian Morse.
fields.body:
Shares in Argonaut Games, the computer games designer, mounted a spirited recovery yesterday, rising 8p to 42.5p after an upbeat note from Beeson Gregory analyst Julian Morse.

He believes recent bad news from the company - profit forecasts for 2000 have been reduced after the decision to defer development of the Malice title for Microsoft's X-box - is more than discounted in the present share price.

Argonaut, which came to the market at 96p in March, hit a low of 34p on Friday.

With £16.5m of cash on its balance sheet, Mr Morse reckons Argonaut is undervalued and a strong buying opportunity exists.

The long-term outlook for the computer games market is still healthy - next generation consoles are expected to generate higher software sales than were seen at the peak of PlayStation cycle - and Mr Morse expects a strong recovery.

fields.headline: Buoyant Apple boosted by iMac
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Apple Computer was last night expected to continue its remarkable turnaround with a jump in profits on the back of the successful iMac desktop computer.
fields.body:
Apple Computer was last night expected to continue its remarkable turnaround with a jump in profits on the back of the successful iMac desktop computer.

Its rival Microsoft was likely to strike a sombre note, analysts said, with earnings growth from its main desktop software knocked by a recent slowdown in PC sales.

Apple, headed by Steve Jobs, was due to announce third quarter earnings ahead of its annual MacWorld exhibition in New York today. Wall Street analysts expected the company, which introduced its sorbet-coloured range of iMac computers a year ago, to introduce a new version.

Among improvements suggested by observers were a faster G3 processor or chip or a more conventional mouse instead of its round one.

Analysts expected the company to report a 26% increase in third-quarter earnings at 44 cents a share yesterday in spite of a seasonal slowdown.

Some doubts have remained about Apple. In a note to clients, Andrew Neff, analyst at Bear Stearns, wrote: "Investors do not accord it the valuation it deserves because - in our mind - Apple is still viewed by many as a reformed alcoholic - just one step away from the gutter."

Microsoft was due to reveal a slower rate of earnings growth yesterday. Overall revenues were expected to grow 1 per cent to $5.8bn, compared with $5.4bn last year.

fields.headline: ARM does better than ever
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: ARM Holdings' steep growth showed little sign of levelling off yesterday after the microchip designer reported better than expected pre-tax profits and firm margins.
fields.body:
ARM Holdings' steep growth showed little sign of levelling off yesterday after the microchip designer reported better than expected pre-tax profits and firm margins.

The Cambridge firm, which designs the chips that control around two-thirds of the world's mobile phones, topped analysts' forecasts by reporting a pre-tax profit of £8.3m and robust margins of 32%.

The City had been expecting pre-tax profits of £5.4m to £8m, and a slight dip in margin levels to reflect an increased investment in research, development and people costs.

Shares in ARM climbed initially but in response to events in the Nasdaq closed down 7.5p at 782.5p, valuing the eight-year-old firm at £8bn.

Chief executive Robin Saxby warned, however, that margins were likely to fall as ARM intends to spend more on staff recruitment and developing new technologies.

"We have around 520 staff now and expect to take that number past 600 by the end of the year," he said.

Some analysts had expected the number of units ARM shipped to fall off during the quarter, but Mr Saxby said the company's expansion into areas other than mobile telephones had added 10m to shipment numbers.

Analysts said they were pleased to see evidence that ARM is moving into new areas and reducing its reliance on mobile phones.

fields.headline: National Express buys Prism for £166m
fields.trailText: National Express yesterday became Britain's largest geographical train operator, with franchises stretching from Scotland to Wales, with an agreed £166m deal to buy out Prism Rail.
fields.body:
National Express yesterday became Britain's largest geographical train operator, with franchises stretching from Scotland to Wales, with an agreed £166m deal to buy out Prism Rail.

The deal, which has been recommended to Prism shareholders, gives National Express control of nine of the 25 rail franchises. The move reflects the growing dominance of a handful of train operators, led by National Express, Virgin, Stagecoach and Connex.

One of the biggest winners will be Prism's founder and chief executive Giles Fearnley, who make £6m, and the former chairman Godfrey Burley, who will also take home £6m. Eight other founding shareholders will make a further £13m.

National Express already owns five franchises: ScotRail, Midland Mainline, the fast-link between London and Leeds; Gatwick Express; Central Trains, based in Birmingham and Silverlink, which connects north London to the southern suburbs. To these, the company can now add most of the sprawling Welsh routes - comprising Wales and West and Cardiff Railways - as well as the London commuter routes run by London, Tilbury and Southend and the west Anglia section of its WAGN franchise, covering most of Norfolk, Suffolk and parts of Essex.

Phil White, National Express's chief executive, said: "This will give us a 20% market share of the business. It gives us the opportunity to enhance our position in the growing London and south east market."

Mr White said National Express would look hard to bolster leisure travel into London - a tactic which improved ticket sales at Midland Mainline.

Giles Fearnley, Prism's chief executive, claimed the deal "recognises the strength that we have built up since privatisation".

Prism said that the deal, which equates to 615p a share, would give the combined group sufficient financial resources to participate in the current refranchising process.

Under the deal - and with the regulator's approval - National Express will run the loss-making Wales and West and Cardiff Railway franchises until next March.

It has also promised to manage them for a further six months during the shadow strategic rail authority's refranchising.

National Express has made the move because it has benefited from a 30% increase in passenger volumes in the past five years, and is likely to benefit from a further 50% increase in the next decade.

The acquisition of Prism will enable National Express to enhance its portfolio by adding two long-distance commuter routes into London.

fields.headline: Whelan builds up stake in Hi-Tec shoe firm
fields.trailText: JJB Sports chairman Dave Whelan has quietly built a personal 3% stake in Hi-Tec Sports, the struggling sports shoe manufacturer that is examining the possibility of a £16m management buy-out.
fields.body:
JJB Sports chairman Dave Whelan has quietly built a personal 3% stake in Hi-Tec Sports, the struggling sports shoe manufacturer that is examining the possibility of a £16m management buy-out.

Hi-Tec said on March 8 that its management team was considering a 30p per share bid to take the company private, but has not updated the market since then.

Last week Hi-Tec made six separate disclosures to the stock exchange under the City code on takeovers and mergers relating to share purchases made by Mr Whelan since May 16.

Takeover Panel rules stipulate that persons dealing within an offer period usually have until noon the following day to declare whether they have bought or sold any shares, although disclosures are sometimes delayed if the investor is building or disposing of a substantial holding over several days of dealings.

The disclosures say Mr Whelan has been buying Hi-Tec shares at around 26p each.

Last night Mr Whelan was not returning phone calls. However, a source close to him blamed "an administrative cock-up" for the failure to notify the market. Neither Hi-Tec nor JJB Sports would comment.

Hi-Tec shares have fallen from 48p in summer 1998 to around 26p today due to changing tastes in the sportswear market and a lower contribution from its US division.

Mr Whelan is one of Lancashire's best-known and most successful entrepreneurs. A former Blackburn Rovers player, he has turned JJB Sports into a leading sportsware chains. Hi-Tec is one of its suppliers.

Last month Mr Whelan said he was selling up to 4.5m JJB shares, raising some £23m to help fund Wigan's new JJB stadium.

The disclosures say Mr Whelan has been buying Hi-Tec shares at around 26p each. Last night Mr Whelan was not returning phone calls. However, a source close to him blamed "an administrative cock-up" for the failure to notify the market. Neither Hi-Tec nor JJB Sports would comment. Hi-Tec shares have fallen from 48p in summer 1998 to around 26p today due to changing tastes in the sportswear market and a lower contribution from its US division. Mr Whelan is one of Lancashire's best-known and most successful entrepreneurs. A former Blackburn Rovers player, he has turned JJB Sports into a leading sportsware chains. Hi-Tec is one of its suppliers. Last month Mr Whelan said he was selling up to 4.5m JJB shares, raising some £23m to help fund Wigan's new JJB stadium.

webTitle: Foolish farce of Baan's fancy figures

fields.headline: Foolish farce of Baan's fancy figures
fields.standfirst: Wacky world of Dutch commerce
fields.trailText: BaanFans.com is one of those corporate website home pages which has not been updated of late. The initial reaction is to check the browser address: this is the Baan that "has become one of the world's biggest software groups and expects to remain on a fast growth track for the foreseeable future" and whose share price had risen tenfold since the May 1995 flotation in recognition of earnings and revenue that just about double every 12 months. Or at least it was until last year.
fields.body:
BaanFans.com is one of those corporate website home pages which has not been updated of late. The initial reaction is to check the browser address: this is the Baan that "has become one of the world's biggest software groups and expects to remain on a fast growth track for the foreseeable future" and whose share price had risen tenfold since the May 1995 flotation in recognition of earnings and revenue that just about double every 12 months. Or at least it was until last year.

Of course, the figures coming out of this Dutch software house, selling its manufacturing software to 4,000 clients, were partly fiction. Its recent history, bouncing between threatened receivership and quasi-competing takeovers, has been pure farce.

Yesterday Baan said losses of $289m (£200m) for 1999 reported in February should have read $311m, while net revenue was $619m rather than $635m. Now it is openly declaring if the $713m bid on the table from Britain's Invensys - the reinvented BTR Siebe - fails to go ahead, Baan's ability to continue as a going concern will be in doubt.

Such a desperate statement has been forced by the extraordinary action of ING, the Dutch banking group, which owns just under 6% of Baan and which has indicated that it will not accept the Invensys offer. In the wacky world of Dutch commerce, with some 4,000 jobs at risk, ING stands to gain $100m in tax deductions if Baan goes bankrupt against just $40m if it sells to Invensys. There have also been reports of another bid led by Ernst Sonneveldt, a Dutch financier claiming to represent "several captains of industry" who wants to fund a rescue through a big rights issue.

All this has been good for 20% off the Invensys price in past months, which says that the market is not sure whether chief executive Allen Yurko knows how costly this continental foray might prove. He might talk to financial chief Kathleen O'Donovan about how Sir Owen Green from BTR's heroic days or even Sir Barrie Stephens of Siebe might have responded. The betting is they would have canned the existing offer, and then rebid at a 20% discount.

Sweets to come
British Biotech may have famously struggled to come up with any useful drugs but it did manage to produce something sweet for its directors to chew on yesterday.

The struggling Oxford-based company, which has just finished slashing 40% of its workforce, has announced a set of mammoth share option packages which could turn all its executive directors into millionaires within two years.

Chief executive Elliot Goldstein is the biggest winner; if the shares reach 90p by July 2002 he can buy 1.75m at 5p. This would give him a potential profit of £1.5m, while all three of the other executive directors stand to make £1m.

The shares closed yesterday at 22.5p, so there is a long way to go before any dream holidays can be planned. However, the target is not quite as difficult as it sounds - there is a general consensus among analysts that British Biotech's market value is far too low, depressed by the business's past notoriety.

With cash in the bank of £76m, British Biotech is valued at £150m. This underestimates a development pipeline which includes some highly promising antibiotics and a lung cancer treatment which has eradicated tumours in mice during clinical trials.

Among British Biotech's peers in the sector, Cambridge Antibody Technology has drugs at similar stages, yet is worth more than £1bn.

As time goes by British Biotech should manage to escape its troubled past. Dr Goldstein and his colleagues look set to be extremely well-rewarded for being in the right place at the right time.

Ofex prudence
Few people seem to care about a statement issued at the end of last week by Ofex, the unregulated trading facility run by the stock broker JP Jenkins.

"In line with prudent practice," dealings in six Ofex companies have been suspended after a Midlands-based firm of corporate advisers called Griffith & Lamb were served with an intervention order by the Financial Services Authority, the City watchdog, halting its business. The companies affected are: Environmental Polymers, Henderson Morley, Legends Surf Shops, Monticello, Procomm Group, Sythetic Dimensions, Talbex and Viatrade.

Without delving into the business practices pursed by Griffin & Lamb, the case affords an opportunity to warn that while Ofex probably sports many fine companies, investors really do risk losing all their money in a very short period of time if they play this particular equity casino.

The examples are endless - and to date, the City's regulators have treated it as a problem outside their bureaucratic boundaries. But it is a policy which should be reviewed.

webTitle: 1,600 steel jobs to go in Wales as Corus cuts again

fields.headline: 1,600 steel jobs to go in Wales as Corus cuts again
fields.trailText: Corus, the Anglo-Dutch steelmaker, is to cut 1,600 jobs in south Wales, bringing the latest round of redundancies to more than 4,000. The British workforce will fall to 27,500, a tenth of the number 30 years ago.
fields.body:
Corus, the Anglo-Dutch steelmaker, is to cut 1,600 jobs in south Wales, bringing the latest round of redundancies to more than 4,000. The British workforce will fall to 27,500, a tenth of the number 30 years ago.

The bulk of the job losses are at Llanwern, the strip plant near Newport, and Ebbw Vale, which supplies products for the car industry, with a small number to go at Port Talbot, the other integrated plant.

Corus, created last year by the merger of British Steel and Hoogovens, employs more than 6,000 in south Wales, but industry sources confirmed that none of the Welsh plants faces closure in the present phase of cost-cutting.

Details of the job losses, primarily due to the strength of the pound despite its recent fall, are to be given to union officials and politicians in Wales tomorrow and formally announced on Friday.

They come on top of the 2,600 announced in south Yorkshire, Scunthorpe and Teesside and effectively bring to an end the manpower review initiated by Sir Brian Moffat, now Corus chairman, to offset a 40% revaluation of sterling three years ago. Corus/British Steel had shed 6,500 jobs before the latest round of redundancies.

Industry and City sources warned that capacity closure may become inevitable if the pound remains close to its present value against the euro. Llanwern, heavily dependent on the fortunes of the ailing car industry, is the most vulnerable to closure, the sources confirmed, acknowledging the political row that might ensue.

Declining British car output and the overall malaise in manufacturing allied to political uncertainty about joining the euro could prompt Corus to transfer output to Holland - or Poland.

Union sources condemned Friday's announcement in advance, with Sir Ken Jackson of the AEEU comparing it with BMW's airing of its plans for Rover through the media.

"The workforce deserve better than this," he said. "Corus has chosen the wrong option and investment is the only way forward. If the pound falls in value they will have lost a large part of their skilled workforce in the UK and they will never come back again."

Sir Ken contrasted Britain with the German industry's soaring output, up 17% so far this year spurred by a weak euro and heavy investment.

webTitle: NatMags buys up British interests of Gruner & Jahr

fields.headline: NatMags buys up British interests of Gruner & Jahr
fields.standfirst: Prima and Best to join stable of up-market glossies
fields.trailText: Editors at the upmarket National Magazine Company were left choking on their rocket leaves yesterday when the publisher swooped on the owner of popular women's titles including Prima and Best.
fields.body:
Editors at the upmarket National Magazine Company were left choking on their rocket leaves yesterday when the publisher swooped on the owner of popular women's titles including Prima and Best.

NatMags is buying the British publishing assets of Gruner & Jahr, the German group which arrived in this country in the mid-80s. Its other titles include Your Home, Prima Baby and Focus, a science and technology monthly .

Soho-based NatMags saw off a rival bid from IPC, the consumer magazine group which came close to finalising a deal last week.

The titles join a NatMags stable which includes Country Living, Harpers & Queen, Esquire and Cosmopolitan. The group, owned by Hearst, will publish its first weekly magazine through the acquisition of Best.

Duncan Edwards, NatMags' deputy managing director, said: "We've bought a very succesful publishing group with high volume products. This is a strategic entry into a mass market."

Holger Wiemann, managing director of Gruner & Jahr, said the company was withdrawing from Britain with some regret but had decided to focus resources on markets including France and the US where it had met with more success.

The publisher, which is 75% owned by Bertelsmann and 25% by the Jahr family in Hamburg, made a much-trumpeted entry into the British market in 1986 with the launch of Prima. The title today sells 413,000 copies, while Best shifts 462,000.

Growth and new launches both stalled in the 1980s and the sale of the British business has been expected.

Content from the magazines will help to underpin NatMags' recently announced plans to launch an internet business aimed at the women's market - uk.women.com. Mr Edwards said that the potential upside for the website of the acquisition was an "added bonus".

The business was bought for an undisclosed sum.

William Randolph Hearst, the legendary US media magnate, established NatMags in London in 1910. The company launched Good Housekeeping in 1922, She in 1955 and Harpers & Queen in 1963. Its most recent launch was Zest in 1994.

The loss will prove a disappointment to IPC which has struggled to improve its performance in the past couple of years.

webTitle: Family control remains intact at Young & Co, the south London brewer

fields.headline: Now hear this
fields.standfirst: Young tries megaphone diplomacy on Guinness Peat
fields.trailText: Family control remains intact at Young & Co, the south London brewer, after chairman John Young routed New Zealand-based corporate raider Guinness Peat yesterday.
fields.body:
Family control remains intact at Young & Co, the south London brewer, after chairman John Young routed New Zealand-based corporate raider Guinness Peat yesterday.

Using a megaphone to reinforce his message Mr Young, 78, said he was fed up with Guinness Peat's regular attacks at the company's annual general meetings: "I don't know what to do - I've tried using microphones, I'll try using a megaphone.

"For the third year running, some shareholders don't seem to be able to hear what the majority are saying and voting."

Guinness Peat, which has a 10% stake in Young & Co, wants changes to the share holding structure to loosen the Young family's grip on the business. It claims there is a lack of "dynamism" on the board, which restricts the chances of growth.

Youngs' shares have dropped from 600p at the beginning of the year to 425p. Guiness Peat feels the company needs to expand. Its ideas for change won overwhelming support from institutional investors: 79% of "A" shareholders voted for an end to family control. The Young family, however, used its hoard of "B" shares to block changes, and Mr Young won overwhelming support from the 300 private shareholders at the meeting.

One investor said Guinness Peat should "take its money and run back to the land of the amber nectar".

Many at the meeting in Wandsworth Town Hall, were keen to preserve company tradition. One said: "It must be evident that most shareholders don't want and don't support Guinness Peat's annual moves. We want to maintain continuity and to be able to drink real beer."

Guinness Peat's UK director, Blake Nixon, said after the meeting: "Their indifference to legitimate questions was pretty appalling. If this company was fully democratic, the board would be voted out the next day."

Clashes between Mr Nixon and Mr Young have become annual events. In previous years, Mr Young has come armed with a shield, boxing gloves, a muzzle and a beekeeper's hat.

fields.headline: Williams counts cost of divorce
fields.trailText: Williams, the security and fire protection group, yesterday saw some of the gloss wiped off its plan to unlock shareholder value by splitting itself into two businesses.
fields.body:
Williams, the security and fire protection group, yesterday saw some of the gloss wiped off its plan to unlock shareholder value by splitting itself into two businesses.

The market welcomed the plan when it was announced in March, but yesterday wiped millions of pounds off the group's market value when the cost was revealed.

The company said it would make an £80m one-off charge to cover demerger costs, and added that margins at its Chubb and Kidde businesses would fall by 1% this year as a result of the allocation of additional operating costs.

Williams' shares, which rose after the demerger plan was announced, fell 15.4% yesterday before recovering slightly to close 53p down at 344p. The downturn cut the group's value by £386m to £2.5bn.

Analysts said the companies could not recover the lost margins by next year. "There will be some downgrades coming through," said one.

They interpreted the margins warning as a sign that the two companies would concentrate on reinvestment and acquisitions rather than follow Williams' high-dividend policy.

The group said yesterday that Chubb's sales had risen by 12% and Kidde by 13% during the first half of the year and that prospects for the second half were good.

As part of the demerger plan, Williams has sold the Yale locks business to Sweden's Assa Abloy for £825m in cash and shares. The share stake in the Swedish company will be owned by Chubb.

The group has sold its north American paint business and its Masterchem Industries subsidiary for nearly £300m.

Sir Nigel Rudd, Williams' chairman, is to become chairman of Kidde, with Michael Harper, managing director of the fire protection products business, as chief executive.

Roger Carr, Williams' chief executive, is to become non-executive chairman of Chubb, with Robert Gasparini, managing director of the group's global systems and services operation, as chief executive.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: City news in brief
fields.body:
Nationwide is next target

Stephen Major, the Northern Ireland plumber who started the windfall ball rolling at Bradford & Bingley, is turning to the Nationwide, the largest remaining mutual home loan organisation. He is to seek 500 like-minded Nationwide members to call a special meeting and put down a resolution at next year's annual meeting.

The Nationwide's anti-carpetbagger defences include a rule that windfalls gained by those joining after November 1997 must be given to charity. The society won a three-year respite from demutualisation following an unsuccessful 1998 move.

Hyder looks at a break-up

Hyder, the Welsh multi-utility, yesterday further muddied the waters surrounding its future by saying it was re-examining the option of break-up as an alternative to two competing bids. It told shareholders that it could reactivate plans to sell its electricity distribution business (Swalec) and transfer its water operation (Dwr Cymru) to alternative ownership. The group is being courted by Nomura with a £403m bid and Western Power with a £464m offer that is still to be cleared by regulators.

FSA legislation timetable

The government announced its timetable to complete legislation and other preparations for implementing the Financial Services and Markets Act within "about a year". The government said by next week it will introduce a revised code of market conduct which will include detailed material about the financial services authority's powers in relation to market abuse. By late summer the body's authorisation, supervision and enforcement manuals will be finalised.

United offloads US magazines

United News & Media sharpened its media focus on Tuesday with the sale of the US arm of trade publisher Miller Freeman to Dutch publisher VNU for $650m (£435m) in cash.

Under the deal VNU - home to trade journals such as the Hollywood Reporter - will take on various business titles and exhibitions ranging from sport to travel, while United will hold on to its US hi-tech interests such as CMP Media.

United said it was also close to selling Miller Freeman's European arm - a business for which Anglo-Dutch publisher Reed Elsevier is widely expected to bid. United shares ended 1.42% up at 930p, lifted partly by talk of a possible rival bid for the group. VNU shares were 1.59% down at €55.70.

Citigroup and AOL forge link

Citigroup and AOL have agreed a deal whereby AOL will offer Citigroup's products to its users. The pair will build new payment and money transfer features across AOL, AOL.COM, CompuServe, Netscape Netcenter, AOLTV and Digital City, as well as AOL Instant Messenger and ICQ. Citigroup chief executive Sanford Weill said the alliance "will bring us closer to offering consumers a suite of financial services anytime, anywhere, through the channels they prefer".

Cash to carry middle England and Labour heartlands

Special report: the comprehensive spending review
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown yesterday fired the first shots in the general election campaign when he unveiled a £43bn increase in public spending over the next four years to appeal to voters across the board.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown yesterday fired the first shots in the general election campaign when he unveiled a £43bn increase in public spending over the next four years to appeal to voters across the board.

The chancellor declared that his prudent management of the economy allowed him to inject billions of pounds into health, education and transport without risking a return to "boom and bust".

Cheered on by Labour backbenchers, Mr Brown told MPs that education was the government's priority as he pledged to increase spending by 5.4% a year in real terms from £45.8bn this year to £57.7bn within four years.

"The best education for all, from early learning to lifelong learning, is not a time-honoured social ideal but in today's world an absolute economic necessity," the chancellor said.

In an attempt to demonstrate increased spending in education at a grassroots level, he announced a dramatic increase in the funds that will be channelled directly to schools to allow headteachers to buy books and equipment. From next April, the "special payments" budget will increase from £300m to £540m, handing £70,000 a year to the headteachers of Britain's larger secondary schools.

Mr Brown barely touched on the NHS - the government's other main priority - because he announced a 6.1% rise in health spending earlier this year.

Instead, he concentrated on middle England issues, such as transport, crime and defence. In response to growing public anger at Britain's crumbling transport infrastructure Mr Brown pledged to increase spending on transport by about 20% a year - from £4.9bn this year to £9.1bn by 2004.

"We will make a step change in investment in public transport," Mr Brown said. "We are able to raise spending on roads and public transport by significant extra sums to meet the needs of business and the public."

On the day that the government released figures showing an alarming increase in violent crime, the chancellor announced a 6.4% annual increase in the Home Office budget from £8.2bn this year to £10.6bn in 2003-04. Jack Straw will today unveil how he is to spend the new resources.The chancellor balanced his appeal to middle England voters with gestures to supporters in Labour heart lands who were angered by the government's decision to stick to Tory spending plans for the first half of the parliament.

The housing budget is to be increased by 12% a year, injecting an extra £1.6bn a year. "Across the social sector we will ensure that half a million more houses will be modernised or repaired, part of a 10 year plan to eliminate all substandard housing," Mr Brown said.

The government's New Deal initiative, which has trained 500,000 unemployed young people with funds from the windfall levy, is to be made permanent and is to be extended to all the unemployed.

Mr Brown was cheered by Labour MPs as he hailed the measures on housing and the New Deal. "Our poorest council estates suffer unemployment four times, and burglary rates three times, the national average," he told MPs. "These unjustifiable and divisive inequalities cannot be tolerated."

To fend off Tory charges that he is reverting to a traditional tax and spend cycle, the chancellor said that he was able to announce significant increases in public spending because of his success in stabilising the public finances.

"It is only because we have put the public finances on a sustainable footing that I can raise spending," Mr Brown said as he announced an increase in the current surplus from £17.1bn to £20.4bn and a fall in debt as a share of GDP from 37.1% to 36.8%.

"Our promise was to reduce the costs of failure - the bills for unemployment and debt interest - in order to reallocate money to the key public services," Mr Brown said.

But Tory MPs laughed when the chancellor slipped up and said that his statement would "underspin" - rather than underpin - Britain's public finances.

Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, dismissed Mr Brown's statement as a reversion to an old style Labour policy of "tax and spend" which would cost many Labour MPs their seats at the next election.

"The Labour party fought four general elections on a policy of tax and spend - those were the four that they lost," Mr Portillo said. "The only time they won was when they appeared to commit themselves to Tory prudence."

Deriding Labour as "big spenders not wise spenders", Mr Portillo said that Mr Brown had only been able to pay for the extra spending by raising duties on petrol, alcohol and cigarettes which hit the poor.

"Isn't it true that those who can least afford it have been taxed and taxed until the pips squeak?" he asked. "Labour backbenchers know what's happened and they know a chancellor who taxes the poor is no socialist hero."

Mr Portillo struggled to make himself heard as Labour MPs barracked him in the wake of William Hague's decision last week to abandon his guarantee to cut taxes. The speaker Betty Boothroyd added to Mr Portillo's woes when she slapped down noisy Labour MPs, saying that she wanted to hear "the leader of the opposition".

Matthew Taylor, the Liberal Democrat Treasury spokesman, said millions of people would be dismayed that the chancellor had barely mentioned pensioners in his statement. With £43bn to spend, Mr Brown's 75p pension rise, which "looked miserly" when it was announced in March, now looked "positively mean".

Describing Mr Brown's approach as "bust-boom economics", Mr Taylor said that the Lib Dems had been vindicated in their view that the chancellor had capped public spending for the past three years to build a pre-election war chest.

"What we actually suffered from is the problem of a Conservative budget in the early years of this parliament and the costs that [the chancellor] has imposed on pensioners, pupils, patients, the police and public services as a whole," Mr Taylor said.

webTitle: Leader: Fiji is set on a course it will come to regret

fields.headline: Goodbye democracy
fields.standfirst:
Fiji is set on a course it will come to regret

Special report: the Fiji coup
fields.trailText: A racially motivated assault by nationalists on ethnic Indians living in a village in the Dawasamu area, near Suva, may prove to be a harbinger of worsening violence and division in Fiji.
fields.body:
A racially motivated assault by nationalists on ethnic Indians living in a village in the Dawasamu area, near Suva, may prove to be a harbinger of worsening violence and division in Fiji. Local newspapers reported yesterday that about 100 families had been forced to flee their homes as the attackers looted and set buildings on fire and terrorised the inhabitants at knifepoint.

This is not the first such incident since George Speight, a failed businessman turned populist demagogue, launched an armed coup against the elected, Indian-led government in May. Last week's negotiated end to the ensuing hostage siege, the appointment of a new president, and the creation yesterday of a nationalist-minded cabinet has done little to reduce tensions. With the country split demographically by 56% to 44% between indigenous Fijians and Indians, close cooperation between the two groups would seem to be necessary and unavoidable. Fiji's hard-won 1997 multiracial constitution did indeed provide a framework for power-sharing. But that document, along with credible democratic rule, trust and goodwill, has been wilfully destroyed by Mr Speight's and his supporters' arrogant insistence on racial dominance and by the unsavoury, unwise complicity of the tribal chiefs and the military.

Given that the new government lacks Indian members in any senior posts (some candidates are said to have refused to serve out of fear for their families' safety), and given that Mr Speight is still not satisfied, despite the jobs offered to several of his supporters, there seems every prospect of more trouble like that at Dawasamu. Ratu Josefa Iloilo, the new president, describes himself as "dedicated to promoting national unity and encouraging moderation, inclusiveness, consideration and compassion for all in our country".

But his prime minister, Laisenia Qarase, who has usurped the position rightfully held by the deposed Mahendra Chaudhry, gives the lie to such utterances. Before being confirmed in office, he sought to appease nationalists with guarantees of preferential treatment and affirmative action favouring indigenous Fijians, coupled with vague promises of wealth redistribution. Just how long do these people think the Indian community's forbearance will last?

Along with the political, social, and human damage, the economic bill grows daily. Australia and New Zealand, rightly appalled that Mr Speight's constitutional vandalism has been officially rewarded, have finally fulfilled their threat to impose trade, aid, sporting and diplomatic sanctions. The Commonwealth, and other aid donors like the EU, may have no option but to follow suit. Such actions, while understandable, are likely to make matters worse by further impoverishing all Fijians. One day, self-interest if nothing else will oblige the two communities to reach an accommodation. But right now, Fiji's nationalists seem set on causing even more unnecessary suffering.

webTitle: BBC fights court ban on interview

fields.headline: BBC fights court ban on interview
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the BBC
fields.trailText: The BBC began moves yesterday to fight a court order preventing it from broadcasting an interview with a teenager who is believed to have fled with a religious cult.
fields.body:
The BBC began moves yesterday to fight a court order preventing it from broadcasting an interview with a teenager who is believed to have fled with a religious cult.

A judge at the high court in London issued an injunction early yesterday, following an application by the family of Bobby Kelly, 16.

The Today programme had intended to broadcast a telephone interview with him yesterday morning, but the family fears he is being coerced by the Jesus Christians.

The court order prevents the media from reporting any interviews with Bobby Kelly, who disappeared from his grandmother's home in Romford, Essex, more than two weeks ago.

He has corresponded by email with a number of journalists, and has spoken to his grandmother by telephone.

The BBC went back to the high court yesterday in an attempt to have the order lifted, or at least varied. After legal arguments were aired, the case was adjourned until Thursday. Mark Damazer, the assistant director of BBC News, said later that the corporation had thought it important to defend itself.

"We thought our interview was a legitimate piece of journalism, part of a developing story which reflects issues of importance to the public."

It is understood the injunction was sought because of fears that Bobby Kelly, in his other correspondences with the media, was being "guided" by the people with whom he is staying.

He is thought to be with members of the Jesus Christians group, whom he met when they were handing out leaflets in Romford just before he ran away from home.

The order was granted by Mr Justice Singer in favour of Bobby Kelly's grandmother, Ruth Kelly, and prevents newspapers and broadcasters from using "the detail or substance of any report, interview or communications" received from Bobby Kelly or any of six named representatives of the Jesus Christians.

They are David Mackay, the leader, Susan and Roland Gianstefani, Nigel David, Andrew Eagles and a man known as "Reinhardt".

Bobby Kelly was made a ward of court and his grandmother was named as his legal guardian by the high court last week. Mrs Kelly told the court that she had spoken to her grandson on the phone but was concerned that someone was "guiding his responses" and that he sounded like a "complete stranger". She said that her grandson met a member of the Jesus Christians handing out leaflets in a local market. Later that day he told her that he was leaving home to go with them.

There are fears he may have been taken to Germany. Officials at ports and airports have been told to be on the lookout for him.

Mr Mackay, who exercises strict control over his followers around the world, founded the Australia based Jesus Christians in 1981. The group is guided by a literal interpretation of the Bible. He said in an email to a Sunday newspaper that he did not know where Bobby Kelly was, but expected that he would be handed over to the authorities soon.
