webTitle: GMG shows interest in Yorkshire Post's owner

fields.headline: GMG shows interest in Yorkshire Post's owner
fields.trailText: Guardian Media Group, publisher of the Guardian and Observer newspapers, yesterday joined the line-up of potential bidders for Regional Independent Media.
fields.body:
Guardian Media Group, publisher of the Guardian and Observer newspapers, yesterday joined the line-up of potential bidders for Regional Independent Media.

GMG, which already owns regional newspaper titles including the Manchester Evening News, has made an application to the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, to gauge whether an offer for the company would be given regulatory approval.

The application follows similar moves in the past three weeks by the acquisitive American media group Gannett, owner of Newsquest, and Johnston Press. Mr Byers is expected to deliver his response in the autumn.

RIM, which owns the Yorkshire Post, was a £360m buy-out from Lord Hollick's United News & Media in 1998 and is one of Britain's largest remaining independent regional newspaper groups. Analysts suggest that the business would now be worth £500m to £650m.

As well as the Manchester Evening News, GMG's regional newspaper division comprises the Manchester Metro News, City Life and Manchesteronline, with more than 40 other paid-for and free titles.

The group also has interests in television production through GMG Endemol, and is trying to build up its radio division.

A statement from GMG said that it had noted Gannett's and Johnston's applications and had submitted its own to be considered along with them. The acquisition of newspaper assets is automatically referred if a company has paid-for circulation of 500,000 or more.

RIM's other daily titles include the Yorkshire Evening Post in Leeds, the Star in Sheffield, the Lancashire Evening Post in Preston and the Wigan Evening Post.

fields.headline: Brown's £43bn spending spree
fields.standfirst:
Challenge to Tories to match figures

Special report: the comprehensive spending review
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown gave Labour supporters the news they had long wanted to hear yesterday when he finally unveiled the £43bn public spending package that he has painstakingly crafted to modernise Britain's ailing public services - and win the government a second term.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown gave Labour supporters the news they had long wanted to hear yesterday when he finally unveiled the £43bn public spending package that he has painstakingly crafted to modernise Britain's ailing public services - and win the government a second term.

Labour MPs were jubilant as the chancellor ended his three years of parsimony with a challenge to the Conservatives to match his massive increases for education, health, transport and crime-fighting or make clear what they would cut.

"We have made our choice. It is now for those who oppose our spending plans to state clearly where their cuts would fall. This government has been prudent for a purpose," he ended with a flourish.

In a cascade of statistics, Mr Brown promised education and employment an extra £12bn a year by 2003-4, £13bn more to the NHS and a startling average increase of 20% a year in spending on the battered transport infrastructure.

The shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, said that Labour's second comprehensive spending review marked a return to "tax and spend" and amounted to a pre-election "splurge". But backbench Labour MPs roared their approval. "This is good news, the economy is in sound shape and it will bring a lot of extra support to Labour," the former cabinet minister Jack Cunningham, predicted.

Andrew Mackinlay, a backbench critic, said: "There is a lesson here - that ministers, instead of concentrating on spin, have a good record to show on delivery and substance. Brown has been some one who has listened to the party and the country and is a chancellor who delivers."

Mr Brown's cabinet colleagues will seek to maintain the political momentum over the coming days. John Prescott will announce details of his national plan for transport tomorrow with Alan Milburn doing the same for health next week. Both are crucial to reconnecting with voters whose disappointment with Labour helped push the government's poll lead over the Tories down to 7% in this week's Guardian/ ICM poll.

Mr Brown yesterday itemised some of David Blunkett's plans - including extra money for every headteacher to decide how to spend on books and materials, £6,000 a year for the smallest primary school up to £70,000 for large comprehensives.

"We want the public to see this money being invested locally," a senior Downing Street official said. After years of controversy over "hype, double-counting and spin" many ministers, including Mr Blunkett, are determined to translate the chancellor's billions into numbers that voters can grasp.

The three-year CSR, covering 2001 to 2004, also provided extra money to recruit more policemen, a 4.3% real terms increase in Chris Smith's budget to encourage wider participation in culture and sport, even a modest increase in defence spending to improve Britain's global military mobility.

The first such increase since the cold war, it was yet another sign that Mr Brown and Tony Blair intend to protect their own political flank against "middle England" charges that they are weak on populist issues such as defence and crime.

All the extra money has been granted on condition that every department fulfills the 200 public service agreements they have signed. All have promised better performances in return for their extra cash.

As this week's crime figures underline, the new targets - including sharp cuts in key offences - are a hostage to fortune for Mr Brown and the prime minister, who sat at his dominant chancellor's side. But one jubilant public sector union, Unison, likened the review to "rain at the end of a long drought".

During his 38-minute speech Mr Brown was adamant that he had not unleashed an old-fashioned spending spree, but was instead making good "the damage done by the legacy of decades of under-investment across our public services". That was only possible, he said, because he had first created a stable economic environment for growth and turned round the costly burden of unemployment, poverty and ever-rising social security bills.

Yesterday's review did not neglect the poorest. Mr Brown confirmed that - as reported in yesterday's Guardian - the welfare-to-work New Deal is to be made permanent. There will be more money for childcare, for poorer regions and inner cities. The anti-drugs budget will rise to nearly £1bn by 2003-4.

But Mr Brown said the public finances were in even better shape than he had anticipated at the time of the Budget. Thanks to falling unemployment costs, booming tax receipts and the mobile phone auction, debt repayments this year alone will be £18.1bn, not £11.9bn as originally planned.

Current spending will grow at 2.5%, in line with the underlying growth rate in the economy. But capital spending during 2001-4 will virtually double to 1.8 % of GNP - another gamble for Labour after three years in which major Whitehall departments have proved incapable of spending the capital sums they have been allocated.

The City took the news calmly, satisfied that the Treasury has the situation under control provided the economy continues to thrive. Markets barely moved. The CBI welcomed overdue spending on transport projects while expressing "reservations about a level of public spending above 40% of GDP" - which it will reach in 2002-3.

The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, called it "a desperate effort to rally flagging Labour morale".

All the extra money has been granted on condition that every department fulfills the 200 public service agreements they have signed. All have promised better performances in return for their extra cash. As this week's crime figures underline, the new targets - including sharp cuts in key offences - are a hostage to fortune for Mr Brown and the prime minister, who sat at his dominant chancellor's side. But one jubilant public sector union, Unison, likened the review to "rain at the end of a long drought". During his 38-minute speech Mr Brown was adamant that he had not unleashed an old-fashioned spending spree, but was instead making good "the damage done by the legacy of decades of under-investment across our public services". That was only possible, he said, because he had first created a stable economic environment for growth and turned round the costly burden of unemployment, poverty and ever-rising social security bills. Yesterday's review did not neglect the poorest. Mr Brown confirmed that - as reported in yesterday's Guardian - the welfare-to-work New Deal is to be made permanent. There will be more money for childcare, for poorer regions and inner cities. The anti-drugs budget will rise to nearly £1bn by 2003-4. But Mr Brown said the public finances were in even better shape than he had anticipated at the time of the Budget. Thanks to falling unemployment costs, booming tax receipts and the mobile phone auction, debt repayments this year alone will be £18.1bn, not £11.9bn as originally planned. Current spending will grow at 2.5%, in line with the underlying growth rate in the economy. But capital spending during 2001-4 will virtually double to 1.8 % of GNP - another gamble for Labour after three years in which major Whitehall departments have proved incapable of spending the capital sums they have been allocated. The City took the news calmly, satisfied that the Treasury has the situation under control provided the economy continues to thrive. Markets barely moved. The CBI welcomed overdue spending on transport projects while expressing "reservations about a level of public spending above 40% of GDP" - which it will reach in 2002-3. The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, called it "a desperate effort to rally flagging Labour morale". fields.headline: Spending review in brief
fields.standfirst: Special report: the comprehensive spending review
fields.trailText:
Scotland
Scotland will have to wait until September to learn exactly how its £3.4bn share - a rise of 4.4% - of the chancellor's cash will be apportioned. It is up to Holyrood to decide how the money is spent and the Scottish parliament is in recess for the summer. However, finance minister Jack McConnell said that "front-line services" would be the priority and big cash injections would go on modernising schools, improving health, revitalising public transport, and tackling drugs and crime.
fields.body:
Scotland
Scotland will have to wait until September to learn exactly how its £3.4bn share - a rise of 4.4% - of the chancellor's cash will be apportioned. It is up to Holyrood to decide how the money is spent and the Scottish parliament is in recess for the summer. However, finance minister Jack McConnell said that "front-line services" would be the priority and big cash injections would go on modernising schools, improving health, revitalising public transport, and tackling drugs and crime.

Agriculture
Big increases in research in BSE-like diseases in sheep and goats as well as cattle are promised as part of a 6.3% a year average rise in agriculture spending over the next three years.

Extra money is also being made available to compensate farmers for the loss of cattle from TB as that epidemic grows. The Treasury has confirmed that it will match new "green farming" funds distributed as part of reforms to the EU's common agriculture policy, which should help secure a big expansion of organic farming and the reversal of a long-term decline in farmland birds. More grants for flood and coastal defence works are promised next year.

Legal departments
The lord chancellor's budget will remain almost static over the next four years. Just over £1.6bn will be allowed for legal aid annually until 2003-04, with savings achieved by a more stringent test for qualifying and tighter controls on lawyers' charges.

The crown prosecution service, which was seriously underfunded, will receive an injection of cash, and an extra £10m a year for the next two years. Some of the money will go to creating better links between prosecutors and police.

Northern Ireland
The Northern Ireland Office will be given an extra £316m to implement the reforms of the Good Friday Agreement including policing, criminal justice and compensation payments.

New deal
The new deal is to become a permanent initiative. In the past it has been funded by the windfall tax imposed on the privatised utilities. From 2001-02 it will be funded by a new employment opportunities fund which will be worth £1.4bn by 2003-04.

webTitle: Jilted Prudence misses stand-up tragedy routine

fields.headline: Jilted Prudence misses stand-up tragedy routine
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: It can't be much fun being one of the women in Gordon Brown's life.
fields.body:
It can't be much fun being one of the women in Gordon Brown's life. Take Sarah Macauley. We always assumed the couple were engaged to be married - and believed it even though Mr Brown's spin doctor, Charlie Whelan, told us it was true.

But now Ms Macauley must feel she is in an emotional limbo. Does he still love her? Does he want to commit his whole life to her happiness? She is sometimes seen by his side, and he went with her to her brother's wedding in America, but she wears no engagement ring.

However, she is blessed compared with Prudence. You may recall that for years the chancellor was helplessly in thrall to Prudence. Like any young man obsessed with the passion of his life, he couldn't stop talking about her. He would mention her 20 or 30 times in a speech.

"We must proceed with Prudence," he would say. "It is all thanks to Prudence," he might aver, his eyes glowing with adoration.

How different things are now! Prudence spends a long time waiting by the phone these days. She received just four passing mentions in Mr Brown's speech yesterday. At one point he claimed that the money he was spending like a drunken lottery winner was "not at the expense of Prudence, but as the result of Prudence". But this was the kind of formal tribute a man pays his first wife, distantly courteous rather than warm.

It was a curious speech, for he announced gifts for everyone and everything - pensioners, schools, post offices, transport, police, the BBC world service, developing countries and even the Chernobyl nuclear reactor. Also, the tooth fairy is now going to leave leather bags of gold under every pillow. Yet the vocabulary the chancellor uses is still closed in, tight and restrained.

Incentives will be "locked in"; money is "tied", fiscal policy "strengthened". There is much talk of "discipline". He speaks about "frontline services", using the language of the military strategist to describe nurses and teachers. You just know for a fact that, as a boy, Gordon's piggy bank was made of cast iron and bolted to his bedroom floor.

The dour recitation of good news continued. If there were tragedy clubs at which people came to watch stand-up tragedians, Mr Brown would be a star. The government had cut the national debt by £18.1bn. "It is the largest repayment of debt in any year since the war," he said, in the manner of Rolf Harris announcing the death of a puppy.

Tories sat still, miserable and silent. "We have not and will not relax that discipline," he exclaimed, then fatally went on: "I have three policy announcements to underspin." I suppose he meant "underline" or "underscore". Either way, it was too late. The Tories collapsed all in a happy heap. "You are never knowingly underspun," said Kenneth Clarke later.

This mistake - Mr Brown will never be allowed to forget it - was more or less the only good news the Tories had all day. Michael Portillo seemed ill at ease, and his voice squeaked and cracked like a pubertal choirboy.

As happy Labour MPs jeered everything he said, the Speaker made things worse when she rose to ask for quiet. "The house was in good order most of the time while the chancellor was speaking; I expect the same for the leader of the opposition."

The leader of the opposition! Even William Hague's usual placid smile looked sour and taut when he heard that, and the Tories were finally too glum even to mind Mr Brown's finishing flub: "They come to the house and predict doom, boom, er, doom, and gloom."

Or "boom boom", as Basil Brush would say if he were a stand-up tragedian.

webTitle: Sport scores over arts in funds race

fields.headline: Sport scores over arts in funds race
fields.standfirst:
 Theatres face disappointment as limited cash looks like failing to meet all the demands

Special report: the comprehensive spending review
fields.trailText: Sport has triumphed over the arts in the government's spending review, with a big push on sport in schools now clearly emerging as one of Labour's key vote-winning strategies.
fields.byline: Fiachra Gibbons, Tim Radford  and  Vivek Chaudhary
fields.body:
Sport has triumphed over the arts in the government's spending review, with a big push on sport in schools now clearly emerging as one of Labour's key vote-winning strategies.

Cash strapped regional theatres will have to wait until next week to see if the overall 4.3% rise in spending on arts and sport will be enough to save them.

The Arts Council chairman, Gerry Robinson, had demanded an extra £100m a year alone for his organisation. With only £105m of extra money in the pot next year across the whole Department for Culture, Media and Sport, he is not likely to get anything like that figure.

Last night, however, the Arts Council was putting a brave face on it. "We are delighted that the chancellor has said the arts will received a significant funding increase. We look forward to receiving the detailed figures." The Guardian has learned that the bulk of the extra arts spending may only come in 2003.

Sport in schools is the priority, though Mr Smith was last night keen to emphasise that every sector would benefit. "This settlement is very good news indeed for everyone who cares about sport, arts and culture. Such a significant spending boost will give sporting and cultural organisations the resources they need to nurture and reward talent and excellence." Details will be released next week.

There was good news too for science, which for two decades struggled with a continuing squeeze on research funds. It is now facing a steady increase in real terms of 5.4% for the next three years. If the £1bn announced less than two weeks ago to beef up laboratories and bolster stipends for researchers is included, the picture looks even rosier, with an increase of 7% a year for the next three years.

A steady increase at such a rate would lead to a doubling of government investment in civil science over the next decade. This is almost precisely what British scientists have campaigned for.

The money will also include £250m dedicated to what the government calls "21st century research". Much of this will go to exploiting the new understanding of human genetic makeup and could yield dramatic new weapons against once-intractable diseases.

Some will also be invested in the next stage of the electronics revolution, and will pay-off in dramatic advances in robotics and communication.

There will also be £100m for "knowledge transfer" - the tricky process of turning academic discovery into commercial enterprise to build Britain's wealth.

fields.headline: EU cash aid guaranteed
fields.standfirst: Special report: the comprehensive spending review
fields.trailText: The chancellor's promise of a new approach to raise investment levels in some of the poorest parts of the UK was greeted with delight yesterday.
fields.body:
The chancellor's promise of a new approach to raise investment levels in some of the poorest parts of the UK was greeted with delight yesterday.

Large parts of Wales, together with Cornwall, South Yorkshire and Merseyside, stand to benefit from billions of pounds in aid under Europe's Objective 1 programme to regenerate economically deprived parts of the EU.

The chancellor said that within the departmental allocations made yesterday the government would ensure funding for the European structural funds projects, including Objective 1. This was estimated to total £4.2b over three years, including an estimated £600m for new Objective 1 projects in the English regions. Public spending in Wales will be allowed to increase by an average of 5.4 % in real terms over the next three years, the biggest increase the Welsh settlement has ever had.

The spending figures - rising from £8bn this year to £10bn in 2003-04 - include £421m the assembly can draw down from EU funds allocated to west Wales and the valleys under Objective 1.

But opposition number crunchers were quick to claim that Wales was being short changed. The Labour executive faces a torrid time during a debate on the spending review this morning.

Plaid Cymru called the settlement a slap in the face for Wales, claiming that only part of the £1.2bn EU component of the regeneration funds was being made available and that no government money had been allocated for match funding.

The Conservative economic development spokesman, Alun Cairns, said the prime minister had failed to live up to his promise not to let Wales down. He said match funding for Objective 1 would have to be found from budgets set aside for education and health.

The three English counties have been promised a total of £2bn under Objective 1, while west Wales and the valleys are in line for £1.2bn.

Cornwall county council gave a cautious welcome to the statement but said it would need to see the details.

The county needs to raise £300m in match funding to unlock £300m of EU aid for regeneration projects.

webTitle: Hooray for Hollywood, says Gore, as stars shun Bush

fields.headline: Hooray for Hollywood, says Gore, as stars shun Bush
fields.standfirst: It's Michael Douglas and Barbra Streisand v Chuck Norris and Pat Boone in battle for celebrity endorsements
fields.trailText: George W Bush still has a narrow lead in the American presidential opinion polls, but when it comes to the election campaign star wars, Al Gore is on another planet altogether.
fields.body:
George W Bush still has a narrow lead in the American presidential opinion polls, but when it comes to the election campaign star wars, Al Gore is on another planet altogether.

The Democratic candidate has assembled a glittering cast list of Hollywood endorsements that leaves no room for doubt about why his party has selected Los Angeles as the site of its national convention next month, at which Mr Gore will officially launch his bid for the White House.

Mr Gore's financial backers include such box office megastars as Robert de Niro, Harrison Ford, Gwyneth Paltrow and Sharon Stone, each of whom has contributed the annual legal maximum donation for an individual of $1,000 (£670).

No fewer than 17 Hollywood Oscar winners have already given at least $1,000 each to the Gore campaign, underlining the extent to which the Bill Clinton-era Democratic party has successfully cultivated the backing of entertainment celebrities in addition to its traditional business, trade union and grassroots constituencies.

A survey of celebrity financial donors to the Gore presidential campaign shows that the US vice-president has overwhelming support among entertainment industry bigwigs and stars, some of whom will be paraded on the platform when the convention opens in Los Angeles on August 14.

Other major names on Mr Gore's donor list include Kevin Costner, Michael Douglas, Tom Hanks, Jack Nicholson and Jerry Seinfeld. Mr Gore's former room mate from his Harvard University student years, the film actor Tommy Lee Jones, gave $1,000 to his old friend in 1999, and has done the same again this year.

Among others who have helped Mr Gore to pick up a total of $880,000 in individual donations from the entertainment world over the past two years are the actors Nicolas Cage, Candice Bergen, Richard Dreyfuss, James Garner, Larry Hagman, Mariel Hemingway, Jimmy Smits, Mary Steenburgen, Lily Tomlin and Jeanne Tripplehorn.

Musicians who have given money to the Gore campaign include Sheryl Crow, Herbie Hancock, Quincy Jones, Nancy Sinatra, Barbra Streisand, and the Tamla Motown founder Berry Gordy. Ms Streisand is expected to perform at the Democratic convention.

Hollywood magnates and directors on the list include David Geffen and Steven Spielberg of DreamWorks, both of whom are long time Clinton intimates, and Michael Eisner of Disney - who covers his bets by giving to both Mr Gore and Mr Bush. The directors Rob Reiner and Oliver Stone are also Gore backers.

Compared with Mr Gore's Who's Who of celebrities, his Republican rival can muster only a small and distinctly B-list group of stars. Indeed the Texas governor's entertainment industry endorsements are easily outshone by the names who have given money to the Green party presidential nominee, Ralph Nader.

Against Mr Gore's star power, Mr Bush can only counter with names like the 1960s crooner Pat Boone, country singer Loretta Lynn, actor Chuck Norris and the Texan concert pianist Van Cliburn.

Fittingly, the veteran activist Mr Nader has already grabbed the backing of some of Hollywood's most durable and radical stars, notably Paul Newman. The Oscar-winning actress Susan Sarandon, who has played a leading off-screen role in recent campaigns against US death penalty and gun laws, is also a Nader backer.

Another longtime embodiment of Hollywood radicalism, Warren Beatty, has lived up to his promiscuous reputation by giving $1,000 to both Mr Gore and Mr Nader in each of the past two years. The iconic country music star Willie Nelson has given Mr Nader his verbal endorsement, but has not so far backed it with a recorded donation.

The Green candidate told reporters last week that the vice-president was sufficiently alarmed by the inroads Mr Nader has been making into the Democratic donor base in Hollywood that Mr Gore had personally telephoned some Nader backers to woo them back into the fold. Mr Gore's camp denies that charge, but there is little doubt that he has been alarmed by the strength of Mr Nader's support in states such as California which Mr Gore must carry in November.

Mr Gore has had some long overdue good news in the opinion polls this week, with three new surveys all showing that he has managed to narrow Mr Bush's lead significantly. A Gallup poll last weekend for CNN showed Mr Bush leading by 45%-43%, compared with a 50%-41% margin a week previously. A CBS News poll also gave Mr Bush a two-point lead, 43%-41%, compared with a 47%-39% margin in a similar survey in May.

Presidents in thrall to the silver screen

From the days of President Warren Harding in the 1920s presidents have courted the company of movie entertainers, but it was John F Kennedy in the early 1960s who brought the White House and the silver screen closer than anyone before him.

Kennedy's ties to Frank Sinatra, who had introduced him to one of his mistresses, Judith Exner, were confirmed when Sinatra was asked to produce JFK's inauguration party, at which the star escorted Jacqueline Kennedy to her seat.

Kennedy's affair with Marilyn Monroe consummated the new intimacy. But JFK's immediate successors were less dazzled by the entertainment world. Richard Nixon, who had grown up in Los Angeles at a time when many Hollywood stars - such as Charlie Chaplin, Humphrey Bogart and Edward G Robinson - were firmly on the left, remained characteristically suspicious of all such links. Only a handful of stars, notably John Wayne, were welcome in the Nixon White House.

Ronald Reagan transformed his party's attitude. The only film actor to be elected to the presidency, Reagan wallowed in the connection between life and its depiction on the screen, frequently confusing the two. Reagan's 1981 inauguration was a celebration of wealth, connection and ostentation, and again featured a leading role for Sinatra.

"This is the first administration to have a premiere," cracked the TV host Johnny Carson, as Efrem Zimbalist Jr hosted a two-and-a-half-hour celebration. Ethel Merman sang Everything's Coming Up Roses. Charlton Heston read passages from great American literature. Donny Osmond massacred a Chuck Berry classic into Go Ronnie Go, while Sinatra himself sang Nancy with the Laughing Face to the new first lady.

Twelve years later, playing his sax at his inaugural ball, Bill Clinton became the first rock'n'roll president. The redefinition of politics as entertainment was complete, and America was governed by a man who almost squandered the presidency for a girl from Beverly Hills.

The Oscar-winning actress Susan Sarandon, who has played a leading off-screen role in recent campaigns against US death penalty and gun laws, is also a Nader backer. Another longtime embodiment of Hollywood radicalism, Warren Beatty, has lived up to his promiscuous reputation by giving $1,000 to both Mr Gore and Mr Nader in each of the past two years. The iconic country music star Willie Nelson has given Mr Nader his verbal endorsement, but has not so far backed it with a recorded donation. The Green candidate told reporters last week that the vice-president was sufficiently alarmed by the inroads Mr Nader has been making into the Democratic donor base in Hollywood that Mr Gore had personally telephoned some Nader backers to woo them back into the fold. Mr Gore's camp denies that charge, but there is little doubt that he has been alarmed by the strength of Mr Nader's support in states such as California which Mr Gore must carry in November. Mr Gore has had some long overdue good news in the opinion polls this week, with three new surveys all showing that he has managed to narrow Mr Bush's lead significantly. A Gallup poll last weekend for CNN showed Mr Bush leading by 45%-43%, compared with a 50%-41% margin a week previously. A CBS News poll also gave Mr Bush a two-point lead, 43%-41%, compared with a 47%-39% margin in a similar survey in May. Presidents in thrall to the silver screen From the days of President Warren Harding in the 1920s presidents have courted the company of movie entertainers, but it was John F Kennedy in the early 1960s who brought the White House and the silver screen closer than anyone before him. Kennedy's ties to Frank Sinatra, who had introduced him to one of his mistresses, Judith Exner, were confirmed when Sinatra was asked to produce JFK's inauguration party, at which the star escorted Jacqueline Kennedy to her seat. Kennedy's affair with Marilyn Monroe consummated the new intimacy. But JFK's immediate successors were less dazzled by the entertainment world. Richard Nixon, who had grown up in Los Angeles at a time when many Hollywood stars - such as Charlie Chaplin, Humphrey Bogart and Edward G Robinson - were firmly on the left, remained characteristically suspicious of all such links. Only a handful of stars, notably John Wayne, were welcome in the Nixon White House. Ronald Reagan transformed his party's attitude. The only film actor to be elected to the presidency, Reagan wallowed in the connection between life and its depiction on the screen, frequently confusing the two. Reagan's 1981 inauguration was a celebration of wealth, connection and ostentation, and again featured a leading role for Sinatra. "This is the first administration to have a premiere," cracked the TV host Johnny Carson, as Efrem Zimbalist Jr hosted a two-and-a-half-hour celebration. Ethel Merman sang Everything's Coming Up Roses. Charlton Heston read passages from great American literature. Donny Osmond massacred a Chuck Berry classic into Go Ronnie Go, while Sinatra himself sang Nancy with the Laughing Face to the new first lady. Twelve years later, playing his sax at his inaugural ball, Bill Clinton became the first rock'n'roll president. The redefinition of politics as entertainment was complete, and America was governed by a man who almost squandered the presidency for a girl from Beverly Hills.

fields.headline: Cheers muted by inflation fears
fields.standfirst: Special report: the comprehensive spending review
fields.trailText: Business yesterday said the chancellor's spending plans could force up inflation, interest rates and taxation in coming years, despite giving a guarded welcome to the Treasury's investment programme.
fields.body:
Business yesterday said the chancellor's spending plans could force up inflation, interest rates and taxation in coming years, despite giving a guarded welcome to the Treasury's investment programme.

The plans, which foresee an average 6.6% annual increase in the Department of Trade and Industry budget over the next three years, include an initial £270m investment in modernising the Post Office and ensuring the survival of much of its rural network.

Digby Jones, director general of the Confederation of British Industry, said: "Although business will have reservations about a level of public spending above 40% of GDP, we are pleased at the chancellor's determination to attack the under-investment of the past."

Ian Peters, deputy director general of the British Chambers of Commerce, demanded a greater sense of urgency to get real improvements on the ground, especially in transport "to tackle the annual £20bn cost to business of congestion".

He said the chancellor's commitment to raise spending at a faster rate than economic growth could have inflationary consequences, forcing interest rates and sterling higher and damaging manufacturing.

Ruth Lea, head of policy at the Institute of Directors, said: "Today's huge increases are only affordable because of the large increases in the tax burden since 1997. Moreover, there is no guarantee that the cash injections will deliver the goods."

Stephen Radley, chief economist at the Engineering Employers' Federation, gave the package a guarded welcome but said it carried a danger of higher borrowing costs and business taxation.

But John Monks, the TUC general secretary, hailing a "much-needed boost to public services," said the package was "eminently affordable" and "should pose no threat to inflation or interest rates".

webTitle: Smile please: how an 18th century portrait gave birth to the power grin

fields.headline: Smile please: how an 18th century portrait gave birth to the power grin
fields.standfirst: Taste for teeth on show began in France says historian
fields.trailText: Could this be the face that launched a thousand toothy smiles? A British historian claims to have found the origin of today's power mouths - the gleaming incisor-filled grins perfected by the likes of Tony Blair and Julia Roberts - in the demurely parted lips of the court painter to Queen Marie Antoinette.
fields.body:
Could this be the face that launched a thousand toothy smiles? A British historian claims to have found the origin of today's power mouths - the gleaming incisor-filled grins perfected by the likes of Tony Blair and Julia Roberts - in the demurely parted lips of the court painter to Queen Marie Antoinette.

In an article in the latest edition of the historical journal Past and Present, Colin Jones, of Warwick University, singles out a key self-portrait from the eve of the French Revolution by the artist, Elisabeth-Louise Vigée-Lebrun. Her painting shows her, alongside her daughter, flashing a primitive version of the toothy smiles that now decorate every glossy on the magazine racks.

"Maternal lips were parting to reveal not a Rabelaisian black hole but rather a new visitor making a daring but durable entry into history," said Professor Jones. "An emblem of purity, transparency, naturalness and personal identity. The teeth, clean, white, sparkling, symmetrical, suave."

The portrait scandalised a contemporary gossip, Moufle d'Angerville, who wrote: "An affectation which artists, art lovers and persons of taste have been united in condemning and which finds no precedent among the ancients, is that in smiling _ [Mme Vigée-Lebrun] shows her teeth."

In words which Cherie Blair would find surprising, she goes on: "This affectation is particularly out of place in a mother."

Prof Jones points out that 18th century France was the birthplace of modern dentistry. Before then even the elite of society, who appeared in portraits, had nothing to be proud of in their teeth. He admits that teeth and open mouths occasionally appeared in art before the late 18th century, but the depiction usually suggested there was something wrong with the subject.

"Protocols of artistic representation in place since antiquity had not permitted the exposure of teeth in a portrait without that gesture being coded as revealing its subject to be demotic, demented or morally deformed," he said. "Yet it had become just possible by the end of the ancien régime for a painter to show a beautiful woman smiling and showing her teeth without such pejorative connotations."

Jacob Simon, curator of 18th century portraiture at the National Portrait Gallery, in London, said the earliest open-mouthed portrait in their collection was a painting of Lord Nelson's mistress, Emma, Lady Hamilton, by George Romney. The Hamilton portrait was painted two years earlier than that of Mme Vigée-Lebrun, in 1785, but Mr Simon conceded that given the prejudices of the time the sitter might have come under Prof Jones's heading of "demotic, demented or morally deformed".

"The toothy smile is a 20th century cliché," Mr Simon said. "I can first find it in the very late 18th century but then only fairly sporadically until you get to the 20th."

The word dentist was coined in Paris in 1728 by the surgeon Pierre Fauchard, who first laid out the scientific principles of modern dentistry and emphasised the care and preservation of teeth rather than pulling them out when they were rotten. He rose to fame at a time when syphilis and the mercury-based contemporary cure for it were ravaging people's teeth and the mass consumption of sugar was under way.

Before the emergence of Fauchard Parisians depended on such tyrants of the mouth as Fat Thomas, an enormous tooth-puller who used to practise on the Pont Neuf dressed in a hat with peacock feathers and a scarlet Turkish coat, under the banner "The Tooth, and If Not, the Jaw".

Louis XIV, the Sun King, lost half his upper jaw to a determined tooth-puller in the 1680s. At that time the best false teeth on offer were discarded human teeth fitted to hippopotamus jaw, or the discoloured wooden dentures worn by George Washington.

But in the enlightenment of the later 18th century Paris became to dentistry what California is today - the leading source of toothbrushes, a centre for tooth powders and the origin of porcelain false teeth as an alternative to hippo jaw.

Fauchard himself pioneered a popular spring-loaded style of denture, which had an unfortunate tendency to jump out of the owner's mouth without warning.

webTitle: High commissioner to Fiji withdrawn in protest

fields.headline: High commissioner to Fiji withdrawn in protest
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Fiji coup
fields.trailText: The British government withdrew its high commissioner to Fiji yesterday in protest at the formation of a government that all but excludes the country's ethnic Indian population.
fields.body:
The British government withdrew its high commissioner to Fiji yesterday in protest at the formation of a government that all but excludes the country's ethnic Indian population.

In London the Foreign Office minister, John Battle, called in the Fijian high commissioner, Filimone Jitoko, to press for the restoration of democratic rights in Fiji.

But the Foreign Office decided against trade sanctions saying the impact would be felt by the poorest Fijians and the ethnic Indian population, who make up the bulk of the business community.

The new government was formed after a 56-day hostage crisis instigated by George Speight, leader of a Fijian nationalist movement.

Britain, which has no aid programme to Fiji, has already stopped ministerial and military visits and supported the suspension of Fiji from Commonwealth councils.

Britain's main import from Fiji is sugar. Tourism from Britain has already been hit because of the hostage crisis.

A Foreign Office spokeswoman said the British high commissioner, Michael Dibben, had been recalled "for consultation", a diplomatic device for registering a protest without breaking ties.

Mr Battle said yesterday: "We are disturbed that the deal struck to secure the release of the hostages abrogates the 1997 constitution and leaves almost half the population of Fiji without democratic representation." He added: "Relief at the safe release of all the hostages should not obscure the fact that the crisis for Fiji is not over."

The Foreign Office said: "We are not going down the trade sanctions route because that kind of thing would not affect Speight but would affect people who are already suffering."

Although the government includes representatives from Mr Speight's group, he has only four sympathisers in a government that comprises 20 cabinet ministers and 12 assistant ministers. The line-up includes just one ethnic Indian, George Shuit Raj, an assistant minister.

Mr Speight, unhappy at the failure of his supporters to secure more places, predicted more civil unrest. "It will result in a backlash. They are treading on some dangerous ground. I think they are going to meet some stiff resistance."

Asked if Fiji could expect a return to unrest, Mr Speight said: "I am predicting it. The fun is just beginning."

According to a statement released by President Ratu Josefa Iloilo's office, members of Fiji's ethnic Indian minority initially accepted cabinet posts but later withdrew "due to concern for the safety of their families".

fields.headline: Sarah Payne murder hunt begins
fields.standfirst:
Appeal for information about van seen by brother

More about the Sarah Payne case
fields.trailText: Police confirmed yesterday that the body of a girl found in a field in West Sussex was that of eight-year-old Sarah Payne.
fields.body:
Police confirmed yesterday that the body of a girl found in a field in West Sussex was that of eight-year-old Sarah Payne.

The girl's parents visited the spot where her body had been dumped in the undergrowth. Sarah's mother, Sara, and father, Michael, spent 20 minutes at the field in Pulborough.

They hugged each other as they crossed the road to the scene and laid six stems of lilies and an arrangement of white and lilac flowers. They also examined other tributes placed nearby by members of the public and police.

Later the couple were deciding whether to visit the hospital mortuary where Sarah's body was being held.

As a murder hunt began, informed police sources said it was not believed that the killer had used a weapon. It was not yet known if Sarah had been killed at the spot. A postmortem examination had not clearly established how she died. Detectives said the body was naked but would not say if there was evidence that the girl, who had been missing since the start of the month, had been sexually assaulted.

Police continued a detailed search of the area where the body was found by a farmworker on Monday and appealed for more help from the public, especially about a white van spotted at the time of Sarah's disappearance.

She went missing from a country lane near her grandparents' home in Kingston Gorse, West Sussex, on the evening of July 1. A massive nationwide search followed until the body was discovered partially hidden in a field beside the A29 road between Pulborough and Billingshurst, 12 miles from where Sarah was last seen alive.

At an emotional press conference yesterday, assistant chief constable Nigel Yeo confirmed that fingerprint checks had revealed that the body was Sarah's.

A half-minute silence was observed as a sign of respect to the little girl. Mr Yeo said it was probable that the body had lain in the field since the first weekend in July.

He said police were still searching for Sarah's clothes, including a blue dress and black shoes.

Mr Yeo focused attention on a white van seen by Sarah's brothers when she went missing. He asked members of the public to try to remember if they had seen such a van in the area where she disappeared or near the spot where the body was found. He also asked local people to recall if they had observed anyone working on a white van, perhaps removing its doors.

Asked about the mood of Sarah's parents, he said they had been "pragmatic" throughout and added: "There was a possibility that they would have to face this scenario." He said that the mood among police officers was "grim but determined".

Sixty-five officers, some with sniffer dogs, have been combing the area around the spot where the body was discovered. Specialists carried out a fingertip search, then other officers used scythes and rakes to hack back the thick undergrowth to search for clues. Helped by fine weather, they hoped to finish the search by last night.

The A29 nearby remained closed and a tent continued to protect the area.

Wellwishers began to arrive with bouquets of flowers, which were passed on to police and placed near the spot.

One read: "You are in our hearts and in our minds. God bless you, little one and your family. Our hearts go out to you." Another said: "Sleep sweetly, little angel."

At Sarah's school, Bell Farm county middle school at Hersham, Surrey, the headteacher, David Sutton, called a special assembly to break the news. Teachers and pupils were in tears.

webTitle: Hunt for husband after family killed

fields.headline: Hunt for husband after family killed
fields.trailText: Police last night were looking for the husband of a woman found murdered with the couple's two children at their home in Northampton.
fields.body:
Police last night were looking for the husband of a woman found murdered with the couple's two children at their home in Northampton.

Claire Austin, 31, was discovered on the kitchen floor, with her poodle dead beside her, by her mother and stepfather on Monday. She had been stabbed to death. Keiran, eight, and Jade, seven, were found strangled upstairs.

Detectives said they were looking for Philip Austin. Neighbours had told Mrs Austin's parents, who have not been named, that the family had not been seen for several days.

Detective Superintendent Chris Cross said: "The scene that met the parents was beyond belief - officers who entered after them found appalling scenes in the two back bedrooms where the bodies of the two children lay."

He said police found a large kitchen knife at the scene.

More than 50 officers from Northamptonshire police were looking for Philip Austin, 31, a fork-lift truck driver who works locally. He had not been at work for several days. His blue Proton car, registration G502 PBU, was missing.

Det Supt Cross said: "I would appeal to him directly to contact the incident room on Northampton 01604 700700. It is vital that we speak to him as a matter of urgency."

Mr Austin, who had been married for eight years, had previously left home for long periods after family rows but had always returned.

Det Supt Cross said it was clear that Mrs Austin, a part-time social services home help, took pride in her children and her home.

An autopsy at Kettering general hospital on Monday found that she had died from stab wounds to her chest and strangulation. Keiran and Jade were strangled with ligatures.

webTitle: Two guilty of '£1.8m racket' in passports

fields.headline: Two guilty of '£1.8m racket' in passports
fields.trailText: Up to 600 illegal immigrants may have been helped to stay in Britain by a corrupt immigration officer in a racket that raked in as much as £1.8m.
fields.body:
Up to 600 illegal immigrants may have been helped to stay in Britain by a corrupt immigration officer in a racket that raked in as much as £1.8m.

Chris Emmett, 35, and trainee lawyer Christian Jideofo, 40, were found guilty at the Old Bailey yesterday on conspiracy charges relating to their part in the four-year racket.

New passports were supplied to people who had overstayed their permission to stay in Britain. Emmett, an immigration officer at Gatwick airport, stamped the passports, giving their holders the right to enter Britain indefinitely.

Emmett and Jideofo collected £3,000 a time from clients, mainly from Nigeria and Ghana. Some 76 people helped to stay in Britain have been traced so far, but sources with knowledge of the case believe the total could be as high as 600.

Mark Gadsden, prosecuting, told the jury the 76 were just "the visible tip of a much larger iceberg".

Judge Timothy Pontius adjourned sentencing until Friday and said he would hold an assets confiscation hearing on Emmett in November.

Mr Gadsden said that proceeds from the sale of two properties had been found in a Channel Islands account under the name of a company which owned the house that was Emmett's home in Purley, Surrey.

He told the court that between 1992 and 1996 Emmett had "grossly abused the trust" he had held.

His wife, Elizabeth Emmett, 30, who had also worked as an immigration officer at Gatwick, was cleared in the middle of the seven-week trial when the judge ruled that there was insufficient evidence against her.

Emmett said in court that his lavish lifestyle came from businesses he ran selling second hand cars and double glazing.

During one eight-month period he had spent £250,000, about £1,000 a day, on "lavish living".

The jury took five hours to find Emmett and Jideofo guilty of conspiracy to defraud the home secretary and conspiracy to facilitate the entry of illegal immigrants into the UK.

A Home Office spokesman said that officials would examine what lessons could be learned: "This verdict is the successful conclusion of a lengthy and complicated joint investigation by the Metropolitan police and the immigration service.

"The investigation demonstrates our commitment to rooting out corruption within the public service."

Lawyers for Jideofo and Emmett were considering an appeal. In court they had argued that those who had bought stamps and passports to remain in Britain, and had testified for the prosecution, had done so because they had been promised, or hoped for, permission to stay.

The Home Office last night was adamant that "no deals were done".

But in a report on one prosecution witness, George Ukor, an immigration officer wrote: "Recommend that leave to enter be deferred until after the court appearance so as not to prejudice the outcome."

Mike Schwarz, solicitor for Jideofo, said: "It was a case where the prosecution was as much on trial as the defendants."
fields.bodyText: Up to 600 illegal immigrants may have been helped to stay in Britain by a corrupt immigration officer in a racket that raked in as much as £1.8m. Chris Emmett, 35, and trainee lawyer Christian Jideofo, 40, were found guilty at the Old Bailey yesterday on conspiracy charges relating to their part in the four-year racket. New passports were supplied to people who had overstayed their permission to stay in Britain. Emmett, an immigration officer at Gatwick airport, stamped the passports, giving their holders the right to enter Britain indefinitely. Emmett and Jideofo collected £3,000 a time from clients, mainly from Nigeria and Ghana. Some 76 people helped to stay in Britain have been traced so far, but sources with knowledge of the case believe the total could be as high as 600. Mark Gadsden, prosecuting, told the jury the 76 were just "the visible tip of a much larger iceberg". Judge Timothy Pontius adjourned sentencing until Friday and said he would hold an assets confiscation hearing on Emmett in November. Mr Gadsden said that proceeds from the sale of two properties had been found in a Channel Islands account under the name of a company which owned the house that was Emmett's home in Purley, Surrey. He told the court that between 1992 and 1996 Emmett had "grossly abused the trust" he had held. His wife, Elizabeth Emmett, 30, who had also worked as an immigration officer at Gatwick, was cleared in the middle of the seven-week trial when the judge ruled that there was insufficient evidence against her. Emmett said in court that his lavish lifestyle came from businesses he ran selling second hand cars and double glazing. During one eight-month period he had spent £250,000, about £1,000 a day, on "lavish living". The jury took five hours to find Emmett and Jideofo guilty of conspiracy to defraud the home secretary and conspiracy to facilitate the entry of illegal immigrants into the UK. A Home Office spokesman said that officials would examine what lessons could be learned: "This verdict is the successful conclusion of a lengthy and complicated joint investigation by the Metropolitan police and the immigration service. "The investigation demonstrates our commitment to rooting out corruption within the public service." Lawyers for Jideofo and Emmett were considering an appeal. In court they had argued that those who had bought stamps and passports to remain in Britain, and had testified for the prosecution, had done so because they had been promised, or hoped for, permission to stay. The Home Office last night was adamant that "no deals were done". But in a report on one prosecution witness, George Ukor, an immigration officer wrote: "Recommend that leave to enter be deferred until after the court appearance so as not to prejudice the outcome." Mike Schwarz, solicitor for Jideofo, said: "It was a case where the prosecution was as much on trial as the defendants."

webTitle: Woodwards forged invoice, claims US lawyer

fields.headline: Woodwards forged invoice, claims US lawyer
fields.trailText: An American lawyer who acted for the former au pair Louise Woodward told a court yesterday that an invoice relating to a stay at her home was "a complete forgery".
fields.body:
An American lawyer who acted for the former au pair Louise Woodward told a court yesterday that an invoice relating to a stay at her home was "a complete forgery".

Elaine Whitfield Sharp was giving evidence on the second day of the trial of Louise's parents, Gary and Susan, at Chester crown court.

The couple, now estranged, deny submitting a forged invoice for $15,400 (£9,100) to their daughter's appeal fund, established after her arrest in February 1997 in connection with the death of eight-month-old Matthew Eappen. They also deny furnishing false information.

Mrs Whitfield Sharp, who originally comes from Merseyside, said she was told about the invoice by a journalist in June 1998, after an appeal fund trustee read in a British newspaper that Mrs Woodward had not been charged for her accommodation. Under questioning from Bernard Lever, prosecuting, she said she would never have charged $2,200 a month to put someone up in her spare room, as the invoice alleged.

"That would be outrageous. It would be extortionate. That is more than our mortgage," she told the court.

"Apart from the fact that I wouldn't charge somebody to stay in the spare bedroom after inviting them into my home, I think $2,200 is an outlandish figure."

Louise Woodward was convicted and imprisoned for second degree murder in October 1997, but the verdict was subsequently reduced to involuntary manslaughter and she was sentenced to the time she had already served awaiting trial.

The court heard allegations made during US legal proceedings that Gary Woodward transferred £180,000 from the fund to an offshore account. The jury were told to dismiss the matter because it was irrelevant, but Nick Johnson, defending, said that a statement made by Mrs Whitfield Sharp on the matter showed that she was "quite prepared to say anything about the Woodwards in order to make life difficult - you have really had it in for the Woodwards, haven't you? The reality is, as you well know, Gary Woodward on a number of occasions paid your husband cash."

Mrs Whitfield Sharp rejected suggestions that she had sought to profit from the case by negotiating media deals or writing a book about it. She also dismissed the defence's suggestion that an email she had sent to another of Louise's lawyers, Harvey Silverglate, gave the "clear impression that up to the middle of November you had been receiving money from the Woodwards in connection with their stays at your home".

"That is a lie," Mrs Whitfield Sharp replied.

The trial continues.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: •With the question of security regarded in Downing Street as far more important than Mr Tony's revelation as a bigger imbecile than even we imagined (quite right too: bombing Belgrade to perdition to deflect charges of being "soft" on defence was a bit naughty, but I'm sure they'll understand), news arrives of an earlier security breach involving my tubby friend Roger Liddle.
fields.body:
With the question of security regarded in Downing Street as far more important than Mr Tony's revelation as a bigger imbecile than even we imagined (quite right too: bombing Belgrade to perdition to deflect charges of being "soft" on defence was a bit naughty, but I'm sure they'll understand), news arrives of an earlier security breach involving my tubby friend Roger Liddle.

Roger's indiscreet dinner party bragging caught our attention recently, and it seems he guards his personal effects as loosely as his tongue. As head of European policy at No 10, he attended a pre-summit meeting of Euro parliamentarians in Lisbon a couple of months ago, and had a splendid time.

Only when back in Blighty did he realise that his briefcase, packed with sensitive documents, was still in Lisbon. A flap ensued at No 10, officials were dispatched and the case was located and restored to its owner, with all the sensitive documents intact (albeit read and wiped for fingerprints.) Roger, Roger, you really must stop being so clumsy.

Impressed by how Mr T copied most of his splendid memo from a Daily Mail leader article, my colleague Kay Balogun takes a moment from his regular duties manning the Guardian tea-trolley to ring Downing Street.

Can you confirm, Kay begins, that Mr T intends to spend some time today leaning against the fence looking over into his neighbour's garden? After all, that's what Fred Basset's doing on page 63 of the Mail. "We don't know. We can't give you any details about this," says a young pup. "Hang on."

But they've tried that trick before, and if we'd fallen for it then we'd still be hanging on today. Kay replaces the receiver and returns to his trolley.

The spirit of Corporal Jones spreads, meanwhile, throughout High Command. A caller to the policy unit in Millbank was told that all staff, even telephone operators, were in a meeting all afternoon - one clearly connected with identifying the source of the leak. Outside people had been drafted in to answer the phones.

When this reader rang back later, he was told that staff "would not be allowed out for the foreseeable future". Don't panic, don't panic...

In the wake of this new triumph, Diary pundit Steptoe is racing to finish his book on Mr T's successor.

The West Highland terrier also plans to make a market on the next Speaker and the new editor of the Spectator when new Tory candidate Boris the Jackal Johnson resigns - a market complicated by the fact that so few of the front runners (Christina Odone of the New Statesman and highly ambitious Blairite Sion Simon among them) are Tories.

Depending on how negotiations about an emergency secondment to the No 10 press office go, I may well throw my hat into the ring myself.

A typically sober effort arrives from Blake Publishing. "Through their column in the Mirror and now Punch, they have made a legion of people very, very rich," says the press release of James Hipwell and Anil Bhoyrul, authors of City Slickers: Make a Million in Twelve Months... and if "legion" means themselves and Piers Morgan, so they have.

It does seem odd that nowhere in the book do they mention the alleged reasons behind their abrupt departure from the Mirror. Still, making a million pounds in a year sounds very nice.

Hats off to that least charlatan of pollsters Philip Gould. By way of a belated 50th birthday present for the man whose commitment to second guessing public opinion has done so much to make Mr T the fearless leader he is today, Philip is included in the International Who's Who.

Due to a technical problem, his leisure interests ("ingratiating myself with Mr Tony; having memos leaked; driving the Express's circulation down towards a million") have been omitted, but they should be in next year.

webTitle: Camp David negotiators burn midnight oil

fields.headline: Camp David negotiators burn midnight oil
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Middle East negotiators were yesterday preparing to pursue peace talks into the early hours of this morning in an effort to clinch a historic agreement before President Bill Clinton leaves for the G8 summit in Japan.
fields.body:
Middle East negotiators were yesterday preparing to pursue peace talks into the early hours of this morning in an effort to clinch a historic agreement before President Bill Clinton leaves for the G8 summit in Japan.

The White House attempted to maintain a sense of urgency, insisting that Mr Clinton would not delay his departure for Okinawa this morning, and that he wanted a result before leaving.

The Palestinian delegation also warned that they did not intend to remain at the Camp David talks after today. Officials in Gaza even said that Yasser Arafat was packing his bags and preparing to leave in the face of an impasse, although such reports have become a regular feature of Middle East brinkmanship.

The Palestinians have hinted they would be ready to resume the negotiations in August and right up to September 13, when Mr Arafat has threatened to declare a Palestinian state unilaterally in the absence of a comprehensive accord.

However, Israeli officials have pointed out that any progress made at Camp David might unravel under the pressure of press leaks and domestic politics if the prime minister, Ehud Barak, returns home without a complete agreement. They speculated that today's deadline could be a White House bluff, and that Mr Clinton might delay his departure if a settlement seems within reach.

With the presidential jet, Air Force One, being prepared for departure, there were few signs that a comprehensive agreement was at hand. While the US mediators continued to impose a news blackout on the substance of the talks, the speaker of the Israeli parliament, Avraham Burg, said he had spoken to Mr Barak by telephone, and found him "not really optimistic" about the summit's chances of success.

"We have not reached the moment of truth, the moment of decision," Mr Burg said. "It is more on the pessimistic side than the optimistic."

He said the two sides "had never been so far apart" on the future of Jerusalem, the fate of Palestinian refugees and the borders of a future Palestinian state - the key issues at the heart of the 52-year conflict.

Joe Lockhart, the White House spokesman, said Mr Clinton had stayed up until 5am yesterday in talks with Mr Barak and in consultations with his aides. He was woken five hours later for a meeting with Mr Arafat.

"There are people who have been up most of the night for the last three nights, so they're tired. But they're going to stick with it," Mr Lockhart said.

However, he denied rumours that Mr Clinton might postpone his flight to Japan and perhaps send the vice-president, Al Gore, in his place.

The US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, cancelled a visit today to London, where she was due to address a meeting of the American Bar Association, so that she could stay at Camp David.

Leaks from the talks have suggested that an agreement could be within reach on the fate of the 3.6m Palestinians, driven from their homes by the 1948 and 1967 wars. Israel was said to be prepared to accept the return of a few tens of thousands of refugees for "family reunions"; the remainder would be compensated from an international fund.

Israeli and Palestinian sources have said they expect about 90% of the West Bank to be handed over as the basis for a future Palestinian state. But the deepest differences yesterday remained about the future of Jerusalem.

The Israeli newspaper Ha'aretz reported that Mr Barak had rejected an American "bridging proposal", by which Israel would offer the Palestinians territory inside Israel in return for Israel's annexation of huge Jewish settlements ringing Jerusalem.

There was also no sign of agreement on the future of Jerusalem's walled Old City, which encompasses some of the most holy sites in Judaism, Islam and Christianity. Mr Arafat's aides have said that the Palestinian leader could not return home without the prospect of sovereignty over the Old City's Al Aqsa mosque.

In the absence of clear signals on how the talks have been progressing, the world's press have had to rely on photographs of the talks published by the White House to gauge the mood of the talks.

webTitle: No fast track to US asylum for Bahrain runaway

fields.headline: No fast track to US asylum for Bahrain runaway
fields.trailText: The story of an American marine who fell for a young woman from Bahrain's ruling clan and forged military papers so she could enter the United States has failed to captivate the heart of an immigration court judge.
fields.body:
The story of an American marine who fell for a young woman from Bahrain's ruling clan and forged military papers so she could enter the United States has failed to captivate the heart of an immigration court judge.

Hollywood, which has already bought the love-across-the-divide story, must now wait to see whether it has a happy ending.

A California judge, Ignacio Fernandez, refused on Monday to drop a charge of illegal entry to the US against Meriem al-Khalifa, 19, who came to the country in November last year after falling in love with Jason Johnson, 25, a US marine she met at a Bahraini shopping mall. They married two weeks later in Las Vegas.

The couple had carried out a clandestine love affair because her family did not approve of the relationship.

Ms Khalifa will have to prove that she qualifies as a political asylum seeker. Her lawyers argue that she would face serious persecution if she was deported to Bahrain. But according to the the Gulf state's Washington embassy, her family have stressed that they love her and that she will face no reprisals.

In making his ruling at a closed session hearing of the immigration and naturalisation court in San Diego, the judge made it clear that the onus was on Ms Khalifa - whose father is one of the many cousins of Kuwait's emir - to prove that she faced a genuine threat if sent home.

"I can guarantee that this is not just as case of 'Daddy will be mad at me'," Jan Bejar, the lawyer representing the couple, told reporters. He said he was seeking a delay of 90 days before the next hearing, to compile a defence.

Private Johnson has said in interviews that his wife could face death at the hands of people whipped up by angry Muslim clerics if she went home, on the basis that she had eloped with a non-Muslim who was also an American. Middle East experts in the US have said they doubt this, Bahrain being fairly liberal in some respects, but that social stigma could attach to her.

The couple had hoped that the court would throw out the immigration authorities' charges and allow Ms Khalifa to apply for permanent residence.

But the use of forged military documents is not being taken lightly by the authorities. With the papers, Ms Khalifa boarded a commercial flight to the US . Landing in Chicago, she tried to go through immigration wearing baggy clothes and a New York Yankees baseball cap, so as to resemble an American, but officials stopped her.

The Marine Corps demoted Mr Johnson to private and assigned him extra duty.

Since being married the couple have lived at Camp Pendleton, the marines' base north of San Diego.

webTitle: Brazil battles to hold back oil spill

fields.headline: Brazil battles to hold back oil spill
fields.trailText: Workers in southern Brazil were yesterday stringing barriers across the Iguacu river and digging runoff channels to stop the country's worst river oil spill from reaching cities and the scenic Iguacu falls.
fields.byline: Alex Bellos in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
Workers in southern Brazil were yesterday stringing barriers across the Iguacu river and digging runoff channels to stop the country's worst river oil spill from reaching cities and the scenic Iguacu falls.

About 1m gallons of crude oil spewed from a burst oil refinery pipe into a tributary of the Iguacu on Sunday, endangering drinking water, farm land and animal life as the river current drove the slick 25 miles in under two days.

It is the second major spill this year at refineries operated by the state-owned oil company, Petrobas. In January about a third of a million gallons leaked into Guanabara bay, near Rio de Janeiro.

"This is absolute negligence," said the environment minister, Jose Sarney Filho. "We cannot allow a company the size of Petrobras to get away with at least two serious accidents in less than a year."

The river spill was harder to control because of the persistent current, said Jose Antonio Andreguetto, president of Parana s state environmental agency. Environmentalists said their goal was to stop the spill from reaching Uniao da Vitoria, a city of 70,000 people on the Iguacu river, about 125 miles downstream. The city depends on the river for drinking water.

The threat that the oil could reach the Iguacu falls, 400 miles away, was remote, said Mr Andreguetto, adding: "But the possibility cannot be discarded."

The spill has affected more than 10,000 riverside residents, who have been told to stop irrigating crops and cooking with river water. Dead fish, birds and mammals are washing up on the Iguacu's banks.

Three barriers were set up across the 150ft-wide river above Uniao da Vitoria. If they fail to halt the oil, a dam and a reservoir downstream attempt to collect whatever slips by.

Fernando Gabeira, an activist and federal congressman for the Green party, said Petrobas lacked emergency controls to stop the spill, which lasted two hours on Sunday afternoon. "The team working that day was not trained to avoid this type of accident, nor did they have the necessary equipment," he said.

The company's president, Henri Phillipe Reichstuhl, said it accepted full responsibility for the accident.

Rail subsidies will double to more than £2bn a year until 2004 as the government pours £22.5bn into rail and road improvements over the next three years.

The transport budget will rise in real terms by 20% over this period from £4.9bn this year to £6bn next year, £7.4 bn in 2002 and finally to £9.1bn in 2003-4.

Details of the transport package over the short term and the next 10 years will be announced by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott tomorrow. But last night he expressed satisfaction at the outcome. Mr Prescott said: "Better transport is a key element of a prosperous economy and is essential to help improve the competitiveness of British business. The plans will help end decades of underinvestment."

The railways' current declining subsidy, inherited from the previous government, was due to drop to below £1bn next year. But the chancellor and Mr Prescott have combined to ensure that sufficient money is available to rebuild poor rail infrastructure. This is based on forecasts that passenger usage, up by 30% since privatisation, will rise by around 50% in the next 10 years.

A note of caution was sounded last night by some government sources on how the rail money will be spent, with one problem being Railtrack's appalling housekeeping on the £5.8bn upgrade of the west coast main line project between London and Glasgow. The project's costs have more than doubled, and ministers are concerned that the new money for rail should not be thrown at rescuing the project.

It is expected that the £22.5bn will be divided two thirds into public transport projects, the rest to road improvements. Motorists should not expect to see big capital expenditure roads projects. The M25 will not be widened, but the M6 in the west Midlands and around Manchester is likely to be enhanced.

The key to the roads programme will centre on giving local authorities cash to reduce road maintenance backlogs in their areas. The highways agency will be given the money to tackle congestion at some of the worst blackspots on trunk roads, including building more bypasses.

Help in providing more flexible transport services for people in rural areas will increase from £60m to £95m, but this will still leave many isolated parts of the country without any bus services.

Some money will also be set aside to develop light rail use in cities, of which the latest example is Croydon in south-east London. Manchester already has a light rail service, and similar plans are proposed for Bristol and Portsmouth.

Part of Mr Prescott's budget will be set aside to underpin the public private partnership to restructure the London Underground. Ministers have not said publicly what the figure will be, but bidders for the project have been told that about £2.5bn of public money has been earmarked to make up any shortfall.

The AA welcomed the government's pledges to spend more on transport as a "refreshing change from decades of penny-pinching underinvestment that have all but ruined the UK's transport system". John Dawson, the AA's poilicy director, said: "This represents the most serious attempt to tackle our transport crisis for years."

The Association of Train Operating Companies said it was not yet clear whether the review would provide enough additional funding. To build a bigger railway over the next 10 years would cost £52bn for infrastructure and £7bn for passenger trains. "We will play our part but extra government funds will be needed."

Targets

Transport budget to rise by 20% a year in real terms

Rail subsidies to double

Cash to improve road maintenance

fields.headline: Overstretched forces win minimal increase
fields.standfirst: Special report: the comprehensive spending review
fields.trailText: The armed forces have extracted the minimum credible increase in their budget in the light of serious overstretch, undermanning, and inadequate equipment.
fields.body:
The armed forces have extracted the minimum credible increase in their budget in the light of serious overstretch, undermanning, and inadequate equipment.

The defence budget will rise from just under £23bn this year to almost £25bn in three years time. It will rise in cash terms next year by £400m, an increase in real terms - taking inflation into account - of 0.1%. It will rise in real terms by 0.2% and 0.7% in the subsequent two years but will continue to decline in terms of GDP, a measure of the country's wealth.

The armed forces this year will also get a one-off payment of £200m from the Treasury's reserve in recognition, a senior defence official said yesterday, of the need to replace equipment shortcomings exposed by the Kosovo war.

The budget, which restores some of the cuts imposed by the 1998 strategic defence review, were settled only "late in the day" after tough negotiations with the Treasury, officials said.

In a leaked memo written in April, Tony Blair warned his advisers: "On defence, we need to make the [comprehensive spending review] work for defence. Big cuts and you can forget any hope of winning back ground on 'standing up for Britain'."

Yesterday, Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, called the settlement a "vote of confidence" in the armed forces and showed the government was "serious about defence".

However, a defence official described the settlement as "at the margins" and "not an absolute bonanza". He added: "We are not going to be announcing any big new projects." Finessing the figures, the Ministry of Defence described the rise as "the first planned real terms increase" in its budget since 1985, before the end of the cold war.

The government also announced a new "conflict prevention" budget managed by the MoD, the Foreign Office, and Department for International Development.

It will total about £500m next year, with a quarter earmarked for Africa where almost half of all war-related deaths occur.

However, officials said it was unclear what kind of crisis this new budget - which could provoke inter-departmental disputes - would cover.

Figures published by the Treasury also reveal that the combined budget for the security and intelligence agencies - MI5, MI6, and GCHQ - will rise from £803m this year to £941m in three years' time, an increase of about 17%.
