fields.headline: The text that got away
fields.standfirst:
As the inquest into Tony Blair's leaked memo continues, we have uncovered a fascinating alternative
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: As the inquest into Tony Blair's leaked memo continues, we have uncovered a fascinating alternative.
fields.body:
The following text has come into the possession of the Guardian, identified only as Touchstone Issues - the Memo Blair Should Have Sent:

There are a clutch of issues - seemingly disparate - that are in fact linked. To deal with them, we need a strategy that is discreet but which, should it find its way into the newspapers, would not be completely humiliating. I recall the advice of an American president who told his aides to give any memos they were about to send a final read-through - imagining them on the front page of the Washington Post. I think that's a good rule, and it should go for our deliberations, too. Of course, it's absurd to think a top secret message from the prime minister might ever leak - the very idea! - but it's worth imagining the great British press and public over our shoulder at all times.

In fact, while we're on the subject, memo to Jack: this recent spate of leaked emails and faxes to and from Number 10 has got me wondering about our new "snooping bill". I know it was meant to sound tough on crime - hunting down cyber-terrorists and pornographers and all that - but I'm coming round to the view that email really ought to be private, even from the authorities.

I think we should ditch this Regulation of Investigatory Powers bill. We'll get a nice headline out of it, too: RIP, RIP. And we can dress it up as an advance for civil liberties and proof that we're a listening government, etc. Such a move won't just delight all the liberal hand-wringers at the Guardian. Half the country uses email these days: they don't much fancy having their steamy one-liners to Sandra in Marketing being pored over by PC Plod either. This is a good example of what could be a liberal, yet populist issue: we can call it Stop the Snoops. I, personally, should be associated with this.

Anyway, back to those touchstone issues. First, we might need to see off all this spin-not-substance, government-by-focus-group stuff. I think there's a way to do that. We can say that, yes, we are populists - if populism means listening to the people of this country and respecting what they believe. Sometimes that will mean taking the temperature at an MP's surgery, sometimes a session with a focus group. The principle is the same: in a democracy, no politician has to apologise for listening to the people and trying to deliver what they want. After all, we know what we think of politicians who are out of touch with popular feeling: we call them arrogant and kick them out of office.

But we should take this argument further. We have to stress that there need be no clash between this kind of populism and radical, conviction politics. Instead, it means conviction radicals simply have to make their case to the broad mass of public opinion. Any liberal who fears that cannot be done is a faint-heart who doubts the appeal of his or her own ideas. If our vision is right, it will appeal - as long as we are creative in explaining it. Put simply, we can make a populist, tabloid-friendly case for a radical, centre-left agenda. We just have to dare.

My thoughts are:

i) Crime: here's an example of a nut we cracked once - only to forget how we did it. As you all know, I coined, with no help whatsoever from any other senior Labour figure, what may be the liberal-populist slogan of the decade: tough on crime, tough on the causes of the crime. The sheer brilliance of that line was that it captured both halves of our message. Now, the kind of panic-artists who dreamed up that nonsense about £100 on-the-spot cashpoint fines were remembering only the first bit of the slogan. We forgot to push the second half: tough on the causes of crime.

Via that phrase, Gordon's announcement yesterday of squillions more on education can be linked directly to our crime agenda. So can the great success of the New Deal. We can say that we are getting to grips with the roots of crime - attacking the spiral of poverty and deprivation that causes our young men to go off the rails. Sure, it doesn't feed into improved crime statistics straightaway. These things take time. But link our work on the roots of crime with a proper respect for the law - rather than abusing it with on-the-hoof wheezes that solve nothing - and we will do the right thing and win popular plaudits.

ii) Asylum seekers. So far we have run around boasting about our toughness on "removals", only mentioning genuine refugees as an afterthought. We have got this the wrong way around. We need to remind people first of the basic, human obligation to welcome the stranger in need - and, second, we need to explain what's in it for us: spelling out how much Britain has gained from newcomers.

Once again, this will lend itself easily to populist treatment. Get me to visit some refuge where there are a whole lot of asylum seekers (preferably women with children) who underwent unspeakable torture in the countries they fled. Get that on the Six O'Clock News and just watch the numbers shift. I'll get into full Diana mode, holding hands and listening to stories. Next we'll get a whole lot of celebs to tell how their parents/grandparents were the asylum seekers of their day: Ben Elton or Ken Hom or Meera Syal, it doesn't matter. Just as long as middle England realises how many of its favourites trace their roots to middle Europe, middle Asia or middle Africa.

With that in place, establishing the legitimate right of people to immigrate, then we can be as hard as we like on people who abuse the rules. Until now, we have whipped up too much anger on the latter, unable to draw on any goodwill toward the former. The Kosovo campaign proved the British can be a compassionate nation when confronted with real people in distress, no matter how different they are from ourselves. We can tap into that again.

There are similar, populist versions of every one of the policies the cautious say are too liberal, or too unpopular for Labour to run on and win. We just have to have the courage to make our case. We don't have to match the Daily Mail brand of rightwing populism with rightwingery of our own. Instead, we can be leftwing and populist - with no apologies.

While we're at it, we may want to question the status of all these cultural matters as "touchstones". My guess is that voters still judge governments on the core tasks: education, health, pensions. Here we need to keep our heads down, make the right reforms and spend the money Gordon doled out yesterday. We have a decent story to tell here. People felt the pain for three years while we sorted out the fundamentals and got the economy right. Now they can feel the gain in gradually-improving public services, knowing that they are living in a house built on secure foundations. Oh, and let's be populist about this, too: let's talk about tangibles, rather than abstracts - about hip-replacement factories, rather than £20bn investments. And remember. I should be personally associated with as much of this as possible.

jonathan.freedland@theguardian.com

fields.headline: That thinking feeling
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV:  Nancy Banks-Smith
fields.trailText: Brain Story/Better By Design/A Many Splintered Thing
fields.body:
Brain Story (BBC2) offered the teasing suggestion that religious experience is an aberration of the temporal lobes and can be induced in a lab. So doctors really are God then?

Dr Michael Persinger of Ontario, whom God preserve, if He exists, claims he can induce mystical experiences and even the sense of an unseen presence in his lab. (The unexpected prominence of Canada suggests they put money into the series.) He said, "most explanations for unusual phenomena are attributed to gods. One thing we do know is that the experiences we call God in mystical experiences are from the brain, and now we know we can experimentally duplicate them."

His blindfolded subject reported seeing light, colour, an eye, a tunnel, movement and, finally, a face.

To launch a cerebral series like Brain Story in midsummer and in competition with Big Brother (for which preview tapes were not available) does not suggest it is the BBC's favourite child. "Wolves", "thrown to" and "whip up the sleigh, Igor" come to mind.

It was not all easy viewing. The eyes of those suffering from brain damage showed a most profound distress. Except for one. Dick Lingham is losing the use of his frontal lobes, which are associated with personality, social behaviour, the you-ness of you, but he has become a passionate painter, as if a new skill has rushed in to fill the vacuum. His wife notices he no longer knows or cares what effect his behaviour has on people. As he said, hardly raising his eyes from his painting, "I must drive her to distraction, but I'm unaware of it. One of the strange by-products of my illness is you don't really mind", and laughed. She doesn't tell him how strangely he is behaving. She loves him.

Love is next week.

Richard Seymour and Dick Powell are back to reshape our seats and lift our spirits in Better By Design (Channel 4). Richard - you would guess him to be a Dick - looks disconcertingly like Clarissa Dickson-Wright with whiskers. He is more or less upholstered in denim. Dick, conversely, wears a nice, light suit. You could take Dick anywhere. You could take Richard anywhere too but you would feel constrained to keep explaining he was a genius.

In the past they have redesigned, for instance, loo seats to rather muted applause from British manufacturers. This week it was airline seats for the Swiss. Richard, and you quite see why, finds economy airline seats too close for comfort. They have no leg room. This is your punishment for being poor. At best you get coffee in your crotch; at worst thrombosis in your leg. Richard and Dick slimmed the seat, replacing foam with net, which gave extra inches. The arms and seat now flipped up. They called it the skeleton seat. I would recommend another name. They did not take up Dr Farrol Kahn's exciting suggestion of seats with pedals. The exercise would keep your circulation going and possibly, if you all pedalled together, keep the plane going. As I limped off after a long evening's viewing, it struck me that critics also need a specialised seat. Something guaranteed to keep you awake.

The excellent A Many Splintered Thing (BBC1) sported a taxi driver Bernard Shaw would have loved. Russel is married and having an affair (if this reminds you of Goodnight Sweetheart, Geoff Deane wrote for that too). He is debating with himself the right thing to do. "The right thing to do!" said the cabbie. "Are you nuts? Rightness is a subjective state dependent on the prevailing morality of the time. It's an arbitrary concept. If you lived in Gomorrah, they'd give you the keys of the city. Morality is in the eye of the beholder. Ergo, it cannot constitute the basis of a rational decision. Forget about right. Do what's best." According to the cast list, his name was Albie. He had the sort of face that, if attached to a stout, wooden handle, would give you a serviceable axe.

The Freeman of the City of Gomorrah protested that there must be absolutes. It was indisputably wrong to kill someone. "It was OK to kill Nazis", said the axeman. Perhaps he was a refugee from the Kray gang. More likely, they ran away from him.

I think he was a figment of the temporal lobes myself. A Many Splintered Thing has spotted that much of the really interesting stuff is in the mind. Like God.

If you lived in Gomorrah, they'd give you the keys of the city. Morality is in the eye of the beholder. Ergo, it cannot constitute the basis of a rational decision. Forget about right. Do what's best." According to the cast list, his name was Albie. He had the sort of face that, if attached to a stout, wooden handle, would give you a serviceable axe. The Freeman of the City of Gomorrah protested that there must be absolutes. It was indisputably wrong to kill someone. "It was OK to kill Nazis", said the axeman. Perhaps he was a refugee from the Kray gang. More likely, they ran away from him. I think he was a figment of the temporal lobes myself. A Many Splintered Thing has spotted that much of the really interesting stuff is in the mind. Like God.

fields.standfirst: What manicurists watch on television
fields.trailText: What manicurists watch on television
fields.byline: Sin Pattenden spoke to the US Nail Parlour, North London
fields.body:
Susie: "I like to watch a lot of the comedies - I'm very fond of that man what's his name? Curly hair, bit chunky, hehee! Yeah, Alan Davies, I love that programme, Many Splintered Thing, it's so funny. I have to watch Tweenies videos with my daughter and I like them, haa! It's very silly and brightly coloured but I find it relaxes me in a strange way. It makes my daughter throw up sometimes, though, she gets overexcited."

Dee: "I've looked at the sort of nails that the ladies have on television and they're not very well presented. It's more your older lady who will have immaculate nails, but I see some girls and their nails are chipped and they're short. I like Friends and I like Ricki Lake and I like Jerry Springer but I never see that. Yeah, I like the talk shows - I like to watch people let go."

Mina: "I have no views on television. I like to go to the gym after work and keep fit, then I find I have no time for TV or anything like that. I go shopping in the evenings and only have time to do everything then, so I don't sit down and chill out. If I could watch one thing at work? I think it would be Brad Pitt. I would have him in the stockroom sorting out glosses and colours. I'd teach him to give a good manicure, hahah! If he brought Jennifer Aniston along? Oh no, I wouldn't let her in. Hee hee! Even if her nails were broken!"

Siobhan: "I'm sure we had Fern Britton in once, but I didn't know what she would be doing round here. Yeah, I used to watch Ready Steady Cook, I thought it was funny. I never cooked anything off it, but I learnt you could crush garlic by hitting it with a knife. I don't like garlic very much anyway, but my husband is always trying to get me to cook my lamb curry, because he says it's the best. Person I don't like? Er that's hard. I don't like Denise Van Outen, I think she's a bit common, if you see what I mean. And very rude, I don't like that. I think my husband does though, hm."

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Education Of Little Tree/Picnic at Hanging Rock/Hoop Dreams/Lolita
fields.body:
The Education Of Little Tree

(Richard Friedenberg, 1997)

6pm, Sky Premier

Little Tree (Joseph Ashton) the son of a part-American Indian father and a white mother, is taken in by his grandparents after his parents' death. Thus is opened up to him a new world, living deep in the mountains of Tennessee and learning about his Cherokee heritage. But this is 1935, and the authorities are after him to go to an "Indian" school Freidenberg's film, based on a novel by Forrest Carter, is full of breathtaking mountain scenery, which detracts from a plain, moving tale of an unjust world.

Picnic at Hanging Rock

(Peter Weir, 1975)

6pm, FilmFour

Haunting account of the disappearance of three schoolgirls in the eerie Aussie outback, circa 1900. Great on atmosphere: the weirdness of the ley-lined wilderness; the picnicking party indolent in the heat; the sexual repression of the finishing school. And there's no easy answer to the mystery, just a teasing, disturbing riddle. Stars Rachel Roberts.

Hoop Dreams

(Steve James, 1994)

8pm, FilmFour

A three-hour documentary about two young basketball players might not seem a riveting evening's sport, but James's film is extraordinary. We meet the pair of young hopefuls (William Gates, Arthur Agee) on their way to high school at the age of 14 and watch their struggle over four years for the sporting success that will take them out of Chicago's inner city.

Lolita

(Adrian Lyne, 1997)

1.50am, Sky Premier

A fairly decent attempt to film Nabokov's indecent novel about a man's love for an under-age nymphet, and the whole emotional trauma of love. In raising the girl's age by a couple of years Lyne undermines the book's satirical intent, but he stays closer to the novel than Stanley Kubrick's 1961 version. And there are some fine performances - Jeremy Irons as the bemused and distressed Humbert; Frank Langella the shadowy Quilty, and Dominique Swain (pictured) a seductive Lolita.

fields.headline: Fund hands £400m to poor areas
fields.standfirst: Special report: the comprehensive spending review
fields.trailText: The government moved to calm restless voters in Labour's heartlands and rural Britain with a package of measures designed to revive rundown communities, improve regional economies, and even save threatened sub-post offices.
fields.body:
The government moved to calm restless voters in Labour's heartlands and rural Britain with a package of measures designed to revive rundown communities, improve regional economies, and even save threatened sub-post offices.

Ministers have acted on recommendations from a recent national strategy for neighbourhood renewal with a modest £400m to help tackle what the chancellor called the causes of poverty, rather than just the consequences.

Gordon Brown also announced a £500m boost in the budgets of eight English regional development agencies, and ruled that they would be able to decide priorities of their own within a block grant.

John Prescott, the deputy prime minister and environment secretary, hailed the spending review as a big boost for the regions and local government, with spending set to rise by 11% a year on average over the next three years.

Housing will receive an extra £1.6bn by 2004 to make inroads into a repairs backlog estimated at £19bn, while local government in England was promised an annual increase of 3% over inflation. This will take spending from £46bn this year to almost £55bn by 2003-4. Ministers are also working on a financial package to "maintain the post office network in both rural and urban areas", the chancellor said.

Pressure groups generally responded warmly to the initiative, which involves a £400m new neighbourhood renewal fund, building on recommendations from a report by the government's social exclusion unit.

The unit's recent national strategy for neighbourhood renewal suggested a special cross-cutting mini department in Whitehall that could oversee work principally undertaken by the Department of the Environment, the Department for Education and Employment and the Home Office in many of the country's 3,000 poorest communities.

The chancellor has decided to place faith in new partnerships between councils and Whitehall to deliver a national strategy aimed at bridging the divide between the poorest communities and the rest of the country.

webTitle: Milburn's demands limited by recruitment problems

fields.headline: Milburn's demands limited by recruitment problems
fields.standfirst:
 NHS to get 27% cash rise over three years
 Personal social services to rise by 29%

Special report: the comprehensive spending review
Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Ministers battling for extra resources during the comprehensive spending review had assumed Alan Milburn, the health secretary, would seek to top up the 6.1% real terms increase for the NHS over four years that he secured in the March budget.
fields.body:
Ministers battling for extra resources during the comprehensive spending review had assumed Alan Milburn, the health secretary, would seek to top up the 6.1% real terms increase for the NHS over four years that he secured in the March budget.

But after working out the detail of the national plan for health, he decided to make no further demands. As the plan will make clear next week, the pace of improvement in the NHS over the next few years will be limited by problems of training and recruiting extra staff, not lack of resources.

According to the spending documents published yesterday, the total NHS budget will rise from £44,485m this year to £56,653m in 2003-4, a 27.3% cash increase over three years. The personal social services budget will rise from £9,407m to £12,208m over the same period, a cash increase of 29.7%.

Health ministers are withholding information about how these resources will be al located until publication next week of the national plan and the government's response to the royal commission on long-term care of the elderly. The commitments will include:

 training and recruitment of thousands more doctors, nurses and other health care staff;

 investment in more hospital beds;

 breaking down professional boundaries to maximise performance at every level of healthcare, including nurse-led injury clinics to deal with less serious cases in accident and emergency departments;

 use of private hospitals to cut NHS waiting lists for operations such as cataracts and hip replacements.

The biggest element in reform of social services will be a commitment to provide free nursing for the elderly and others who need long-term care in residential homes. The government will provide an extra £1.3bn a year to make nursing care a universal benefit, replacing controversial means testing that forced thousands of old people to sell their homes to cover costs.

Ministers will reject the royal commission's recommendation that older people in homes should get free personal care, including bathing, washing and feeding. Relief from these costs will remain means tested.

Mr Milburn said: "This package represents a historic opportunity for improvements in health and social care." More elderly people would get the high quality care they need to live active lives in the community.

He added that new resources will "improve the life chances of children in care, by helping them reach the standards achieved by their peers in school and then in finding jobs".

Age Concern said the package for older people was disappointing.

"Yet again pensioners seem to be last on the government's shopping list ... Yet again we are left waiting for the government to show its hand on long term care," said Gordon Lishman, the charity's director general.

"The system is crying out for reform and the government must grasp the nettle and make personal care free, as well as nursing care, if its reforms are to introduce equity into the system," he added.

Jack Jones, president of the National Pensioners Convention, said the chancellor had missed a golden opportunity be failing to raise the basic state pension and restore the link with average earnings.

Targets

For personal social services

 Higher quality care and rehabilitation for the elderly

 Drive to give children in care the same life chances as their peers

For food standards agency

 Measurably improve public confidence in national food safety

 Reduce food-borne illness by 20%, cutting salmonella levels in chickens on sale in shops by 50% by 2004

improved local authority enforcement of food safety and standards

webTitle: Patients of infected doctor get hepatitis

fields.headline: Patients of infected doctor get hepatitis
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Two patients of a heart surgeon who contracted hepatitis B and who carried out more than 750 operations at hospitals in Liverpool, Hull and Aberdeen have become infected with the disease.
fields.body:
Two patients of a heart surgeon who contracted hepatitis B and who carried out more than 750 operations at hospitals in Liverpool, Hull and Aberdeen have become infected with the disease.

Ajay Singh Gehlot, 42, treated the patients who were staying at the Aberdeen Royal Infirmary when he was working there last year. A further 126 former patients have tested negative with the virus, which attacks the liver.

Health officials have now contacted 500 of the surgeon's former patients in the north-west treated at the Broadgreen cardiothoracic centre in Liverpool, and 139 patients who were treated at two hospitals in Hull. The surgeon was employed as a junior doctor in Hull in the early 1990s. He was in Liverpool between July 1996 and September 1998. He later moved to Aberdeen.

Management at the Liverpool hospital were aware of his condition before he performed any operations, but considered the surgeon to be in a low-risk category for transmitting the virus. The patients in Scotland became infected with hepatitis B last year.

It is understood that the surgeon is now working in the United States. Letters have been sent to his former patients advising them to contact their doctor for a blood test.

Mike Bone, chief executive of the Broadgreen cardiothoracic centre, said: "Because it is some years since the exposure, there is a very, very small chance that anybody could still be infected. Some people who catch the infection do not have any signs, that is why we are offering the blood tests." He said there was no criticism of the surgeon.

Tony Hart, consultant microbiologist at the centre, said: "When the surgeon came to work here he told us he had hepatitis B, but at the same time was graded as a low-risk carrier. Our understanding of the disease has since changed and under new Department of Health guidelines we have undertaken this procedure to identify those patients."

He said none of the former patients who had been contacted had developed any symptoms of acute hepatitis.

The treatments carried out at the centre by Mr Gehlot included heart bypass operations and open heart surgery. He also worked as a junior doctor on heart operations at Castle Hill and Cottingham hospitals in Hull between March 1990 and January 1991.

East Riding and Hull health authority said that it had contacted 139 of the surgeon's former patients. "We recognise that patients may be anxious about this news but they can be reassured that all the research evidence shows the risk of infection is very remote," the joint statement by the health authority and hospital trust said. "Nevertheless, following national guidelines, we have taken the view that it is prudent to take all precautionary steps possible."

fields.headline: £11.9bn investment in learning
fields.standfirst:
 Focus shifts to problem pupils
 Heads get discretionary cash rise

Special report: the comprehensive spending review
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: David Blunkett, the education secretary, last night hailed the £11.9bn increase in education spending as the biggest investment for at least 20 years.
fields.body:
David Blunkett, the education secretary, last night hailed the £11.9bn increase in education spending as the biggest investment for at least 20 years.

Funding per pupil in England is increasing by £370 in real terms by spring 2004, on top of a £300 per pupil increase since the election, Mr Blunkett said.

Primary schools, and further and higher education colleges all have reason to be pleased with yesterday's announcement. But, more subtly and profoundly, the settlement reflects Mr Blunkett's tilt in focus towards the secondary sector - in particular towards under-performing children in the "dip" years between 11 and 14 - and generally to inner city schools.

New targets for 14-year-olds and funding through the new cross-departmental Children's Fund to help vulnerable children and the existing Sure Start scheme will be key to the education secretary's progress, tackling underachievement in what he calls "challenging communities".

Mr Blunkett was determined that education spending kept pace with the NHS. And in percentage terms - health has a bigger budget - they are neck and neck.

Education spending in the UK is set to rise from £45.8bn to £57.7bn between 2000 and 2004 - an annual real terms average of 5.4%, and 5.6% in England alone.

If this year's spending is included, the Department for Education claimed a 6.6% rise over four years across the UK compared to health's 6.1%, and 6.7% in England compared to health's 6.3%. Between 1998 and 2004 spending will increase across the UK by 33%.

The £11.9bn rise assumes an increase in education spending by the devolved parliaments. In England, the budget will increase by £3.3bn next year. Over four years it will rise by £10.4bn to £49.2bn. Labour's key electoral pledge of increasing the proportion of national income spent on education will be kept, the government said, rising from 4.7% of GDP in 1996 to 5% by 2001 and 5.3% by 2003.

Having delighted head teachers by giving them £300m to spend as they would choose in the March budget, that grant is increasing next year to £540m.

Primary schools are getting a bigger share of the direct grant money this time. Whereas £9,000 was the maximum last time, a typical primary will receive £20,000 next year.

Primary schools with under 100 pupils will get between £6,000 (£3,000 last year) and those with 100-200 pupils will get £12,000 (£6,000 last year).

Those with 200-400 pupils will get £20,000, those with 400-600 pupils up to £25,000 and those with over 600 pupils will get £40,000.

Smaller secondary schools will get £50,000 compared with £30,000 last year, schools between 600 and 1,200 pupils will get £60,000, and schools over 1,200 will get £70,000 (£50,000 last time).

That money is on top of the extra 5.5% the government says it is providing in the revenue support grant for next year, and the extra money for performance pay, class sizes and the standards fund.

National targets are going to be introduced at aged 14 for key stage 3 for the first time, with 85% of pupils being expected to reach the required standard in English, maths and information and communications technology, and 80% in science, although not until 2007 and there will be consultation along the way.

By 2004 every local edcation authority will be expected to ensure at least 38% of its pupils reach five A-Cs at GCSE. To headteachers' irritation, there will be targets to reduce truancy by 10% by 2002

In higher education, Mr Blunkett had already promised a £295m increase next year and has added an extra £100m to that, claiming a real terms increase in funding per student for the first time in a decade and overall, a 4.6% real terms increase.

About £50m will go to boost academic pay in an effort to halt the "brain drain" to the US. Another £20m will go towards schemes for widening access and encouraging more working class students to go to university.

Peter Lampl, whose Sutton Trust set the framework for the elitism debate by crunching a damning set of statistics on higher education, was last night appointed adviser to the higher education funding council. Other money will go towards the new "e-universities" project.

Higher education funding for 2002-4 is to be announced at a later date.

As revealed in the Guardian on Monday, Mr Blunkett is giving £50m to sixth form and further education colleges to extend performance related pay.

NUT general secretary Doug McAvoy welcomed the additional funding but said the government would pay at the ballot box "if the money, like so much in the past, is simply a mirage".

John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, welcomed the increase but added that additional performance targets were not necessary.

Nigel de Gruchy of the NAS/UWT was more upbeat: "I welcome the fact that the government has got something right. Education is a real winner today."

Targets

 Ensure more than 85% of 14-year-olds pass standard at key stage II in English, maths and information and communications technology (ICT), and 80% at science by 2007

 Increase percentage of pupils obtaining five or more A-Cs at GCSE by four percentage points from 2002-4

 Raise targets at key stage II

 Reduce adult literacy and numeracy problems by 2004

 Widen access to higher education

Labour's key electoral pledge of increasing the proportion of national income spent on education will be kept, the government said, rising from 4.7% of GDP in 1996 to 5% by 2001 and 5.3% by 2003. Having delighted head teachers by giving them £300m to spend as they would choose in the March budget, that grant is increasing next year to £540m. Primary schools are getting a bigger share of the direct grant money this time. Whereas £9,000 was the maximum last time, a typical primary will receive £20,000 next year. Primary schools with under 100 pupils will get between £6,000 (£3,000 last year) and those with 100-200 pupils will get £12,000 (£6,000 last year). Those with 200-400 pupils will get £20,000, those with 400-600 pupils up to £25,000 and those with over 600 pupils will get £40,000. Smaller secondary schools will get £50,000 compared with £30,000 last year, schools between 600 and 1,200 pupils will get £60,000, and schools over 1,200 will get £70,000 (£50,000 last time). That money is on top of the extra 5.5% the government says it is providing in the revenue support grant for next year, and the extra money for performance pay, class sizes and the standards fund. National targets are going to be introduced at aged 14 for key stage 3 for the first time, with 85% of pupils being expected to reach the required standard in English, maths and information and communications technology, and 80% in science, although not until 2007 and there will be consultation along the way. By 2004 every local edcation authority will be expected to ensure at least 38% of its pupils reach five A-Cs at GCSE. To headteachers' irritation, there will be targets to reduce truancy by 10% by 2002 In higher education, Mr Blunkett had already promised a £295m increase next year and has added an extra £100m to that, claiming a real terms increase in funding per student for the first time in a decade and overall, a 4.6% real terms increase. About £50m will go to boost academic pay in an effort to halt the "brain drain" to the US. Another £20m will go towards schemes for widening access and encouraging more working class students to go to university. Peter Lampl, whose Sutton Trust set the framework for the elitism debate by crunching a damning set of statistics on higher education, was last night appointed adviser to the higher education funding council. Other money will go towards the new "e-universities" project. Higher education funding for 2002-4 is to be announced at a later date. As revealed in the Guardian on Monday, Mr Blunkett is giving £50m to sixth form and further education colleges to extend performance related pay. NUT general secretary Doug McAvoy welcomed the additional funding but said the government would pay at the ballot box "if the money, like so much in the past, is simply a mirage". John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, welcomed the increase but added that additional performance targets were not necessary. Nigel de Gruchy of the NAS/UWT was more upbeat: "I welcome the fact that the government has got something right. Education is a real winner today." fields.headline: Ulster arsonists in tit-for-tat attacks
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Sectarian arsonists in Northern Ireland are stepping up attacks on religious property in the wake of the Drumcree crisis. A Catholic church and an Orange hall were severely damaged yesterday.
fields.body:
Sectarian arsonists in Northern Ireland are stepping up attacks on religious property in the wake of the Drumcree crisis. A Catholic church and an Orange hall were severely damaged yesterday.

Police blame hardliners for up to a dozen attacks on churches and halls in a fortnight. Politicians and church leaders on both sides yesterday called for an immediate halt.

They believe loyalists were responsible for the fire at the Church of Our Lady at Harryville in Ballymena, Co Antrim. They removed a grille and smashed reinforced glass before piling up pews and carpets inside and setting them alight.

The church was at the centre of a dispute for more than a year over nationalist objections to an Orange Order march in nearby Dunloy. Loyalists staged often violent pickets at evening mass every Saturday until May 1998.

Patrick Walsh, the Catholic bishop of Down and Connor, visiting the church, said: "I know all right-minded people will have great sympathy for the priests and people of the parish. In the face of all they have suffered they have been among the foremost in working to promote good community relationships in Ballymena."

The Orange hall hit was in Ligoniel, north Belfast. It had been damaged on July 12, the climax to the marching season, and the arsonists returned yesterday to burn it down.

It was the seventh arson attack on an Orange hall since temperatures began to rise over the Drumcree issue. The most serious was on a hall in Aghalee, Co Antrim, last week.

Six members of the Protestant Apprentice Boys were at a meeting when four masked men threw petrol bombs into the hall. They escaped before the blaze took hold, but several suffered from the effects of smoke.

One man at the meeting said: "We were upstairs with the curtain fully drawn back, lights on, and cars parked outside. Whoever came with the intention of doing what they did knew that there were people in the hall."

webTitle: Kinnock says EU reform is working

fields.headline: Kinnock says EU reform is working
fields.standfirst: Special report: the European Commission
fields.trailText: Reform of the European commission should ensure that it never again faces the scandals that brought its humiliating collapse last year, Neil Kinnock claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
Reform of the European commission should ensure that it never again faces the scandals that brought its humiliating collapse last year, Neil Kinnock claimed yesterday.

Mr Kinnock, the commission vice-president with responsibility for reform, acknowledged that change was slow in coming. But he insisted that "real and systematic progress" had been made since he launched his white paper earlier this year.

Strategic planning, financial management and a modernised personnel policy had all seen advances, as had the fight against fraud - a key issue for many member states.

Mr Kinnock called the last six months the "swan" period of his programme: "Fairly quiet - even serene - above the surface... and paddling furiously underneath."

But he added: "Obviously, there are some areas in which we would have liked progress to be more rapid. The reality is however that pace has to be consistent with quality and practicality."

Mr Kinnock, former Labour party leader, was one of the few commissioners to survive the fall of Jacques Santer's team after allegations of mismanagement, fraud and cronyism. He returned last September with a brief to overhaul the functioning of the EU's 20,000 staff.

Diplomats say he faces his greatest difficulties with the unions on issues such as mobility, disciplinary procedures and training, and say it is a tribute to his political sense that he has managed - so far - to avoid a strike.

Hundreds of staff could be reshuffled to tackle shortages under plans to be unveiled next week. Commission departments have been asked to assess the impact of a 5-15% cut in staffing levels on their ability to perform core tasks.

The commission has already cut its number of departments to streamline bureaucracy and decision-making.

Successful reforms are seen as vital to reviving public faith in a deeply unpopular institution. One key move was the establishment last month of a new internal audit service to keep track of finances.

fields.headline: Brown's 'suicide' mission
fields.standfirst: Special report: the comprehensive spending review
fields.trailText: Help the Aged claimed the chancellor's decision to "overlook" the 10.8m pensioners in his £43bn spending statement amounted to "political suicide".
fields.body:
Help the Aged claimed the chancellor's decision to "overlook" the 10.8m pensioners in his £43bn spending statement amounted to "political suicide".

Gordon Brown announced a "major package" of investment in services for elderly people would be unveiled next week, the principal plank of which would be proposals on funding care of the elderly.

He also flagged the "pensioners' credit," aimed at boosting the incomes of the poorest elderly people, proposals for which are due in the autumn.

This was highlighted in the March budget, when Mr Brown said it should mean that a pensioner with income of less than £100 a week, or a couple with less than £150, would qualify for the new credit to improve their income.

The pensioners' credit has been mentioned "time and time again," and all the speculation suggested that the announcement on long-term care was likely to deliver a blow to many elderly people by requiring them to pay a large part of their nursing costs, Help the Aged said.

"In the biggest spending increase in recent history, the old have been overlooked yet again," said the charity. Pensioners were four times more likely to vote than young people, and for the government to disregard their needs in this way was "political suicide".

fields.headline: Prison strikers may die
fields.trailText: Human rights activists in Turkey warned yesterday that four prisoners who have been on hunger strike for more than two months are on the verge of death.
fields.body:
Human rights activists in Turkey warned yesterday that four prisoners who have been on hunger strike for more than two months are on the verge of death.

The warning came as two newspapers published photographs, smuggled out of another jail, of inmates who say they were tortured during the violent suppression of a protest.

The four men on hunger strike in Kirklareli prison - all members of an extreme leftwing group - are demanding a transfer to another jail. They have been on hunger strike for 63 days, refusing all sustenance except sugary water.

"They will die any day now; they are extremely weak," said Husnu Ondal, the chairman of the Human Rights Association. "It will deepen the sense of crisis in the prison system."

Turkish jails house almost 70,000 inmates in badly overcrowded cells. Government plans to move inmates convicted of "political" crimes from large dormitory wards to small cells holding a maximum of three people each have led to growing unrest.

More than 10,000 people are in prison for political offences. Many of them, especially hardline leftwingers and Kurdish inmates, believe that their security will not be guaranteed if they are forced to leave the large wards they run themselves.

Their concern was heightened by the brutal suppression of a protest at Burdur prison in the south of the country this month. Paramilitary police stormed a ward which prisoners were refusing to leave to attend a court hearing. In the subsequent violence, one man had his arm severed when a bulldozer broke down a wall.

Last year, at least 10 inmates died when security forces stormed a prison dormitory in Ankara. A parliamentary commission said the inmates had been tortured. In 1996, 12 prisoners died in hunger strikes.

The justice minister, Hikmet Sami Turk, has said he is determined to build clean prisons where inmates can live in good conditions.

webTitle: China and Russia play unity gambit

fields.headline: China and Russia play unity gambit
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: The presidents of Russia and China clasped hands yesterday in Beijing in a display of unity designed to send a message to the superpower across the Pacific ocean.
fields.body:
The presidents of Russia and China clasped hands yesterday in Beijing in a display of unity designed to send a message to the superpower across the Pacific ocean.

Jiang Zemin and Vladimir Putin put their names to a statement warning the US that if Washington persists with its plans for a "mini star wars" missile defence, it could set off a new nuclear arms race.

"The plan to develop a national missile defence system (NMD) seeks unilateral military and security advantages," said the statement. This would present "the most grave adverse consequences not only to the national security of Russia, China and other countries", it went on, "but to the security and international strategic stability of the US itself".

The statement also declared that incorporating Taiwan "in any foreign missile defence system is unacceptable".

The two presidents claimed that their meeting signified an upgrading in Sino-Russian relations, which have been cordial but low-key in recent years.

Mr Jiang said that the two countries had "entered a new stage of development"; Mr Putin announced that the summit would "reinforce our relationship and develop a higher level of contact".

Enough time has elapsed since the enmity of the 1960s and 1970s for these declarations to carry some meaning, though Beijing's foreign policy planners insist that China seeks equally good relations with the US.

Mr Putin, who arrived on Monday and goes on to North Korea today, is being presented by the Chinese media as a strong leader who knows what is best for Russia and wants to restore its international standing. He is also shown in a human light as a loving father who regrets he is now too busy to see his daughters before they go to sleep.

Mr Jiang made the most of the smattering of Russian which he retains from his time studying engineering in the Soviet Union. He spent a year at the Stalin Autoworks in Moscow in 1955-56, and says he developed a liking for Russian black bread and popular songs of the Stalin era.

He chatted to Mr Putin without an interpreter as the two walked the red carpet in Tiananmen Square, where the Russian president was given a 21-gun salute with full military honours.

They also signed agreements on the joint construction of an experimental nuclear reactor, and on banking, energy transfers and education.

Both sides say they want to boost bilateral trade. It falls far short of the goal set five years ago of $20bn (£13bn) annually. China is eyeing potential sources of oil and natural gas in Siberia and the former Soviet republics of Central Asia.

Trade rose slightly in the first half of this year to an annual level of $7bn, but this was well below the $10bn in 1994.

"Weapons are likely to remain the strongest bond in the two countries' economic relationship," the New York Times reported at the outset of Mr Putin's visit: China needs advanced military technology and Russia needs customers.

Other than in weaponry and gas, however, "Russia's troubled economy presents a far less attractive export market for China than the US , Europe and Japan", the paper commented, "and Russian goods cannot compete in China against domestically manufactured products or high technology imports from Japan and the west".

webTitle: Queen is unimpressed as she opens Berlin embassy

fields.headline: Seal of disapproval
fields.standfirst:
Queen is unimpressed as she opens Berlin embassy
Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Britain's new embassy in Berlin, which the Queen opened yesterday, appears to have left the royal couple less than impressed.
fields.body:
Britain's new embassy in Berlin, which the Queen opened yesterday, appears to have left the royal couple less than impressed.

The Queen and Prince Philip flew out of the German capital leaving behind them the impression that they had been unmoved by Michael Wilford's innovative £18m sandstone structure.

The prince declined to answer reporters' questions on his view of the building, and the architect said that the Queen had intimated her disapproval by saying: "I understand that some people like it."

Germans are watching the new embassies taking shape in their restored capital with unusually keen interest, as the chancelleries of the world struggle to outdo one another. The significance of the contest was underlined by the Queen.

"Berlin will no longer be an outpost, but a geographic centre of the continent," she said during her opening speech.

France's new embassy has been delayed by cost overruns and there is a raging controversy about the security for the United States' mission, which will be built just around the corner from Britain's embassy in the shadow of the Brandenburg gate.

The Americans are demanding a cleared perimeter zone which the Berlin authorities say is unacceptable.

fields.headline: Gentleman Jim
fields.standfirst: In the 60s he was Australia's only aboriginal pop star, in the 80s he fell into pub-gig obscurity - and now he has found his voice again. Jimmy Little talks to  Jane Cornwell
fields.trailText: In the 60s he was Australia's only aboriginal pop star, in the 80s he fell into pub-gig obscurity - and now he has found his voice again. Jimmy Little talks to Jane Cornwell.
fields.body:
Jimmy Little strolls on to the stage at Hanover Expo in a powder-blue suit, bootlace tie and Cuban heels, a stylish counterpoint to the jeans and T-shirts of his guest backing band, Karma County. "Music is one of those beautiful things in life that helps us to understand stories," says the 63-year-old aborigine softly, launching into a languid rendition of Nick Cave's (Are You) The One I've Been Waiting For. "I've never left Australia before now," he adds. "This is all wonderfully weird."

Though not, perhaps, as weird as the concept album that got him here in the first place. Messenger, Little's 27th commercial recording, is a collection of 11 songs from Australia's contemporary rock canon, crooned by an artist who began his career at 16, had a number one in 1964 with a country gospel number called Royal Telephone and was for years Australia's only aboriginal music star.

Little rose to fame singing international hits, as was insisted by the live audiences of the day. ("I'd get booed off otherwise," he says). When the burgeoning pop market checked the demand for his Bobby Darin and Everly Brothers covers, he returned to the gentle country-rock beloved of indigenous Australians. The Jimmy Little Country Spectacular filled the clubs until the early 80s, its demise hastened by the alternative rock scene that Messenger so smoothly subverts.

Little was languishing in semi-obscurity on Sydney's pub circuit when he was spotted by Karma County frontman, Brendan Gallagher, in 1996. "I was transfixed," Gallagher recalls. "All I could think of was getting that voice on tape." Little's "interpretations" were released in Australia last year. Where, thanks to a combination of critical acclaim, cross-generational appeal and approval from the songwriters - "Jimmy Little has the sweetest, saddest voice in Australia," observed Neil Finn - Messenger has become ubiquitous.

Here were songs of love, loss and yearning by cult artists such as the Church, the Go Betweens and Ed Kuepper, songs that had entered the national psyche, sung by an old-style crooner enjoying a Terry Callier-like renaissance. Little considers aboriginality a professional irrelevance. But - in a climate where Australian prime minister John Howard refuses to apologise formally for the sins of his forebears - he has become a reluctant spokesperson for his people.

The eldest of seven children, Little was raised among his mother's people, the Yorta Yorta, at the Cummeragunja Mission in northern Victoria. When not working as a fruit picker, his father headed a touring vaudeville troupe that featured a 30- member all-male gum-leaf orchestra (just fold one over and blow). Entertaining rural white Australians meant blacking up to sing Mammy before imparting serious cultural messages with Dreamtime myths and original guitar-led songs such as Give the Coloured Lad a Chance.

"A non-indigenous audience didn't want to hear too many of the traditional stories," says Little in Hanover. "They wanted to hear the big-screen musicals performed live." He nonetheless cites the singing cowboys and minstrels he saw at his local picture theatre - where aborigines were segregated from whites - as among his early influences. "I knew then I wanted to be a troubadour. My pride in my heritage has always been intact. I saw myself as an urban warrior from the bushland. Instead of hunting emus and wallabies I was hunting jobs and opportunities."

Little was awarded Pop Star of the Year in 1964, the era of the racist White Australia Policy, when Rolf Harris was still singing the line "Let me abos go loose, Bruce" on Tie Me Kangaroo Down, Sport. He says it made him all the more determined to be himself, and insists that the evergreen popular ballads he covered have parallels with the oral tradition of his culture. By moving into country music he was also returning to his roots: post-war, aborigines appropriated an American genre they heard constantly over the wireless and used it to take their stories to a wider audience.

"I didn't want to restrict myself to just one style, either," shrugs Little, who was inducted into the Australasian Country Music Roll of Renown in 1994. "I wanted to diversify." His other great love - aside, that is, from his wife of 45 years, Marjorie Rose - is acting. Forays have included a role in a 1959 Billy Graham film, Shadow of the Boomerang, and most recently as an aboriginal elder in Wim Wenders's Until the End of the World. "I've used the arts to send the message out in all directions," he says.

In the 80s, with his audiences dwindling, Little took a break from performing and qualified as a teacher of aboriginal studies. "I went walkabout," he smiles. "I wanted to take my experience of the mainstream back to the classroom, to see if there were any other Jimmy Littles there. I'd tell them, 'You need to be in touch with your past to know where your future is.'" At the end of that decade he was named Aboriginal of the Year.

With such an impressive CV (he's also sung for the Pope in Alice Springs and, on the back of Messenger, been enrolled in the Australian Recording Industry Hall of Fame), it's easy to understand why some aboriginal activists have become frustrated with Little's unwillingness to take a leadership role in rejuvenating the reconciliation process between white Australians and the land's traditional owners. "Politicians do their job and I do mine," he says. "As I am now I can walk down the middle path. Maybe I get more done because I feel affiliated with everyone."

So does he think the Australian PM should apologise? "I don't need his 'sorry' to make me feel good. I've met many Australians from all walks of life who in their deeds are saying, 'I'm sorry' daily."

For the time being at least, Little is content to relay any messages through his - or rather, through other people's - songs. "I didn't want to take things too far away from the original in case I offended the artist," he says of Messenger. "But I wanted to open up the songs enough to put my sentiments in there." (AC/DC's It's a Long Way to the Top is in the can for a mooted Messenger 2).

"You know," he adds with a grin, "I'm always telling people how much I love Jim Reeves, Nat King Cole, all those golden greats. And they say, 'Jimmy, you don't sound like any of them. You sound uniquely yourself.'"

Jimmy Little plays the Womad festival at the Rivermead Leisure Centre, Reading (0118-939 0930). Messenger is out on Festival.
fields.bodyText: Jimmy Little strolls on to the stage at Hanover Expo in a powder-blue suit, bootlace tie and Cuban heels, a stylish counterpoint to the jeans and T-shirts of his guest backing band, Karma County. "Music is one of those beautiful things in life that helps us to understand stories," says the 63-year-old aborigine softly, launching into a languid rendition of Nick Cave's (Are You) The One I've Been Waiting For. "I've never left Australia before now," he adds. "This is all wonderfully weird." Though not, perhaps, as weird as the concept album that got him here in the first place. Messenger, Little's 27th commercial recording, is a collection of 11 songs from Australia's contemporary rock canon, crooned by an artist who began his career at 16, had a number one in 1964 with a country gospel number called Royal Telephone and was for years Australia's only aboriginal music star. Little rose to fame singing international hits, as was insisted by the live audiences of the day. ("I'd get booed off otherwise," he says). When the burgeoning pop market checked the demand for his Bobby Darin and Everly Brothers covers, he returned to the gentle country-rock beloved of indigenous Australians. The Jimmy Little Country Spectacular filled the clubs until the early 80s, its demise hastened by the alternative rock scene that Messenger so smoothly subverts. Little was languishing in semi-obscurity on Sydney's pub circuit when he was spotted by Karma County frontman, Brendan Gallagher, in 1996. "I was transfixed," Gallagher recalls. "All I could think of was getting that voice on tape." Little's "interpretations" were released in Australia last year. Where, thanks to a combination of critical acclaim, cross-generational appeal and approval from the songwriters - "Jimmy Little has the sweetest, saddest voice in Australia," observed Neil Finn - Messenger has become ubiquitous. Here were songs of love, loss and yearning by cult artists such as the Church, the Go Betweens and Ed Kuepper, songs that had entered the national psyche, sung by an old-style crooner enjoying a Terry Callier-like renaissance. Little considers aboriginality a professional irrelevance. But - in a climate where Australian prime minister John Howard refuses to apologise formally for the sins of his forebears - he has become a reluctant spokesperson for his people. The eldest of seven children, Little was raised among his mother's people, the Yorta Yorta, at the Cummeragunja Mission in northern Victoria. When not working as a fruit picker, his father headed a touring vaudeville troupe that featured a 30- member all-male gum-leaf orchestra (just fold one over and blow). Entertaining rural white Australians meant blacking up to sing Mammy before imparting serious cultural messages with Dreamtime myths and original guitar-led songs such as Give the Coloured Lad a Chance. "A non-indigenous audience didn't want to hear too many of the traditional stories," says Little in Hanover. "They wanted to hear the big-screen musicals performed live." He nonetheless cites the singing cowboys and minstrels he saw at his local picture theatre - where aborigines were segregated from whites - as among his early influences. "I knew then I wanted to be a troubadour. My pride in my heritage has always been intact. I saw myself as an urban warrior from the bushland. Instead of hunting emus and wallabies I was hunting jobs and opportunities." Little was awarded Pop Star of the Year in 1964, the era of the racist White Australia Policy, when Rolf Harris was still singing the line "Let me abos go loose, Bruce" on Tie Me Kangaroo Down, Sport. He says it made him all the more determined to be himself, and insists that the evergreen popular ballads he covered have parallels with the oral tradition of his culture. By moving into country music he was also returning to his roots: post-war, aborigines appropriated an American genre they heard constantly over the wireless and used it to take their stories to a wider audience. "I didn't want to restrict myself to just one style, either," shrugs Little, who was inducted into the Australasian Country Music Roll of Renown in 1994. "I wanted to diversify." His other great love - aside, that is, from his wife of 45 years, Marjorie Rose - is acting. Forays have included a role in a 1959 Billy Graham film, Shadow of the Boomerang, and most recently as an aboriginal elder in Wim Wenders's Until the End of the World. "I've used the arts to send the message out in all directions," he says. In the 80s, with his audiences dwindling, Little took a break from performing and qualified as a teacher of aboriginal studies. "I went walkabout," he smiles. "I wanted to take my experience of the mainstream back to the classroom, to see if there were any other Jimmy Littles there. I'd tell them, 'You need to be in touch with your past to know where your future is.'" At the end of that decade he was named Aboriginal of the Year. With such an impressive CV (he's also sung for the Pope in Alice Springs and, on the back of Messenger, been enrolled in the Australian Recording Industry Hall of Fame), it's easy to understand why some aboriginal activists have become frustrated with Little's unwillingness to take a leadership role in rejuvenating the reconciliation process between white Australians and the land's traditional owners. "Politicians do their job and I do mine," he says. "As I am now I can walk down the middle path. Maybe I get more done because I feel affiliated with everyone." So does he think the Australian PM should apologise? "I don't need his 'sorry' to make me feel good. I've met many Australians from all walks of life who in their deeds are saying, 'I'm sorry' daily." For the time being at least, Little is content to relay any messages through his - or rather, through other people's - songs. "I didn't want to take things too far away from the original in case I offended the artist," he says of Messenger. "But I wanted to open up the songs enough to put my sentiments in there." (AC/DC's It's a Long Way to the Top is in the can for a mooted Messenger 2). "You know," he adds with a grin, "I'm always telling people how much I love Jim Reeves, Nat King Cole, all those golden greats. And they say, 'Jimmy, you don't sound like any of them. You sound uniquely yourself.'" Jimmy Little plays the Womad festival at the Rivermead Leisure Centre, Reading (0118-939 0930). Messenger is out on Festival.

fields.headline: A breath of fresh air
fields.trailText: In 1995, the Edinburgh festival was taken by storm. The theatre company responsible, Teatr Biuro Podrozy, hailed from Poland, and their whip-cracking, stilt-walking evocation of life in a war zone, Carmen Funebre, won three festival awards and rave reviews. Five years on and the company are back in the UK with a production that's likely to test to the limits their reputation for spectacular outdoor drama.
fields.body:
In 1995, the Edinburgh festival was taken by storm. The theatre company responsible, Teatr Biuro Podrozy, hailed from Poland, and their whip-cracking, stilt-walking evocation of life in a war zone, Carmen Funebre, won three festival awards and rave reviews. Five years on and the company are back in the UK with a production that's likely to test to the limits their reputation for spectacular outdoor drama.

"We've never done anything on this scale before," admits director Pawel Szkotak. "But we have a space available to us which is unique in Europe. It's very significant, very thoughtful, very beautiful and very good for this subject."

They're not heading to Edinburgh this time, but to Coventry - to the ruins of the bombed cathedral, to be precise. Teatr Biuro Podrozy have been to Coventry at least twice before during the city's Arts Alive festival. It was during one of their productions of Carmen Funebre that the Belgrade Theatre's artistic director Bob Eaton thought of asking the Poles to stage a millennium production of Coventry's mystery plays - biblical works with their roots in medieval England.

There's no shortage of mysteries this year. Bill Bryden's production of Tony Harrison's northern mystery cycle has been and gone at the National Theatre. The Royal Shakespeare Company's Greg Doran is directing the York plays in the imposing Minster. Others are in either rehearsal or production at places such as Chester, Lichfield and, believe it or not, Newport Pagnell.

But Eaton sounds very confident when he says: "This production in Coventry will be unlike any other mystery play in Britain. It will be more adventurous and spectacular than anything attempted before."

Eight British actors and six Poles have come together for rehearsals in a vast former car showroom, which had to be purged of rats to make it habitable. A further 75 amateur performers are being put through their paces by directors of local community theatres. Their contribution will be extracts from the Old Testament, confined to the first 45 minutes.

Teatr Biuro Podrozy themselves are concentrating on the period from the birth of Christ to the crucifixion, via a shocking massacre of the innocents. Chalked on the showroom wall are some useful English-Polish translations, like "do yootra" which means "see you tomorrow". Szkotak seems to have enough English at his command to make plain what he wants in terms of performance and striking visual effects.

A huge plastic globe, like the biggest beachball in the world, is being bowled slowly across the floor. Eventually it is hoisted on a stand and topped by a red plush throne, to be occupied first by Herod and then by Pilate. A powerfully built local black actor called Joe Speare is playing both roles. When he finally clambers to his throne, he's up in the rafters with the strip lights gleaming powerfully on to his shaved head and shiny, thigh-length boots.

Only one member of the cast comes near him in height, and that's the Polish actor playing the Angel Gabriel. On stilts. The devil arrives on a bike, one hand on the handlebars and the other clutching a noisy ghetto blaster. Judas takes his 30 pieces of silver in the form of used bank notes that he stuffs into the inside pocket of his grubby mac. Mary and Joseph , stirred up by the devil, snarl at one another in Polish as she tries to explain why she's pregnant with another's child. At one point, they appear to be part of a troupe of travelling players pushing their wooden wagon away from machine-gun fire.

We seem to be back in a comparatively modern war zone again. When I ask Szkotak where all these images of war come from, he says simply: "Polish history is full of blood." His partner, the actress Marta Strzalko, goes on to forge a link with the war-time history of Coventry Cathedral. "It's such an amazing place," she says, "that we couldn't stay indifferent to what happened here."

Teatr Biuro Podrozy have already done street theatre in Poland based on the story of Mary and Joseph. "Directors of Polish summer festivals are coming to see this play in Coventry and I think they'll take it," says Strzalko. But heaven knows what the regular churchgoers will make of their interpretation of the biblical story. Or how it would have been viewed by the Coventry Shearmen and Tailors who commissioned the play in the first place. Eaton is confident on both counts.

"I think the Shearmen and Tailors would have been well into it," he beams, mischievously. "After all, these plays were a demonstration of the power of the guilds against the church and the aristocracy. They were showing off their civic pride against the twin bastions of feudalism, and sometimes they were kicked out of churches for being too controversial."

Eaton unearthed the play in the city archives. "It was written in 1549 by Thomas Crowe, but the original manuscript has been destroyed in a fire," he says. "Luckily, it was transcribed by a Victorian antiquarian. It still stands up as a fantastic piece of literature."

Only fragments of the original work have survived in the updated version; they are stitched into the running commentary by two narrators. The emphasis is very much on the visual, sometimes shockingly so - making this the antithesis of the cosy nativity play.

"The cathedral authorities here have always been open to new interpretations of the biblical story," Eaton says. "We've talked it through with them and they're aware of the potential power of this work and these images."

Could they not be upset by them? "I hope not," interjects Szkotak, who describes himself as an agnostic with Catholic roots. "But the message is for all people, not just churchgoers. This story is as relevant now as it ever was."

"That's why," Strzalko adds, "we're staging the second half in modern dress, closer to their own realities. Christ could be their neighbour or their friend. We hope the images will be so powerful that atheists and religious people will be satisfied. We believe in the power of art."

The Millennium Mysteries is at Coventry Cathedral till August 5. Box office: 024-7655 3055.

fields.headline: Rituals on parade
fields.trailText: At this time of year the essential equipment for a theatre critic is an umbrella and a tube of midge repellent. Oh, and a map of Britain's stately homes. Nowadays no self-respecting stately home is without its summer season of Shakespeare by the lake or in the rose garden. Graduating drama students who once saw children's theatre as a way into the profession, now form outdoor theatre companies and tout for business.
fields.body:
At this time of year the essential equipment for a theatre critic is an umbrella and a tube of midge repellent. Oh, and a map of Britain's stately homes. Nowadays no self-respecting stately home is without its summer season of Shakespeare by the lake or in the rose garden. Graduating drama students who once saw children's theatre as a way into the profession, now form outdoor theatre companies and tout for business.

Of course, many of these performances with their accompanying picnic hampers may be jolly social occasions, but have as much to do with theatre as a summer's evening at Kenwood for the 1812 overture and fireworks has to do with classical music. Essentially these affairs are a substitute for the village fete, or a form of cocktail party where the culture is gulped down as easily as the Chardonnay. They are marked by the exclusivity that so dogs theatre.

But, as many companies have discovered, outdoor theatre can also be inclusive, attracting a diverse audience, many of whom might never step inside a theatre building.

Jonathan Petherbridge, artistic director of the outdoor theatre group London Bubble, whose long experience with outdoor productions began in 1981 with a promenade version of Gone With the Wind, says that taking theatre outside alters the relationship of the audience with the piece. During performances of Gone With the Wind he was intrigued to discover that "the audience were more like supporters. They felt they were involved in the action, they wanted it to work, they weren't being ignored."

The feeling that an outdoor audience is with you not against you is something that Ben Crocker, the artistic director of Exeter's Northcott Theatre, has also noticed. Crocker's production of A Midsummer Night's Dream will mark the theatre's sixth annual residency in the nearby Rougemont gardens. At a time of year when theatres are often hard-pressed to sell tickets, last year's Shakespeare in the Gardens season was 91% sold out.

With access a key word with arts funders, outdoor theatre should have a distinct advantage, but too many dire productions have made funders suspicious. Ian Hastings is just completing his first year as artistic director of the Dukes theatre company. His first outdoor production in Williamson Park, Lancaster, is a new version of Don Quixote. He believes that as the novelty of outdoor performance wears off neither audiences nor funders will be fobbed off by work that has no real content.

"You've got to make the experience a different one from walking in the park and throwing a stick for the dog, and you've got to make it more than just an event, although that of course is part of its appeal," says Hastings. "We are a subsidised theatre, and we can't apply different criteria to what goes on in the park from what goes on in the building during the rest of the year."

Giving the audience more than it may realise and more than it thinks it wants (outdoor audiences are notoriously susceptible to fireworks and often seem to yearn for nothing else) sometimes requires as much ingenuity as dealing with the unexpected storms that a British summer can unleash. (There is a theory that part of the success of outdoor theatre is that it encourages a Blitz-style spirit as people huddle beneath blankets to protect themselves from the weather.)

Perhaps more than anything, performances outside refuel the debate about the theatre's relationship to both the space in which it is created and to the wider community. A Midsummer Night's Dream means one thing when performed in the Pimms and picnic gentility of the Open Air Theatre in London's Regent's Park, quite another when seen in secret nooks in Greenwich Park.

London Bubble's Petherbridge believes that theatre outdoors can challenge perceptions but can itself become an institution if you always revisit the same sites. This year the Bubble will be heading for the back streets of Rotherhithe, Deptford and Shooters Hill for a promenade version of the 5,000-year-old Sumerian myth, Gilgamesh. The company will be bringing together professional performers, members of the Bubble's participatory groups and a choir to tell the story of the urban king who is out of control.

"We want to create a piece that brings together audience and performers to participate in the sort of celebration and ritual that large scale and somewhat impersonal projects such as the Dome and the River of Fire fail to deliver," says Petherbridge.

Our yearning for rituals and ways to make meaning of our lives shouldn't be underestimated. In its most basic form this is what theatre does, but when, as we have done over the last 500 years, you remove it from the streets and open spaces and lock it away in special buildings it is increasingly hard to make the connections between what we see on stage and our own lives.

London Bubble's Gilgamesh is at Mayflower Gardens, London SE16, from July 26 to 29, then tours. Details: 020-7237 1663. Don Quixote is at Williamson Park, Lancaster (01524 66645), till August 19. A Midsummer Night's Dream is at Rougemont Gardens, Exeter (01392 493493), till August 12.
