webTitle: Leader: What Gordon Brown offers in the spending review is necessary and affordable

fields.headline: Mr Brown's bold boost
fields.standfirst:
This package is necessary and affordable
Special report: the comprehensive spending review
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown's spending review was the most carefully leaked in recent history. Hardly anything was new. Yet many people will be still be rubbing their eyes in disbelief at the way a Labour chancellor was able to announce large rises in real public spending without triggering civil disturbances in the City.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown's spending review was the most carefully leaked in recent history. Hardly anything was new. Yet many people will be still be rubbing their eyes in disbelief at the way a Labour chancellor was able to announce large rises in real public spending without triggering civil disturbances in the City. Spending will rise 6% this year (after allowing for inflation) followed by three years at 3.25%, including a 5.25% rise in core areas like health and education.

We know that it is partly being done with mirrors: the big increases are only possible because Labour froze spending in its first two years to below what the Conservatives would have done - and the doubling of spending on public investment (including a long overdue 20% a year increase in transport) is mainly making up for the huge underspend of recent years. It is also true that after the end of the next three-year period public spending as a proportion of the whole economy will still be significantly lower than in most of the Thatcher years, and below that in comparable European countries. But that is not the point. Public spending has now been rehabilitated in the public consciousness as something as desirable as it is necessary - so long as it is implemented efficiently.

The Conservatives, until recently almost defined by a hostile attitude to increased public spending, have been forced to pledge themselves to match Labour's spending on health, and Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, said earlier this week that the Conservatives would spend more on public services than Labour over a 10-year period. Yesterday's three-year plan does not start until April, so most of it will not happen until after the next election when voters will be asked to endorse it - and the Conservatives have been challenged to cut it. As one Labour wit said yesterday: this is really a post-electoral spending boom.

Education was the winner on the social front. Health's bonanza had already been announced in the wake of the NHS crisis in March- an annual 6.1% real increase over the next four years. David Blunkett, assisted by Labour's unequivocal election commitment to make education its first priority, has won annual increases of 6.1% in real terms over four years to April, 2004. Until now, education has been squeezed much harder than health, with its share of GDP falling from 5.2% in 1992 down to 4.6% last year. Now the graph will dramatically climb and should exceed even the last Labour government's 5.4% figure by 2004.

True to Treasury leaks, this investment comes with new tough conditions in tow - new literacy and numeracy targets for 14-year-olds and a new challenge to primaries to help young children who fall behind. There is a welcome boost to Sure Start for pre-school pupils, an equally welcome broadening of education maintenance allowances helping poor pupils to stay in school, and a new service providing individually tailored support for children who drop out. Help for this last group will be boosted by the creation of a new national children's fund, which will have a £450m budget over three years. Labour's heartlands will be happy, too, that housing is getting a long over due boost with a 12% annual increase over four years as well as a new £400m neighbourhood renewal fund to help improve facilities on the poorest estates. The inequalities which people face on such estates - a burglary rate three times the national average, unemployment four times as high and mortality rates 30% higher - demand a steeper redistribution than this, but it is a start.

The law 'n' order spending details are not being released until today, but it looks clear from the 6.4% real rise in the Home Office budget that there are additional police on the way over and above the extra 5,000 promised for the next two years in the March budget. Tough targets to ensure that inefficient forces lift their game will be essential if this money is not to be wasted. The chancellor also increased defence spending after years of post-cold war decline under the Tories, boosted his New Deal measures and conjured up more money for the arts and, very creditably, for overseas aid to help alleviate world poverty. All this should boost Labour's lagging electoral fortunes. Even before the announcement, our ICM poll published yesterday morning showed Labour far ahead of the Conservatives in the crucial areas of education (18%) and health (19%). Last night's Tory response to this urgently needed reinvestment will have widened the gap.

Some critics say Mr Brown has pushed fiscal prudence to the limit. But it is hard to make this stick when he has a higher than expected budget surplus of £20.4bn (not including the £22.5bn from the radio spectrum auction which is being banked) and when the economy - hit by the effects of the overvalued pound - is slowing down. Increased public spending is needed socially as well as economically to make up for the neglect of recent years. Mr Portillo is right to say that he will be watching very carefully how efficiently it is being spent, and how the Treasury's new appraisal techniques will work. It would be better if their efficacy was monitored by the Audit Commission rather than Mr Blair's bland annual report.

Mr Portillo also asks whether Mr Brown will keep to these high levels of public spending even if the economy drops below the expected growth rate. We hope he will, because the increases will be needed more than ever in those circumstances as a stabiliser to avoid recession. In any case, the electorate will be able to make up its own mind. And judging by the seismic changes in middle England about the benefits of purposive spending, the outcome might surprise even Mr Portillo.

fields.headline: No: 1680
fields.standfirst: Berlin
fields.trailText: Berlin
fields.body:
Was geht, mein Herr? I beg your pardon?

Was ist das Problem? No problem. Not with Berlin, anyway. No, the problem's with our own capital.

What can you mean? Berlin's better than London.

Says who? Says Bild.

The newspaper? Bilge, more like. I can't imagine that our patriotic countrymen have taken too well to being sneered at by a bunch of Germans. Now that you mention it, no. Yesterday's Daily Mail took pains to point out that Berlin is "awash with illegal immigrants", an "evil stench" pervades the city, and that "no one even bothered to mention its existence until 1244".

There you go. Makes you proud to be British. But what sparked this unexpected criticism? Roger Boyes, the Times's man in Berlin, wrote a column saying it was a boring city. And Bild hit back.

How was the timing of this counter? Not bad, now you mention it. The Queen is currently enjoying a quick jaunt to Germany to open a new embassy there.

Hardly a very diplomatic welcome. What are Bild's ridiculous complaints, anyway? That London is too expensive and that we should stop sneering at the Germans.

We haven't made one German joke yet in this Passnotes! There's still time.

So let's just get this straight: London's got Tate Modern, the big wheel, the wobbly bridge and Madonna lives here, but Bilge is saying Berlin's better? Daft, I know, with its skyline of highrise flats and cranes, and the music of David Hasselhoff coming out of every doorway. But Germany is the new black. Apparently.

According to Bilge, no doubt. And they're not even good at football any more.

Do mention: All those famous people who live in Berlin such as . . . erm, Gerhard Schröder.

Don't mention: You know what.

fields.headline: The weekend starts here
fields.standfirst: There was a time, not so long ago, when only religious zealots or hardcore antiques freaks watched television on Sunday morning. But then T4 changed that forever. By  Phelim O'Neill
fields.trailText: There was a time, not so long ago, when only religious zealots or hardcore antiques freaks watched television on Sunday morning. But then T4 changed that forever.
fields.body:
Unless you have a vested interest in either God, antiques or the countryside, there has been little reason to watch television on Sunday before midday. As in the Old Testament, this God slot scheduling area has forever been seen as a day of rest for viewers and programmers alike, causing a huge and, with the benefit of hindsight, obvious gap for the young adult market. Broadcast 52 weeks a year with no opposition to see off, Channel 4's T4 umbrella (no one knows what the T actually stands for) has firmly embedded itself into this slot, providing a long needed alternative for those of us who feel we have little in common with John Craven or Esther Rantzen.

Offering a less kiddie-oriented service than Saturday's morning output, T4 was originally created to form a brand around Sunday's omnibus edition of Hollyoaks - already established as a big draw. But since its inception in October 1998, T4's catchment has shifted from 14-20 year olds to its current 16-34 age group, allowing a more relaxed, less patronisingly hysterical delivery than this time slot, 9am-1pm, usually allows, addressing the fact that its viewers are more likely to be nursing a hangover than greeting the day whacked up on Sunny Delight and Jesus.

So just what is T4 giving us? Presided over by the amiable Dermot O'Leary and Margherita Taylor, the schedule looks like this: 9 am: City Guys - a fairly useless teen sitcom concerning a pair of kids, one rich, one poor, attending a NY school. They're the original Odd Couple, except of course they're not. 9.30am: CatDog - one of those post-Ren And Stimpy attempts at studied wackiness where any inspirational moments seem accidental. It's the kind of show that would have R&S creator John K glad he's still alive, as all the spinning in his grave would make him nauseous. These two shows seem fairly incongruous with the rest of the morning's output, presumably due to the target audience unlikely to have dragged themselves out of their pit, and conceivably to bore younger viewers into finding something else with their day to avoid the more corruptive material to follow.

It's only when we hit 10am that things start to take shape, with Bits - a cleaned-up version of the late-night computer games and gadgets show wherein three impossibly feisty female presenters review all that's new in the impenetrable-to-anyone over-30 world of what was once called video games. It's fast, informative, irreverent and typically T4, getting its message across via a mixture of snappy camera moves and occasional shots of the hostesses' cleavage.

10.30am sees the arrival of Planet Pop. Formerly the domain of a couple of grins on sticks doing the record companies' PR job, this show underwent a drastic change with the addi tion of highly personable ex-Kenickie singer Lauren Laverne. It is less sarcastic in tone than BBC's The O Zone, with more leftfield strains of music without short-changing either style, bridging the gap between Royal Trux and Steps. 11am - hallelujah. It's the Hollyoaks Omnibus. Lately, of course, Hollyoaks has become required viewing, by virtue - for want of a better word - of its wild inconsistencies. Torn between its old-style frivolous nature, with good-looking teens/ ugly adults and bad acting, and its newer bent to address such subject matter as bullying, abortion and gay rape, it's like watching two different programmes cut together.

12.40pm: Dawsons Creek. The pairing of this with Hollyoaks is what gives T4 its strength. Ostensibly dealing with the same subject matter, the two shows couldn't be more different. Though it's stuck to its original idea of overly self-analytical teenagers, Dawson's emphasis has shifted from Dawson and Joey, who, dramatically speaking, are rapidly disappearing up a different kind of creek, to allow the other characters to shine.

But T4 is more than just the sum of its parts: the presenters are required to watch all the shows in advance and are allowed a great deal of freedom to knock the more ludicrous storylines and characters. Its growing reputation is attracting more "dangerous" guests - a relative term, but remember it's on at the same time as Countryfile and Jesus 2000. The cast of Queer As Folk have all appeared, often finding themselves reined in by O'Leary and Taylor as they forget the hour and the day. The choice of musical guests is also enjoying a change. Acts who normally avoid rising this early, such as Ian Brown, Embrace and The Charlatans, are queuing up to appear, while the quality of pop turns is increasing - soon, two Spice Girls will appear on the same show. Having now been deemed worthy of showing the weekly Friends repeat and spilling over to an extra Tuesday evening slot, this imprint seems to be living up to Channel 4's remit. An alternative with a cohesive link.

So it seems as if, while no one knows what the T stands for, any derogatory guesses will prove unfair.

fields.headline: Court circular
fields.standfirst: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.body:
Not for the first time during his lengthy film-making career, Roman Polanski has found himself in a spot of legalistic bother, with Artisan Entertainment - producers of the diminutive auteur's recent clunker The Ninth Gate - claiming he absconded from the set with over $1 million in misappropriated funds. According to the suit, filed last week in LA District Court, Polanski's troubles began when French tax authorities refunded his production company - the inventively-named RP Productions - six figures in VAT spent while the project was shooting in Paris. Having financed the less-than-earth-shattering end product, Artisan were (perhaps reasonably) expecting the money to be passed on to them - except the director had other ideas, "brazenly" depositing the cash in a private bank account and "refusing all requests to return it". Sparks are sure to fly if and when the case eventually comes to trial, although given the famously outstanding US arrest warrant filed against Polanski for statutory rape back in 1978, it seems unlikely wee Roman will be attending hearings in person.

Meanwhile, no one could accuse Dr Dre of failing to pick on someone his own size, after the expansive hip-hop star filed a $25 million suit against the entire city of Detroit late last week. And the nature of the beef? Local cops threatening to shut off the power during Dre's performance at the Joe Louis Arena a fortnight ago unless the rapper pulled a video of himself and fellow reprobate Snoop Doggy Dogg holding up a liquor store, to be screened before his entrance to the stage. "It's an absolute violation of the First Amendment", exclaimed Dre's attorney Howard King. "The whole city has a stormtrooper attitude." For their part, the police were no quicker with the olive branch: "If we need to," countered Greg Bowens, spokesman for Detroit mayor Dennis Archer, "we'll just go ahead and see them in court."

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Divorce - Right Or Privilege?/Connect
fields.body:
Of the 250,000 couples marrying this year, well over 100,000 will part. Contrast that to the days when divorce required a costly act of Parliament, carried no right to remarry, and fewer than ten a year succeeded. In a new series, Divorce - Right Or Privilege? (11.0am, Radio 4), Melissa Benn (pictured) trawls back to when women not only had to prove their husbands' adultery but their desertion. Until 1854, on the other hand, men could secure large damages from their wives' lovers.

Quentin Cooper's series on the application of new technologies to human needs explores the strange world of virtual reality. As he discovers in Connect (9.0pm, Radio 4), the original concept goes back to the training of military pilots in the first world war. Now the technique is being applied to such diverse areas as the treatment of stroke victims and the rehabilitation of people with serious burns. But such uses can run into some curious misconceptions.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: GP 'defrauded NHS of £1m'
fields.body:
GP 'defrauded NHS of £1m'

A doctor, Roland Hankin, 52, appeared before magistrates in Weymouth in Dorset on 50 charges of defrauding the NHS of more than £1m while having worked as a general practitioner in Dorchester. The case was adjourned until September.

Model wins libel damages

Model Kelly Antonucci, 24, was awarded £7,500 libel damages at the high court yesterday after being portrayed as what she called a "scheming money-grabber". What's on TV magazine falsely reported that, after marrying Mike Antonucci, 52, she had spent his £2.8m lottery win; the couple had separated but he was not penniless, the court heard.

Retrial set for Greenpeace 28

Greenpeace's executive director Lord Melchett and 27 others face a retrial on charges of destroying GM maize on a Norfolk farm. They will appear at Norwich crown court on September 4. A previous trial failed to agree a verdict.

BBC's new public policy chief

Caroline Thompson, deputy managing director of BBC World Service, has been appointed as the BBC's director of public policy. In the run-up to a white paper on broadcasting she will lead the fight against abolition of the board of governors, and steer the BBC's digital TV strategy. Matt Wells

It's now or never for Elvis fans

Elvis Presley memorabilia, including two partly-smoked Hava Tampa cigars, are up for auction at Bonhams on July 27. An amplifier and speakers used by Jimi Hendrix on tour are also for sale.

webTitle: Letters: One-liners from aggravated Guardian readers

fields.headline: Opinions differ
fields.trailText:
Opinion polls (Poll slide adds to Blair gloom, July 18) are based on samples and any estimates they produce come with a calculable margin of error. When this is taken into account, voting intention has not changed at all between May and July of this year. But why let the facts get in the way of a good story?
Patrick Sturgis
London School of Economics

webTitle: Libyans 'put bomb on jet in Malta'

fields.headline: Libyans 'put bomb on jet in Malta'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Libya and the Lockerbie trial
fields.trailText: The day before Pan Am flight 103 blew up in the skies over Lockerbie the two Libyans accused of the atrocity flew into Malta, where they are alleged to have planted the bomb which blew up the aircraft, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
The day before Pan Am flight 103 blew up in the skies over Lockerbie the two Libyans accused of the atrocity flew into Malta, where they are alleged to have planted the bomb which blew up the aircraft, a court heard yesterday.

According to immigration cards produced in evidence at the Scottish court in the Netherlands, the Libyan suspects arrived in Malta from Tripoli on December 20 1988.

They stayed on the Mediterranean island for one night before returning to the Libyan capital on the day of the explosion.

webTitle: Letters: Response to article on Norman Finkelstein

fields.headline: Finkelstein: the row rumbles on
fields.trailText: Norman Finkelstein's editor, Colin Robinson, inadvertently makes the best defence for Jonathan Freedland's criticism of Finkelstein's The Holocaust Industry (Letters, July 17). Robinson states that in the controversy over Hannah Arendt's Eichmann In Jerusalem, the scholar of Jewish mysticism, Gershom Scholem, "defended" Arendt "as someone who loved the Jews".
fields.body:
Norman Finkelstein's editor, Colin Robinson, inadvertently makes the best defence for Jonathan Freedland's criticism of Finkelstein's The Holocaust Industry (Letters, July 17). Robinson states that in the controversy over Hannah Arendt's Eichmann In Jerusalem, the scholar of Jewish mysticism, Gershom Scholem, "defended" Arendt "as someone who loved the Jews".

Scholem, perhaps ungenerously, wrote the opposite: "In the Jewish tradition there is a concept, hard to define yet concrete enough, which we know as Ahabath Israel: 'Love of the Jewish people ...' In you, dear Hannah, as in so many intellectuals who came from the German left, I find little trace of this" (June 23, 1963). And Norman, boychik, you're no Hannah Arendt.
Dr Michael Berkowitz
University College London
m.berkowitz@ucl.ac.uk

 Prof Lappin and Dr Schindler (Letters, July 13) dismiss Norman Finkelstein as "a crank". Since the mid-80s Dr Finklestein has, with Avi Shlaim, Noam Chomsky and Benny Morris, been at the forefront of a group of courageous Jewish academics who have suffered much abuse in their attempt to re-examine the foundation myths of Israel, particularly the notion that Palestine was "a land without a people for a people without a land".

If few people today would question the existence of the Palestinians and their right to self-determination, that is at least partly due to Dr Finklestein's brave work detailing the suppression and falsification of Palestinian history by Israel's supporters. On the basis of his previous books, The Holocaust Industry deserves to be taken seriously as the work of a respected scholar of personal and intellectual integrity.
William Dalrymple
London

webTitle: Letters: Readers comment on the complexity of racism in Britain

fields.headline: There are middle-class racists too, you know
fields.trailText: Your report on Northend ward, Erith (The suburb where one in four voted BNP, July 15) at least dispelled the myth that Bexley is a leafy, middle-class area. The northern part of the borough, which runs along the Thames, is as deprived as any inner city, thanks to more than two decades of Conservative negligence.
fields.body:
Your report on Northend ward, Erith (The suburb where one in four voted BNP, July 15) at least dispelled the myth that Bexley is a leafy, middle-class area. The northern part of the borough, which runs along the Thames, is as deprived as any inner city, thanks to more than two decades of Conservative negligence.

Your photographer could easily have captured graffiti-scrawled empty shops in a half-finished concrete jungle of a town centre, where the remaining traders are facing bankruptcy. The latest assault on this entirely deprived area is the news that a health centre for 30,000 patients will now not be built. Apparently it is, at £4m, too small to be acceptable under the private finance initiative. In the face of this, fascist movements like the BNP flourish, expressing in gross terms what the people of Erith, Slade Green, Belvedere and Thamesmead know: that they are a forgotten community.
Cllr Margaret O'Neill
Erith Labour councillor

 Whilst you are ever ready to highlight racism on council estates, I have yet to read an article that analyses the depth of middle-class racism in the UK. You seem to prefer to ignore the latter whilst smearing working-class people as fodder for fascism.

The whole thrust of the BNP article was that the working classes are inherently gullible enough to vote for fascists. But out of an electorate of 7,000 only 456 voted for the BNP. Whilst continental fascist parties have always aimed for and often gained support from the lower-middle and middle classes, in England they have always attempted to recruit from the working classes and received short-shrift for their impertinence.
Mick Hall
Grays, Essex

 Only a short time after the trial of nail-bomber David Copeland and the recent BNP election result in Bexley, both of which you expressed strong concern over, we are presented with a full-page article on the Young British National Party (For race and nation, G2, July 18).

How is it you can, on the one hand, talk of the dangers of the popularity of these groups and then print an almost tongue-in-cheek feature giving free publicity to the Nazis? Nazis should not be allowed column inches in any publication. They should be left in the gutter where they belong.
Patrick Ward
National organiser, Rebel

 Stephen Bierley wrote more than 40 column inches about Britain's Davis Cup match with Ecuador without a single mention of one of the worst displays of sportsmanship I have ever seen from an English crowd. So loud and prolonged was the booing which greeted Ecuador's heroic victory that the BBC's Sue Barker had difficulty making herself heard.

Could the reason for silence on the subject be the fact that the display of verbal hooliganism didn't come from England's working-class football thugs, but from its finest middle-class Wimbledon yobbos?
Mike Butler
Twickenham, Middx

webTitle: Letters: Response to Nick Davies' education series

fields.headline: Minister's reprimand
fields.trailText: Far from having a "toxic effect" on education, our programme of intervention in poorly run education authorities is helping raise standards in schools (The primary school where crack dealers came calling, July 17).
fields.body:
Far from having a "toxic effect" on education, our programme of intervention in poorly run education authorities is helping raise standards in schools (The primary school where crack dealers came calling, July 17).

While I have every sympathy for this headteacher's personal difficulties, Nick Davies is wrong to say that our plans to outsource Haringey's education services contributed to the problems she faced. We have intervened in Haringey to address the inadequate service provided to schools and are working with the authority to turn things around speedily.

We have not tied education officers down in meeting after meeting, but have helped the authority to strengthen its education management team to improve the support given to the borough's schools. Together with Haringey, we are looking for an external partner to ensure that schools, pupils and parents in the area receive a sustained high quality education service.
Estelle Morris MP
Minister for school standards

 Angela Ellis's "life spun out of control", "things just spiralled out of control". This was nothing compared to the breathtaking example of moral relativism displayed by Nick Davies. I read the piece with disbelief that anybody could conjure such a perverse interpretation from these events.
Tony Greenwood
London

 P & N Minney (Letters, July 17) ask if performance-related pay has ever been suggested for government. Such a system already existed. It's called elections: if you lose, you don't get paid at all.
Richard Humphries
Sutton Coldfield, W Mids

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.body:
In presenting a report headed The culling fields, page 9, Society, July 5, about the possible connection between badgers and bovine tuberculosis, we failed to acknowledge a connection between the author of the piece, Trevor Lawson, and one of the people quoted in the article, Dr Elaine King, from the National Federation of Badger Groups. Mr Lawson and Dr King are married to each other. While we do not suggest that this connection in any way influenced the content of the piece, failure to declare the connection is against the Guardian's policy and, in this case, an omission that was entirely the paper's fault, since Mr Lawson quite properly declared the connection to John Vidal, the editor of the pages on which his article appeared. Mr Vidal told him he could go ahead with the article since he was a trusted contributor and a leading reporter in this field. Mr Vidal neglected to ensure that an appropriate declaration was made. The Guardian is not questioning Mr Lawson's integrity. The decision to run the piece without a declaration was an error for which the paper apologises.

Lord Woolf is no longer master of the rolls (Top judge hits at mandatory sentences, page 10, yesterday). He became lord chief justice in June this year. The prisoner of war camp in Sumatra, to which we meant to refer in our obituary of the Australian nurse, Vivian Bullwinkel (page 18, July 17) was at Palembang, not Palemberg.

Frank Patterson, the tenor whose obituary appeared on page 20, yesterday, was taught by Dr Hans Waldemar Rosen (not Valdemar), and Patterson's wife, Eily O'Grady was a pianist rather than violinist.

The Italian newspaper La Repubblica was founded in 1976, not in 1978 as we suggested in a report on page 11, July 17.

St Andrews is on the north-east coast of Fife. We suggested it was some way from there in a map, page 2, Travel, July 15.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. webTitle: Letters: Comment on unattributable quoting in journalism

fields.headline: Fleshing out ghostly voices
fields.trailText: Alan Rusbridger (No more ghostly voices, July 15) is right to identify a problem with political journalism. As anyone watching Saturday's News From Number 10 could see, there are spinners in the media as well as the Whitehall machine.
fields.body:
Alan Rusbridger (No more ghostly voices, July 15) is right to identify a problem with political journalism. As anyone watching Saturday's News From Number 10 could see, there are spinners in the media as well as the Whitehall machine.

He argues that unattributable quotes create a credibility gap, and "journalism which is not believed has failed". His solution is that Guardian reporters must be much more specific about the description of sources. This is illogical. Non-attribution is an essential tool of journalism.

The essence is trust. The first two pages of Saturday's FT refer to "a government insider" in one report, and a "senior Whitehall insider" and "one observer" in another. Is it really argued that the FT and the Guardian are not to be trusted?

To bolster his case, Mr Rusbridger attacks my own recent report on the description of Gordon Brown as "power-crazed" and "bonkers" by government colleagues. Some of the chancellor's colleagues believe it is madness to suggest now, as he is doing unattributably, that he could veto euro membership early in the next parliament.

The attribution is deliberately vague to protect sources who deserve to be protected. Both the Independent and the Observer, where I have been political editor, would have put this story on the front page.

As for the problem, more openness would help. Lobby briefings should be open to all-comers; they should be televised; and we need more press conferences with the prime minister. But, please, let us not rush into curbs on the good journalism that works well.
Anthony Bevins
Political editor, The Express

 Alan Rusbridger positions most problems in the corrosive relationship between the Lobby and government spokespeople, or on those whose job it is to "drip poison on Ken Follett, Gordon Brown ... et al".

This intemperate sentence betrays the media's own blind spot - an all-consuming obsession with spin. Take your lead story on the government's annual report - "hedged around with admissions that there was still much to do" (Poverty gap hits Labour boasts, July 14). So, if the government proclaims some achievement it is "boasting and spin doctoring"; if it says we haven't got a fair and just society yet, it is hedging about and admitting failure. If spin is about language and presentation, then what has the Guardian done by positioning these stories and their trivial arguments on the front page and telling them the way it has? It has spun them of course, but some call it journalism.

I head up the communications output of Brighton & Hove council. Research data suggest that nearly 70% of residents think their council keeps them informed, against a national average for local authorities of 37%. Still we are called spin doctors.

I fully understand the frustration that led Alistair Campbell to start publishing lobby briefings on the Downing Street website. It's not spin-doctoring, it's a mission to explain.
Tony Miller
Brighton & Hove council
tony.miller@brighton-hove.gov.uk

 The use of the words "ghost voices" was most appropriate, because the whole business of government briefing and communication does seem to be like a séance - knock once if it's attributable, twice if it's not. Surely all that is required is the truth: what was said and who said it. The reader can then be left to judge its worth and people can be held accountable for what they have said.
Harry Glenister
 Taunton, Somerset

webTitle: Belgians free 'riot' soccer fan for appeal

fields.headline: Belgians free 'riot' soccer fan for appeal
fields.standfirst: Special report: football violence
fields.trailText: An England football fan convicted of sparking riots during Euro 2000 was yesterday set free from a Belgian jail after his legal team successfully argued that he had legitimate grounds for appeal.
fields.body:
An England football fan convicted of sparking riots during Euro 2000 was yesterday set free from a Belgian jail after his legal team successfully argued that he had legitimate grounds for appeal.

Mark Forrester, a former member of the England supporters club and an Aston Villa season ticket holder, will now be permitted to return to the UK but will find himself back in Brussels later this year for his appeal hearing.

Forrester's conviction last month, for inciting riots ahead of the England-Germany match when he allegedly assaulted several police officers, still stands.

Aged 33, and married with a two-year old child, Forrester was the only England fan to be given a custodial sentence during the tournament after police witnesses described how he kicked and punched their colleagues and encouraged other fans to attack riot police.

Judge Regine Claeys told Forrester at the time that there was "very clear and detailed evidence" that he had instigated riots on the night of June 16 and that he was "very provocative and aggressive".

His lawyers argued yesterday, however, that the special fast track procedure under which he was convicted meant they did not have enough time to put together a proper defence, and that they were not permitted to bring in witnesses who would have supported his case.

The advocate general of the Brussels appeal court yesterday acknowledged that certain elements of the case did need to be rechecked.

Jan Fermon, Forrester's lawyer, immediately claimed he would now be able to clear his client's name. "The police case is that he was identified on three separate occasions as being involved in trouble. Yet there is evidence that on at least two of those occasions he was not present. If we are allowed to produce a full defence case we can show that the police were mistaken."

Stephen Jakobi, a solicitor and director of the Fair Trials Abroad Trust, has already called the case "the most serious deliberate abuse of human rights by a court system in western Europe since world war two", and yesterday argued that it also had far reaching implications for the UK. "This kills the fast track procedure and is a total vindication of the fact that it is an abuse of human rights."

He said the idea that Britain should recognise what were often questionable rulings by foreign courts, which sometimes deprived British nationals of their passports, was unacceptable. "Europe is nowhere near ready for the mutual recognition of criminal judgments and it would be a way of incorporating worst practice into best practice in countries such as the UK. It may need a rethink on the way the hooligan bill is looking at things."

Forrester, a company manager from Birmingham, has already served one month of a one year jail sentence and was yesterday escorted to court by eight armed police officers before being set free.

His father, Carl, who travelled to Belgium for the England-Germany match with him, welcomed the court's decision but said it came too late. "My son has already lost his job and with it his company car because of the case," he said.

"We can prove that we were not even in Brussels at the time of the first two violent incidents. If there is any justice in Belgium my son will be cleared."

The police will review the case, study video footage of the night, and interview other witnesses, including Forrester's father and friends.

fields.headline: Fayed plea on joint inquest fails
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Mohamed Al Fayed yesterday lost another round in his fight for a joint inquest into the deaths of his son, Dodi, and Diana, Princess of Wales - a hearing that could yet put him in direct conflict with the royal family in the courts.
fields.body:
Mohamed Al Fayed yesterday lost another round in his fight for a joint inquest into the deaths of his son, Dodi, and Diana, Princess of Wales - a hearing that could yet put him in direct conflict with the royal family in the courts.

At the high court in London, Mr Justice Newman refused permission to challenge the decisions of the Surrey coroner, Michael Burgess, and the Queen's coroner, John Burton, to hold the inquests separately. He said there was no evidence to suggest their decisions were unlawful.

But Mr Fayed would be able to seek a judicial review again once any fresh evidence from his appeal against the findings of the French inquest had emerged.

He is appealing against the French court ruling last September that the car crash in Paris in August 1997 was the result of "loss of control, speed and alcohol".

Michael Mansfield QC, for Mr Fayed, said the two bodies had been brought back from Paris to Fulham mortuary and later fell under the jurisdiction of different coroners "by chance".

He argued that if the coroners took different views on the directions of separate inquests "there was a real risk of different evidence, different witnesses and different verdicts". This was not in the interests of justice.

Mr Justice Newman agreed there was "a wide margin of difference" between relatives of Princess Diana and Dodi Fayed on a range of issues. But the potential for controversy - and benefit or harm to the interests of justice which might follow - had been reasonably weighed by the coroners.

fields.headline: Quake fear for nuclear plant
fields.trailText: The French nuclear safety inspectorate has demanded the closure of a key nuclear reprocessing plant in the south of the country because it is built on an earthquake zone which seismologists fear could soon become active.
fields.body:
The French nuclear safety inspectorate has demanded the closure of a key nuclear reprocessing plant in the south of the country because it is built on an earthquake zone which seismologists fear could soon become active.

One of the jewels in the crown of France's once unchallenged nuclear industry, the plant at Cadarache, on the mouth of the Rhone, has become a massive liability, producing mixed oxide fuel for the German nuclear industry, which Berlin says it is going to phase out.

After five years of fruitless negotiation between safety inspectors and plant operators, details of an official seismological survey have been leaked to a watchdog group in Paris.

The survey reveals a "significant growth" of activity in the area around the plant since December 1993. The last big earthquake in the area was in 1913, but the surveyors say the fault line is capable of generating a major earthquake once in a hundred years.

A map shows fault lines running on three sides of the plant on the river Durance, a tributary of the Rhone. Without challenging the seismologists' findings, Cogema, the operator of the installation, has offered to encase the plutonium treatment plant in a concrete shell. But the inspectors say this is fraught with difficulty.

Far from responding to the safety concerns, Cogema has increased its production of mixed oxide fuel (MOX ) to 40 tonnes a year, five times greater than at the Sellafield plant in Britain.

The director of the nuclear safety inspectorate, André-Claude Lacoste, told Cogema that it would have to close the plant "shortly after the year 2000". He said the closure date should be "definitive and non-negotiable" and complained about the delay and obfuscation that his inspectorate had encountered. He told Cogema in a letter: "I consider the situation unacceptable."

Cogema threatened to transfer the production of MOX to another southern plant, at Marcoule, itself at the centre of an environmental row.

The threat infuriated the safety inspectorate, to the extent that one of its top officials scribbled the comment "blackmail" on the Cogema letter before sending it to the French environment minister, Dominique Voynet, who is the leading Green minister in the government.

Photocopies of the increasingly terse correspondence also arrived at the offices of a Paris-based nuclear watchdog, the World Information Service on Energy .

Mycle Schneider, the group's director, argued: "The fact that this has been going on for five years without the industrial side of the nuclear industry having come up with a clear answer to the requests of the official safety authority, means that the French goverment has to step in and seize control."

The group claims that the Cadarache plant, built in 1962 to service France's now defunct Superphénix fast breeder reactor programme, has never been properly licensed, making it unclear which minister has the authority to close it. But it believes that the writing is on the wall for European production of mixed oxide fuel, which was one way of using the quantities of plutonium produced in spent fuel rods at civil reactors.

Cadarache takes the plutonium separated from the spent fuel rods at the main reprocessing plant at La Hague in northern France and converts it into MOX fuel which services two-thirds of Germany's nuclear reactors.

webTitle: East German drugs pushers escape jail

fields.headline: East German drugs pushers escape jail
fields.standfirst: The issue explained: drugs in sport
fields.trailText: Former East German athletes who were fed drugs to enhance their sporting performance yesterday reacted with dismay after the men who masterminded the systematic doping programme walked free from a Berlin courthouse.
fields.body:
Former East German athletes who were fed drugs to enhance their sporting performance yesterday reacted with dismay after the men who masterminded the systematic doping programme walked free from a Berlin courthouse.

Manfred Ewald, once head of the mighty Gymnastics and Sports Federation, was given a 22-month suspended sentence. Manfred Höppner, the doctor who administered the substances that wrecked the lives and bodies of hundreds of competitors, received an 18-month suspended sentence.

Both were convicted of aiding and abetting bodily harm.

In their verdict, the judges said that they had been aware of the side-effects, which ranged from the stimulation of excessive body hair in women to liver, kidney and menstrual problems. One of Höppner's "patients", who won the 1986 European shot-put title as Heidi Krieger, was in court to hear the outcome of the case as Andreas Krieger. She had changed sex after years of being injected with male hormones.

One swimmer, Carola Beraktschjam, testified earlier in the proceedings that she had been made to take 30 pills a day.

Ewald and his erstwhile medical director were ordered to pay the legal costs of 20 former women athletes who jointly sought the prosecution of the officials. But it was unclear whether either man would be able to pay the bills arising from a trial which lasted, albeit intermittently, more than six months. The womens' lawyer said an appeal was possible, but unlikely.

"We, the victims, are not satisfied," said a former discus-thrower, Brigitte Michel.

"The two defendants got away with it," claimed Friedhelm Julius Beucher, the head of the sports committee of the lower house of the German parliament.

Ewald refused to comment as he edged his way past jostling reporters outside the court. But Höppner congratulated the judges on a good job, adding: "I can live with this decision."

He and his former boss were by far the most senior figures brought to trial since the courts began taking an interest in the doping programme. Mr Beucher said the end of their trial would probably put an end to the state's involvement. But he added that civil suits might still be brought.

The court found that Ewald was the "driving force" behind the doping programme. A member of the Communist party's central committee from 1963, he was president of East Germany's main sports federation from 1961 until 1988.

The judges accepted the prosecution's contention that he and Höppner simply brushed aside scientific evidence of the dangers in their determination to boost East Germany's international image; with less than 17m inhabitants it came to rival countries such as the United States and Soviet Union, whose populations ran into the hundreds of millions.

At the 1976 Montreal Olympics, the East Germans' won 40 gold medals. Their "secret" lay in Höppner's pills and injections.

In a comment which many of his former patients will regard as supremely ironic, he said after yesterday's verdict: "You have to be able to lose sometimes."

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.body:
French troops battle Serbs

French troops fired tear gas to disperse hundreds of Serbs who massed around a UN police station, took a UN policeman hostage and stoned peacekeepers to demand the release of a Serb arrested for allegedly burning cars, officials said.

Four Serbs and two UN policemen were hurt in the clash on Monday in the Serb part of Mitrovice in Kosovo, Lieutenant Colonel Philippe Eriau said. The UN policeman taken hostage was later released.

Iran lets girls dress brightly

Iran has eased the Islamic dress code for schoolgirls in Tehran, making way for "bright, happy colours" in place of traditional black.

The new directive, released yesterday, reflects President Mohammad Khatami's social and cultural liberalisation programme. Instead of the traditional black or drab colours, "elementary students can wear bright, happy colours such as light blue, beige, pink, light green and yellow in school", it said.

Portugal world fair scandal

Once touted as a showcase of Portugal's can-do mentality, the 1998 world fair now faces a possible criminal investigation into mismanagement and alleged murky dealings.

A finance ministry probe uncovered evidence of financial crimes which could put some organisers in jail, reports said yesterday. For every 100bn escudos (£291m) of the event's funds spent, 16bn escudos were misused, the inspectors found.

Swaziland bans short skirts

Swaziland will ban mini-skirts in schools to combat the spread of Aids, officials said yesterday.

The ban, which will affect girls over 10, is aimed at stopping sexual relationships between teachers and their pupils in a country where at least 25% of the population is HIV-positive.

Bomb in Cape Town garage

A bomb in a rubbish bin exploded yesterday at a staff car park at Cape Town's international airport, causing minimal damage and no injuries.

Police have blamed a vigilante organisation called People Against Gangsterism and Drugs for unexplained bomb attacks in the city since June 1998. The group denies responsibility.

Convicts blast out of jail

Three convicts escaped from a jail in Belgium yesterday after accomplices used dynamite to blow a hole in a wall, reports said in Verviers, 75 miles east of Brussels.

webTitle: Sex video review after court ruling

fields.headline: Sex video review after court ruling
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, is to announce next week his plans to tighten obscenity laws after a high court ruling allowing the sale to adults of R18 videos depicting explicit consensual sex.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, is to announce next week his plans to tighten obscenity laws after a high court ruling allowing the sale to adults of R18 videos depicting explicit consensual sex.

Yesterday, because of the ruling, the British Board of Film Classification was forced to issue guidelines permitting the legal sale of hard core sex videos.

The film censors' guidelines spell out what is not acceptable, as well as what is, in the R18 category of sex videos, which are allowed to be sold only through licensed sex shops.

Berth Milton, the chief executive of the Private Media Group, one of the largest sex video producers, said: "We think this is a tremendous opportunity for the supply of quality adult material in Britain."

The guidelines say that scenes depicting aroused genitalia, masturbation, oral-genital contact, penetration, non-harmful fetish material, and group sexual activity will be permitted.

webTitle: Keep girls out of jail says charity

fields.headline: Keep girls out of jail says charity
fields.trailText: Courts are still jailing girls aged 15 and 16 despite a pledge by the home secretary, Jack Straw, that from April this year teenagers should no longer be sent to prison, the Howard League, the penal reform group, said last night.
fields.body:
Courts are still jailing girls aged 15 and 16 despite a pledge by the home secretary, Jack Straw, that from April this year teenagers should no longer be sent to prison, the Howard League, the penal reform group, said last night.

The league's figures show that 80 girls under 18 were held in prisons in England and Wales last month. Latest official statistics published on girls aged 15 and 16 alone showed that 25 were in young offenders' institutions in March 1999, just before Mr Straw made his pledge.

The number of girls under 18 in jail rose from 79 in 1992 to 302 in 1998. In the same period the number cautioned or found guilty at court fell from 2,183 to 1,632 per 100,000 of the population.

The League's director, Frances Crook, said: "These figures explode the myth that girls are becoming more violent. The huge increase in the number of girls being sent to prison is a result of more punitive sentencing, not increasing crime."

The league has found that jailed girls faced bullying, drugs and self-harm. The level of education was poor, and girls mixed with older and more serious offenders. Mr Straw said in March last year that 15- and 16-year-olds needed to be placed in local authority care rather than prison, and that in the longer term girls aged 17 would also be placed outside prisons.

In a high court test case in August 1997 the practice of automatically placing juveniles in adult prisons was ruled unlawful. The prison service at first redesignated all jails holding young females as adult prisons and young offenders' institutions, the league said, but the government now accepted that jail was not a suitable environment for girls.

fields.headline: Murder trial colonel freed
fields.trailText: A former Khmer Rouge commander accused of killing three western tourists in 1994 walked free from court in Phnom Penh yesterday, after being granted amnesty.
fields.body:
A former Khmer Rouge commander accused of killing three western tourists in 1994 walked free from court in Phnom Penh yesterday, after being granted amnesty.

Chhouk Rin had been charged with the kidnap and murder of Briton Mark Slater, Australian David Wilson and Frenchman Jean-Michel Braquet.

But the judge ordered his immediate release because he was covered by an amnesty for Khmer Rouge cadres who turned themselves in to the government. Chhouk Rin was made a colonel in the Cambo dian army after his surrender.

Braquet's father shouted at the court before storming out, while the parents of the other victims sat silent in disbelief.

Human rights observers in Cambodia have complained of the soft treatment handed out to Khmer Rouge leaders believed guilty of atrocities. A joint UN-Cambodian plan, delayed for two years, to try the senior figures for crimes against humanity, will be debated soon by the country's national assembly.

Another Khmer Rouge defector, Sam Binh, was charged with Chhouk Rin in connection with the murder of the westerners' but did not appear in court. He is working as an adviser to the Cambodian ministry of defence.

The three backpackers were taken hostage after the train on which they were travelling was blown up. They were killed after attempts to negotiate a ransom failed. Chhouk Rin was the commander of the Khmer Rouge soldiers who attacked the train, on which 13 Cambodian passengers were also killed.

Another former Khmer Rouge commander, Nuon Paet, who did not surrender to the Phnom Penh government, was sentenced to life in prison last year for his role in the train murders.

webTitle: Plan drawn up to avert food panic if BSE found in sheep

fields.headline: Plan drawn up to avert food panic if BSE found in sheep
fields.standfirst: Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: Contingency plans to prepare for the disastrous consequences of a food panic if BSE is found in sheep are being drawn up by the government and meat industry.
fields.body:
Contingency plans to prepare for the disastrous consequences of a food panic if BSE is found in sheep are being drawn up by the government and meat industry.

Detailed advice on changing slaughterhouse and butchery practices is being considered to help save the £385m a year sheepmeat trade from collapse even though no evidence has yet been found that the disease is occurring naturally in the 40m national flock.

But officials of the food standards agency warned yesterday that evidence "might emerge at any time in the next year or two from studies under way".

They said that present controls designed to prevent the theoretical risk of human infection from mutton and lamb, introduced after the crisis that hit beef in 1996, would not be enough if a dangerous BSE-like agent was in sheep as well. Some even sugested it would be "very difficult" to remove all risky material from meat before it went on sale because of the way BSE has been shown to work in sheep in the laboratory. It spread far more widely through the carcass than it did in cattle.

The ministry of agriculture last night insisted that its scientific advisers were keeping the problem under constant review. "Any action, if BSE was to be found in sheep, would depend on evidence at the time. We are not going to pre-empt what advice they would give," a spokeswoman said.

David Croston, of the meat and livestock commission, the government-backed industry body, confirmed it had been studying changes but added: "Until science tells us what we should be removing, we can't act. There is no strong evidence as of yet about what we should be doing. If someone says we have to remove x, y and z, we know how to do it and we will then advise the industry in an appropriate manner."

It was difficult to quantify the impact on the industry or the extent of changes that might be needed.

Ian Gardiner, deputy director general of the National Farmers' Union, said: "It would be entirely improper if experts in such agencies did not develop contingency plans." But he too was keen to stress that the risk of BSE appearing in sheep did not appear to have increased in recent months.

Some of the concerns were outlined in a "working document" provided by agency leaders for discussion with consumer groups, the meat industry, vets and families of victims of the human form of BSE, known as vCJD, whose deaths have been linked to eating infected material from cows before risky parts of the carcasses were banned from food between 1989 and 1995.

Scientific advisers to the government have so far decided not to widen controls, although they have commissioned an assessment of risk to public health.

Heads of sheep are already banned from human consumption, a move introduced in 1996 particularly to protect ethnic minority groups. In addition, the tonsils and spleen of all sheep and the spinal cords of sheep over a year old are banned.

But intestines are still used for sausage casings, and lymph tissue, also infected in laboratory experiments, is wide spread through other meat on lambs and sheep.

The main fear is that the presence of scrapie, a BSE-like disease in sheep not known to have endangered human health, may be disguising the BSE agent, which may have transferred to sheep through now-banned cannibalistic feeding regimes in the 1980s. Scrapie-infected sheep brains are being tested using mice to detect whether a BSE-like strain is evident. The agency document suggested one might be identified "at any time".

"Due to the limitations of existing studies and available methods, failure to detect BSE in the national flock will not be conclusive evidence that it is not present." The tone of the document contrasts with that of scientists on Seac, the advisory committee for BSE and its human form, which suggested last February that tests on sheep brains up to then "do not have the characteristics associated with BSE".

The agency hopes genetic breeding techniques will increase sheep resistance to BSE and scrapie over the next 10-20 years. Meanwhile, the agriculture ministry has contacted US counterparts who ordered the destruction of sheep imported from Europe because they displayed signs of a BSE-like disease. It appears satisfied that some were suffering from a form of scrapie.

There is no strong evidence as of yet about what we should be doing. If someone says we have to remove x, y and z, we know how to do it and we will then advise the industry in an appropriate manner." It was difficult to quantify the impact on the industry or the extent of changes that might be needed. Ian Gardiner, deputy director general of the National Farmers' Union, said: "It would be entirely improper if experts in such agencies did not develop contingency plans." But he too was keen to stress that the risk of BSE appearing in sheep did not appear to have increased in recent months. Some of the concerns were outlined in a "working document" provided by agency leaders for discussion with consumer groups, the meat industry, vets and families of victims of the human form of BSE, known as vCJD, whose deaths have been linked to eating infected material from cows before risky parts of the carcasses were banned from food between 1989 and 1995. Scientific advisers to the government have so far decided not to widen controls, although they have commissioned an assessment of risk to public health. Heads of sheep are already banned from human consumption, a move introduced in 1996 particularly to protect ethnic minority groups. In addition, the tonsils and spleen of all sheep and the spinal cords of sheep over a year old are banned. But intestines are still used for sausage casings, and lymph tissue, also infected in laboratory experiments, is wide spread through other meat on lambs and sheep. The main fear is that the presence of scrapie, a BSE-like disease in sheep not known to have endangered human health, may be disguising the BSE agent, which may have transferred to sheep through now-banned cannibalistic feeding regimes in the 1980s. Scrapie-infected sheep brains are being tested using mice to detect whether a BSE-like strain is evident. The agency document suggested one might be identified "at any time". "Due to the limitations of existing studies and available methods, failure to detect BSE in the national flock will not be conclusive evidence that it is not present." The tone of the document contrasts with that of scientists on Seac, the advisory committee for BSE and its human form, which suggested last February that tests on sheep brains up to then "do not have the characteristics associated with BSE". The agency hopes genetic breeding techniques will increase sheep resistance to BSE and scrapie over the next 10-20 years. Meanwhile, the agriculture ministry has contacted US counterparts who ordered the destruction of sheep imported from Europe because they displayed signs of a BSE-like disease. It appears satisfied that some were suffering from a form of scrapie.

webTitle: The best boxing gym scene: In Too Deep

fields.headline: The best boxing gym scene: In Too Deep
fields.trailText: Cincinatti. Undercover cop Jeff Cole (Omar Epps) has been assigned the task of infiltrating the operation of local crimelord God (LL Cool J). As he walks into the latter's boxing gym, his senior officer Preston D'Ambrosio (Stanley Tucci) briefs him in voiceover.
fields.body:
Cincinatti. Undercover cop Jeff Cole (Omar Epps) has been assigned the task of infiltrating the operation of local crimelord God (LL Cool J). As he walks into the latter's boxing gym, his senior officer Preston D'Ambrosio (Stanley Tucci) briefs him in voiceover.

"Dwayne Gittens is his real name. Comes all the way from New Jersey. We haven't been able to get anyone near him, but we figure he's hooked into at least 80% of the crack in the city."

God/Gittens is working on a leather punchbag supported by one of his many cronies. As he lays into it, his henchman lets the bag slip away from him.

"Hold the bag, T", God snarls.

"Alright, alright."

He sets about the bag once more; again, T allows his grip to loosen.

"T - hold the fucking bag!"

"Alright, I'm holding, I'm holding."

God stares his friend in the eye.

"You let this bag go one more time and I break your jaw."

"Alright."

God throws another series of punches. Again, T lets the bag swing free. Hesitating for just a second, God throws an uppercut to the side of the bag, knocking his lieutenant cold to the ground. He gazes down at the figure at his feet.

"What are you... fuckin' stupid? "

See also: Raging Bull, Midnight Sting, Rocky

Don't see also: Rocky II, III, IV, V

Pointless trivia: In 1994, LL Cool J established a summer camp for disadvantaged city children called Camp Cool J.

fields.headline: Helping hands
fields.standfirst: Role of advice agencies is under threat
fields.trailText: Role of advice agencies is under threat.
fields.body:
Exposure of the distress and unfairness caused to disabled people by the Department of Social Security's notorious "benefit integrity project" was largely thanks to the Disability Alliance advice and lobbying group. But for the alliance's work, the Labour government might well have continued with the intrusive and harsh benefit checking system it inherited in 1997.

The alliance's central part in the "bip" affair is featured in a report being launched tomorrow to highlight the important role played by voluntary sector advice agencies in combating social exclusion. It is, says the report, a role often overlooked.

With advent of the Community Legal Service, the body set up earlier this year to bring together government and voluntary advice agencies, there are fears that the role could be marginalised.

Maxine Holdsworth, policy and development officer of the London Advice Services Alliance (Lasa), says: "Unless the link between advice and tackling social exclusion is understood by policy-makers and funders, there is a danger that the Community Legal Service will see access to advice eroded rather than enhanced - particularly for socially excluded groups."

The report, Advice: Responses to Social Exclusion in London, has been produced by Lasa in association with leading advice agencies. It outlines case studies, including that of the Disability Alliance and "bip", showing how agencies respond to social exclusion among individuals and communities in the capital.

Cases profiled include the work of Age Concern Hounslow in enabling elderly people in Brentford, west London, to claim welfare benefits worth an extra £250,000 a year; the 25 years of achievements of Off Centre, an agency providing holistic support for young people in need in Hackney, east London; and the advice and representation offered by Lesbian and Gay Employment Rights (Lager) to those facing discrimination at work because of their sexual orientation.

Lasa is calling on central, local and the new London government bodies to produce joined-up strategies to counter social exclusion, including a central place for advice services. It points out that the issues commonly addressed by advice agencies - benefits, housing, debt, immigration - are issues disproportionately affecting the lives of those facing social exclusion.

The report says: "Advice providers must work alongside funders and policy-makers. They need to be included as equal partners in planning for an inclusive Community Legal Service that makes a difference in people's lives."

 Advice: Responses to Social Exclusion in London is available at £5 inc, from Lasa Publications, 2nd Floor, Universal House, 88-94 Wentworth Street, London E1 7SA (020-7377 2748)

fields.headline: Strip teaser
fields.standfirst: The book of the film: Ghost World
fields.trailText: The book of the film: Ghost World.
fields.body:
The average feature-film script weighs in at 100 pages - one per minute of the final movie - and comes chock-a-block with dialogue, explanations, hints of what kind of film it might make if only it winds up in the hands of the right director. What a script can't tell you is what a film will look like, feel like. At some point in the process, a storyboard artist might come in to help sketch out the eventual visuals. So why not dispense with scripts and storyboards altogether, and simply have all films written in the form of comic strips?

This method should work a treat, on the evidence of Ghost World, a collection of strips - a graphic novel, if you must - by American artist Daniel Clowes. Ghost World, a rich, complex feature film in its own right, is soon to be released as an actual movie, starring Thora Birch, from American Beauty, and Steve Buscemi. The director is Terry Zwigoff, who made Crumb, the extraordinary documentary portrait of cartoonist Robert Crumb and his dysfunctional family. Zwigoff is an unknown quantity when it comes to fiction, but judging by Crumb, he'll be more than capable of handling Ghost World's subtleties (yes, in a comic book). Clowes and Zwigoff collaborated on the screenplay, but I wonder how much it resembles a conventional script - I'd like to think Clowes at least drew a few faces in the margins.

Clowes, a versatile master of comic-art pastiche, used to be known as a pop surrealist. His first hit series featured jazzily executed beatnik hero Lloyd Llewellyn; then his own regular title Eightball launched a labyrinthine straight-from-the-id serial called Like a Velvet Glove Cast in Iron, so nightmarish that it made Twin Peaks look like a Merchant-Ivory number. But in his realist mode, Clowes is a sensitive observer of character and culture - his one-off strip Caricature, about a middle-aged hack caricaturist falling for a hip, callow admirer, is as insightful and emotionally rich as the best American short stories.

Ghost World is in Clowes's realist vein. Its stars are Enid and Rebecca, teenage small-town girls who hang out, waste time, laugh, lapse into gloom. They spend a summer indulging their snootily ironic tastes - sniggering at lame TV comedians, frequenting "the Mona Lisa of the bad, fake diners", analysing the Freudian language of cookie packaging. They think they're smarter than their peers, and pretty much are, but occasionally their assurance takes a blow: they gradually accumulate guilt at the heartless prank phone calls they make. They're not smart, adorable kids, but self-absorbed, cynical, sentimental, appallingly patronising towards the old and the ugly. But you can't help loving them.

Clowes is brilliant at the precociously jaded, know-it-all cadences of teenage dialogue, but he does as much with looks as with words. Bespectacled, nerd-chic Enid goes through endless fashion hoops trying to define herself, as her hair switches from spiky green to bobbed black, and she swaps her trapper's cap for a ludicrous bat-eared mask from the local sex shop. Subtle facial expressions count for everything - a grossed-out twist of the lip, or the melancholic blankness on Enid's face after she loses her virginity. Grotesques cross the girls' path, but the real freaks are the stereotypes who think they're classy outsiders - repellent grinners like the editor of an outrage fanzine, or the ex-punk turned "big-ass corporate fuck" who thinks he's screwing the system.

Ghost World's eloquent shifts prove that comics can create mood with perfect economy. The best in-joke has Enid fantasising about famous comics artist "David Clowes", whom she imagines as a tough-jawed intellectual. In the final frame on page 29, Enid sees the real Daniel Clowes, looking excruciatingly geeky; in the first frame on page 30, she's sitting disconsolate over her soda. Most films would spell out that emotional transition: Clowes does it in the turn of a page. The saga's conclusion says volumes about leaving youth and home behind, but everything is implied in the elimination of dialogue and in the subtle change of Enid's physique and wardrobe, even the bag she's carrying. Clowes, like several other comics artists, could teach film-makers the futility of overstatement.

The Ghost World film seems to be in good hands, but you can't help having your fears, and Clowes must have had them too. When he wound up the Velvet Fist series in Eightball, he followed it up with an epilogue in which Hollywood buys the strip and mangles it beyond recognition. The final frame has a character watching the movie on TV and talking about the cartoonist who wrote it: "He got a lot of money from the movie and became a cocaine addict and then he got into heavy debt with the mob and now he's a born-again Christian." Fingers crossed, then.

Ghost World is published by Jonathan Cape, priced £6.99.

webTitle: Children in poorest families get help to succeed at school

fields.headline: Children in poorest families get help to succeed at school
fields.standfirst:
 Sure Start targets under fives at risk
 Voluntary groups funded to aid difficult teenagers

Special report: the comprehensive spending review
fields.trailText: The government's determination to tackle child poverty and social exclusion was underlined yesterday when Gordon Brown announced a cross department initiative to help the poorest and most vulnerable children in Britain.
fields.body:
The government's determination to tackle child poverty and social exclusion was underlined yesterday when Gordon Brown announced a cross department initiative to help the poorest and most vulnerable children in Britain.

In an effort to break the cycle of disadvantage, the chancellor has doubled investment in the Sure Start programme which aims to improve the life chances of under-fives by ensuring they are ready to learn when they begin school.

He also announced a Children's Fund to be run by voluntary organisations, which will identify and provide services for children showing signs of difficulties, and Connexions, a personal adviser service to help 13 to 19-year-olds stay in education.

Child poverty activists welcomed the measures but warned that Mr Brown must continue to act to raise the incomes of families on benefits, which he has raised substantially in Labour's last two budgets. The government's figures show that the vast majority of children in poverty live in families where no one is in work.

"We hope that the fact that nothing further was announced today doesn't mean that the problems of people supporting children on benefits are sliding down the agenda," said Geoff Fimister of the Child Poverty Action Group.

The new children's fund will work with national children's charities and local community organisations which offer one to one help for children and families at risk, before they hit a crisis. Its budget for next fiscal year is set at £100m, rising to £200m by 2003-04.

Yesterday's announcement marks a new high in cooperation between the voluntary sector and government departments to tackle Britain's problems of ingrained poverty and deprivation. Over the next three years, £70m of the fund's budget will be distributed directly to voluntary sector organisations.

"The war against child poverty requires not just additional cash but the support and encouragement of all forces of care and compassion in every community," said Mr Brown. "It can only be won by the combined efforts of parents and private, voluntary, charitable and public sectors working together."

Children's charities welcomed Mr Brown's call for more cooperation. The Children's Society, NSPCC, Save the Children Fund and Barnardo's welcomed the new money and in a statement said that it was only through working with local communities that the government could make any difference to the lives of poor children.

However, the charities expressed disappointment that there was not more funding for the network of local and regional children's funds which will total only £70m over the next three years. "This must be linked to a coherent, long term strategy to end child poverty," said Neera Sharma, policy adviser for Barnardo's.

Investment in Sure Start, the existing scheme to help vulnerable pre-schoolers, will be boosted by £315m by the end of the three years covered by this spending review. The number of programmes will be doubled so that the expanded scheme will reach a third of poor children under four in England.

In return, the departments responsible for Sure Start, Health and Education have agreed to reduce the numbers of children on the programme who are re-registered as at risk by 20%, to cut smoking by pregnant mothers by 10% and reduce the number of children living in households where no one is employed.

Connexions, the new advisory service, will work on truancy and raising educational achievements. It will be coordinated with expanded services for vulnerable young people including mental health services, housing support and drug treatment.

Mr Brown also announced a £380m programme for children between five and 13, to bridge the gap between Sure Start and the Connexions service.

fields.headline: Robson recruits Crossley
fields.trailText: Middlesbrough have moved swiftly to provide competition for goalkeeper Mark Schwarzer by recruiting the hugely-experienced Mark Crossley.
fields.body:
Middlesbrough have moved swiftly to provide competition for goalkeeper Mark Schwarzer by recruiting the hugely-experienced Mark Crossley.

Crossley joined Boro on a two-year contract yesterday evening on a free transfer from Nottingham Forest after successfully completing a medical.

The Barnsley-born 31-year-old made more than 300 senior appearances for his first club Forest in 13 years at the City Ground and has been capped twice by Wales. He will plug the gap left by Ben Roberts, who joined Charlton on a free last week.

Crossley will compete with Marlon Beresford, who is currently battling against a back injury, to provide back-up for Australian keeper Schwarzer.

"Signing Mark on a free transfer is a great deal for the club," said manager Bryan Robson. "He's got vast experience of Premiership football and has always done a very steady job for Forest.

"As a goalkeeper he should be at the peak of his career at his age. He will obviously compete with Marlon Beresford for Mark Schwarzer's first-team jersey."

Crossley will be involved in the club's pre-season campaign, which gets underway on Friday night with the North Riding Senior Cup semi-final trip to Conference side Scarborough. He becomes the third player to join Boro so far this summer along with Christian Karembeu and Paul Okon.

webTitle: Powergen calls in police over website security breach

fields.headline: Powergen calls in police over website security breach
fields.standfirst: Powergen
fields.trailText: Gas and electricity supplier Powergen was today "urgently" contacting more than 2,500 customers after their banking details were revealed on the company's website in a major security breach.
fields.body:
Gas and electricity supplier Powergen was today "urgently" contacting more than 2,500 customers after their banking details were revealed on the company's website in a major security breach.

The incident arose when a customer encountered the names, addresses and banking card numbers of other consumers when he tried to pay his bill online earlier this month.

John Chamberlain, a freelance IT consultant from Leicester, said he had discovered three files containing the bank details of more than 7,000 home and business customers.

Mr Chamberlain told BBC Radio 5 Live: "I couldn't believe what I saw. It was basically names, addresses, credit card details, account numbers and so on.

"I thought, 'I wonder if I'm in here', so I clicked the search button and typed in my name and off it went and found my name, address, credit card number, expiry date..."

Powergen said that the information had not been obtained "fairly" and that it had called in the Metropolitan Police to investigate the breach.

Spokeswoman Isobel Hoseason said: "We take the security of customers' personal information very seriously. Until Tuesday, the allegations by the individual behind the breach of security were unsubstantiated.

"It wasn't until late yesterday that we had any evidence that there had been a breach in security.

"We are aware of the customers who may be affected and will be contacting them today. We hope customers will bear with us.

"We have passed all the information to the police who are now investigating. We were confident that our website was robust. We had our website tested by professionals and the security on that website is robust."
